description:
I organized a large gathering at the Asian Art Museum and thought they were wonderful to work with. Jenn Silagi in the Groups Department was very responsive and accommodating. We had 33 people and rented a room to host our celebration and two docent-led tours. Everybody at the museum was beyond professional and welcoming. The one thing I'd note is that we were in the Education Room that is usually used for arts activities and classes. The tables were pretty marked with old paint and ink. Because we were serving food, I had to run out and buy some tablecloths to mask the marks. Just something to keep in mind if you're planning a gathering with food. It'd be totally perfect for an arts-based activity. 

Also, we had catering from Sunday in the Museum. Janet Lee and her team were awesome. They were able to accommodate last minute adds to our order and were all around helpful and supportive. We had a mixed platter of pastries from Craftsman and Wolves and assorted teas. 

We had a great time and will definitely be back!
author: Peggy L.

description:
I'm so lucky to have gotten to live near the Asian Art Museum for the past year, it's an amazing gem of SOMA/The Tenderloin. My girlfriend and I were members since last year, and we're only cancelling it since we're going to be moving soon.

There are two floors of permanent exhibitions, with art and sculptures from several Asian and Middle Eastern countries, such as China, Japan, Korea, Myanmar, Iran, Iraq, and many more. As an Iranian American, I really appreciate the room of Iranian art and artifacts. They also have special exhibitions that rotate every few months, which do an excellent job of relating ancient art to modern culture. 

The member benefits are totally worth it! You get free admission for you and a guest, and access to a ton of free social events and tours. It's sometimes hard to keep track of everything that's going on, and you have to reserve in advance, but the events we got to go to were extremely high quality. The tour guides are extremely knowledgeable, and often they design the tours themselves. 

The Cafe is also awesome! A little pricey, but it's great food, and the only place to get Boba Guys without waiting in line. 

Overall this museum is great! It's a little small, but they're planning an expansion soon, and I can't wait to see it!
author: Arya B.

description:
Met up with my friend who was visiting.  He insisted we meet at his favorite museum for the Divine Bodies exhibit and I happily complied as he was paying for me too.  
While the exhibit was interesting, the one thing that had me at hello was the Ganesh statue.  When we took the escalator to the third floor I took a good 10 minutes admiring the sculpture and wishing they had a smaller version of it at the museum shop. 
When you get a chance, check out the gift shop.  They have cute little kitschy things.  I of course had to get myself a ganesh statue, not quite like the museum sculpture but significant enough for me to bond with it.
Tip-Taking the bart and getting off Civic is the best way to go as it's such a short walking distance to the museum.
author: Maureen C.

description:
This a gem!!!!  I love Asian art and this satisfies my whims...it's like another world.  It is filled with beautiful pieces from all decades and oh I dream...of how it would have been to live in those times.  They have put together an amazing collection and the building itself is breathtaking inside.  

I love their Thursday night event which we can enjoy the museum at a nominal cost and kids under 12 are free.  This is truly a treasure to visit and in fact we will be there tonight!!!
author: Mari S.

description:
The couple whose wedding I was in town for recommended this as something to do if we had time while in town. At least two fellow attendees had visited also.
I went to the special exhibit about meditation et Al, runs through end of July '18. I liked the third floor, Jade room, swords and pointy stuffs. I am saving the second floor for another visit. Info overload alert, but heck it was all interesting to learn about and see for one's self. Part of the building is under construction, but it shouldn't dissuade visitors.
author: Marin C.

description:
I have lived in Thailand and visited Tibetan China, Korea, Laos, Cambodia, and Malaysian Borneo. During those visits, I got a generous dose of artistic traditions. This museum has got to have the broadest and deepest scope of Asian art pieces outside of the Asian continent.

What a lovely experience this was for me. I had several hours to spare this afternoon in SF, and this was the perfect place to spend it. All of Asia's vast regions are all very well represented here.

Without spending extra money for special temporary exhibits, I was able to see and experience a massive amount of Asian art history. I could have easily spent another entire afternoon here, as well. I will obviously return :-)
author: Glenn S.

description:
Super cool museum with lots of art from various Asian countries including India, China, Korea, Japan, Philippines, and Southeast Asia!

I loved see the diverse types of art ranging from jade to porcelain to bronze. There was an interesting video about how to dress and elephant. Man, that elephant is definitely more stylish than I am! 

There are three levels: third and second floor are the main exhibits and the first houses the special exhibit. I came early (11am) on the first Sunday of the month, so I got free admission and no line! As I left, at around 1pm, the line to the museum was out the door. Super long, so come early to avoid waiting. 

The day I came also happened to be when there was a special event called Floating Garden of Emotions, and there were some interactive activities, which helped people be more mindful of their emotions. For instance, there were different colors of balloons (red for anger, yellow for happiness, etc), and within each color, there were subcategories that go within the main broader emotion, which you write the word on the balloon. Then you get a white piece of paper and write what triggers that emotion, and on the back, a way to deal with that. Last, you tie the balloon and the paper on the string, and it's fun to read what others have written!
author: Tiffany H.

description:
I have always loved Chinese and Japanese art so I was so happy to find this museum on my recent trip to the Bay Area. The museum is really affordable and far more expansive than I would have expected. After walking in, you head to the third floor and work your way down. The museum is set up regionally and then chronologically by region and includes a ton of placard information. 

My husband, who loves art but not specifically Asian, really enjoyed the layout of this museum and kept commenting on how much he was learning. As predicted, I did love the Chinese and Japanese galleries especially. However, I was pleasantly surprised by the Korean galleries. 

We came to the museum with my grandfather who isn't very mobile but we were pleased with the level of accessibility offered. He stayed in the cafe and enjoyed his visit and food there. Beyond that, the museum store is quite expansive and offers a variety of merchandise from typical books, to ceramic pottery, and cookbooks for a variety of Asian cuisines. 

Having visited once, I hope to make it back soon for a longer exploration of the galleries and special exhibits.
author: Hannah W.

description: Pretty cool account of artistic expression in Asia, with sections separated by country and epoch. Lots of vases and explanation of the different materials and techniques. Also, many deities are represented from across the continent. I couldn't help thinking I was at a furniture store though. A few rooms with contemporary art, and a subpar exhibit that costs this museum a star.
author: Julio H.

description:
First off, I had high expectations from this place since my ceramics teacher raved about it but I wasn't too impressed from the get go. 

HOURS:
Monday: closed
Tuesday-Sunday: 10AM-5PM

BART/ENTRANCE:
Went on a Thursday and decided to take BART since it was a walking distance. Get off at Civic and it's about a 5~ minute walk so it was convenient. If you spot the gigantic ceramic dragon, right behind it is the entrance. 

PRICE:
Right off the bat, the girl at the front desk wasn't friendly whatsoever. GA is $15 but with your student ID, it's $10.
Special exhibition is $5 added on top of GA.  
Children under the age of 12 are free ! 


GIFT SHOP/FIRST LEVEL/EXHIBITS:
First level is the gift shop which had a good amount of souvenirs and Knick knacks (most items were overpriced). The first level also includes their featured exhibition which is currently: Couture Korea (until feb 4th,
2018). 

LEVEL'S:
2ND: Japan, Korea and China
3RD: Himalayas, Tibetan Buddhist, Southeast Asia, Persian world and West Asia, South Asia.

HUNGRY?
They have a cafe, I didn't go inside but at least you can grab a bite to eat after your museum exploring. Open from 10am-4:30pm. 

OVERALL:
Nothing really caught my eye, maybe a piece here and there. I viewed the museum in less than an hour and left unsatisfied. Sad :(
author: Grace Anne D.

description:
I've been coming to the Asian Art Museum since I was a kid. There aren't many museums in the US dedicated to solely the arts of Asia, so it's great to know that a city as multicultural and diverse as San Francisco has a museum dedicated to this part of the world. Coming to the Asian Art Museum gives me a great sense of pride and understanding of my Asian roots.

Located in the Civic Center area of SF, the Asian Art Museum is easy to get to via public transit (eg Bart and Muni). Long ago, the Asian Art Museum used to be located in Golden Gate Park but moved to its current location in 2003. The Asian Art Museum houses relics from all across Asia-from China, Korea, Japan, all the way south to Indonesia, and all the way west to Iran, Pakistan and India. Asia is very large and diverse, and the collection of art here reflects that diversity. 

Of note, the Asian Art Museum has recently expanded its collection of arts from the Philippines. There has been past remarks brought to the attention of the museum about why the Filipino art section was so small/limited. So it's great to see that the museum listened to its patrons, and expanded its Filipino art collection. I was able to see the growing Filipino arts section at the museum during my recent visit a few weeks ago -- it included various textiles and woven wear, which were pretty neat!

The museum entrance fee is $20 for adults. However, admission is free on the first Sunday of every month (except for special exhibits which there is a small surcharge, if you want. Definitely worth every penny!

I'm happy that the Asian Art Museum has stayed around for so long. I'll definitely be coming back for years to come!
author: Matthew L.

description: Pretty interesting museum!!! I had a different view on how the set up of the museum would be, but it turned out better than I expected. The first Sunday of every month the admission is free so here I was on a FREE DAY!!! I paid an additional 10 dollars to see the special exhibit called Divine Bodies and it was pretty cool. It was really great to see a section dedicated to the Persian Era! What really caught my eye was the Japanese Tea Room, it was so unique.
author: Neloffer E.

description: This is and always has been a wonderful place to visit... Always changing and always moving forward.
author: Jamy A.

description:
When I came to visit this museum, it just felt as if that it wasn't completely finished. Walking in it was pretty standard and the museum itself was 
pretty clean. For me at the time I was there, in the upper levels there were some items that were missing as they were being set up for the new part of the museum. 

This museum is definitely worth it to check out if you have time and you want to learn more about the Asian culture and art. It was nice to see a museum like this because from where I live, I would never see something like this and it would be pretty much impossible. So good on San Francisco to build this. The art that they have here is great, but I wished to see a little more and that the whole museum was done. Definitely a fan of this place and will probably come back if I'm in town.
author: Bruce K.

description:
I was pretty impressed with the Asian Art Museum. They have two floors of general exhibits, while the first floor is reserved for the special exhibits, a café, and a giftshop. 

Our first stop was the front desk to purchase tickets ($15.00 per person), and the gentleman behind the desk couldn't be more friendly and informative. On top of providing us with a map of the museum, he also pointed to where the restrooms and café were, and informed us that we are to start the exhibit on the third floor.

We stopped at the café before heading up to the third floor. I had a pumpkin quiche, which was good but cold, and very overpriced. It came with a healthy portion of salad, which was the best part. 

The first exhibit was the Southeast Asian exhibit, and it was my favorite. It has so much history with each piece, we spent a majority of our time in these rooms. The pieces were extraordinary. We had to rush a little through the second floor because the museum closed at five, and we were running out of time. 

The museum is a very short walk from the Civic Center BART station, so getting there was quick and easy. 

I would definitely love to come back and more thoroughly explore each exhibit, as well as check out the special ones.
author: Jonathan R.

description:
Had a wonderful time excepting the screaming tour group of kids, sorry.
Thought they could do better with the India and Pakistani history...
Love love love love love the Korean exhibit they did. Such amazing history and I didn't know... walked away with utter admiration for the Korean peninsula and all its Glory.
Truly enjoyed the layout and treasure on display.
All of the staff encountered were super professional and a mega shout out to the two elderly volunteers at the info desk, how do you stand it I don't know but my God you are super professional with everyone... thanks for that.
Gift shop is reasonable and staff knows their stuff.
Do well to avoid the street full of crap pants or naked meth freak homeless people and rush inside for safety
Although I thought the bum washer out front was a novel idea, couldn't they all just go shower in the tenderloin or under whatever bridge they live at? Why in the center of a tourist Mecca?
author: Andy B.

description:
Date: 7/11/2017  Time: 9:30 AM  60°  Sunny

As many times as I have visited the Asian Art Museum during my lunch hour while working catty corner at the Ronald P George State Building, I never sat down and took the time to write a review. I have visited on a few occasions on those first free Sundays of each month. Then a friend of mine who is a member of this museum has invited me as a guest to visit. I even bookmarked the museum to prepare a review when they had the terracotta warriors exhibition. It was never done. 

Thus, I am here at this museum for the Flower Power exhibition, which is currently occurring until October 1, 2017. My review is long overdue, in that one should have been written about seven years ago when I started writing reviews on yelp. Okay, it's better late than never to finally say what I think about this museum and what it has on display.

There were 33 of us from Mastick Senior Center. We were divided into three groups for the docent tour of the special exhibit. Each of us was given an audio head set to listen to the docent. The docent leading my group did a superb job in the narration of the Flower Power exhibit and answering our questions. She was informative and I appreciated her presentation. I found myself taking notes of what was being said; thus, allowing me to do a somewhat detailed review. 

The Flower Power exhibition is in celebration of the flower power movement of 1967. Wow...that is 50 years ago. The movement had its start in Berkeley. Definitely it was the Summer of Love. Make love, not war. Where was I at that time? (Graduated from jr. high school and waiting to start high school as a sophomore.) In my mind, the late Scott MacKenzie is singing San Francisco (Be Sure to Wear Flowers in Your Hair), a song that was very popular at that time. RIP Scott. 

Moving forward to this special exhibit, which I enjoyed immensely, has left me with the a deeper appreciation and understanding of what the flowers symbolize, especially in the Asian cultures (Buddhism, Hinduism, Persian, Indian). 

The six flowers mentioned by the docent were lotus (pure love), cherry blossom, chrysanthemum (longevity), roses in the Persian and Indian cultures symbolize beauty, elegance, refinement, perfection; plum blossom along with bamboo and pine symbolize integrity, persistency, perseverance under adversity; and tulips. Also, in Hinduism, the Shiva and the pair of elephants on lotus thrones symbolize fertility, creation, wealth and prosperity.

One of the gold colored panels on displays had other flowers illustrated - hibiscus (fragile beauty), blue hydrangea (wanderer), lotus, chrysanthemum, red hollyhocks (peace) and lily (purity).

The twelve monthly flowers that were displayed are as follows: plum blossom, peach blossom, magnolia, peony, pink lily, lotus, opium poppy, hibiscus, canna, yellow hibiscus, chrysanthemum; wax plum, nandina and luchan pine.

According to the docent, some of the artifacts were contributed by the late Avery Brundage of IOC fame. These artifacts are located on the second and third levels of the museum.

Finally, when visiting the museum, I recommend stopping in at their gift shop and the cafe. The gift shop has a large variety of books, scarves, greeting cards, post cards, gourmet food items, etc. The cafe has the usual pastries and baked goods, beverages, salad and entree of Asian influence. 

The annual basic membership is $89. Membership has its benefits - unlimited visits to the museum, one guest is allowed, 10% discount in the gift shop.
author: Carol C.

description: What an amazing experience we had at the AAM in San Francisco. The exhibition we saw was godly, an amazing showcase on the divine. We experienced three floors of sculptures, artifacts, literature scrolls, buddhas, pottery, and so much more. We were taken back to to the year 100, it was amazing. Located right across from city hall in the civic center area the price is $15 and $10 for Students! It was a DEAL for the amount of history you get to experience. Not to mention the building is historic and beautiful.
author: Karlos G.

description: The Asian Art Museum was an interesting place to learn rich art, history and all the great experience as a traveler to explorer. We enjoyed learning so much about the Hinduism, Buddhism, and old artifacts that were over 2000 years old. Great place for couples, and family fun learning education
author: Eve L.

description:
I admit I'm a museum freak. I have been to many and one of my favorites is the Asian Art Museum in San Francisco. So auspicious. The AAM is located in the old main library, the Beaux Arts-style building was built in 1917. The location in the Civic Center of San Francisco makes it convenient for all to see. I can spend hours here...

Originally the AAM shared space with the De Young Museum in Golden Gate Park. In 2003 it officially moved to the current location. The security entrance is at street level. The AAM collection has thousands of works of art and artifacts from all major Asian countries and traditions, some dating to over 6,000 years old. 

You will find Tibetan drawings to Cambodian sculptures to samurai katana swords to ancient landscape scrolls the AAM has it all under one roof. My personal favorites include Hokusai & Otagawa Kuniyoshi Ukiyo-e prints, Buddhist statues from the Kamakura era, Chinese scroll paintings from the Qing Dynasty, and anything Tibetan related. I also enjoy 17th century Shunga, but shhh. 

GENERAL ADMISSION: 

Adults: $15
Seniors (65+ w/ ID): $10
College Students (w/ ID): $10
Youths (13-17): $10
Thursday Night Special (5pm+): $10

AAM members: FREE
Children (12 & under) FREE
SFUSD Students: FREE
Active U.S. Armed Forces
(+ up to five family members): FREE
Target First Free Sundays: FREE

The AAM has a top notch gift store & exceptional cafe for all to enjoy too! I hope this review helped and I hope you get the chance to visit one of my favorite museums anywhere! And this ain't no ancient Chinese secret;)
author: Eric R.

description: Cool museum for sure. Not sure what to say as I believe their exhibitions rotate so what I saw may not be there for you. Either way, go there and enjoy a glimpse into history!
author: Josh S.

description:
I've passed by this museum multiple times. Asian
art is usually not my preference . If you are a library
member they have a program called 'Discover
And Go'. This program allows free entrance to
two people and occasionally a family.
We we're pleasantly surprised at how beautiful
and well organized and presented this museum is.
Beautiful Buddhas that are centuries old, pottery,
some jewelry. They had a special Buddhist gong
that you could welcome in the New Year. 
   Art from all areas of Asia : China, Thailand,
Japan, Korea,Philippines and much more.
    There is a gift shop and a cafe that serves
Asian food .
    Enjoyable visit.
author: Gayle G.

description:
The Asian Art Museum has one of the biggest collection of art from Asia, and focuses mainly art history from that part of the world. The admission price includes an audio guide and takes you through the history of Asia. Starting with India, it supposedly goes in chronological and geographical order, but I'm not exactly sure. The museum has a very extensive collection, so seeing everything within a visit would be hard to do and definitely not the best way to go about exploring this place. My suggestion is to pick a few sections and focus on those. If you still have the stamina, definitely check out more. 

The permanent collection spans two floors and represents almost all regions of Asia, from Persia to Japan, including India, Southeast Asia, China & Korea. I was particularly impressed with their selection of Chinese jade treasures as well as Korean pottery of both Goryeo and Joseon dynasties. I also found out by Japanese netsukes, never seen these before, even in Japan.

I highly recommend the Asian Art Museum in San Francisco. Spend at least two hours here if you're planning to go.
author: Steve N.

description:
As a museum worker, it's always a great day to see what other museums have in store. It's always a nice time to slowly take your time and see what's new with each visit; however, the Asian Art Museum definitely gives a different experience than I would get at something like the MoMA.

In my experience, many museums do have their own permanent collection and rotating borrowed collections; however, the bulk of the Asian Art Museum is their permanent collection of Eastern and some South/Southeast Asian art that is rarely altered. Many times, the special exhibitions are where the real party is at, so it's much more worth it to go the extra mile and pay for that.

I love the Asian Art Museum for what they have to offer on free days, family weekends, and events through the year. The activities they have to offer are intriguing, build a better knowledge for the community about Asian arts, and inviting to convince goers to come back and see more on the next visit.

If there's one thing they need to change as a museum, it would have to be the very stark contrast of Eastern arts in collection versus South and Southeast Asian arts in collection. The Eastern Asian arts seem like they're dominantly in display and always at the center, while the South and Southeast Asian arts seem like they're not being actively sought after as much as, let's say, Korea, China, and Japan. This gap between the two really needs to be narrowed; however, this rant's really for art historians, so keep on trying Asian Art Museum!
author: Renneth D.

description:
Went to see the new Tomb Treasures exhibit.  There are 3 rooms full of stuff to read & see.  I think you need at least 1-2hrs to see it all.  If you want to see the other 2 floors you might need more time.

Pics allowed in Tomb Treasures just No Flash.  Lots of jade stuff like Jade Coffin and they funniest is the Phallus - jade penis!

Went to the 2nd & 3rd fl, so-so for me but I've been many times.
author: Ann L.

description: The cafe has pretty good food and you don't have to pay for the museum to eat at the cafe. The chicken rice bowl is delicious and the fried donuts with Matcha have an original flavor.  The ambience is good and when the weather is nice it's great to sit on the outdoor patio.
author: Lo J.

description:
Free visit to the Asian Art Museum? Yes please; the first Sunday of each month is free. You still have to pay for the special exhibitions, bit it's a discounted price. 
It was my first time ever here. I'd been wanting to come for a while but just didn't. Took the BART and it's SOOOO convenient. Literally a 2 min walk, and it takes that long because you may have to wait for the crosswalk. 
Anyhow, the museum is 3 levels, with escalators and elevators. I love that there is tons of natural light inside. We started off on the 3rd floors and went down. There are tons of displays. You have the option of getting headphones, which I didn't. 
If you haven't been, I would totally recommend coming here.
author: Sarika S.

description:
This museum was incredible and deserved another day!  First of all, the building is quite impressive - both the new additions as well as the repurposed Library building. The stairs in the main entrance are awesome and the surroundings are beautiful as well. I strongly suggest taking a free docent tour, if possible. We did so and it turned out to be a personal tour. After the tour we backtracked to look closer at some of the exhibits. 

The café, on the first floor, is inviting and a welcome respite during our 5 hours in the museum. Senior admission to the museum was only $10 and well worth it. 

I particularly enjoyed the exhibit focusing on the Buddha and the history of the Buddha throughout time as well as in different countries. The carvings, both wood and stone were quite impressive. Definitely a "must see" when in SF and we will definitely return.
author: Dave W.

description: The Museum of Asian Art has a huge collection of works of art. There are several rooms in the museum, in each is placed a unique style direction, a certain epoch. There are widespread works of painting, sculpture, graphics, photography. We liked products made of porcelain, ceramics. There is also a souvenir shop with a large assortment of goods. The museum is open daily from 10-00 to 17-00, except Monday.
author: Anna C.

description:
My cousin and I went to the Asian Art Museum on a free Sunday (thanks Target!). People were already queueing up before they opened, and we were maybe 10th in line or so.

There were no exhibits to see on the first floor, because they were setting up for their next special exhibit. So we went all the way up to the third floor and worked our way down.

If you like seeing Buddhas from many different time periods, the South Asian section on the third floor of the Asian Art Museum is the place for you. There were a lot of them. Art from Persia, Southeast Asia, and China is also on display.

Chinese art continues on the second floor. You will also see art from Japan and Korea. There is a display on the art and culture of the Sikhs. 

If you take the time to read the card or plaque next to each and every exhibit, you will not be able to go through the museum before they close. You must be much more selective or visit again and again! Even though it was a free day, I never felt really cramped in the museum. My friend told me that was due to the lack of a special exhibition. Otherwise it would have been a total madhouse!

If you get hungry during your visit, there is Cafe Asia (opens at 11) on the ground floor. But be warned, it's not cheap.
author: The Bottomless Pi T.

description:
This is really an excellent museum, with outstanding exhibits housed in a beautiful building.  The collection of Chinese, Japanese, and Indian art is comprehensive and well-presented, without being unnecessarily cluttered with innumerable artifacts, as is often the case at other museums that seem to be intent on showing off everything they have as opposed presenting the cultural heritage of a people.

There are two primary reasons why I'm not giving this place 5 stars.  First, while there is an impressive array of ancient art, there is hardly any contemporary art.  Asian art is more than just 400 year old ceramics and silk paintings, more than 1000 year old carvings of Buddhist deities.  There were a handful of modern Japanese ceramics that were a beautiful blend of traditional styles and 21st century influences; more displays such as this would be welcomed.

Second, whereas there are certain cultures that are well-represented here, there are that are sadly underrepresented.  There is currently a special exhibit of Filipino art, but this amounts to just two small rooms of a handful of textiles and other small objects.  To their credit, the curators of the museum acknowledge that their Filipino collection is embarrassingly small, especially given the very large Filipino population in the Bay Area, and they have been working to rectify that.  Along the same lines, the Persian art is housed in a single small room; it would be great if this important culture were better represented in this otherwise fantastic museum.
author: Lee L.

description:
I've been to many SF museums's, but had never actually been here, despite passing it many times. Also, I'm huge into Asian history, so it made no sense for me to not visit. 

The good news is that with student ID, so you get a few dollars off the entrance fee, which helps a lot. The size of this place is decent. It's three floors and they all offer something very unique. It's pretty easy to know where you are going and staff is everywhere to help you out. It was quite fascinating to see pieces from Japan, China, Korea, India, etc that were sometimes over a 100 years old. 

While having many pieces that are quite old, this place feels very modern, but it is SF. They are not going slouch. Overall, it was a great experience and hope to come again in the future.
author: Benny H.

description:
If there's one more reason why the Bay Area is as amazing as it is (like we all need another reason why the Bay is the BAE), it's that museums are EVERYWHERE - far as the eye can possibly see. For example, in the South Bay/Silicon Valley area, you have places like the Tech museum and the Pace Gallery. Heck, even Intel has its own little space for the public. In the East Bay, you have places such as the Oakland Museum of California. 

And in San Francisco, you have more museums than you can count on your fingers. Asian Art Museum is definitely one that I recommend you all check out. 

Recently, my girlfriend and I had this ambitious plan (well technically I dragged her along with me, but you know) of visiting 3 different museums around the Bay in one day. The second on our list was the Asian Art Museum. The really cool thing (that makes the Bay Area EVEN BETTER) about this museum and several others around is that it's free during certain days of the year. For example, it's ALWAYS free every first Sunday of the month. That's like 52 days of annually! Even if you don't come during a free day, it's only $15 for general admission (similar to other museums like de Young and Legion of Honor). 

Contrary to what you might think, the Asian Art Museum is located on Larkin Street near the Civic Center (I always thought it'd be in the city's Asian neighborhoods such as the Sunset or Chinatown). This location is SUPER accessible for city dwellers, specifically people who take public transit, because the museum is right next to Civic Station Bart + other bus stations. Driving may be a bit of a pain since parking can be limited. However, on weekends after 6pm it should be free! I would just be careful and make sure you lock your car and take all your belongings with you...

From the outside, it may seem like the Asian Art Museum is pretty small (and maybe not worth your time), but the interesting thing that we noticed right away when we walked in was that this place really knows how to pack a whole bunch of stuff in a tight space; there's at least 3-4 different floors within the museum, and each one has a TON of exhibits to explore. During our time here, we saw things from Buddha statues to incredible art on the walls. My personal favorite, and one that really capped off an amazing day, was the station towards the entrance that had FREE flowers. Basically, there was a special exhibit going around called "Flower Power," basically a way to show the public the magic of nature. Next to the exhibit was a bed of flowers people could just take and give to strangers to brighten up the day. My girlfriend and I both took one, and we had THOUHT that they werent really but THEY WERE. It was such a nice thing that the museum was doing that really made me appreciate this place further. They really have a lot of cool opportunities for visitors to engage with the community. 

Overall, I'm glad we took the chance to explore the Asian Art Museum. If we actually came on a day where we'd have to pay, we'd definitely still go. The only real downside about this museum is that given the space (and even though they pack a lot), you can definitely get through the entire place in around an hour. Still, I think the Asian Art Museum of SF is worthy of an "omg, I'd travel 2 hours for this."

Have fun and prosper!
author: Bryan W.

description: We visited here after lunch in Chinatown.  We just had an hour so visited this museum quickly.  Luckily, my parents had free passes so our admission were complimentary.  There are tons of exhibits to look at so wished we had more time.  However, it was good enough for us with our limited time.
author: Phillip Y.

description: This is one of my favorite museums in SF! Have been here several times for the regular exhibits, a Thurs night visit, special exhibits as well as a private holiday party. The space is beautiful with nice light and a great gift shop. It's definitely on the smaller side but extremely dense and could easily spend a day getting lost in thought here. The special exhibits are pretty great - saw one recently on Korean couture.  The museum offers free admission on the first Sun of every month! Great place to spend a few hours.
author: Yin H.

description: I almost didn't go here until I read the reviews: I think of a dry dusty infrequently visited wing of the museum when I think of Asian Art, but that is totally a wrong bias!  This museum goes a long way to blow up the irrelevance and leads you through the many strands of what we westerners call "Asian" but what really makes up a vast number of cultures and regions.  They start you off making sure you understand that there is so much diversity, I was so intent on getting each branch that time flew by so fast and I had to leave before I even finished one floor, frustrating but wonderful!  The building is an old library which is repurposed for the museum, the ground floor is a sort of open Asian market for arts, crafts and foods.   Definitely at the top of the list for your museum visits to the city!
author: Brandon B.

description:
Back again for more fun at the Asian Art Museum.  Loved seeing the tomb treasures again (next time I'm going to take the docent led tour!)  This time I took the Art's of China tour (2pm)- so very interesting!  Our docent was fascinating, and I feel like I learned a lot more than I would have on my own.  I really loved being guided through the overwhelming number of treasures.  I had not realized this was the biggest collection of Asian art outside of Asia.  Also, I did not realize this was the old library building- repurposed  to be a museum.  What a fabulous history this building has!  

I am truly enjoying my membership benefits.  I brought friends with me to check out the museum, and we all thoroughly enjoyed ourselves.  I can't wait to go back.  

The museum gift store was (again) fabulous.  We loved the Woo Garden jam we got last time- so I picked up some more.  So delicious.  I just love this gift shop.  What a fantastic place.  Children's blocks with Arabic letters?  Yes.  They've got you covered.  All manner of fabulous children's books?  You bet.  And, of course, Woo Garden jam.  Seriously decadent jam.  I've never seen it anywhere else- and I'm so glad I discovered it here.
author: Alex M.

description:
Great place, excellent location and the events they have here are phenomenal. 
I got a massage here at an events , oh and some of the snacks I've tried are to die for.
It's right by union square and downtown Market street area. This place is really unique.
I learned alot about the asian culture here. There's so much art and things in the culture I was unaware of. I highly suggest coming here.
author: Luke S.

description:
I can't believe this is the first time visiting SF's Asian Art Museum (AAM).  My company holds Asian diversity events yearly and they always provide flyers and promotions for AAM - they have special exhibits that change and is a short walk from Civic Center BART.  So really no excuses not to go at least once!

OVERALL
Very nice museum!  Small enough (3 floors) so you can see most of the exhibit from one visit.  Clean restrooms on every floor, excellent cafe (I'll review separately), nifty museum store, free WiFi, and free rental of their virtual museum audio guides (which we did not use, arg!).  All that and the museum was super clean and modern.  Definitely pay extra for the special exhibit ($25/pp for Saturday).

SPECIAL EXHIBIT
Until mid September 2016, the special exhibit are some artifacts dating back to the last few emperors of China (Qing, Ming, Yuan, Song).  Four exhibit rooms showing cool pottery, paintings, and bios of the various emperors and what they did to develop the art movement in China back in the day.  Many of the exhibits were from the National Museum of Taiwan.  The most famous was in the last room dedicated to Empress Dowager Cixi - the pork belly rock!  Note photography isn't allowed for the special exhibit - they have fine print on all the entrance areas.

PERMANENT COLLECTIONS
The second and third floors house their permanent collections and photography is allowed.  I liked the third floor the best with all those cool statues and carvings from India and Thailand.
author: Daniel C.

description:
Last time I was at the Asian Art Museum was when it was in the old De Young in the 80's.  An empty and mostly boring place to wander around looking at "the stuff".  I could "do" the whole place in about 30 minutes.

Fast-forward 30 years - Holy Cow!  You can spend 4 hours and not adequately see all of the treasures - and it is not at all boring!

We wanted to see the National Palace Museum pieces from Taiwan.  I went to Taiwan to see their stuff  in the 80's.  It was impressive!  The Nationalist Chinese grabbed all the good stuff in China before they left the place to Mao and his buddies.  Back in Taiwan, they dug a big cave into a mountain and stored all the loot there - and then would regularly truck out a bunch of stuff to display at the National Palace Museum.  It made the stuff displayed in the De Young exhibit look like bric-a-brac from Chinatown... so I never wanted to see the Asian Art Museum again... until the recent exhibit of the National Palace Museum stuff came into town.  I was not disappointed!   The portraits of the emperors, the emperors seal and that rock fashioned into an incredibly delicious looking piece of roast pork - it was all terrific.  If you have the opportunity to see this exhibit, don't miss it.

The rest of of the stuff?  Two more levels of objects from "Asia" an the second and third floors - includes India, Japan, Korea and other places in the general area.  It was nice to see Asian people bringing their children to view the treasures of their heritage.  "See?  This is what our people did!" 

Parking cost $25, so bring your wallet. 

The three items that I liked best are shown below:
author: Steve S.

description: Absolutely gorgeous - wonderful variety of art from lots of regions, styles, and time periods, and the rotating exhibits are always worth seeing! The food is great as well.
author: Chloe J.

description:
This museum really covers all the Asian cultures in an organized, relaxing way.  There are four (five?) floors to explore, and it's a pleasure to just wander around taking in all the amazing art.  I've also been to most of their special exhibits recently (which are included in the admission price), and those are also amazing.  They do a great job of describing and explaining without getting tedious.
Down side is parking - but no one enjoys parking in the city.  However, it is very close to Bart.
author: Lydia C.

description: This place was amazing and probably my favorite thing I did on my trip to California. To see so many works of art that are hundreds to a thousand years old is absolutely breathtaking. The audio tour was good so you could learn about each piece, or skip ahead to another piece. This place is super clean, and has a very calming feel to it. They had guides for kids and tourists that kept them engaged. They have an amazing collection here and I would recommend this place to anyone visiting Sacramento. It was free for military so I'm not sure on the price.
author: Chūta K.

description: Loved this place. Took my family here first Sunday of the month (which is free!!!). My kinds were so happy we went. They have kids activities on the first floor. Second and third floor offer a lot of historical objects to see from all the Asian countries! Would highly recommend to friends and family!
author: Bob L.

description:
I bought a regular membership here so I can view the current special exhibit, the Emperors Treasures. If you just bought a ticket as a one time deal, it costs more to see the special exhibit. So why not spring for an $80 membership?  Four visits and you'll get your money's worth!

Ok enough about the membership plug. I dropped in on my lunch break to take a gander at the fine craftsmanship of imperial Chinese Art. The exhibit did not disappoint. Many items were just so beautiful and handmade. They won't allow picture taking at the special exhibit so I shelled out for the book. 

I didn't go upstairs because my lunch break was over but I'll drop in again to look. 

Staff was nice and pleasant.
author: Wendy H.

description: This review is ONLY for the restaurant at the Museum (the Museum itself is 5 stars). They recently changed the menu and configuration and it is a disaster both in terms of food and ambience.  The prices are higher, the menu is more limited and the service is non-existent. We waited 15 minutes in a line just to order then another 20 minutes for our food.  This has always been our "go to" place before the symphony and opera but no longer - we almost missed our performance this time!
author: Hank W.

description: Had a great fun at this place. such a wonderful museum with Asian history being stored in it. You will be amazed to know how the historical people lived and had different rituals. perpect for history lovers. thanks
author: Amenda S.

description:
Came here for the 50th anniversary weekend. This was a free admission weekend. The building is impressive and grand. There were a lot of nice performances and activities (crafts, calligraphy presentation, music, dancing) which created a really fun atmosphere. This made it really nice for both adults and kids. Even us adults enjoyed trying our hand at making a paper fortune cookie. Plus, it was nice to have a place to sit for just a minute and relax between taking in all this information and history. I did not dine at the cafe but the food looked good. It was also really nice that they have a complimentary coat check for both umbrellas and jackets given that it was a rainy day.

The only issue we had was the organization of the exhibits and activities. It was difficult to navigate at times and there was not great signage. Also, they would only allow certain entrances to things without being able to provide clear directions to the appropriate entrance locations.
author: Susan G.

description:
Love this Museum and what they had to offer.  We came by here for the first time last month, when they had the free museum day.  Since we didn't have much to do and just happened to be in the city that particular day, why not take advantage of the opportunity.

When we finally went inside, I thought it was going to be a small exhibit.  We ended up walking around the whole gallery for few hours.  It was a great learning experience to know other cultures and their beliefs.  Many artifacts are so awesome to look at and amazing how they preserved them.

And though we got lucky with the free admission fee, I would still recommend this Museum to anyone even if you have to pay to get in.  It really is worth seeing.

This place also have nice cafe area and cute souvenir store inside.
author: Grace L.

description: Beautiful and peaceful. I spent hours in here and it was impeccable. Great music and air conditioning. Would highly recommend to anyone that is interested in art, Asian art, or exploring new cultures.
author: Taylor R.

description:
Food for the Brain ? You got to visit the museum.... Buddhism , Hinduism , Japanese ..... Want to absorb all the knowledge I could while viewing and reading those very interesting details..about the lifestyle of the Ming Dynasty.. To the Implicate headrest to the jade Making...

First Sunday .. Thursday after 5 is $5.. Don't mind coming back and relieve the yesteryears...
author: Donovan L.

description: The museum is beautiful and the amount of pieces of Asian art that is displayed here is insane! My girlfriend and I were there specifically for the Philippine Art exhibit. The exhibit currently does not have much of a collection of art yet but the few things they did have were great examples of what the Philippine culture has to offer. Next to several of the art pieces were little signs that had a brief explanation from respected members of the Philippines community, of what the art meant to them. I thought it was a very nice touch to the exhibit. Overall, the museum is definitely worth a visit if you are in the area and want to view more wonderful art than you can handle.
author: Jay R.

description:
Museum was awesome. Loved  the free tours by docents. Would return with kid.

Restaurant was good. 4.1 stars. Got beef skirt which was good. It was spicy and tender. A bit expensive.

Vegan cauliflower soup was good too. 4.2 stars.
author: Jenny V.

description: Beyond words beautiful artwork statues ceramics gemstone lacquer furniture visually astonishing. My service puppy and I sat on small stools used headphones watch listen artists on small monitors describe their work. I am disabled and staff opened doors showed me elevators were so attentive . The marble stairs I remember sliding down as child when it was Main Library the transition from place stored precious books to precious art in a mix of modern glass rooftops to marble Sistine Chapel like ceilings of marble are outstanding.
author: Patricia H.

description: Incredible art and I was forunate to be there to see a scheduled sweet, dance performance. People working there were kind, helpful.
author: Leslie K.

description: I took the kids on Free Museum Day - first weekend of the month.  This is still one of the best museum in there city - love all the artifacts from Asia, especially those from China.  After the museum, we went across the street to play In the new play structures!  Great additions SF!
author: Huy L.

description:
Asian Art Museum near Civic center is wonder facility.   The exhibits feature beautiful objects and art work from India to China, Korea, Japan and islands through the Pacific.

Great programs for families and children.
author: Mandi T.

description: One of the city's best cultural institutions. Incredible space, incredible collection, and they host events that put the other museums in town to shame - lots of one-time events related to the exhibitions but some great annual ones too, like the New Year's bell ringing, SFUSD arts festival, CAAM film festival gala. Must-see.
author: Kyle A.

description:
I came here specifically for their Rama Epic exhibit, so I'll talk about that.  The exhibit was broken up into 4 rooms.  Each room had somewhat of a theme, but ultimately it was a hodge-podge of the same information.  Personally, this style of art wasn't for me, but that's a personal choice.  What really annoyed me is that the writing on the walls often repeated itself rather than providing new or more specific information.  So once I'd read a few of the placards, everything else seemed to be a regurgitation.  

Overall, not a great experience.  But again, museums are pretty personal
author: Denis S.

description: I went to the Asian Art Museum for a friend's wedding. Beautiful building, perfect location. Food and drinks were awesome!
author: Zuleyha S.

description:
Pretty great Korean collection! Most museums have a pretty small Korean gallery, if they have one at all. Their permanent Korean galleries have some fantastic lacquered mother-of-pearl pieces, silk tapestries that I've never seen, a couple modern pieces, and of course pottery. I only had an hour to spend here so I focused my time in those galleries. I would like to return to spend more time in the other galleries. Admission was 15$ for one adult in the afternoon.

If you visit, at least pass through the Korean Pottery gallery to visit the duck. He is adorable!
author: Ian T.

description:
Excellent museum! Well curated and I love the diversity of the pieces. I went on the free first Sunday's and it was really a nice way to spend the afternoon. 

I liked the 28 Chinese modern art exhibit as well as the large rice paper installation piece. One of my favorite museums in the city! Their cafe is also top notch and a good place to grab food whether or not you go to the museum.
author: Semuteh F.

description:
A huge swath of the world is magnificently represented here, and the constantly changing traveling exhibits ensure that your interest will always be piqued.  The building itself is worth the visit. It was the old main branch of the San Francisco library.  When the Asian Art Museum outgrew its space at the DeYoung they decided to take this lovely library space. An Italian architect made the architectural revisions that now allow the museum to display their art magnificently. 
Check with the library for free days and discounted days and for a schedule of children's activities.
Regarding the restaurant, we normally like to enjoy lunch in museums but we did not find anything to eat here that appealed to us.
Enjoy the museum!
author: Linda B.

description: The permanent exhibition has some really neat displays. I would highly recommend coming here. Once in a while they have some cool special exhibitions. Just came back today from their Han Dynasty tomb treasures on loan from China. Very informative and interesting exhibition.
author: Kenson K.

description:
I originally came here for the special exhibit, the Han tombs, but ended up loving the rest of the museum more. Access to this museum is easy, with it being a short walk from Civic Center/UN Plaza Bart. Outside the museum is this colorful dragon lion thing, you can't miss it!

The special exhibit was cool, although slightly underwhelming in my opinion. Most of it was things like figurines, armor, and eating and drinking ware. There were also several interactive items used to demonstrate how instruments like bells sounded during the Han dynasty.

The rest of the museum was pretty awesome as well, with there being a lot of Chinese, Japanese, and Korean art specifically. There were also some smaller exhibits, and one about Sikhs in California stood out to me in particular. The layout is a bit confusing, but I think seeing the exhibits in any order works equally well.

The gift shop had a lot of cool things, though unexpectedly expensive, and the café does not really have anything you could eat as a full meal.

Overall a cool place to check out if you have an afternoon free!
author: Austin F.

description:
This is a magnificent museum, with apparently a focus on Asia. 

My dad had a phone call before we entered the museum, so that gave me a chance to explore the statues in front of the museum. Statues included one with a kirin. There was also a bus stop, that advertised the new Pixar movie, Finding Dory. I had already watched the movie the week before, but am still fascinated by the humor, and grace of the movie. 

Anyhoo, we entered the museum. Senior discounts are $10, and regular admission is $15. We also skipped the special exhibition featuring art from the National Palace of Taiwan, because it cost more, don't remember how much. 

So, it took us about 2 hours, but we basically got in at 1pm, and left by 3pm. Because of convenience, we opted to have lunch at the café inside the museum, Café Asia. 

The food was tasty, but not exceptional. No problem though, I didn't go to the museum just for the food. 

The exhibits that we explored, included art from Pakistan, China, Korea, India, and other sorts of religions, geography, and culture. I was concerned about going to enjoy some of the exhibits deeper into the museum, because the museum was very dark.

Luckily, I had someone with me, who is braver than I am.

Nonetheless, I fully enjoyed this museum, and will visit again. Their exhibits are exceptional, and people mind their own business. 

Would recommend this place to others - even non-Asians.
author: Stephanie O.

description:
Not really being a museum kind of guy, I was surprised to have a good time here as I AM a party kind of guy... not really ; ).  One of our banks hosted their holiday party here recently, giving me an opportunity to enjoy this place... at least part of it...for the first time.  Being a Japan based bank, the current exhibit, Looking East, which describes the influence Japan had on impressionist art and vice versa was the perfect theme for this party.
This private event was held in the upstairs rotunda where the catering company offered a variety of food and imbibe for its loyal customers.  The food and drink stations were positioned in each corner with four large tables in the center with a variety of foods ranging from dim sum, sushi, and other goodies.
After a short appreciation speech by the bank and an informative speech by the museum curator, we were allowed to tour several exhibit rooms on the ground floor.  I was only able to finish one room as the conversation with the hosts took precedence over my tour of this museum.  The security staff were cordial and professional in giving directions and greeting us.  As we left the venue, my guest and I were given this (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=3dEUGjmms_Yydgf-hGr8iw&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q).  Happy days... my first holiday gift of the season! Big thanks to Union Bank for this event and the Asian Art Museum for hosting it.  Will be back.
author: Mike C.

description: This was a really nice museum but I wish it had more of a selection of west Asian relics.  Most everything focused on Buddha, pots, and drawings of flowers.  It seemed like the voice of West Asia was completely absent even though it says that West Asia was included.  Otherwise it represented the traditional things you think of when it comes to Asian museums.
author: Michele C.

description:
Outside of Asia itself the SF Asian Art Museum is not as good as it gets but can certainly hold its own ground. I am partial to the top/third floor where the SE Asian i.e. mostly Khmer sculpture is located. 
.
I have a personal affinity for this building because as a native born San Franciscan I have many memories of this space being our Main Library.  I believe its repurpose was very successful.  Today it houses a diversity of art that is more reflective of our current population. 
.
Visitors will find a gift shop on the first floor as well as a cafe one can visit with out having to purchase entrance into the museum itself.
author: Caesar A.

description:
Meeeh.  
Had a holiday party here and not very impressed with the place. The staff was a little bit PITA in that we walked all the way upstairs to find out some display rooms were close for our party and were shoo'd out

If you're into the Asian art there might be some interest here but I probably would not come back
author: Rich K.

description: One of my favorite museums in San Francisco or anywhere! Beautiful building near San Francisco City Hall and they always have fascinating exhibits. They have a great cafe with Asian style food here as well. Recently saw an exhibit about the Chinese Han Dynasty, which was in power approximately 2000 years ago. Previously had enjoyed an exhibit about the "Ramayana," the story of the mythological Hindu figure "Rama" who was an incarnation of the God Vishnu. Very interesting for me because I did not know much about this story before. The exhibits are very well presented and the gift store is just awesome. I highly recommend.
author: Patricia C.

description: If you are into Asia this is the perfect place! I went here because of an Asian friend, he really enjoyed it.
author: Gerrit P.

description:
Great museum ever, so beautiful and really quite. They have lots of stuff from different countries, and I never seen lots of them before in my whole life.

Very interested when i visited here. Nothing to say more just beautiful
author: Steve Vu N.

description: I had a wonderful tour with one of the docents. What a fabulous collection!  Each piece was perfectly lit and positioned for maximum appreciation!
author: Polly R.

description: Excellent museum.  Great collection of artifacts from different parts of Asia
author: Wai K.

description: This museum was HUGE. We could have explored more, but we ran out of energy!!! It was the perfect way to spend a rainy day in San Francisco!! There were prices of art from most of Asia's countries and a wide range of time periods. It was organized very well and there were escalators when we were to tired to climb the stairs. Highly recommend this to complete a rainy day San Fransico tour.
author: Donna B.

description:
Disappointed with this museum. It was unorganized and unmaintained. The glass on several of the displays was dirty. 

I agree with one of the other reviews that say it felt like an Asian history museum only. I was hoping to see more modern pieces in addition to the old stuff.
author: Emma M.

description:
First off, the Museum itself it gorgeous and the gift shop is a must see, as well. The ladies inside were very friendly and welcoming and not pushy. Tickets were $10 senior $18 adult and $5 for reciprocal memberships. Group discount as well. 

We really enjoyed the Flower Power exhibit. The Docent was lovely and very knowledgeable- it's a free tour. Do it! It was mostly our group and it felt very personal. 

Special Thanks to Darlene, manager of the Cafe Asia.  She was very accommodating with arranging a special area for us to sit.  Darlene was SO patient and calm and we were all happy with our experience. Our food came out really quickly- and Not to mention it was delicious. I ordered the Vietnamese silver noodle dish: yummy! Clear noodles with ground pork, cucumbers and lime with some kind of lettuce to wrap it in. The tea was good and served in a cute little teapot. Overall great choices to choose from if you're looking for some Asian flavors and nice ambience and great customer service. 

I came with a large group of about 20. - Not many places these days will go out of their way for customer service- this place is no exception. 

-a must see Museum to see if you're in the City.
author: MK C.

description: This is a pretty cool museum right near city hall.  IF you like Buddhas, you will not be disappointed.  Would've liked to see more focus on people from smaller areas and groups, but the exhibits were enjoyable.
author: Tom T.

description:
The Asian Art Museum used to be a wing at the De Young Museum in Golden Gate Park.  Through the years, its collection has outgrown its space. Eventually in 1994, the City of San Francisco approved a measure to renovate the former Main Library to make it the new home of the Asian Art Museum.

Designed by the World famous architect Gae Aulenti - best known for her award-winning project of  the Musée d'Orsay in Paris - the museum has a Roman Empire kind of grandness as well as an old, traditional kind of Asian opulence.  There are plenty of open spaces that enable people to enjoy the exhibits and not feeling crowded.  There are also many places for one to sit and stare at the art, and to ponder and wonder.

As the museum states in one of the signs, there really isn't anything known as Asian culture, as inhabitants in different regions have little in common with each other (culturally).  Therefore, the museum's collection is divided into 7 distinct groupings:

* South Asia
* The Persian World and West Asia
* Southeast Asia
* The Himalayas and The Tibetan World
* China
* Korea
* Japan

The museum is made up mostly of adjoining rooms with each room hosting a specific grouping distinctly.  The focus of each room is clear.  As you move from room to room, you'll get a feeling like you are traveling from one country to another, from one dynasty to another, from one century to another.

From one World to another.

This has to be one of the largest (if not the largest) collection of Asian art in the Western World.  It contains exhibits ranging from over 6,000 years ago to near modern times.  The collection is huge and impressive.  However, I did find that they had an overwhelming amount of deity in their collection.  While I understand that deity is a great part of Asian culture in many regions, I am hoping that in the future they can balance it out a little.

What it cost to get to San Francisco:  An arm and a leg.

Admission: $15.

Experience:  Timeless and priceless.
author: Rob L.

description: This museum rocks! It is full with centuries of history of east and south Asia. I highly recommend it. You will see samurai suits and dragons and miniature artwork.
author: Marco C.

description:
Classic San Francisco museum and a must-see for any local or visitor... or anyone looking for a good workout because getting through every exhibit involves a LOT of walking. I remember coming here once as a kid, but I'm glad I got the opportunity to visit again with a group of friends on Free Admission Day, which is the first Sunday of every month.

The museum is easy to navigate, and the exhibits are thought-provoking. There are plenty of well-written descriptions throughout each exhibit, and there are guided tours available for those who are interested. The tour guides are so enthusiastic here! Anyways I'm not usually a fan of museums but this one is really worth the visit.
author: Stefanie C.

description: Been here several times now. Lots of great exhibits. And new Filipino Historical room which I hope expands.
author: Joseph B.

description:
Worth going on free days which are the first Sunday of each month. I just perused the museum, but they do have some beautiful works. 
It was very crowded when I went on the free day, but the line to get in went pretty fast.
author: Laura K.

description: Nice place to visit in a quiet and high class environment.  Very clean and nice people that run the place.  There are two main floors for the exhibit and it should only take you are 2 to 3 hours to complete.   I am not sure but they attempt to charge more for a special display or presentation on the first or bottom floor.  It would have escalated the price to be much higher.  Skip this first and see if the other parts of the museum would satisfy you and your guests.
author: Ala L.

description:
This was my second visit to the Asian Art Museum, and I recommend it for people that enjoy Asian Art.  If it isn't your thing, don't bother.  I've been to Japan, China and Thailand, so enjoy seeing their art.  There is also art from India, Bhutan, Korea, Vietnam, Tibet, Pakistan, Afghanistan, etc.  Buddhism, Shintoism, Hinduism, etc explained.   Very diverse overview!

The security isn't as tight at this museum as others, so it's more relaxing.  There was a special exhibition of Taiwanese art that was enjoyable.  I especially liked the room filled with treasures of the Empress Dowager Cixi.  I had been to the Forbidden City, so interesting to see how she lived there!

$15 admission tickets is a good price, and they do have a free day once a month, and $5 after 5pm on Thursdays.  No excuse not to spend a few hours looking at what the Asian Art Museum has to offer!
author: Marie B.

description: This is one of the best museums in San Francisco, and offers a world class collection of Asian art, well and elegantly displayed (in a building that once housed the main public library). Also features a very good and pleasant museum cafe, which offers good dishes from a variety of Asian cuisines.
author: Jethro B.

description:
This review is for the AAM as a wedding venue.  It was AWESOME.  When we found out that the AAM could be rented out for weddings, we knew that we had to have it here.  The space is absolutely gorgeous as anyone who has been there knows and photographs beautifully.  There are few places in SF that can match the grandeur of the AAM, much less the cultural and historical atmosphere of it as well.

As anyone who has planned a wedding knows, the facility staff plays a huge role in your overall happiness, stress level, and successful execution of the event.  We had the fortune and pleasure of working with Minda who was fantastic to work with and very accommodating and experienced at these events!  Because of her help with us during our planning phase, we never once felt stressed about anything which sounds weird even when I say it since I always thought it was supposed to be stressful.  Well it wasn't with AAM and it was definitely because of Minda and her great team!

In short, we had an absolute blast hosting our wedding here and our guests did too, in fact it was so epic that we got covered by several media outlets and it was no doubt because of the overall epicness that was the AAM and its epicest team that helped make our dreams a reality!  

5 Stars all around: venue beauty, venue ease of working with, venue staff, venue environment, venue preferred vendors, venue epicness
author: Chris C.

description:
I've loved going here since I was child to a volunteer and even now as a night art lover. 

$5 Thursday nights after 5pm (pay $10 and you can get the special exhibit!!)

Also it's pretty awesome that the cafe food is themed after their exhibits. Both the curry and pork belly were awesome! 

If you're a parent, there is a great section on the first floor that has an interactive exhibit for kids to color, fold origami, or other activities!
author: Elaine L.

description:
Beautiful exhibits.  Peaceful and serene layout of the building.  I especially liked the "Enter the Mandala" exhibit.  First you must cross the circle of fire......

From their website:

 Mandalas are maps of Buddhist visionary worlds.
Minutely detailed and saturated with philosophical meaning, these works (most often paintings or sculptures) are a feast for the eyes and the mind--nested squares and circles are arrayed to represent the center of the cosmos and the four cardinal directions. For Buddhist practitioners, however, mandalas are not just images to view, but worlds to enter--after recreating the image in their mind's eye, meditators imaginatively enter its realm.

But is it possible to have this experience without years of meditative discipline?   

Enter the Mandala says yes. In this exhibition, 14th-century paintings align a gallery with the cardinal directions, transforming open space into an architectural mandala--a chance to experience the images in three dimensions, to dwell in the midst of the cosmic symbols and be transported to another world. Visitors can literally "enter the mandala," exploring places in the cosmos--and perhaps themselves--that might otherwise remain invisible.
author: Thomas D.

description:
My favorite museum. Hands down.

I love their fun Thursday Night events when they happen. I take full advantage of their First Free Sundays (happening every month) when I can. I always make it a point to attend their Filipino American History Month Celebration every October.

My one critique is they need to acquire more Filipino artifacts for their collection. If not permanent, at least for the event in October. They literally had only three on exhibit from the thousands of objects in their collection.

Aside from that, it's a beautiful museum and one of my favorite places in SF. It's a must-visit.
author: Michael M.

description:
Went for the "Looking East" exhibition. It was truly amazing but ONLY with the audio. Dont go paying $20 to go in and then skimp on the audio for $5. 

My only complaint was that the analysis of how east met west was structural and did not go deeper into how the japanese influence helped accentuate the meaning of the painting.

Overall, a great exhibition.
author: Fred J.

description:
I absolutely LOVE this museum!!
Beautiful collections of masterpieces from all over Asia!
Quiet and serene atmosphere.  Kind staffs.
I especially loved the 3rd floor exhibit! (Of ancient Buddhas and Indian God statues)
I'll be back soon! 
(You get a great view of the City Hall too when visiting there; However, the area surrounding the museum is full of homeless people... I recommend going during the day time)
author: Sunny S.

description:
Came here to see the Emperor's National Treasures from Taiwan exhibition.  It was amazing to see the difference in the items displayed here in this exhibition when compared to the items on display in the permanent collection.  The special exhibition has items that are really more colorful, shiny, and striking.  I also enjoyed the art history lessons displayed on large panels throughout the exhibition.  

The permanent collection is helpfully displayed by geographic region and is also interesting and contains a few modern pieces.  

First Sunday of the month is free and the museum closes late at 9p on Thursdays.  We went on a free Sunday by accident and the special exhibition was a mob scene.  The rest of the museum was practically vacant in comparison.  

Free coat check for your backpack and the special exhibition prohibited photographs.  

Also extremely impressive was the restoration of the inner grand stairwell and second floor main hall.  Classic architecture looked brand new. The wings of the old library building were completely gutted and rebuilt.  I enjoyed the panels describing the history of the museum, which tended to overlook some of the more unsavory aspects of the life of Avery Brundage.
author: Doctor G.

description:
I had such an awesome time here! Highly recommended! 

Definitely worth the 1hr wait time in line, which to be honest I enjoyed quite a bit. While standing in line we got a chance to take pictures with the sculpture outside of the museum and met such great people that the time flew by. Once you make it inside, you'll be blown away by how much diverse Asian art they have in their despite the fact that it seemed much smaller than expected. I learned a ton and fell in love with so many pieces of art. Such an awesome learning experience! ^_^
author: Christina H.

description:
Nice museum. Place was clean, spacious, Air Conditioned, and the assigned  hostess (probably a volunteer) was very nice and friendly. Most of the exhibits had descriptions and you can even check out a headset that tells the history and background. And their exhibits, oh man their exhibits! it was plentiful and in abundance.

Honestly I can't think of anything NOT to like; even the restroom was clean and the gift shop was reasonably priced.

The hostess mentioned that the first Sunday of every month is free, but I have a difference of opinion here. For this nice of a museum, I would feel bad about coming here for free, and I would have no problem paying the regular $15.00 (kids under 12 are free). 

And when you're done, you can walk across the street to the plaza and enjoy some food from the food truck!
author: Eric T.

description:
3 levels of awesome art & artifacts. I didn't know what to expect. So glad I visited, beautiful building. Parking is difficult. I suggest taking BART. The museum is directly across the street from Civic Center station (U.N. Plaza exit). 
Farmers Market on Sundays & Wednesdays too.
author: Jennie R.

description: Great place to learn and see different Asian history. My favorite is about Buddha. Had to see my cultures art history.
author: Juddi K.

description:
The Asian Art Museum does it again!  We love this place!

Yesterday  we attended the Terracota Warriors exhibit!  I have always wanted to go 
to China to see the Terracota Warriors and now some of them are here in SF!

We were able to use our Oakland Museum reciprocal membership level to
get into the museum and pay only for the Terracota Warriors portion.

Despite a lot of people milling around (many were in organized groups) we
were able to enter the exhibit right away.  I hear the weekends and the Free Days
are pretty crowded.

The Asian Art Museum features their special exhibits in three different rooms.
There is a lot to see and a lot of info to be read.  One gripe I have is that the
signs describing the objects are written in a very small font .  With the dim lights it is almost impossible to read (at least for me)

The first two rooms are teasers.  You'll see artifacts, ornaments, bells, 
swords, cross bows, a couple of videos, maps.

In the vestibule you'll see two chariots with horses--very impressive

There are activities for kids.

In the main exhibition room are the warriors and horses and more artifacts.
You can get an up-close view of the soldiers.  Their facial features are so real and fascinating.  Apparently there is a definite hierarchy of foot soldiers to generals by their helmets and costumes.

There is also a wonderful video that shows the massiveness of the army.
Their discovery in 1974 almost surpasses the discovery of King tut's tomb.

I am a little dismayed by the manner in which a good Yelp bud was treated regarding her small backpack.  I've seen plenty of women with large purses (that could knock out Attila the Hun or a Sumo wrestler with one quick turn) in the exhibits.

If the coat check person said it was okay then that should have been the end of the story.  I guess their overzealousness was in the name of being overly protective.

Note that the admission price is steeper on the weekends.

The Terracotta Warriors are totally worth seeing!
author: Rinky N.

description: Seems like the main exhibit doesn't change, but the ones that do, require you to pay additional $20 to see, was it worth it? Only if you're super into art. Get the audio tour if you want to listen to the history. I do prefer MOMA more, can't wait til it opens, but this place is worth checking out once.
author: Minerva L.

description:
Absolutely amazing museum. 
In addition to Chinese art the collection includes pieces from many other cultures including India, Iran , Korea and SE Asia.
It is set up in a way that makes the art very understandable. Written material includes historical information explaining how one culture influenced the others.
There is a smattering of modern Art in addition to ancient treasures.
The two and a half hours we spent in the museum seem to go very quickly. Then we had a nice lunch in the café.
( In the future we will take an Uber because to getting to and from the museum involved walking through very unpleasant areas. Even taking Market  Street back to the hotel which we thought would be better was not .
author: Karen S.

description:
There was a long line of people waiting to get into the museum, but it went by quicker than I expected. I went on a "Target First Free Sunday". It cost an additional $10 to see the special exhibit- China's Terracotta Warriors. 

There were three galleries on the first floor featuring the special exhibit. Two of the galleries featured objects and artifacts. The most exciting of the three is of course the terracotta warriors and horses. I'm glad I got to see this piece of history. I'm in awe at the work that must have been put into creating the terracotta army. The galleries were crowded, so I wasn't able to enjoy my viewing experience to the fullest though. I later bragged to my mom I got to see the terracotta warriors, but she was not as impressed as I hope she would've been. The last day of the exhibit is May 27th, so make sure to catch it!

While I enjoyed the art located on the second and third floors, it didn't match my excitement of viewing the terracotta warriors. I did like the Buddha sculptures, there were so many that it would be easy to lose count.
author: Helen H.

description:
I could not wait when they announced that there would be a TerraCotta Warrior Exhibit coming to the Asian Art Museum. I have not been to the Asian Art Museum for a long time but Xian China is one of the places that I really want to travel to. Parking is convenient right across the street and just a walk up some stairs to the museum. 

The exhibit is attracting many people. There was a line to get the $22 weekend tickets and to get in. It was a beautiful day so the slight wait was not so bad. You can take non flash photos which was a plus. 

The TerraCotta Warriors even though there are only ten of them were spectacular. I did not expect to see the true TerraCotta Warriors outside of China. The Warriors are a real draw. I have never seen the Asia Art Museum with so many people. The exhibit is only in San Francisco until March 25. Posted some great pics.
author: George F.

description: Beautiful pieces of art and history, well worth the admission price. Takes about 3 hours to walk through and get a decent grasp of each region.
author: Sara G.

description:
This is my favorite museum and definitely my favorite thing to do in San Francisco. They keep the exhibits well lit and organized according to each part of Asia. This museum is spectacular! I got in for free with my sister because of the Discover and Go pass that you can get online through your local library. Check it out! 

I am in love with this museum! 
 Only negative... parking is a pain and can be expensive.
author: Laura B.

description:
This review is purely dedicated to the Rama Epic! It was like my entire childhood came to life. I learned so much and I had no idea that the story traveled to other countries! It was interesting to see the different stories from Thailand and Burma. I also loved the different endings (even within the Indian Subcontinent there are different stories!) I also loved the volunteer staff that is there to share all their information. 

*Spoiler Alert* This is where they lose one star. 1) I thought it was the Free Day but I guess you still have to pay $10 for the special exhibits.
