That's what I get when I'm in charge of date day and I tried to be cheap about it and choose the free option...hahaha 2) The volunteer docents were awesome! However, I wish there was a Pronunciation 101 class. For example, Sita is pronounced "Seetha". I say this because I don't speak any of the Indian languages and if my American-Born Confused self can say the names, I think everyone else can too. Ravana="Rah-vunah", etc. Small little pet peeve but hey, I had to learn how to say Beethoven and Tchaikovsky right? 3) The most important part of the story is the Lakshman Rekha! The three lines that Sita couldn't cross in order to be safe. And they called it "The Magic Circle". Whaat? But I guess it's analogous to watching your favorite book become a movie and then pointing out all the parts they missed. 

However, let's go back to those awesome four stars they earned...it was an experience I will always cherish. I want to go and watch all of the old Mahabarat videos again! 

I would like to come back again for the other exhibits. The museum seems very well organized! I'm not a museum person but skipping the Rama epic felt like skipping out on Temple...
author: Leena B.

description: I greatly enjoy this museum full art great works of art and artifacts from all over the Asian continent.  It's three floors all filled with great works.  It's $15 to get in which is a but high but it's worth it for a couple hours to get out of the cold.  It's one of my favorite museums in the city.
author: Anthony G.

description:
I don't go to the Asian Art Museum more than once a year at tops, but it's definitely something any SF resident or visitor should check out at least once. 

The Asian Art Museum has a great regular collection, with pieces from several countries, and they also have some interesting exhibits. I recently view the Floating world exhibit and was surprised I never heard about its scandalous going-ons before.

They're also one of the museums in the city that does a free day, possibly once a month. It's only $15 to get in normally, but if your funds are on the low and you don't mind dealing with the people the free days are good to take advantage of.
author: Jon T.

description:
At $25 per adult on the weekend, this is a...well, let's just say that this is an "ambitiously expensive" museum for San Francisco. It's almost THREE TIMES the price of the De Young. It's $3 more expensive for weekend admission than the Whitney in NYC (which is larger, more diverse, and an architectural icon). It's $9 more than the Louvre!

On top of that, it's a zoo. I went toward the end of the Japonisme/Impressionism exhibit, and the special exhibit galleries were so cramped that it was impossible to really look at any of the art. Twenty people would be crowded around a tiny woodblock print at a distance of five feet, trying to squint to see the details. Unpleasant, to say the least. If I hadn't stuck around until 4pm to wait out the crowds, I would have considered the visit to be a total rip-off.

The main collection galleries were better, but much closer to a natural history museum than an art museum. Much of the collection consists of statuary and religious artifacts from shrines and tombs around Asia. This is fine, but I wouldn't pay $25 to see it. I'd say that you have to have an archaeologist's level of interest in asian antiquities to justify a visit.

I'm definitely not returning on the weekend. It might be more worthwhile at the $10 price point on Thursday nights.
author: Tim R.

description: OK museum, but management needs to get their workers on the same page. On coming in, one employee encouraged us to put our stuff in a complimentary backpack, to be returned at the end of the visit. We thought, great, no need to use the coat check. Now, how do most people wear a backpack? On their backs! So did we. We were stopped at the door of the first exhibit we entered & told that we couldn't wear the backpacks on our backs! So, back out to the coat check to check everything. So glad we didn't get a membership to this museum.
author: Deb L.

description: We had recently visited the museum which was quite good but today we saw the special Tomb exhibit which was terrific and worth seeing. I especially enjoyed the free guided tour which was excellent
author: Marion J.

description:
This museum is full of variety and different types of art.  It is 3 stories with the art on the 2nd and 3rd.  Leave yourself a few hours to go through it.  I normally get bored wandering through museums, but this one kept me entertained.  There are tapestries, vases, sculptures, figurines and dishes.  I went at lunch time on a Thursday and it wasn't too busy only a few field trips.  

Take a lot of pictures and check out the store on the first floor.
author: Darika S.

description:
Of all the museums I've visited in my brief and uneventful life, the Asian Art Museum is my favorite. Here are four reasons why.

1. The "28 Chinese" exhibit. This was easily the highlight of the museum. The art pieces are thoughtfully curated, and it was a welcome break from the monotony of western European and North American art that most young people are exposed to.

2. The Rubell panel. I had the good fortune to come exactly on the night of the panel and discussion with the Rubells, the power couple who collected, organized, and sponsored the 28 Chinese exhibit. The Rubells were entertaining and informative speakers.

3. The $5 after 5 P.M. deal. My group did this; we saved a lot of money. 

4. The weird vase things with the taxidermied animals inside. Just... Look for three giant vases. You'll be horrified, but you sure won't be disappointed!

The museum can get a little chilly, so I'd bring a light sweater in the summer. 

The Asian Art Museum is a rightful gem in San Francisco. I'd recommend it to anyone interested in art!
author: Connie C.

description:
How often do we really get to travel to another country? What with the expense of plane tickets, exchanging currencies, hotel stay, food and souvenirs, the hassle of going through customs, or just plain out carving enough time away from work and other obligations. 

Let's get real here. I know I'm herra Asian, but even I have not had the chance to visit the "Motherland."

Here at The Asian Art Museum, the continent of Asia and its history is brought to us. 

The current exhibit beautifully showcases Mandalas which are used in Buddhism and Hinduism as a spiritual guidance tool to help with focus and meditation. Used for centuries, this ritualistic practice is still utilized today. At the museum, you can see various types of intricately drawn Mandalas, carefully preserved from all over Asia. Another interesting thing I discovered is that during this meditative practice, depending upon the specific design of the Mandala, a particular mantra is recited along with it. 

*Stares off into the distance with peaceful eyes*

Ommmmmmmmmm

Oh I'm so enlightened, I can't stand it. 

And when you further explore the museum, you travel through different Asian country exhibits ranging from Thailand, Japan, Korea, India, China, Indonesia, and many more. 

Some of the interesting things I saw, which are showcased all year long, were the Japanese Samurai Masks, the Sandstone Indian Deities which were remarkably detailed in carving that have stood the test of time, Southeast Asian puppets, Korean pottery and decorative urns, and variation upon variation of Buddhas sculpted and treasured through the eyes of each culture. 

Phew! What an experience. 

I was able to get a little taste of the different traditions, the values, the honor, the religions, the turmoil, the statuses, the victories and defeats, riches and possessions, the spirituality and humanity of Asian history.

It was a very extraordinary visit. I was also excited to see MOMA's collection coupled with The Asian Art Museum in the collaborative Gorgeous exhibit. Here is where beauty and expression is explored. How often are we challenged in our thought process when it comes to perception? This exhibit was very playful and fun and definitely gets you thinking about whether true beauty is an actual feeling and experience or is it just a visual sensory effect. 

Ah who knowsssss dahling?! *bats lashes*

This monster size of a museum is directly across from City Hall and is right next to the SF Main Public Library. Huge in size, no corner is left untouched. Immaculately detailed and architecturally stunning, inside and out.

Admission depends on the day and time, but it's very fair in price. 

Adults $15
Youth (13-17) $10
Children (12 and under) FREE

This to me is a whole helluva lot cheaper than a trip to Asia if one does not have the means to travel at the present moment. 

Oh and who doesn't like a cheapie freebie? 

Uhhhh Herro!

Fun place to check out on your day off. Pay a little extra for a guided tour. Totally worth it. 

Enjoy!
author: Ann S.

description: I went here to see the special exhibit on the Ramayana, which was spread across four exhibition spaces and presented an assortment of different Ramayana motifs across various tellings of the story (Indian, Thai, etc.). Beyond that, I found their regular collection well curated and extensive despite the fact that museum is in and of itself rather small. I look forward to a return trip soon.
author: Laura D.

description: Locals can get in free by district..check online to see which days are free.  Went to the 50th anniversary awesome performances good people and fun environment and lots of gold!!!
author: Sandra S.

description:
*expect to spend an entire day here.
*Terracotta Warriors exhibit is fascinating. To complete the experience, get the "Warrior" soup at Cafe Asia. (Shrimp and Pork Wontons with Tatsoi, Mushrooms, and Carrots.)
*with the abundance of artifacts and overdose of Asian History knowledge, I was most captivated by the religious gods/goddesses.
author: Amy C.

description:
This review is for the Asian Art Museum as a Wedding Venue, not as a Museum.

The Asian Art Museum met all the requirements we wanted as a wedding venue. It had to be beautiful enough were we did not have to spend loads of $$ to make it pretty off decorations. It had to look grand. It had to be in the City of San Francisco. It had to be NOT your typical restaurant or hotel ballroom. It had to be classy yet contemporary.  It had to fit our budget. It had to have a space where it did not make you feel like you were in a museum.. all the time...

Other museums had met our requirements, except for the budget. Others were charging about $5000 more than the AA museum, at just the STARTING rate. Insane! So after determining the date, we booked with the AA Museum. 

They offer different packages according to how much space you need. We wanted our ceremony to be different than others, so we decided to have it on the steps up to the Loggia Hall. (cue clip from Family Guy about Robert Loggia). Our reception space  was in the Samsung Hall. We did not rent out the North nor South Light Court. I've seen other weddings hold their ceremony there, but I didn't like how the Museum Store showed up in their photos. They also provided the Peterson Room for the bride, WHICH WAS BEAUTIFUL, and one of the classrooms for the groom, which was spacious. 

Working with the AA staff was magnificent. I basically planned the wedding myself with help from my parents, sister and my husband, who was deployed on the other side of the world. He was the one who actually suggested the AA Museum. I had been emailing Minda of the Rental Events department and set up a walk through with another person from the Rental Events dept., Joanna. It was hard at first to image a wedding in the space, but the space was so grand itself, I was sold. 

Before you can sign, they require you to contact the SF Rec and Park Dept and SFMTA to see if there are any street closures or other City events in Civic Center that might affect your night. You also need insurance and a deposit. Since the place is a museum, it will not be open for the wedding party until 5:15 pm and 6:15 pm for guests, so if you want a day time ceremony, you're going to have to go somewhere else. 

Most of my conversations were through email. When I needed a walk through with other vendors at the Museum, I just emailed Minda and she would leave free passes at the Counter for us. As the day came closer, we had a final walk through with Minda and my day of coordinator to make sure everything fit and there was enough amp for all the equipment. She is very organized and professional yet humorous, just what a bride-to-be needed a couple weeks before THE DAY. We had some difficulty getting the Rental Insurance wording correct, but Minda was thorough and patient enough with us to work it out with our insurance provider. 

Everything went smoothly on THE DAY, except for the weather. It looked nice, but the wind was blowing at about 50 mph. Because of museum rules, guests were not allowed in until 6:15 PM, and we had guests already arriving at 5:30 pm. Minda was kind enough to open the doors to save them from being blown away.

We took photos in the gallery and in the halls. I was reluctant at first since the exhibit was PHANTOMS OF ASIA, but there were no scary ghosts floating around. All guests gathered in the Loggia Hall and the ceremony took place in the Grand Staircase. Cocktail hour in the Loggia while family members took photos in the garden behind the Peterson Room. Reception was spacious enough for all the tables, dance floor, dj equipment, cake and 153 guests. Security guards stood out of the way but kept things in check. It was all wonderful. 

Because the Black and White Ball was the same night as our wedding, there were taxis and town cars all over to whisk guests away... and Cyndi Lauper rocking out in the distance in the beautifully lit Civic Center. Couldn't have had a better location.
author: Lauren Y.

description:
I think the Asian Art Museum is worth a visit.  The permanent collection is cool, but the exhibitions are what draws the crowd.  The current exhibit is called "Seduction: Japan's Floating World" which showcases the courtesans of Edo-period Japan.  I went to the opening party, and the Asian Art Museum knows how to throw a party!  The Sisters of Perpetual Indulgence graced us with their presence, and there were sake tastings and dirty haikus.  It was awesome.

I've eaten at the cafe, and I have to say it's not worth it.  There are really great Asian restaurants nearby.  Yes, you'd be walking in the Tenderloin, but I think the food is better outside the museum.  Plus, since the cafe is inside, you'd be paying much more than what's available in the Tenderloin.

The Asian Art Museum is a great place to roam and look at wonderful pieces of art.  If you're looking for a deal, visit on the first Sunday of every month, courtesy of Target.
author: Vira P.

description:
Great place to take your friends/family to have a relaxing day.

I visited during the Roads to Arabia exhibition. They have numbered rooms/pathways that guide you through a journey. Afterwards, there was a craft station to make charms for the new year.

If you want free tickets, check with your local library.
The museum is close to the Civic Center station, but if you are driving then the best garage to park is the law school parking lot.
author: Alex C.

description: A San Francisco treasure. If you don't want to go whole hog and buy a membership go on Thursday nights from 5:00 PM to 9:00 PM for only $5.00. Special exhibitions are an extra $5.00 but even with the extra fin it's one of the greatest values for your entertainment dollar in the city. The café is open in the evenings and they have bottled beer and wine and a nice selection of snacks and desserts. Just one block from Civic Center BART and right on the 19-Polk bus line. Huge underground public parking facility directly across the street.
author: Lou S.

description:
Unless you are a connoisseur of Asian Art, this is a 90-minute to 2-hour museum.  I hit the museum as the temporary exhibits were being disassembled and the next exhibits set up.  

The permanent collections are extensive but pretty esoteric.  You've got to know and love Asian art to appreciate a lot of it.
author: Charles S.

description:
Well worth visiting, especially on a free day. Wasn't overpacked and there was an abundance of space to enjoy all artwork on display. I highly recommend going on a free guided tour to provide insight on certain art pieces and artists. Our guide introduced us to a few of the newer pieces and gave explanations of the techniques used and recommended which pieces to spend more time observing for after the tour. It's about 30-45 minutes, 

One of the more interesting pieces the guide pointed out was the bamboo baskets. What commoner such as myself would've known how complicated the process is and technique required to make such a thing. 

I loved the thought provoking and deep statements she made about some of the art. My favorite one was in regards to an artist being asked how he felt when he completes a piece, to which he replied "when is it completed?"
author: Micki H.

description: I had the wonderful opportunity to go on a personalized tour of the Japanese section of the museum and had front row seats at their special mochi pounding event for the Year of the Rooster. Our tour guide was very knowledgeable about the material covered and encouraged questions and discussion among group members. I had a very positive experience at this place and would definitely recommend it to any art lovers/enthusiasts and those who have any interest in the numerous cultures of the Asian continent.
author: Melodie D.

description:
Located in this San Francisco Civic Center Area. This museum has been around for some time.

Paid parking is on the street or garage nearby. It can get busy as one can take various transit options including the bus. Street parking is subject to miscellaneous crowd. 

This is an affordable museum for all ages. A reasonable priced membership is also available which would cover all the trips in a year, admission to special attractions, discount to the gift shop, Japanese tea ceremonies, and early previewing of coming exhibits. 

Multilevel museum that focuses on the various Asian regions. Organized by region and timeline. Lots of artifacts collected or donated over the years helps connect the timelines and the history of various cultures. Very clean and well thought out

Museum runs various special artifacts and exhibits throughout the year. They are unique to gain an understanding of cultures that one may feel is not in Asia. For example recent there was a special exhibit for Arabia. It was quite intriguing.

The museum can be viewed solo and there are tours that run through the day and specials. Always something going on. Staff is usually well versed and understand the subject to which they are providing  tours for. Good mix of interactive, static, and past features. 

Good: family museum, lot of interesting, always some thing new. 
Bad: neighborhood can be a little sketchy at times. 

I am a member and enjoy visiting fairly often.
author: Denny T.

description:
Come here early before the door opens, at least 15 minutes early and theres a long line since it was free of the first sunday. Waited a little bit over 30 minutes

First time coming here. They had china's terracotta warriors: the first emperor legacy exhibition special theme going on but you would have to pay extra to see that one even on a free day. So i just went to the general admission gallery part on a free day. 

They're big on China region and religions around most Asian countries. Other than a section of China, they also have a good section of Japan, small section of Korea, and southeast Asia and other parts of asia. 

Other then that, this place is not bad. I did enjoy seeing items with the history of the items from different part of Asia.
author: Julie N.

description:
This is a cool place!

Went on a few Tuesday day, presented by Target. Figured, I'd never been there before and it seemed like a cool place to check out. So many exhibit rooms and it's very clean.

Lots of people of course. Arts from all over and there are three floors. Because I arrived late, didn't have a chance to check all of them out. I enjoyed the floor that had the Indonesian artifacts and puppets.

Fun place to take the family or to just roam around when exploring the city!
author: Natalie M.

description:
Went to see the Looking East exhibit.  On their website they said the exhibit was the least busy at 3:30, but arriving at that time didn't allow enough time to see the whole exhibit before they closed at 5.  It sucked being rushed through the last 2 rooms of three total.  

The curation was a bit stale I think they could have done more to interact with the audience like the OMCA does.  The exhibit seemed more slanted towards history and less about describing art and design techniques that were being shared between cultures.  I think some visual aids would have been perfect for example instead of paragraphs of text on the wall.

The audio tour was a bust.  Some of the interviewed people sounded like they were from antique roadshow.  I just want to know about the art concepts, not from an antique collector's perspective.
author: Jes S.

description:
I have not had the opportunity to come to the AAM ever since it moved out of GG Park and away from the De Young. I do recall attending an incredibly fun evening at an Asian gala there back in...oooh.. 1998?

Visiting yesterday reminded me afresh just why museums are so lovely. The peace that falls upon me as I walk through halls of hallowed history, from various regions of the world, traversing centuries, privileged to observe and examine what is before me...it's a treat..it really is.

I just love the melding of history, with religion, with culture....

Because Wednesday was not a busy day, many times I was walking through a large area sola...and that really impressed upon me the strangeness of modern meets ancient.

On my visit, I was thrilled to see Sanjay Patel's (Pixar-man)'s great work and the video explaining his evolution as an artist. Here, too, I learned what a stupa is...that Shiva is known most commonly in its abstract form of phallic linga...that a kris is a dagger, and that there is just so much about this complex world that I just don't know!

Humbled...the AAM is a bit small when the special exhibits are not open....the downstairs cafe is subtle and well-decorated. We ate our snacks in the private dining room adjacent. 

Put thy sticker on for re-entry (as I did... said goobye to friend and kids, walked the Farmers Market for a bit, checked my email at the library, and then re-entered to see more with 'fresher' eyes)! 

cclib.org....owe you a shout out!
author: Jana C.

description:
It was the first Sunday of the month and I had no plans, so I decided to check out the Asian Art Museum. Since it's free on the first Sunday, I figured I would check it out and I was amazed. The museum was so well curated and designed. The halls were divided into region and they explained the religions of the area and how it connected to the art of that region. It was super well-done - I ended up spending four hours there and not even finishing. I wasn't a huge Asian art enthusiast before this museum, but it was very impressive. 

Only downside? I think my coworkers think I'm obsessed with Asian art after talking about it so much!!
author: Kate T.

description:
(Long overdue review):  We visited the museum on September 14.  Our favorite part of the museum was the third floor, which has many gorgeous Buddha sculptures and statues.

For those who have an AAA membership, the second (adult) gets a half-price admission.

If you go there by car, I recommend parking at the UC Hastings Garage (see my separate review).
author: Susan L.

description:
Of all the times I have visited SF and of being from Asian descent, today was my first time visiting the Asian Art Museum! All I could say is, what have I been doing all my life?!? I arrived at the museum at 1PM and did not leave till 6PM!!! Need I say more?? Amazing place! Run, don't walk to this place - you don't have to be Asian to be admitted and to have a good time! I learned so much about my own heritage, as well as having a new found appreciation for other Asian cultures featured there. I want to host a traditional Japanese tea time now with all my friends! Looking forward to that day! 


Don't forget to grab your headphones on the right before heading up to the third floor to start your tour! Don't forget to finish the tour off with going to the meditation area (it's room 31) where you go sit, meditate and gather your self and your thoughts before you thrust yourself into the chaos that awaits in the outside world (literally this is what that area is for!) Enjoy!
author: Nancy N.

description:
Ive bn a member since the 1990s.
You can never go wrong with a high-tier membership bc those allow u to bring in friends during your visit.
At the contributor level, i am a single donor so i can bring up to 3 addl folks with me. this also includes special exhibitions.
i dont accept the donor gifts bc theyre negible. i'd rather have em save on the resources for other use.

Most visit for me entail a 3hr walk through. i like to learn from their signage on the displays
PS. they did a beautiful job converting the old SF public library. you actually dont realize that you're walking the entire bldg as you spiral through the exhibits. and dont forget to check out the grand foyer
author: Keikaikaoakua P.

description: nice excuse to go to san francisco for a weekday getaway.
author: Lisa V.

description:
We went to see the 28 Chinese exhibit this weekend. We went through both the art show as well as the rest of the museum to view the rest of the art. 

This is a gorgeous museum with lots to keep you busy for a few hours. We wandered through all three floors and enjoyed both the exhibit and everything else. 

There's options for tours and recordings with headsets if you enjoy that type of feature in a museum. We just wandered around to look at and read the descriptions and enjoyed every bit of it.

This is definitely one of the better museums I've been at in a long time! I'll hopefully get a chance to visit other exhibits in the future.
author: Cassandra J.

description:
In Grand Style on the Joseon dynasty in Korea is very beautiful. I highly recommend catching it while you can. A jade book is really amazing to see in person.

The other exhibits are great as well. They have a lot on feudal daily life of Japan, scholar life and statues of China, stoneworks of Southeast Asia, and buddha statues from China to Pakistan - all with their own interpretations.

I heard the cafe is pretty good, though I did not try. The gift shop is fun.
author: Jason S.

description:
I only had a limited time here, but I was happy I came because I was able to see a lot. It was definitely a great learning experience & it exposed me to a lot of different religions in the Asian culture. I grew up Catholic, so that's all I really know. I learned about other religions in school, but don't really practice so it was very therapeutic seeing all the ornate Buddha statues. 

This place has 3 floors-- all accessible by elevator or escalator. On the bottom floor is the gift shop, which had some pretty cool stuff. My friends and I started on the top floor & worked our way down. Everything we saw all had historical significance. As a former history buff, I was very impressed with the variation of cultural relics and paraphernalia. I wish I was here longer! I definitely want to come back with more time to spend looking at all the exhibits. Definitely worth my time.
author: Brittany D.

description: I love this museum. I remember when it was housed in the De Young museum in Golden Gate Park way back when. From what I understand, it needed a bigger space. Great collections but a warning to those who park alongside the museum on the street: YOUR CAR WILL GET BROKEN INTO. Biggest drawback is the location in a sketchy area of SF.
author: F M.

description:
I been a member for some 7 years & prior been coming to the receptions. The collections been alway great especially the Xian exhibits, and others exhibits. 

Yesterday I went to the reception and it was disappointed what they served. Strawberries yogurt whip cream was good, but only course was vegetables and meat balls bread stick, After spending a raise price membership I was so disappointed what were served. 

In the past it was excellent with varieties of Asian food, lots of tapas, sushi, noodles, & display all sort of interesting varieties of appetizers. Plus lots of interesting desserts.  Plus entertainment with lots of interesting people.  

I couldn't believe they serve rabbit food & no dessert. 
if this keeps up your enrollments will start declining. Maybe I heard they are saving the money for the expansion. For a long time membership owner I am getting second thoughts of renewal my membership again.  Plus there were very few people  at the reception & the exhibit Emperor Treasure was ok. I wish the old museum n Golden Gate Park was back & the last exhibit when they had the jaded suit treasure from Taiwan was awesome. 

renewal member
author: tina l.

description:
One of my favorite spots in the city - I always make a point to stop by whenever there's a new exhibit. The current one, 28, is awesome; my professional photographer friend and I enjoyed it very much, especially the more experimental pieces. I've also gone to night events and weekend yoga here, both of which can be great.

Tips: the first Sunday of every month is free, and there's currently a 5$ after 5 p.m. special, which is also great!
author: Shendi X.

description:
My friend and I were hanging out one night when she reminded me there was a movie night at the Asian Art Museum. On a whim, we decided to rush over and check it out.

This time, they were showing the Japanese film "Ringu." Five dollars to get in to see it but the price is lower (free?) if you're 18 and younger. 

We got there late so we went in and just sat to watch the movie. Apparently there was a discussion about the film before it started about traditional Japense folk lore I guess and how Japanese spirits are dealt with. After the film, we were encouraged to discuss how the film goes with tradition or how it didn't.

They provided snacks (Japanese ones) and drinks for us but I didn't see them until after the movie. I grabbed a bunch of hi-chews because they're my favorite. 

My friend and I spoke with one of the directors and she said that there would be another movie night next month showing the American version of "Ringu." We'll be there for that.

Totally worth it!
author: Sofia R.

description: Great museum, Emperor's Treasures was a beautiful exhibition. However, the skinny white dude at the admissions desk was VERY rude, impatient, and made me feel uneasy about handing him $15. He needs to be fired.
author: Isabella R.

description:
How to Visit the Asian Art Museum:

1)  Curse yourself for procrastinating and going to an exhibit on the last weekend it is open.  

2)  Buy tickets online for the earliest time you can which is 9:30am ($25.19 per ticket).

3)  Take the BART to Civic Center so you don't have to deal with parking hassles.

4)  Be amazed by the Terracotta Warriors exhibit.

This well curated exhibit was housed in 3 galleries filled with treasures that included jade jewelry, bronze cranes, ornate bells, and elaborately carved roof tiles.  The main gallery had 8 different Terracotta Warrior soldiers, two stately life sized horses, and the most impressive limestone tiles and copper wired uniform and helmet you've ever seen.  There were also chariot drawn horses outside the galleries.

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Terracotta_Army

5)  Roll your eyes when you overhear a mom tell her kid that the beautiful food vessel made over 2000 years ago is "what they ate cereal with" and agree with the guy who said, "This is a clusterf*ck" when the room was overcrowded.

6)  Cruise the gift shop and decide that you are NOT going to pay $899 for a mini version of one of the Terracotta Warrior figures.

7)  Experience schadenfreude when you see the huge line when you walk out the door.

8)  Grab brunch at Brenda's down the street and have an impromptu picnic.
author: Amy C.

description:
Field trip MOM over here plus 50kids!! you can only imagine! LOL The children were well behaved except for some =P For myself this was my first time visiting the Asian Art Museum. This museum was spectacular as your eyes seem to gaze into an institution that houses and cares for a collection of artifacts and other objects of scientific, artistic, or historical importance of Asia. 

The display of countries that were exhibited were Japan, China, Thailand, and Bali. The staff was very warm welcoming and very informative. Our class even received a two hour painting course on how to paint like the ancient scholars. Defiantly a must to pay a visit!!
author: Kathy V.

description:
I came here to see the Terracotta Warriors Exhibit and was impressed by how many pieces they had. Being able to see a terracotta warrior up close (and not behind glass), even if you're at the burial location in China, is a rare opportunity and this museum had several of them. Not surprisingly, it got really crowded. At some points, I felt like a sardine in a can being shuffled along. The exhibits were organized and explained very well. The security was very good (but also very polite) in hunting down and asking people to not take flash photography. 

Be sure to come with full battery on your camera and wear good walking shoes, because, in addition to the special exhibit, the permanent collection is massive and spans several floors. If you want to look at everything at a leisurely pace, it'll take a good 3 hours or more. Exhibits range from AD to BC across every Asian continent and culture. By the end of the day, my head was swimming in knowledge and I was in need of a foot rub. 

The museum offers free admission every first Sunday of the month but special exhibits may require a surcharge. Get there early on these days. (And I mean early morning!) The line tends to run long and be slow to move. To not have to worry about parking in SF, take Bart to the Civic Center/ UN Plaza and the museum is just a hop, skip away.
author: Sophia Y.

description: This museum is huge. I learned some stuff about the origins and spread of Buddhism (and other religions) throughout Asia, as well as cultural/historical/political narratives about Asia. I like how they set it up by geographic area and each had a connection to the previous/upcoming area. It's a bit too big and there's heavy emphasis placed on ceramics, so it feels like I saw 50,000 cups and bowls from every city in Asia from every time period ever. Worth it because of the knowledge I learned about the various cultures, but won't be going back.
author: Neil T.

description:
After all these years, I finally visited the Asian Art Museum for the first time. My sister needed to visit an art museum for a class assignment and asked if I could go with her, so we decided to go on Target Sunday, the first Sunday of the month, when it is free to go in.

I was very impressed with their exhibits. The first floor was the special exhibit on the Larry Ellison collection, which included many folding screens and scrolls. I loved that we could walk around at our leisure and read about each masterpiece. The second floor included art from China, Japan, and Korea as well as the special exhibit on the Cyrus Cylinder. Unfortunately, the wait for that particular exhibit was extremely long. About 45 minutes to an hour. We decided to skip that exhibit and view the rest of the museum. The third floor was mostly sculptures of Buddha. 

What I loved was that each display in the museum included a little card that tells the story behind each artwork. Every scroll tells a story and shows a style of art. Each folding screen can tell the story of four different seasons or the story of a war. I loved that I can learn the story that was involved in the artwork which made viewing everything so much more fun and interesting.

I definitely recommend coming here to view the exhibits. It's relatively cheap on regular day, about $12 for an adult. They also open up the museum on Thursday nights for $5. But if you're not sure if art is your thing, try going on the first Sunday of the month. Entry is free and you can see if this holds your interest. The only downside of going on the free Sunday is that there's a lot of people.
author: Andrea G.

description:
Yet another museum visit for me to fall in love with! Came here with my friend on another first Sunday, so it was free, yay! On the first floor, they had an arts and crafts place for visitors - making badges and re-usable bags. So cool... I felt like a little kid again! :)

This is a three story museum filled with beautiful Asian art (paintings, sculptures, pottery, and more). On the day that we went, they had a food presentation about Filipino-American infused food. They were also handing out pork belly samples - yum! It was really cool learning about how much salt is in different foods. It definitely made me more aware of what I should and shouldn't be eating! I really liked the architectural designs of the museum. I would definitely come back!
author: Christine S.

description:
Honestly, unless you're here for a main attraction, the price is not worth it. Most of the galleries are fairly lackluster, and even though there are three floors, each one leaves much to be desired. After going through NY and seeing some fabulous museums, like the Met or the Museum of Natural History, the Asian Art Museum cannot stand up to those at all. The recent bing ma yung (aka Terracotta Warriors), however, are freaking awesome. There were only 7 of them and 2 horses, alongside several other small trinkets, but I love my history, and these guys were impressive. They could have done much better with the translation. Only the titles were in English and Chinese, while the description paragraphs were straight-up English. That's a disservice to all the Chinese people in the area who cannot speak or read the language. Come on, it's SF.

Oh, and don't be fooled into parking in the underground lot. Waste of money, especially because meters on Sunday are 25 cents for an hour, and there are plenty of 2 hour/unlimited spots very close by.
author: Danny C.

description: I spent 4 hours here one Saturday while I was getting my car repaired and it was so much fun. I loved learning about all the different types of Buddhas and especially liked an exhibit on fabric made out of pineapple from the Philippines. The exhibit on the Japanese tea ceremony was super cool and informative. I learned about the legend of Moon Rabbit from that exhibit and can't believe I didn't know about Moon Rabbit before! The only odd thing to me was that Mongolia seemed to be hardly represented. The museum shop is fantastic but I had a slightly underwhelming experience in the cafe. I had tea, veggie spring rolls, and a lunch special of veggie maki. The rolls were flavorful, but very sloppily put together and service was erratic. I think in the future I will just opt for tea. Great museum all-around, though.
author: Mylie T.

description:
Great museum with a good variety of Asian art.  

I'll be going back because I didn't have enough time to spend in every area of the museum I wanted too.

The layout is unique.  They clearly packed in a lot of art into a city block.  There are escalators, stairs or an elevator on the ends of each floor so if you don't know this you can be placed on the opposite side of the floor you wanted to see.  

Parking...not quite sure where the best place to park is.  I went on a sunday and had a homeless guy help us with a spot but otherwise I don't know where to park during weekday business hours.

Everyone working here was very nice and everything was clearly well organized.  Even though it was a weekend, the crowd was manageable and well directed.

The gift shop has fun things to buy and the restaurant, while a bit small, has descent food.
author: Asa R.

description: Target Free Sundays rock!  Since it is Labor Day weekend, I decided to stop by to see Japanese Art and the Cyrus Cylinder that I had been hearing about.  To my luck and surpise, it was free today!  Yay! I Otherwise, I think admission is about $12, which isn't too bad anyway for all that get you get to see at this museum.  The regular exhibits are always enjoyable, but the Japanese art and Cyrus Cylinder and Persian Art were wonderful!  Even though it was almost an hour wait for the Cyrus Cylinder, it was well worth it.  The architecture inside this museum is classically beautiful and worth the price of admission in itself.  Plus, there's a good cafe inside, gift shop and extra activities for kids and things like yoga and painting.  I always enjoy coming to this museum!
author: Maile N.

description:
Museums can be overwhelming .... and there's really only so much history, learning and art you can process at any given visit.  When I visited the Louvre in Paris, my friend had to pack Gu for me so that I could energy up and walk the full 5 miles I did IN the museum.  

The Asian Art Museum on the other hand, isn't overwhelming in that sense - despite the scope and history of what is "Asian".  I thought the instructional write ups and descriptions that accompanied each piece was interesting and narrative.  I stepped away from the experience wanting to read more about the deities of Indian culture, the skills and process involved in shaping jade and get a refresher course on the motifs found throughout Chinese culture that represent blessings, wealth and longevity etc.

Given my own Chinese heritage and countless visits to museums and historic sites throughout China - I was still intrigued and delighted to discover art and traditions that I've never seen or heard of.  This is definitely worth a visit.
author: Kathleen W.

description: My wife and I were drawn to the Asian Art Museum by its Rama Epic exhibit. Since we had lived in South Asia for eight years and I had served in Vietnam, our expectations were quite high. Initially we were a bit put off by the cost of general admission, $10 for senior citizens plus a $5 surcharge for the Rama Epic exhibit.  We were pleasantly pleased by the quality of the displays and accompanying explanations. I recommend this museum for anyone interested in Asian studies.
author: Russ O.

description:
Amazing, amazing anthropologically-oriented art museum, with a huge variety of collections.  The building alone is amazing, both modern and classic with that urban gravitas that the best museums have.  Love the 'staff picks'-- gives you some insight into the people behind the exhibits!

The terra cotta exhibit alone is worth 10 stars... It's informative, gorgeous, and the app they've created for it is absolutely cutting edge.  I've never seen anything like it, and I work in museums!  They go through all about the archaeology behind the collection, telling you the 'life history' of the objects, from deposition to recovery and curation.  You learn tons about Chinese history, tons about these objects specifically, and tons about contemporary science and history.  It's well-designed, and well-lit.  I could have spent hours with them!

Park across the street at the Civic Center underground garage, if you can find it (the entrance is easy to miss from the street).  Spend hours wandering through the endless but well-organized hallways.  It's a totally blissful immersion!
author: Allison M.

description:
I went to the museum on a free Sunday recently and it was a pleasant experience. Not only the admission was free, it was easy to find free street parking too. 
It was a leisure walk of two hours inside, but I only went through things very quickly. It was not too crowded and had good atmosphere. 
They had lots of collections from China, Japan, Korea, and India, with lots of Buddha sculptures, paintings, Jade, porcelains, and other art works. I have been here a few times before, but it is always interesting to visit it once in a while. 
Aside from the art works, they have a big Greek style exhibition hall hidden behind the front desks at the entry. It is a pity that some people might miss it. It is built with whitish granite and is beautiful and impressive.
author: Peter C.

description:
Visited the museum for the first time to see the Rama Epic exhibition. Loved it. 
If you get a chance, take the tour - very informative and well done. There is a general tour at 10:30 and one for the Rama Epic at noon on most days. The tour makes things come to life - otherwise one can get lost in the exhibits.

The museum gives a great glimpse of art in Asia. The highlight for me was to see the story of Buddhism across Asia through beautiful art.The cafe was great too although a bit pricey.
author: S B.

description: Very extensive art exhibit.  Excellent guides and presentation of information. I could spend half a day in here.
author: robert s.

description:
Initial impression of the Asian Art Museum is that it might be A-OK.....if you can get past their Gestapo backpack patrol

I swear, if 1 more person came up to us in our short 2 hours there to argue we had to check our backpacks, I was going to scream.

And we're not talking just a friendly reminder but actual arguments over the fact I had a small pack that the coat check ALLOWED me to take inside the museum.  It fit their size requirements PLUS, they had run out of personal bags in which to place our valuables so they told us just to keep our bags with us

IS THIS SO HARD TO UNDERSTAND?!?!

Apparently yes b/c we were booted out of the Phantoms Of Asia room & not allowed back in; plus another actual argument ensued in the room of Buddhas b/c the guy just couldn't believe we had been to Coat Check.....until we showed him the token from checking our coats

Why in gods name would I want to try to *sneak* something past you as silly as a backpack??  Did you think I was going to go running & swinging it all around the museum or maybe stash a valuable Buddha inside?  WHAT was the big deal?!?!  Especially after I told you we passed all the requirements from Coat Check - WHY did you continue to argue w/ me?!?!

You ruined our entire visit & we paid full price to visit you!  I got a lot of venom stored up from this initial visit - hopefully it'll die down before your Chinese Terracotta Warriors Exhibit b/c I really do want to come back but sheesh, you HAVE to believe the patrons when we tell you we've passed inspection!

Everything zen?  I don't think so....
author: Adrienne G.

description:
Today, just before walking into the museum on a planned excursion, my platform wedge sandal ripped apart. I mean completely ripped apart. Wedge portion separated from upper. Totally unsalvageable. Making matters more difficult is that I had my 5 year old in her stroller aaaaaaand I was now lopsided, in filthy Civic Center with barely anything between my right foot and someone's urine. I wanted to cry. 
I took a deep breath, walked into the museum and presented my membership card. I sheepishly asked if they sold any shoes at the gift shop, the front desk person heard my story, didn't know but clearly felt bad for me. I went into the gift shop and, of course, they don't have any shoes, but they did have several amazing employees. They took my shoe pieces down to their shipping department (because they had packing tape and glue) and, in less than 15 minutes, fixed my shoe with packing tape enough so that I could make it 2 blocks to the closest Walgreen's, buy a pair of furry loafer slippers (rubber soled so my feet were shielded from street filth), and return to the museum to resume our day. I know my messy braid was even messier from the wind, my eyes were probably crazy with desperation and the shoe had seen better days (though not enough to warrant falling apart like that lol). I am so grateful to those women for their kindness. So grateful that my daughter could see such kindness. So sorry that, in my haste, I didn't get their names. I almost left and got right back on BART but their offer to fix my shoe literally fixed my day. I love this museum for the beautiful art it houses but those people who helped me today are the real masterpieces.
author: Jill D.

description: Their after hours event was very unorganized. Considering we are paying customers, there should be some type of structure and management and there was absolutely none.
author: Lo W.

description:
After so many talks about going to the AA Museum, I finally went!!  I went on the first Sunday, so I was granted free admission into this serene place.  I really enjoyed my visit to the museum.  I also really liked the serenity they kept in the museum.  For example, once I entered the museum, I was told, "SHUT OFF your cell phones!!!!"  Like, wow, it really is part of their protocol to keep the museum quiet.

I missed the TerraCotta Warriors, but I've seen them already, so it was okay.  I really did like the organisation of the museum, and the beautiful staircase is as elegant as can be!  I'm so excited to see my cousin get married here in a few weeks.
author: Jana L.

description:
Worshiping our ancestors is an excellent idea, as perhaps you may agree. Imagining the skill, bravery, savvy and just plain luck our 10,000 generations of ancestors, without the benefit of indoor plumbing, needed to ensure our existence today is staggering. That's why, even after viewing a major exhibit such as the Terracotta Warriors, I ride to the 3rd floor, march past the SW Asian collections right to the Shang and Zhou ritual bronze vessels. 

If you have read Ian Morris' Why the West Rules--for Now: The Patterns of History, and What They Reveal About the Future, you may remember his argument that the "Chinese core" around Anyang circa 1200BCE equaled or surpassed the "European core" in social development. The symbolic power of the bronze vessels and bells (they were made in sets of up to 70 bells) give us some sense of the sophistication of those war lords and their artisans which helped them dominate a large area of central China for centuries.

Photo of a team of horses from the Warriors exhibit is on the Museum's photo page in Yelp.
author: William L.

description:
Gae Aulenti's dream.
The old public library.
Chinese snuff bottles!
author: Nish N.

description:
The Samsung hall is a great venue for performing orchestras, community bands or any type of art performance. The decor is beautiful within and is a semi large arena for those watching a performance. My only grievance is the performers should have an elevated stage in which the audience can see them clearly without cranking our necks out. I went to see an ASWAT performance by the community group ZAWAYA. They are known for showcasing Arab culture through song, dance and percussion throughout the Bay Area vicinity. 

After the performance, we wandered through the Chinese, Korean, Japanese and Saudi Arabian exhibits which were phenomenal. There are some great pieces that stem back thousands of years before even biblical times. 

I was very impressed with the venue. The displays were visually appealing and seemed to be displayed in a clean and organic fashion. The museum is two floors with Samsung hall and displays of the Far East. The first floor was the Royal Arabia exhibit which consisted of 4 separate galleries, coat check, gift shop and restrooms. 

The museum is right across from city hall and not too far from the civic center Bart station. Parking was a breeze on this day since Sunday is free. I encourage all to go to this culturally stimulating center.
author: Ramla J.

description: Good collection and location. Students should remember to bring their ID for discounted admission.
author: Vanessa W.

description:
Growing up I wasn't into Asian art.  Maybe its because the California educational system concentrated on the Western World so I knew more about Impressionism than I did about Asian Art.  But now I appreciate and enjoy it more.  

Since the Geisha -  Beyond the Painted Smile exhibit in 2004, I've had a membership with the Asian.  Some of the exhibits that followed have been great (Lords of the Samurai, Bali, Maharaja, Shanghai) while others have not been to my taste (Phantoms of Asia).  But there's always something in the main collection that draws my attention.  The jade room is gorgeous. I love looking at the Korean textiles, the Japanese ukiyo-e (especially one that depicted one of the lanterns at Sensoji that is not currently on view).

And some of their events are fantastic.  Love the Bell Ringing Ceremony just before New Year and the Mochi Pounding right after.  Matcha nights are always fun.  The nieces enjoy this museum because the kids' activities are very well thought out.

The girls also enjoy the Asian because of the Cafe.  The food is pretty good (must be because McCall and Associates manages it and they're one of my favorite caterers).  Its a great place to relax in between galleries.

And we'll be back soon to check out the Terracotta Warriors.
author: J. P.

description:
There are always so many great events happening in San Francisco, it can be so difficult to pick and inevitably your going to miss something big. The Asian Art Museum always has world class exhibitions, guests and events to take part in. But I feel like its often overlooked. 

The permanent collections are amazing and the special exhibitions are always very special. The currant Terracotta Warriors is no exception.  The first glimpse you get is in the lobby area where they have 2 sets of Chariots. 
We took about just over an hour to see it all, that's about as long as my 4 year old could go without being board with it. Time well spent. Weekdays are much better for avoiding the crowds. The place was near empty on a Friday. 

The gift store in the Asian art museum has the best selection of any museum store anywhere I have been. The items for sale are authentic and pertain to the history of the exhibit. Just an amazing selection. They do a very good job of providing relevant high quality goods that are also attainable, not way over priced. 

Heads up =  The backpack rule is sort of a drag. Bring a small bag or be prepared to check it in (free) at the front.
author: Ben M.

description:
#1 thing I knew I HAD to do when I moved up here was to visit the Asian Art Museum to see the Terracotta Warriors.  I kept pushing it back since im scared of the city though. haha!  Well I have plans for the rest of the month and yesterday was the perfect opportunity to stop in and check out the exhibit.  I heard you would be looking down at the warriors if you went to China to see them so it was rather quite exciting to see them face to face up close.  I was expecting maybe more statues but it's a good amount to have with the amount of people going in and out of the room.  They had 3 rooms but I think they should've had the statues as last.  the other 2 were little stuff.  Not quite as exciting as the Terracotta Warriors.  

I ended up checking out all the floors. I love Asian art and the museum has a great amount of it!   There were 2 other floors to check out and everything was so beautiful!  I love the asian paintings and the statues throughout the museum.   There was a Philippine burial urn that caught my eye.  Mainly because it's from the Philippines.  I can't imagine human bones being inside that thing!  Crazy!!  

Try to go on Thursday nights because it's half off!
author: Chrissie O.

description:
This review is for a wedding at the museum. We got married at the Asian Art Museum in Summer 2015.  

Not only is the museum breathtakingly beautiful but it is a historical building and non profit. Our rental fee was not considered a donation--and therefore not tax deductible, but we felt very good that our money would be going to a place that benefits the public. Also it is a place that we can easily take our future kids to see.

We got married in the loggia on the landing of the grand staircase. Our cocktail hour was in the loggia, and we opened up the 2nd floor galleries to our guests. The dinner and reception were held in Samsung Hall (which used to be the card catalog room when it was the library). 

At first we were a little hesitant about having the ceremony on the stairs as it isn't as traditional. However, after speaking with Lorraine and my now husband, we decided it would be best to maximize the beauty of the space and take advantage of the architecture. Also, it would be cheaper as we wouldn't have to rent out the Hall for the entire day to accommodate set up. 

== Staff: 5 stars ==
We worked with Lorraine and Minda. Most of our communication was via email, and they allowed us to visit the museum as much as we needed to in order to help us plan. Both were a joy to work with, knowledgable, organized, laid-back and responsive. 

Lorraine was our first point of contact. She was so helpful and not pushy. When we met her, we were immediately put at ease. She answered all of our questions promptly and had a lot of useful advice about how best to utilize the space. 

Minda worked with us as our wedding got closer and was on site during our wedding and at our rehearsal at the museum. She was there the entire evening to ensure everything went smoothly. 

== Venue: 5 stars == 
- The museum is GORGEOUS. There are so many great places to take photos and as far as decor, we had to do very little as the Beaux Arts architecture is stunning in photos and in person. 
- There is so much history within the building and in Civic Center Plaza. It was once the SF public library until about the mid-1980s, which my husband and I both love. 
- The ceremony can be held in a variety of places in the museum (grand staircase, side halls, Samsung Hall). There is a lot of flexibility with the space.
- The bathrooms are clean and there are multiple stalls. A little weird to be calling this out, but when having a larger wedding, it does make a difference for guests. 

== Rental Details ==
- There is a list of preferred caterers and all of the best caterers in the city are already on that list, so I wouldn't worry too much. We also viewed this as a plus as we wanted to work with vendors familiar with the space to make the day of as easy as possible.
- Weddings start a little later (6:30pm) and the standard latest end time is 12:00am. This worked out perfectly for us as we had a shorter wedding ceremony on site. 
- One thing that was a little surprising (to us at least) is that they are a little stricter on flowers to help protect the artwork. There are guidelines as well as some preferred vendors, so it isn't too much of an issue.  
- Fee includes security staff, use of the Peterson Room, a small garden and a few other rooms that can be used for vendors. Often times, one of the bonus rooms is used for kids, which is immensely helpful.  

If you're looking for an indoor venue that is classic, elegant and can accommodate 120-180 guests, we highly recommend the Asian Art Museum. The venue is beautiful and the staff is very experienced--helping to make a memorable and stress free wedding.
author: K K.

description:
Came here on Sunday for the Terracotta exhibit. What a nightmare!!!

The people working were so nice, but the people who come here are so barbaric and rude...

They should have made lines in the exhibit, it was mass chaos inside.

They should also ban Ipads for cameras.  They block EVERYTHING!!!
author: David W.

description:
The museum's name is a little misleading since the majority of the items are more on the side of artifacts, historical objects rather than artistic exhibition. They do however have many items of ancient Asian art pieces like religious statues, painting scrolls, and sculptures. It is a good place to be introduced to different styles of Asian culture, and you will be able to see a selected insight on the different cultures. 

The sections for each culture are organized in chronological order, so it feels like a history exhibit you can traveling through segments of time. The China/Japan/Korea section is much larger than the other culture sections. 

In general, the exhibitions feel as if the items come from smugglers and private collectors that favor uniqueness over thematic organization. 

It is a good place to bring dates to.
author: Bai H.

description:
What a wonderful place for a date night and for families with young children! They have a short, interactive and informative guided tour just for kids and an activity kit available at the front desk. The art pieces really took me back in time and took my breath away. The setting for the museum was perfect. Coupled with my lucky public parking adjacent to the museum and a free admission Sunday, it really could not have been more perfect.

So why am I giving them only 3 stars?

My FOUR well-behaved children were complimented by several other patrons as well as the tour guide. They were never an issue. My issue was a particular museum security personnel that stalked me to say, verbatim, "This is a classy place. Do not carry your child on your back. Carry him in front instead."

I had my child in a Kinderpack child carrier.

First, I was not told that I could not carry my child upon entrance.
Second, I fail to see how carrying my child in front would make it any more classy.
Third, I was sure that he lacked the tact and training to approach me in a more friendly, professional manner that one would expect from such a "classy" place.

After having been twice harassed by the same man, I paged a supervisor on my way out, reported the incidents, and he clarified that it was indeed a museum policy for both the child's and the art's sake that children, bags, and backpacks are carried only in front to avoid accidental bumping into the art. Now that is a language I can agree with!

So lesson learned: Only go sans kids. Forget the stroller. It too can bump into the priceless art, senseless parents! (I jest...) Forget the carrier. It isn't classy enough for such a place. What a shame that my husband and I are both Asians, and that our visit had to be cut short. I really hope to give better remarks next time.
author: Kaly P. S.

description:
Went to see the Terra Cotta Warriors, and boy was it more crowded than I expected!  Interesting exhibit.

There is a surprising amount of things to see here and I thought the displays were very nicely organized and arranged.
author: Jennifer A.

description:
We went for the History of Yoga exhibit and were gifted with the unexpected exposition of the "Yoga of Dance" experience.  WOW! There are literally no words to describe the beauty, genius, spiritual groundedness, and bodily control of the women who shared this with us. Tears were literally rolling down my face when they did the initial dance to bless the 'stage' and ground themselves before the 'official' presentation began. If they just did that one song and dance for the whole day I would have been fulfilled.  I don't know if they read these things, but if so, I want them to know they are absolute healers and I am soooo deeply thankful for the energy they contribute to the world - and for what they gave to me and my family for only a short time - it matters so deeply.

Check this out: http://www.kathak.org/site/kathak/
author: Sabrina B.

description: I loved this place. I went here with my art history class and it was amazing to see some of the works in our text books right in front of us. The most interesting to me was just the abundant amount of the different interpretations of Buddha each country had.
author: Jackie V.

description: Great museum had huge collection of art, and was very informative. Would definitely recommend.
author: Franklin J.

description:
First Sunday of the month = free admission!

I came here for one of those free admission days. It was raining and pretty much the perfect museum weather. There's always something magical about going to the museum in the rain, y'know? It was PACKED. I guess everyone else had the same idea. The parking lot was a nightmare.

But the exhibits...oh my gosh...the EXHIBITS. 

The Asian Art Museum has stuff from Japan, Vietnam, Korea, China, obvs. They also have Sumerian art, Indian art...going from exhibit to exhibit is like country-hopping and time-traveling at the same time. It's such a trip. Everything is so beautiful, especially the jewelry. I was with friends so I couldn't linger and tarry as long as I might have, if left to my own devices, but I'd definitely be willing to come back here.

Also, they have a lot of really great events. When I was here they had a lot of Chinese New Year stuff going on for the kiddies. There was also a contortionist, who was INCREDIBLY talented and so sweet with the children. I'd never seen a contortionist before and it was amazing...like seeing a gymnast do a magic show!

My only complaint is the food. The restaurant was pretty overpriced and they didn't seem to have any idea what was in their food since it all came from other places. I tried eating some of their bean curd filled pastries since it was the only thing that was labeled and still ended up getting sick from it. Blegh. Stupid food allergy.

*Wheelchair accessible! Hooray!
author: Megan M.

description:
We visited recently for the Gold / Islamic Courts / Maps exhibit.  Previously we went for the Terra Cotta Warriors and before that it was the Samurai Swords, Armor and Apparel exhibits.  Never have we been disappointed.  The individual items' descriptions bring the exhibit together with continuity and clarity. For the last exhibit we downloaded the AAM and although we didn't use it for the entire visit, when we did use it it was convenient and provided more information that was available on the information placards.  I'm also impressed by the art that was available in the app.  Perhaps I should write a review for the app in the Android store.....hmmm....anyway...

We didn't have time to examine the rest of the museum on our most recent trip but on earlier trips we toured most of the building and were impressed by the range of artifacts.  The museum staff / security (?) are very lenient and patient in enforcing policy.  This is the first time I've actually fallen asleep writing a review so I apologize if I've inspired fatigue in you as well, dear reader.  I suppose that if I have a point it's that this place should be visited soon.  Before the artifacts come to life as in the recent series of films with Ben Stiller.  In time everything will be viewable through VR goggles so you can experience it from the comfort of your couch....but I think there's more value in seeing these things on your feet with your own eyes.  Okay that's more than one point but digression is something I'm struggling with. Something with which I'm struggling.  Anyway we had fun.  Go and you'll have fun too.
author: E G.

description: This is a good place to learn Asian art. I go there at least twice every year.
author: Kent G.

description:
The terracotta warriors exhibit going on right now (and through May 27th) is one of the more high-profile special exhibits that the museum has ever had. And it's super cool to see these things in person. Each warrior is really different - you notice one has higher cheekbones and another has eyes more wide apart. Try to take the docent tour, it's pretty interesting! 

The museum itself has a very big and extensive collection of asian things - mostly pottery type things and like religious statues made of stone. It's cool to see the first time but after that you realize there are a lot of pottery type things (pots, vessels) and a lot of statues of Buddha, so it gets slightly repetitive. i thought that the jade room on the third floor was really cool and the gallery on the second floor with the chinese paintings is really nice. the section with korean art and artifacts is small. 

All in all, the museum is a nice way to spend the afternoon!
author: Sylvia K.

description:
I was here recently for the "Maharaja" exhibit and really enjoyed it.

One of the great things about this museum is that it has so many great historical pieces from all over Asia.  One really can spend a good few hours here to admire all the art.  This museum is also perfect for families since they have a lot of activities for children.  The first Sunday of the month is always free and it's definitely a great way to experience this fantastic museum.
author: Ken G.

description:
The joys of being in college sometimes require you to make a little trip to museums. I needed to come here for my Art History class on Non-Western art. Admission can be pricey, but you can get a discount with a student ID. It's also free admission on the first Sunday of every month. For general adult admission it was $15. And I believe for the special exhibits would have been another extra $5. The special exhibit today was about how "Japan influenced western artists like Van Gogh." I was considering if I should have went to this exhibit but decided not to since my art history class was focusing on non-western arts. I thought it would have been a very fascinating exhibit though. 
 
The museum itself was wonderful, the galleries were amazing and I was just in awe of the cultures embodied into these art pieces. 

This museum also has a little gift shop as well as a restaurant/cafe on the first floor. 

My only bad experience was that I was wearing a thick jacket and a backpack so I gave only my jacket to coat check. The girl working at the coat check area gave me a little black circle with a number and she clearly saw that I had a backpack on. As I was taking photos for my assignment on the 2nd floor, the security guard stops me and tells me that backpacks aren't allowed and that I needed to give it to coatcheck. I was a bit angry because no one said I couldn't bring my backpack with me, especially not the girl working at coat check who clearly saw me with my backpack. So I go back downstairs and give my backpack to her to put with my jacket, and she can't find it. Apparently the number she gave me was not the official locker number but a coat hanger number, and she was fumbling around confused at where she put my jacket. I was at a loss for words because my jacket was misplaced and the number she gave me wasn't even the official locker tag. Sigh. In the end I got my jacket and backpack back and I left. I think the people here need to make it clear that backpacks aren't allowed because not EVERYONE knows that. Also coat check department needs to step up their organizing skills.
author: Lisa L.

description:
It took me a lifetime to understand that visiting a museum does not require viewing every piece of art in the building. Now i walk briskly through and find what appeals to me and linger. There are many items to linger over at the asian art museum, i loved the korean collection, the netsuke and samsung hall. 
During this period of lunar new year, the museum is hosting many family friendly activities and free days, like the first and third sundays in february. A perfect activity for a rainy day, wander in, it's free, and enjoy the treasures.
Staff is friendly, welcoming and helpful. Art projects galore for kids and next weekend promises more lunar new year celebrations.
author: Kelly K.

description: I liked this one, it's got the typical art pieces I'm used to seeing and have seen in other museums around the US and Europe. It was a long stroll walking from The Beat museum in Broadway and moving through Market St near Tenderloin. The Tenderloin area is little intimidating and considered the "ghetto" of the area according to a few locals I talked to. But this museum is adjacent to city hall probably the public library and other major city offices. Kinda surprising it borders a shady area. They have pretty much all the major historical pieces of South and Southeast Asia and there's a lot to take in. I got here at about 4:30 and they do have a late hour discount of $7. I zipped through most of the standing exhibits. There are a few special exhibits on the ground floor which are an additional expense. This is a rather large museum in a rather large building. Make sure you go earlier in the day and take some time. There's a lot to take in. Nevertheless, I did the impossible and went through it in 30 minutes. Very, very nice museum and well-regulated.
author: Vikram V.

description: When you get off the plane, you need to walk.... And I'm all for supporting the local arts!  So I went to the Asian Art Museum on the recommendations of a friend and had a lovely Friday afternoon.  The collection of wooden puppet dolls is so different and the room of jade is beautiful!  I was surprised with the new collection of the 1600's maps from the Jesuits and the Chinese - with the Pacific Ocean as the focal point (not the Atlantic).  I appreciate how much from other than China and Japan they had here.  And a big plus is each room has a story board so you know the connection and history - I learned more than any years in school in one afternoon.  If you were local, I'd consider a membership and take it in a bit at a time over the year!
author: Maureen L.

description:
Wow!  I really enjoyed our time at this museum, and highly recommend a visit!

We visited this museum on a Sunday morning, and found a moderate line at the door.  The docents at the counter were slow at checking people in, but friendly.

The collection was amazing.  I've traveled quite a bit in Asia, and visited many museums there.  This Asian art museum is better than most I've been in.  One FANTASTIC element is that not only do they allow photography, they encourage it!  Awesome!

They have a very large collection of budas and netsukes and some very fine sculptures.  

The gift shop and cafe were both top notch as well.  We did eat lunch here, and found the Pork Bul-go-gi to be very nice. They also had good kimchee, and FANTASTIC yellow split pea soup.  My daughter loved the marble soda they sell as well.  Topping it off, they have water and cups in the dining area, no charge.

The only negative thing was the lack of children's guided tour...  The docent for this was ill...  

If you enjoy museums, and like Asian art, this place is a must do.  I will be back.
author: James M.

description:
Nice, quaint, Asian museum located in SF. If you're in town for a limited time, definitely go check out the other big ones first. 

I came here for a private event, the entire first floor was beautifully decorated and the space was used very well for food and socializing. The rest of the museum was open to us, and I was really looking forward to looking around, but there just wasn't that much to see. There's a cute Japanese section that looked great for sitting and quiet meditation. There's also a really long flight of stairs that leads up to a point where you can look outside and see a little bit of the city.

To keep this brief: it's great for a quiet afternoon stroll, just don't expect too much!
author: Christine L.

description:
I know what you are thinking--another update already?!  Well, I made my anticipated return to the Asian Art Museum to view the exhibit:  Maharajah:  The Splendor of India's Royal Court ongoing now through April 8, 2012. Viewing the artwork and the Cartier jewellery were the factors that inspired my return visit to the Asian Art Museum.  I saw a feature on the exhibition in one of the local news programs and was taken by the sight of a royal silver carriage, a gold throne, and a Cartier necklace commissioned by the Maharaja Bhupinder Singh of Patiala in 1928 (and reconstructed/restored in 2002 with some substitute stones according to a postcard I bought). That is the Cartier necklace I really, really want. (Wink, wink.)

Here is a link to the introduction about Maharajah: The Splendor of India's Royal Court:
http://www.asianart.org/maharaja/about.htm

The exhibit showcases India's royal history from the 1700s to the 1940s examines the real and perceived worlds of the maharaja from the early eighteenth century to 1947, when the Indian princes ceded their territories into the modern states of India and Pakistan in conjunction with England's Victoria and Albert Museum. One of the descriptions from the website promoting the V&A catologue:  "Paintings, photographs, textiles and dress, jewelry, jeweled objects, metalwork, and furniture--Indian objects as well as pieces imported to India from the West--are considered within a broader historical context, exploring royal status and identity, court culture and patronage."  

India was a British colony (and considered the jewel of the British crown) until 1947.  Becoming a maharaja or maharani (king or queen, respectively) and high status. Under British rule, the Indian people were encouraged (or forced) to adopt the Western customs of the British. Some of the Indian people willing adopted and adapted to the British ways of living. 

I got admission through the Discover and Go pass.  When I headed to the wing housing the exhibit, I caught sight of the royal silver carriage made for the Maharaja of Bhavnagar by the First Coach Factory in 1915.  Trimmed with the heads of a bulldogs, swans, and other types of animal heads instead of the usual lions, tigers and bears. Oh, it has been sometime that my breath was taken away by the sight of a silver coach, cor!  The exhibit is divided into three galleries.  Here is a link to an online gallery showing highlights from the three galleries and outside the galleries in the wing:  http://www.asianart.org/maharajagallery/maharajagallery.html 

The first gallery covers the early history of India's maharajas.  There is an example of a the throne room of an Indian court with a depiction and a description of what was in the throne room in that era.  I have an affinity for a beautiful white jade teapot and cover decorated with rubies and gold along with turban jewellery made of gold, rubies, emeralds, diamonds, and pearls  from the 1650s to 1700s. 

The second gallery covers India during the British rule and Western European era.  There was a howdah, an elephant throne, which caught my eye when I entered the gallery.  There is a short video showing how a howdah is placed on the elephant and the attendant getting dressed for the procession.  There was also a long scroll depicting a royal procession, which was really interesting to view and see.

The third gallery focuses on the European/Western influence on India.  This one contained the lusted-after Cartier necklace:  "Necklace. Cartier Paris, special order, 1928. Reconstructed with some substitute stones in 2002. Platinum, diamonds, yellow zirconia, white zirconias, topazes, synthetic rubies, smoky quartz, citrine. Created for Sir Bhupindra Singh, Maharaja of Patiala."  And there was a probable wedding costume:  "Poshak (costume for a woman). About 1900. Silk brocade with gold thread, base metal and sequins. Private Collection."  It was a heavy costume to wear; fortunately, the wearer was able to sit down as desired and to alleviate the bearing of the heavy weight while wearing it.

There was a pleasant surprise, a Bernard Boutet de Monel oil on canvas portrait of the Maharaja Yeshwant Rao Holkar II  of Indore in a tuxedo, white tie, white vest, and (probably) tails wearing a black cape lined in white silk (c.1929).
