There were also photographs of Maharaja Yeshwant Rao Holkar II with his wife, Sita Devi taken by Cecil Beaton; that was a real treat for me to see Beaton portraits in this exhibition.  There was also some western furniture on display that belonged to this maharaja, one that stood out in my mind was an art deco style red leather chaise lounge with a built-in ash tray.  

Outside was the aforementioned silver carriage.  Unfortunately, the owner requested that no photographs of any kind be taken. No problem--a postcard is available in the gift shop.

I do hope I can make another visit to this exhibition before it closes on April 8. I think it is definitely worth a revisit.
author: Chiara A.

description:
Maybe I'm not a huge fan of Asian Art, but I didn't find this museum to be all that exciting to walk around. 

There are many other, more awesome museum options in city.
author: Patrick T.

description:
A few friends and I made it out to the Asian Art Museum for free admission on the first Sunday of the month - thanks Target! I had no idea what I was gonna see, but hey it was all free! and I'm super glad I went! 

The Sanjay Patel "Deities, Demons, and Dudes with 'Staches: Indian Avatars" exhibit was up, and omg am I in loveeee! Sanjay Patel was/is an animator for Pixar... he worked on everything from Toy Story to Cars, and his new work (which he took a 2 year leave to work on) is on display on the 2nd floor... and is absolutely amazing!  If you're in the area, I'd definitely recommend coming to the Asian Art Museum to check this out... on display until April 22, 2012.

We came kinda late so we weren't able to go through everything in their galleries (2nd and 3rd floor)... but of the things I saw, I really enjoyed the Chinese textiles and ceramics as well as all the Buddhist works. 

This is easily one of my favorite art museums (though I haven't been to many). Its well maintained and easy to navigate, and overall a good place to go kill a few hours of your day. It's located right next to SF's city hall and public library, so its also a good place to just go and explore. Come the first Sunday of the month for free admission (special exhibits not included) and free parking!
author: Lana N.

description:
Really big and full of art that your great-great-great-great-great-great-great-great-great grandparents probably touched. Much cheaper than a trip to Asia!

In all seriousness, the Asian Art Museum's collection is very impressive. It's 3 stories and the exhibits continue from one room to the next in a loop formation, so you'll be in Korea one minute and China the next, or go from Southeast Asia to Hindu India suddenly. Large sculptures of Buddha, Japanese brush art, Ming dynasty ceramic vases stand out in my mind now, though they all blurred together at the time as I browsed the exhibits. Don't become daunted or exhausted while you make the journey through the seemingly endless museum. It ends. And you'll be much more cultured after it.

Art aficionados will enjoy, and the self-guided tour seems like the way to go if you have a few hours to spare. Otherwise, the brief descriptions are not bad themselves, supplemented by information about each particular art form or historic period.
author: Brandy A.

description: One of the best museums in SF, always something interesting to look at here. The cafe is great with an interesting selection as well as the gift shop.  The exhibits are well planned and displayed with care. Easy access from public transport as well
author: David S.

description:
Proof that the Qin Were Better than You: Terra-cotta warriors, and inventing chrome plating about 2000 years before the west. It's a guy thing.

Amazing, interesting and beautiful both for history nerds like me and aesthetics like Leigh. Cramped & crowded on a Saturday, as expected. Great advice from a local friend: You can find MOMAs in several places. If you only have time for one museum while in SF, do the Asian. It's one of a kind and only in San Francisco.

Go.
author: Dayne C.

description:
~*~Well curated, Free Audio and live tours~*~

First Sunday of the month is free...so...came to check it out.

1st floor:
Featured (temporary) exhibit.  (Korean Art currently)
2nd floor:
East asian art, Art from the pacific rim
3rd Floor:
South Asian Art

Art is so telling of the history of lands, here I got to see the stories of Asia unfold.  Scrolls, paintings, sculptures, even the building itself is historical.  

Paid Street parking available near by.  

Recommend for a lazy afternoon in the city, tourists and locals.
author: Rimi K.

description:
Love it! Housed in the space previously known as the SF Library, this place has been stunningly made over. My fellow yelpers have paid great homage to this place already, so I'll leave you with a few quick tips:

1) Start on the 3rd floor (walk in, turn right, go all the way up). The museum layout follows the path that Buddhism took as it expanded through India and Asia. I've always found this to be extremely clever, and with that perspective, it becomes a much more thoughtful visit.

2) Since it was the old library, don't forget to stop on the 2nd floor and admire all of the engraved quotes and book references in the stairwell. I love that they kept this piece of history alive!

3) If you come on the 1st Sunday of the month for Target Sunday (read: free admission) come EARLY! It gets packed extremely quickly and once it does you won't get to admire the art peacefully.

4) Food is good, but not outstanding. For the price and location, it's a wee bit steep, so either eat beforehand, or grab a bite at one of the neighboring places on Market Street.

Overall, one of the best museums in SF!
author: Shachi B.

description: Asian Art buff.  Certainly have seen better collections but if you are in the area, worth checking out
author: Guy S.

description:
Today went with the girlfriend to go check out the Terracotta Army exhibit. We've been more then eager to go all year and today that finally happen, it's a beautiful tribute to the first emperors legacy. Many of his after life treasures are their including the famous Terracotta Army soldiers. This exhibit did not disappoint, the emperor himself wasn't their for he has yet to be unearthed but many of his soldiers and Generals are their along with a few horses and his zoo did make the exhibit. This is a must see for anyone whom is interested in Asian art/treasure. 

After our visit upon leaving we made our way to the gift shop, to our amazement you are actually able to bring a little piece of the exhibit home with you. They have traditional made Terracotta mini soldiers ready to go home and protect you in sizes from 5 inches all the way to life size. We personally got a handful of 8 inch soldiers and one General at a very affordable price. 

All in all 110% loved the exhibit already made plans to become members so we can visit this beautiful museum in SF. Thanks to all those that made this beautiful exhibit a very memorable one.
author: Alex O.

description:
The collections are well curated.  I especially liked the flower arranging basket with the gnarled wisteria wood handle in the Tea Ceremony room, the sense of humor in the Netsuke collection, the Ink Landscape by Qi Baishi, and the Bojagi wrapping cloths.

Great place to go on a rainy day.
author: Heather E.

description:
This place was just simply amazing. Three floors, tracking Buddhism throughout the centuries. Its broke up in three floors based upon the tracings and findings of Buddhist beliefs throughout time. 

Stop at the desk and grab your own personal tour guide set. Its headphones and an electronic calculator looking thing. Basically a mini, tablet. It plays video for some of the stops and tells the story of each piece you look at. 

Everyone was very welcoming, yet the security was definitely well-known throughout the place. I stopped in the restaurant area and grabbed a Miso soup while charging my phone to take pictures. It was pretty dam good too. I listened to my recorder while waiting and dropped it off before my tour. 

I was told to start on the third floor for the most accurate historical capturing of buddhism and how it spread throughout Asia. Theres so much scripture, jewelry, art, pottery, furniture, weaponry and just basic knowledge of the culture throughout history. 

I am leaving this short because if I elaborate I would have t go on for days and days of the wonders of this museum in a city so rich in Asian culture, heritage and history.
author: Steve L.

description: With their collection specializing in Asian Art, this place can be overwhelming at some point (especially for my camera. The best part in my opinion were the Javanese dolls. They were so awesome, I stared at them for at least fifteen minutes. Stop by here and give at least three hours.
author: Gill S.

description:
As someone who has been living in the Bay Area for several years, I feel so ashamed that I have been to the AAM not once before. And it's not like it's a secret. You see their posters everywhere! Take the time to come out, ESPECIALLY if you can come on the first Sunday of the month for free admission. Then you really don't have a proper excuse.

My friends and I arrived quite late and were quite rushed throughout the whole museum, but I thought the most interesting exhibit was Larry Ellison's stash of Japanese art. Who knew he was such an artsy dude? Other than that, you owe it to yourself to visit the other parts of the museum, even if you only have two hours to spare. Go admire the very old artifacts, read the insightful descriptions, and inspect the beautifully crafted ceiling. Remember, NO TOUCHING!!
author: Jason T.

description:
New Year's Eve was a great day to check out the Asian Art Museum!

This has been on my to-do list and I'm glad I finally made it over here =) This museum is giant and there are so many awesome pieces of art on display. Three stories contain collections from India, Southeast Asia, Japan, China and Korea. Also since it was New Year's Eve they had a special bell ringing ceremony going on which was very interesting to watch. I very much enjoyed my visit here and would definitely come back, especially since they have new special exhibits from time to time. The Korean one they have at the moment is very interesting! 

P.S. The first Sunday of every month is free (which I didn't know until I already paid my admission fee) so you have no excuse not to visit ;)
author: Sam F.

description:
I really love this museum!!! So great! I've been going to the museum fairly regularly for the last 5 years and am finally a member. Everything at this museum is great, the temporary exhibits are very interesting but it is their permanent collection that really blows the mind. I particularly enjoy the jade collection from China, and the early Indian Hindu/Buddhist statues. 

The cafe is amazing as well. I think that the quality at this museum's cafe is better than at the other museums in SF. But, I do prefer Asian food so maybe I'm a little biased. :) But, I do like their menu and how it goes with the current exhibit theme. 
I would love to see a wider variety of teas. 

As for the exhibits, and of course, I am aware of the politics but it would be interesting to see art from less explored areas of Asia: Mongolia, Vietnam, Kazakhstan's textiles, even parts of Russia (after all it takes up a large mass of the so-called Asian continent), of course, even more India. Of course, I imagine getting art from the above mentioned countries might be difficult but it would be an eye-opening experience to have the opportunity to view art/artifacts from those regions. I do find the Edo-era Japan theme a little repetitive. 

But, I love the museum and am looking forward to going again soon.
author: R. L.

description:
Beautiful place showcasing art from many Asian countries. My friends and I went to see the limited time showing of their ancient Yoga of Dance. It was awesome, I've never seen such contrast between the different rooms. There was a sense spiritual balance and peace in these rooms; the whole thing was a moving experience.
A must see in SF, don't get stuck at tourist attractions if you are visiting, go to this museum!
author: Ezra T.

description:
4.5 - 5 star.

THERE IS SO MUCH TO SEE!

If you visit here, it could literally take you up to a full day to walk through the museum thoroughly. If you want to do a quick visit, still allow at least 2 hours (probably 3 - 4 hours would be the most ideal) for yourself.

Admission is between $10 and $20, if I recall correctly - students and youth get discounts. They also have a temporary exhibit that you may pay extra $5 to go see. 

The main permanent exhibit is located on the third and second floors and there are a lot of things to see. You also get a free audio guide when you are about to walk up to the escalator. Coat check is free - with donation accepted.

I think I really like all the exhibits and I wish I could have had more time to walk around, but I enjoyed my visit nonetheless!

You may bring in your camera and take photos - but no flash allowed.
author: Maria G.

description:
Having been to numerous museums in other countries, I just have no idea why I did not come here much earlier.

The art works are displayed beautifully and explained very well. Admiring and learning about them made me feel like I've traveled throughout the Asian places - over a few thousand years. 

I ran out of energy at about 2/3 of the museum, and one afternoon was certainly not enough for me. When I went, they had the audit guide for free. They also had several free guided tours throughout the day (it's posted by the information desk after you enter the museum), which I am going to join on my next visit for sure. 

Will be back!
author: Sakura A.

description:
If you have no plans to visit the National Palace Museum in Taiwan, you will see a teeny tiny glimpse of the treasures of China here.  Hopefully, the Asian art museum will inspire you to seek out more loveliness in future visits here and elsewhere. 

Entering the front doors to the museum you are required to have your bags and purses inspected and then instructed to turn all electronic devices OFF. Proceed to the ticket counter and enter a quiet sanctuary from the din of this bustling area across from City Hall. We were instructed to begin our tour on the third floor where the treasures of India are on display. 

The second floor houses art from China and Japan. I stopped somewhere in the middle of the second floor and read that the porcelains surrounding me were from the collection of Jerry Yang (yahoo) but a patron informed me his collection of Chinese calligraphy was removed but the signage was mistakenly left up.  Ohhhhmmmmm.  Good to know.

Finally, I made my way to the Larry Ellison collection. I enjoyed the lighting play on one of his Japanese screens that dramatically changes its appearance with the lighting rotation. Very interesting! quiet...very interesting...

Be careful walking into this display when it is dark or dim.  There are low lying wooden benches in front of the display and not much room to maneuver around the people standing to watch the light play.

On my next and future visits I plan to stop and purchase the headphones and self  guided tour and/or join one of the tours listed with starting times at the information table set up across from the museum store.  

I would recommend using the Hastings law school garage located on Larkin just north of the museum.  Very secure, friendly staff, clean and lighted.  We left our car here and walked the distance into Hayes Valley to explore and have a bite there.
author: Rebecca B.

description:
I'd never been here before this past Sunday, but this place is immense and marble-ous. (See what I did there?) The museum itself is as Asian as you'd expect it to be, but it seems quite repetitive with Buddha, Buddha, everywhere! Not that it's a bad thing. I just walked around wishing there was more than statues... maybe bring in modern art? ::shrug:: 

Not exactly my cup of tea. (Pun intended.)

I was there for the Filipino American Heritage Month event, representing the American Heart Association at a sodium information booth & cooking demo. So, this review will be in regards to that. 

The woman who organized the whole event did such a great job with all the logistics and scheduling. Everything ran swimmingly, especially the food events at Samsung Hall.

The audio visual team did a fantastic job with keeping all the sights and sounds going. Seriously, flawless victory. This was probably the smoothest flow of demonstrator/speaker transitions I'd ever experienced. No reverb, no mics too close to the speaker, no static, no nothing. It was amazing! 

I was originally supposed to do an intimate cooking demo with around 20 people or so, but the turnout was a lot bigger than they expected. I found myself at the mercy of ~150ish hungry Filipino folks, eager to sample the goods. Imagine their daggered glares when I spent the first 10 minutes of my presentation essentially bashing Filipino food culture in all its high-sodium, high-calorie, saturated fat laden glory. 

::shudder::

At least there was an awesome woman in the combat boots who helped me with my Madonna headset mic (for the demo that suddenly had a giant audience) and made sure I didn't sound like a goober (at least decibel-wise). She was really nice and reassuring - I was so nervous and wanted to vomit the entire time prior, but she helped to quell my anxiety, even in the slightest, even after the near-catastrophe.  

It was a great event at a beautiful venue and I had a blast.
author: Rosavida C.

description:
This is another one of those amazing places in SF...not sure why I have never reviewed them...

Work brought me there as a chaperone...unruly students from another country visiting SF.  We were paired with Mr. Ed Baer (thank you, sir), who gave us a tour/stories that captured everyone's attention...

With 15 minutes left of our tour, Mr. Baer asked our students if they would like another story or to be let out early.  In unison, all the kids chanted "another story"!  Mr. Baer also kindly included a lady visitor who was not in our group...

I know I'll be back for more!!
author: Barb L.

description:
Everyone should visit the Asian Art Museum at least twice. Seeing relics that are older than your WHOLE COUNTRY by CENTURIES is a humbling experience.

Expect to spend at least three to four hours exploring the exhibits, reading the histories, and comparing the progression of art and symbolism through across miles and years. Try to spot the same re-told stories as they moved from place to place and how they changed as they moved. Bring a friend so you can share the experience afterward and discuss what you learned.
author: Daniel G.

description:
Huge place!! Start at the top and work your way down. 3 stories + insane amount of Asian Art = great way to spend a few hours. It's gorgeous and full of interesting pieces. I like that they have a recommended path for you to take and tons of signage explaining the history of not only the art, but the culture. 

Paid parking is right nearby.
author: Rachel S.

description:
So glad I came in! It was a great culmination of my Asian History class I just finished, and a great attraction on my first visit to San Francisco. God, I just love museums. 

I didn't have my student ID card on me, so the admissions guy asks me rapid fire "Where do you go? What's your major? What's your favorite class?" At my reply of "Regis University! Politics! Spanish!" I'm deemed legit enough for the discount. Awesome!

Luckily, we were there the first day of the Gorgeous exhibit. Go. Very epistemological but eclectic. It's all about perception of beauty.  My favorite part was the descriptions beside the art. These curators are so sassy, I found myself giggling at times. They managed to help derps like me understand the meaning behind the work without the pretension and jargon. 

The regular exhibit was so amazing I got kind of overwhelmed. I kept thinking, I know what that is! I wrote a research paper on that! This artifact has monumental significance to Korean society! I crashed some point in the Southeast Asian collection. You definitely need multiple visits to really grasp the immensity of it.
author: Siena R.

description: I went here week ago. A very educating museum. I enjoyed looking at every object and seeing the detail that was put into them. It teaches you people had a lot of time on their hands for crafts back in the day instead of focusing on the media like we do nowadays lol. The tobacco accessories and the weapons were my favorite part. So beautiful!
author: Pam M.

description: Just got back from seeing the 28 Chinese exhibit at the Asian Art Museum in SF. This stuff is as good or better than anything I've seen at SFMOMA in terms of contemporary art over the past decade. I hope future work holds up to this standard. Only drawback to this museum is the layout of the venue can be confusing, and the ambient conditions can take away from the art itself.
author: Brad A.

description: How can you not love this place? I've been a couple of times and love just getting lost while surrounded by beautiful artifacts that I don't really understand but that's the beauty of museums. Will defiantly visit again on their $5 nights!
author: Miko L.

description: Very much enjoyed coming to see the Emperors' Delight exhibit featuring pieces from the National Palace Museum in Taiwan. Originally I hadn't planned to come because I been to the NPM several times in Taiwan. But I was coming to SF for the weekend and decided to get a ticket. I was very grateful that someone from the ticket office called me to say that the museum was offering a special admission price the weekend of the Gay Pride festivities. He  offered to refund my full price admission so I could get a ticket at the discounted price. I appreciate that attention to detail and the exhibit was very worthwhile.
author: Elizabeth B.

description:
I was fortunate to see the Terracotta Warriors while they were displayed here.  It was jammed packed like sardines but it was worth it.

The admission price is standard for museums.  I like that there is discount for students and seniors.  I LOVE that there is free 1st Sundays.
author: Linda Y.

description:
NOTE TO LOCALS: If you have a public library card with Alameda County, Berkeley, or Oakland you should take advantage of the DISCOVER&GO program! Just go to your public library's website and look for the link. My boyfriend and I took advantage and received free entry into the Asian Art Museum. Occasionally they have black out dates, but might as well try! We saved $44 total by using of this offer!

We came the the museum on a Sunday and primarily spent our time at the China's Terracotta Warriors exhibit. There were three individual rooms filled with various artifacts. Some professional photos with close-ups of some of the artifacts were also available on the walls to show all the detail. Pretty amazing. 

Very easy to get to from the Civic Center BART station. We easily walked over to Union Square after our visit. It was a lovely day in San Francisco :)
author: Tiffany N.

description:
Took Mama S here to see the Terracotta Warriors for Mother's Day.  The exhibit was incredible, except so oversold for Mother's Day...they weren't even checking what time your ticket was for (they were barely checking tickets at all), no time limits enforced, etc.  In addition, they flipped the order of the exhibition rooms and had you start with the Terracotta Warriors themselves, which I assume was a plan to get as many people in and out as possible.

So, kind of ridiculous, but understandable based on the special occasion, and the warriors were eerie and beautiful.

But the real star, for us, was the permanent collection (which was exponentially less crowded than the Terracotta Warriors).  You take an escalator to the top of the museum, and then move through and down several rooms/stories, each collection of rooms themed around an Asian region (Persia, Japan, Korea, multiple Chinese periods, India, Southeast, etc).  

The general collection really functions just as much as a historical museum than an art museum, although many of the rooms did contain contemporary pieces from artists of that region.  Absolutely fascinating collection, ranging from Buddha statues to contemporary Korean paintings to jade miniatures to snuff bottles to illuminated Koran copies.  

I really gravitated the most toward the Japanese aesthetic, and in particular some of the contemporary pieces in the contemplation alcove.

A world class, unique, and beautiful museum.  Definitely worth visiting.
author: James S.

description: I was lucky and was visiting the museum on the day that the museum was free. Although it is an Asian museum, most of the art was from Japan, China and Cambodia.
author: Iris G.

description:
I was a little disappointed to learn that the Maharaja exhibit, which in the advertisements featured works from Sanjay Patel, didn't in fact have any of his pieces (print or otherwise, really) included. His work was confined to one room with a small TV replaying a PBS special and various works on the wall. The multiple exhibits included in the Maharaja portion of the tour were OK, but I was expecting to see a better juxtaposition of then and now, fact and fiction, story, etc. 

P.S. Sanjay Patel's creations are exquisite, and i recommend seeing Sita Sings the Blues (movie) and other projects he's worked on if you're into animation.
author: Vittorio L.

description:
TIP: Come on a Thurs. night to see the Terracotta Warriors for a discounted price of $10 (This includes access to the regular exhibits as well). Order online, go to the front desk (don't wait in the line that is out the door of the museum) and pick it up. 

TerraCotta Warriors exhibit: Thurs night at 7pm was CROWDED. There are 3 rooms: Rm 1 had the Terracotta warriors and horses and was the most crowded for obvious reasons. There are only several warriors on display, but it was worth it to see them up close in personal. Rm 2 had bells and other random artifacts. Rm 3 had knives & a few sculptures. Pictures allowed, but you must have the flash off. 

The bookstore had a few Terracotta Warriors items- paper mask, chocolates, puzzles, and replicas. Nice to wander into and look around.

The rest of the museum was alright- lots to see if you're really interested in Asian art as there was a variety of paintings, vases, sculptures, a huge shrine, etc. Luckily the regular exhibits aren't crowded. I personally wasn't that amazed by the regular exhibit and wouldn't pay full price for it. 

How to get here: Take the Muni or Bart- get off at Civic Center. It is right there- super easy to get to. 

Be sure to see the Terracotta Warriors Exhibit soon- it is only here until MAY 27!
author: Emily C.

description:
I loved the Asian Art Museum! There are just way too many things I could say about this place. The staff is wonderful and the exhibits are well thought out in regards to placement and timeline. I really enjoy how they separate the exhibits by country.  

They have the main exhibit which changes every so often and the current one is a Yoga exhibit. I didn't get to go in but I heard it was great. 

I am looking forward to the next time I get to go here and see a new exhibit when it comes to town.
author: Aron H.

description: Take the tour! I didn't catch the tour guide's name, but she was lovely and very captivating. I learned a lot about Buddha and different Hindu deities. Now I can spot a figure of Buddha  and Hindu deities and have a guess at which region/time period it is from! The prices are also affordable! They have discounts as well if you are a student. Also, if you are an AAA member, you get a discount on your second ticket! Good thing my Dad asked if there was an AAA discount; we saved some $$$.
author: Amanda T.

description:
This museum offers free entry first Sunday of each month so their special Lord of Samurai exhibit was only $5. I got there around 11am and was almost discouraged by the long line. I am glad I didn't because the line moved pretty fast. The wait was at most 10-15 minutes.

The first floor Samurai exhibit was pretty crowded but that is expected. The sword, the armor suits, the calligraphy and art works are all amazing. I am surprised at how new everything seems like. The highlight of the day is when we spotted a modern day samurai - a middle age guy having the entrance sticker glued on his forehead, wearing a warrior helmet (imagine black plastic cap with antenna) and a colorful Spongebob cape (skillfully converted from a beach towel). 

I enjoyed their regular Asian art display. It will probably take a good 4-5 hours to go through their entire collection even for the most efficient museum goers. I will be coming back again on a less crowded day or for their nighttime event.
author: Mona W.

description:
OOOOOOOHHHHH MYYYY GOOOOOOD!!!!!
It was THE BEST exhibition that I've ever been to!
When I've heard that Terracota Warriors will be at SF (there is no need to go back to China =D) I went to the museum and brought the whole family. 
It was so worth it!
Wasn't thinking that Chinese Government will let Warriors to leave Chinese border.. but it happened and I'm so lucky that I've seen that!!
Tickets were just 20 ish bucks which isn't biggy.

There is also a video that provides the massiveness of the army - it's something!
The exhibition closes at March 25!
author: Olga B.

description: Oh man this place is cool. Three floors of gorgeous sculptures, paintings, tapestries and architecture. Free the first Sunday of the month but it's only $12 per adult otherwise.
author: Ish V.

description:
First Sunday of any month, the Asian Art Museum has free admission.   The rest of the month, whatever they charge is well worth it.  Where else in the world are you going to see a Ming Vase in perfect lighting right in front of you?    Exhibits are thought provoking, and content wise the material is well laid out and intelligent.  They are not shy about beginning to explain even the most complex of Asian histories.
Best of the best, world class.
author: Tito Y.

description: This place is cool, but there are better collections elsewhere in the city.   Lots of pottery.
author: Michael E.

description:
I'm not a religious person.  In fact, I'm agnostic.  And sometimes, I'm totally against religion.  Mostly, agnostic.  Yes, you can see why I say I'm agnostic.

Nonetheless, I am intrigued by their Buddha/buddhism exhibit.  So much Asian history, and so much geography to cover.  

Their special exhibits change with the season.  They have docents on every level, and in almost every room.  Unfortunately, I do not find them exceptionally friendly nor talkative.

Prices = reasonable.  Figure out the free days and/or discounted rates.    

Sometimes, this place can take at least two visits to cover all the exhibits.

Easily accessible by public transit. And you're near the SF Public Library Main Branch, if you're curious.
author: Fannie S.

description: Blown away by the museum's collection of Tibetan Buddhist art and relics as well as art from China, Korea, Japan, India and Southeast Asia.
author: Joshua A.

description:
A big shout out to my Yelp Elite friend Dorothy C for taking me to this interesting museum

Dorothy is a big fan of museums and was able to get me in for free on her annual pass. She is making me more cultured on my trips to the Bay Area

The Bay Area has a large Asian population and I think the museum does a good job of representing most if not all of them. The exhibits are laid out by culture and by period and the musuem does lead you round in a logical and structured manner

I found the exhibits to be interesting with good information provided about each piece. They had a good range of eras and art styles on display

I was fascinated to find out more of my own Chinese culture as well as surrounding Asian cultures too

Thanks to Dorothy for broadening my knowledge about my own culture!
author: Yee Gan O.

description: Stayed outside to wait for a shuttle. They opened like 45 min after the posted opening time. Wanted to go in but it was $10 entrance fee so I'd rather wait for a free day
author: Lillian N.

description:
A lot better now that Rosalia is gone. 
Rosanna is a really nice person she really cares about the customers. 
Food is always good and changing so that makes us want to go back all the time. 
The exhibits are always good and the tour guides seem to really enjoy being there.
author: Amra O.

description:
I know you'd never guess...but I'm Asian.

Yep...as a three-dollar bill. When I was a little boy in Dallas, freckle-faced hillbilly kids used to say to me - "Hey, squinty eyes...say somethin' Chinese!"...I'd tell them "Fook Yu" and explained it's what you'd say to your mom after she tells you to clean up your room. Yeah, I got beat up a lot in Dallas.

So I have a fondness for this place since it's the museum of my peeps....and my peeps' ancestors. Yeah, they were hella Asian...much more than me. I've been called a banana ...yellow on the outside, white on the inside. But I'm really a lemon ...yellow on the outside, sour on the inside and very zesty when you rub my skin...hard. Is it getting warm in here?

And we all know how cheap Asians are...hella cheap. I can say that because I still wear clothes I bought from the first Bush administration. That's why you could have knocked me over with a rice paddle when I found out the Asian Art Museum has free first Sundays of the month now. Yep, Target is wisely sponsoring the free days since they know their biggest customers are cheap Asians like me.

I came here with Jamie W. and waited in a line full of...you guessed it ...cheap Asians. OK, maybe they're not cheap, just culturally astute. But what the hell ...they're cheap, too. I got to meet and shake hands with the curator and have my photo taken with Bullseye the Target dog (see my avatar). Guess which one gave me the bigger thrill.

As a lot of you know already, there are three floors of Asian art and antiquities...pieces I've been lucky to see in their original locales like Angkor Wat in Cambodia or the Kama Sutra temples in Khajuraho, India. The big attraction on the main floor was "Drama and Desire: Japanese paintings from the Floating World". The exhibit has already left, but it's like the silk painting screens you would see at my mom's house. Except my mom wouldn't have hung up the porno activity painted on some of them. Boy howdy, hot stuff. Very provocative...and kinda wishful thinking from a purely anatomical point of view.

So come the first Sunday next month. It's worth it. My peeps will thank you for it. Find your inner Asian. Maybe you're like the lemon cream rolled cake at Yasukochi's Sweet Stop in J-Town...white on the outside, yellow on the inside. Mmmm...I need to get me some of that soon.
author: Ed U.

description:
Honestly, I'd say that the best part of the Asian Art Museum is the architecture that you view outside. The exhibits are alright--nothing extremely moving to me (this is obviously an subjective statement).

Since I'm in the military, I got in for free, so I can't regret paying any money. But if I did pay, I would feel that it's not worth going here. Currently, there's a Bali exhibit going on. I checked it out and it's definitely not worth an extra $5 that people would have to pay just for that exhibit.

I do have to say that the lighting and most of the layout is nice. However, I think that the way people move through the museum could be improved. It seemed sort of confusing where to go when you're done with one floor and going to the next one.

I've been to Japan and have seen many other Asian Art exhibits around the world so maybe that's why I didn't really have the best time here. At any rate, there are some really interesting things to see here, but I would not say it's worth going to see.
author: Marlon T.

description: A great place to come and learn about Asian art. $15 to get in, unless you are a student or over 65. Memberships available.
author: Ralph R.

description:
Had this on my list of places to go to in San Francisco and finally went.  on Target Store free admission day in February 2014.

Enjoyed seeing the different displays and I really liked it that they did the lay out by country  It let  you see the similarities and differences between geographic regions.

Nice selection of art pieces.

Spent two hours and could have stayed longer.....
author: Samantha K.

description:
I came here with my fiance on our vacation, and it was a breathtaking, if not overwhelming, experience. I've never been in such a big museum before, and there was a lot to take in. We ended up spending at least 2 hours in there.

Big Points
1. They give student discounts to you, even if you aren't a student in SF. Plus, $5 after 5pm on Thursdays, AND your tickets come with a coupon for Buy 1 Get 1 Free ticket at your next visit. 
2. Coat check. Yes! All museums need this. 
3. Amazing selection of art. However, being half-Vietnamese myself, I looked for art from Vietnam and couldn't find any, even in the sections that claimed to focus on Vietnam, Thailand, the Philippines, etc. There was definitely a greater focus on Japan, Korea, and China. That was a little disappointing.
4. Beautiful architecture. The building itself is a work of art.
5. Free guided tours all day! I didn't take one, but I ran into the group that was going around at about 3 pm. The tour guide was a sweet older Asian woman, and she was super enthusiastic about the art. I hope all of their guides are like this!
6. Cafe Asia downstairs. Guava lemonade. 'Nuff said.

This was a really relaxing way to spend the day, and I hope to come back to SF and this museum again soon!
author: Jaimie C.

description:
Love the free library passes good for 2 adults and as many as 4 kids.

I really love the architecture of the museum.  The old main library was one of my favorite places and so the staircase and the Samsung room where the main catalog used to be are my favorite places.
author: Regi K.

description: I always see the advertisements for the exhibitions at this museum, and they are enticing. I hadn't been to this museum ever despite living in San Francisco for a while, but today I finally went. I am not that into antique Asian art, so it was okay. My father was always into Asian art and always had books or pieces of Asian art around the house, so it reminds me of that. The terracotta warriors exhibit was not as amazing as I hoped it would be. It was really small and not that interesting. There's two floors of art that are separated by country or region. On the second floor is art from China, Japan, and Korea, and on the third floor is everything else. The museum store is small and has some books and merchandise relating to the terracotta warriors exhibit. The building is big and suits the Civic Center area of SF. I think it used to be for the main library. This museum is free of admission to the public on the first Sunday of the month.
author: Denise C.

description:
People walking into this museum and expecting Western styles of art will be disappointed. I suspect that's where a lot of the negative reviews come from. 

The Asian Art Museum is not the place to go to find bizarre abstract sculptures, ornate religious mosaics or paintings of identifiable Western eras. If you want "exciting", go to the de Young. If you want "crazy", go to SFMOMA. If you want a warm, welcoming community of Asians passionate about their history, heritage and culture, go to the Asian Art Museum.

So many nationalities are represented here, though there's a bit more emphasis on the major East Asian cultures. I'd recommend checking out the "basket" section of Japanese art (beautiful designs), the rod puppets and the dagger collection. The current exhibit of Chinese calligraphy is also gorgeous to behold, even if you can't read a Chinese character to save your life. I personally think the book section of the gift shop is fantastic, containing relatively rare cookbooks and textbooks that you definitely won't find on Amazon. If you're looking to learn about the tea culture of Kashmir or the mythology behind famous Chinese dishes, this is your resource.

TIP: In my opinion, the best part of the Asian Art Museum isn't its art. It's the events, which are run by a wonderful community of friendly volunteers who are passionate about Asian cultures. Take a look at the calendar of events on the website. If you like what you see, seriously consider buying an Active-level membership. It's good for 1 year from the date of purchase and costs $75--for 2 people. Yes, that's only $37.50 per person. Most AAM events are free with general admission ($12 for adults). That means you only need to visit the museum 3-4 times in the next year to make your membership worth it. You can also bring in one guest for free on regular days and an unlimited number of guests on special "member" days. So if you like what you see on the calendar, grab a friend, significant other or family member, and buy an Active membership pass. It'll be worth it. I just used mine recently to attend a Chinese gongfu tea ceremony with my friend. Not only was everything free for the both of us, but the ceremony took place in a gorgeously decorated room, there were Chinese sweets to accompany the delicious white oolong tea they brewed for us, the entire event was run by the nicest old Chinese ladies, and we each received a beautiful brocaded pouch at the end containing a glossy porcelain Chinese teacup. 

Not bad for the price of...FREE. :)
author: Josephine L.

description: Visited the museum during the last weekend of the Terracota showings and it was incredibly crowded.  You really could not move and it was packed.  But it was still worth it to see the exhibit and learn about the history.  The rest of the museum wasn't crowded at all and I really enjoyed seeing all of the displays.  Everything is nicely organized and arranged in the various rooms.  You could definitely spend a few hours here and not be bored.
author: Jenn W.

description: I love the Asian Art Museum! I first discovered it when they had a special display of the Asian warriors. It was phenomenal! Lots of great things to see here. They give you an audio guide and you can go through at your own pace and see the things you want to see while at the same time, hearing about them through your audio guide. The cafe is amazing and has excellent rice bowls. If you happen to work close by, you can buy a special ticket to just have lunch here. That's an awesome deal! I highly recommend this museum!
author: Sandra P.

description:
Very awesome.  This museum's building structure and even the surrounding buildings are so beautiful!  I just enjoy walking around this area and to City Hall along the grassy walkway.  

The art itself is great.  There's different areas for Southeast Asia and East Asian art exhibits.  I was sad to find out that all the exhibits on the first floor were closed.  The focus on the exhibits was mostly China, Korea & Japan.  There are some others (Indonesia, Pakistan, etc.) but not nearly as extensive.

If you're a college student (or a graduated one like myself), bring your ID card and it's only $7!  There's also a restaurant, Cafe Asia, on the first floor but it looks expensive and there aren't any Asians inside.

Metered parking is available outside but with a maximum time limit of one hour.  Luckily, you can get a hand stamp for re-entry, within the same day of course.
author: Shannon L.

description: Called to find out the hours and the lady who answered claimed I had the wrong number and then hung up on me. (I got the number from their website...) I proceeded to call three more times with no answer. Checked on yelp, same number.
author: Amber L.

description: Always a pleasure to visit the rich Asian exhibit. So much history & stories to unfold.
author: Jays D.

description:
Take the tour and see the Terra Cotta Warriors. Great museum and parking at civic center was good.

Gift shop was pretty nicely stocked with a variety of neat art and gifts.
author: Troy M.

description: A nice selection of great art. Beautiful building. This museum covers all of asia from every period and isn't that large so coverage is brief. But some of the work is stunning.
author: Will D.

description:
I am at peace.

Walking through the timeless art of this place is pure meditation. Works from the whole of Asia, recent pieces aged only a handful of years to intriguining forms from many past millenia where the only document to history was art itself.

Ceremonial, functional, purely esthetic. This museum has it all. Traditional tea ceremony, statues of worship, pots and weapons, beautiful paintings. The collections almost erratic but always pulled together by the common theme of ancestry. 

This bastion of deeply historic Asian culture should not be missed. History through the eyes of art is a view that can be seen in no other way.
author: Justin N.

description:
They were running a $5 admission special during Pride, and the thought of ducking into air conditioning with clean bathrooms escaping the sweltering crowds and portable outhouses was all too tempting. Art or no art.

So yeah, we came for the comfort, stayed for the galleries filled with pretty things, most especially the temporary exhibit on Balinese funerals. 

When we walked in, they politely asked us to utilize their complimentary coat check for our bags and directed us on which galleries we were allowed to take photos in and which we were not. 

The museum is loaded with pieces of Asian historical items (Buddha and Bodhisattva statues, jade sculptures, wood carvings, samurai armor, all the bowls, jars, and baskets you could ever want to see, etc) as well as more modern, pop art interpretations of the previously mentioned. 

The building has a gorgeous interior architecturally, even.
author: Christine A.

description:
After more than 10 years, I got to revisit this place as an adult. It was a thoroughly enjoyable experience.

The exhibit they were putting on was on classic Japanese art; its role in daily life, and the different ways in which it was used over centuries. Fascinating marveling in the age of the painted scrolls and panel paintings.

This place is clean, well organized, and a great place to learn about culture through the lens of art.

My only point of sadness is seeing how small the South East Asia gallery was; multiple different, distinct cultures, smashed together into a catch-all category.
author: David D.

description: Terrific museum, with its focus on Asian art.  Recently went to the Emperor's Treasures special exhibit and it was fantastic.  Also previously visited for other special exhibits, and they are very well done each time.  Their permanent exhibits are great, and I like how they divide up the sections into China, Japan, India, Korea, etc.  The building itself is beautiful as well.  Several decent options for parking in nearby garages.
author: Leo C.

description:
The  Terracotta Warriors - The exhibitiion was poorly planned. Small spaces and too much going on in the spaces. Videos playing in the same space as the warriorrs were very distractng.
We wanted to eat in tn the cafe, There is a menu at the entrance, but the food choice is not viisible until you are at the foof area. Some people are not able to decide quickly and have questions and so the llne grows. I  saw no provision foir those of us who cannot carry trays.
They tried their best, hen
author: Margit C.

description:
The museum itself is  gorgeous . There are several floors and the escalator is encased in a glass atrium .  There are areas that get a great deal of natural light and other areas that do not have natural light but are  perfectly designed for display of objects that cannot receive natural light.

The exhibits are displayed beautifully.  And, the collection is vast. You can easily spend an enjoyable day or several days at the museum depending on your level of interest.

Visiting the museum was a highlight of our trip to SF and I cannot recommend it too highly. It is an absolute must see.
author: Elyn Z.

description: This place never stops amazing me.  I wish the Korean exhibit was more expansive but the pieces here are beautiful. We are so lucky to have access to the culture this museum offers.
author: Christy M.

description: Absolutely exquisite! I arrived on a Thursday morning, somewhat nervous after seeing the school buses outside. The advice I got was to pick up a free audio device for the permanent collection and start from the 3rd floor. The whispered tip was that the students would clear out about noon. I spent over an hour on a free guided tour of the special exhibits then revisited the pieces with additional appreciation. Then I picked up the audio device and made the spiral from the 3rd floor where I practically had the whole place to myself. I really liked the storytelling that accompanied the various regions. I can say that I had a great time but am not sure young children would appreciate it on their own, probably best with a docent.
author: Siu L.

description:
I visited the Asian Art Museum for the "Shanghai" exhibit on display now through September 5th, 2010 recenty.  Shanghai is such a classy city, and probaby the most classy one in China, way ahead of its time by Chinese standards. 

The exhibit is set up in 4 sections: Beginnings, High Times, Revolution, and Shanghai Today.  

"Beginnings" is a great exhibit depicting the art of Shanghai's rise to becoming an international port city of Asia with the many influences of European traders and governments.  From the Beginnings and into the "High Times" exhibit, comes the classic Shanghai ideal that many of us know Shanghai to be.  

What I loved about the "High Times" exhibit is its display of how Shanghainese women were the front-runners of fashion on China.  There is a wonderful display of 4 traditional gowns.

It was here in Shanghai that the traditional Chinese gowns (Qi Pao in Mandarin and Cheong Sam in Cantonese) first were established among the upper class Shanghainese woman.  These traditional dresses eventually became the norm for all Chinese women throughout the country.  
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/s3kwbvB8qAzZUtV0rSlypg?select=4dpRlABQTcVSVPrZ29iLLw

Most of the Art in the "Revolution" exhibit were propaganda related from WWII to the Cultural revolution, which included many posters rather than art paintings, but it was interesting to see just how full of artistry the propaganda posters were in trying to portray their messages of the time.  

"Shanghai Today" displayed much of the art pieces of Shanghai rising to reclaiming its role as an international trade player.  

Of the various exhibits, High Times was my favorite as it was during these times that the Classical Shanghainese culture really started to shine--from clothing, architecture, music etc.  

My only suggestion for this Shanghai Exhibit would be to play some traditional Chinese--Shanghainese music throughout to really add to the overall feel of putting folks into the scene of how Shanghai life was.  I love museums, but I don't like pitch silence.  

Shanghai is probably one of my favorite Cities in China, as it is such a beautiful metropolis yet still it maintains its traditional roots. 

Definitely visit.
author: Cass J.

description:
Not impressed for $17. The Getty is way bigger and it's free. The venue is very well maintained, beautiful, and clean, as a museum should be, but as far as exhibits go, it's just not that interesting. Maybe I'm just being picky, after being to museum in China and Japan, the exhibits here just doesn't appear as impressive, kind of a seen-this-done-that feel. The modern Buddhism exhibit was the most interesting to me because it merges Buddhism imagery with modern art, not typical of traditional Asian art. 

For an Asian museum in the US, it does have a wealth of artifacts (kind of makes you wonder why all these things are not in their country of origin...), and for those who are interested in Asian culture but haven't the chance to visit the actual countries, this place would be a good preview.
author: Claudia Z.

description:
I love how the 1st Sunday of every month is *free* admission! 

I came here last year for the Shanghai exhibit and I came again today just to explore the other exhibits some more (didn't feel like seeing the Bali one). While part of me enjoys looking at old artifacts, I really liked the modern art exhibit within the Korean section. After seeing all these stone statues of Buddha, it was cool to see him constructed out of reeds that are usually used in basket weaving. 

And thank you to Target for providing all patrons with a free tote bag and Kristi Yamaguchi's new children's book, "Dream Big Little Pig!" She was at the museum today to give a free reading of the book and to sign them. I didn't even know she would be here today so that was a surprise. My friends and I were in a rush to explore other parts of the city, so we only listened to her reading then left. 

Even though the Tenderloin District is considered "sketchy," this museum and City Hall are worth a visit.
author: Bonnie Z.

description: I love a great museum this one is only so so for the collection but I love the building.
author: Mark B.

description:
first sundays of the month are freeee. hoooray!! but please donate. its so hard to keep museums open these days. 

Love the exhibits, museums in general are such wonderful places to vist. its amazing how much of these peices get collected and shipped around the world just so we can come look at them. there is always so much history to be learned and beautiful things to see. I was here a week ago for the Maharaja exhibit and that cartier gem is gorgeous and the story behind is it pretty amazing. its still cartiers largest gem.

beautiful museum, the bf took me here on our first date a few years ago so I could be a little biased, but I love learning and museums are one of the best places to go!
author: Serena L.

description:
The number of high ratings for this struggling museum baffles me. Until the terra cotta warriors exhibit, I hadn't considered going back to, much less reviewing, San Francisco's Asian Art museum. 

In any case, this special exhibit is quite rare. Having worked and traveled in China, the warriors were one of my two unchecked boxes, the other being pandas of Chengdu, also a national treasure. Go see this exhibit. For only $10, it's a deal. Stay and browse the rest of the museum.
author: Mike H.

description:
Thanks to the free admission first Sunday of the month (yay Target) I stopped by last weekend with 5 others. 

We started at the top floor and worked our way down to first. All this time I had never been to this museum so i took my time visiting and reading about practically everything that was displayed. I particularly enjoyed seeing the Japanese armor as well as the display of black Korean hats made horsehair. I've seen the old K drama shows when the distinguished men had adorn themselves with these hats so it was interesting to see the real ones up close and personal. 

For a free admissions day I was surprised that the museum wasnt packed. Its well worth a visit even if you had paid the full day's admission.
author: Esther A.

description: One of my favorite museums to visit with very well-thought, interesting collections! It's also very clean inside.
author: S L.

description:
The Bali exhibit was pretty cool.  They appeal to your senses and put on videos, used darker lighting to highlight to exhibits, and had not just artifacts but an actual gazebo and other life-size exhibits to see.  The exhibit was spread throughout 4 rooms.  There was a lot of Hindi influence I didn't know about.  The exhibit encompassed religion, dance, rituals, tools, weapons, puppetry, transportation, art, pottery, clothing, Dutch influence, etc. so you get to see a general picture of the life in Bali throughout history.  

The rest of the museum is a bit cramped and the layout is as if you're in someone's house.  The ceilings are not high and some of the pieces do not have enough space in the Chinese, Indian, SE Asia galleries.  But the Korean gallery was lighted well and spacious so I was happy.
author: Chris L.

description: This is my favorite asian art museum of all in California! It has a lot of artifacts and exhibits to see and learn. I will keep going to this museum to explore and experience whenever possible.
author: Gqzhi H.

description:
Free the first Sunday of the month. The collection of art work and historial portrayal of Asian history is amazing. Sand stones and weaponary of the past is one of my favorite view into history. It's spacious enough to walk around without running to people. 

Currently their special exhibits is on Bali. For me I was there for the FREE and spending enough time in Bali was more than enough to pass on viewing it; I lived it.
author: Uland W.

description: The pieces in the museum are fascinating, and I like how it was organized. Getting a glimpse of other asian cultures inspired me to read more on it. Also, the lighting was great.
author: Dee B.

description:
I have lived in the San Francisco area nearly 34 years now but, much to my dismay, I only visited this stellar museum a few months ago when a friend informed me about the Bali exhibit.  What an amazing day I had at this jewel  San Francisco possesses with treasures that reflect so many of our city's ethnicities. Every floor is filled with priceless treasures and you are not prohibited from taking non-flash pictures.  The lighting is so excellent, I was able to take numerous photographs, with existing light, that I am using in my blog.

I have been so fortunate to travel over much of the world so I was delighted to recognize many exhibits from countries I've visited.  There was even a wonderful Balinese dancer the day I was there!  I was most impressed with the huge number of Buddhas on display.  Equally fascinating, to me, were the exquisite perfume bottles!  

Much to my surprise, the Asian Art Museum even houses an excellent restaurant with a good selection of Asian foods at a reasonable price so you can plan to spend the whole day there taking in the sites, with a very good lunch on site for a nomial price.
author: Carmen H.

description:
I went for a special event so I didn't get to see much, but what I did see was impressive. And what I saw were the Terra Cotta warriors.

Such marvelous artisanship is on display and the historical descriptions provide some interesting insight into the thinking of the emperor that commissioned the thousands of pieces. 

The museum itself is quite attractive and we had a nice private dinner inside, but I'd like to return in the future to see other parts of the museum.
author: Clayton A.

description:
Vast collection of Asian arts....

Prob the best museum for Asian arts I've seen so far.  This museum's claim to fame is its permanent collection of about 18,000 works of art and artifacts from Asian countries and traditions.  They also have rotating exhibitions and when we were there it was the Maharaja- The splendor of India's Royal Carts.  I really enjoyed this exhibit and recommend paying the extra 5 bucks to see this. 

The museum consists of 3 floors that showcase arts from Southeast Asia,  South Asia, China Korea, Japan, the Himalayas and Tibetan Buddhist world, and the Persian world/west Asia.  I wouldn't say this is a huge museum that would take you a day to get through, unless you are that person that stops at EVERY piece of art to analyze it.  I'm more of a walk through, stop at some things that interest me and move on.  We thought we'd finish this in 1-1.5 hours but found that wasn't enough.  I'd say anywhere between 2-3 hours would've been perfect to walk leisurely around.  

General admission:  12 bucks
Senior citizens over 65:  8 bucks
Student discount with ID and youths:  7 bucks  
Military and children under 12 are  free.

TIP:    1st Sunday of the month for Target Sunday is free!   Come early though, my friend said it gets packed. 

* photography without flash is allowed.  However, photography was prohibited in the Maharaja exhibit.  Boooooo.  There were some good photo ops I wanted...
* free audio tour.  I recommend...
* free coat check with donation- they even let us store our luggage here since we were on our way to the airport after
* activity room for kids
* cafe and gift shop

FYI:  They also hold weddings here.  The entrance staircase to the reception room is very grand and gorgeous.  The room itself is very nice as well.
author: Bernadette M.

description:
I rated this place so low just because I have not yet developed my taste for fine art. 

The museum itself is amazing and well kept. Each exhibit is fascinating in it's own respect but I wish that the descriptions were more appealing to me. Most of the rooms are very dim which is probably to preserve the artifacts, but I felt that I could have used a little more light in some places. The theater is great! It has an adequate amount of space for a lot of visitors to watch whatever feature the museum is presenting. I will make my way back to the Asian Art Museum again some day. 

B
author: Alex T.

description:
The Asian Art Museum hosts its MATCHA events every other month on a Thursday evening - the Museum admission is reduced to $10 and it includes the special exhibit as well as special performances and activities.  I got to check out the amazing Shanghai exhibit, which featured a mix of old and contemporary paintings, drawings, and woodcut prints.  The Asian Art Museum comprehensively highlights various cultural works of Asian countries - from East Asia, South East, and the South.  The building itself is a beautiful piece of Beaux Art architecture.

In honor of the current Shanghai exhibit (which ends on September 5, 2010), that evening's MATCHA event featured a special performance by Coco Zhao , a Shanghai based jazz singer who breathes a contemporary jazz life to traditional Chinese songs, as well as performs his own pieces.  The concert was situated a top the grand staircase of the museum entrance and was filled to max capacity with a diverse crowd in true SF style.
author: Pauline L.

description: This is a true treasure in the heart of the city.  Even if you know nothing about Asian history or culture, go.  The sweep is amazing.  Every item is worthy.  The building is great, too.  Haven't tried the museum cafe yet... a reason to go back.
author: Bob K.

description:
We are so blessed to have our wedding at the most beautiful wedding venue in SF! BEFORE we even booked the museum, Minda, their events coordinator, provided exceptional service. She quickly responded to my thousands of questions and provided us with countless tours of the venue to help us finalize our decision. She also helped us select wedding vendors that have experience working in the museum. Without a doubt, Minda contributed to the success of our wedding and keeping me sane during the crazy wedding planning months. 

As for the venue itself, the museum is a gorgeous space and also a very unique venue compared to other Bay Area locales. We had the cocktail hour at the loggia where the staircase and intricately designed ceiling make it quite a spectacular space to drink it up with your guests. Also our guests were able to enjoy the museum galleries. The dinner was served in Samsung Hall, where the tall ceilings and beautiful windows make the space feel incredibly grand. 

This venue does come with a hefty price tag, but if you have been doing research with SF venues, their rental fee is actually competitively priced as compared to Flood Mansion and Bentley Reserve. Also you can think of the rental fee as a sizable donation to support the arts and culture of San Francisco. 

The museum contains priceless artwork so there are a lot rules vendors need to deal with. An experienced wedding coordinator handled all those vendor rules for us, and we weren't stressed about it at all during the wedding day. We LOVE LOVE the museum and we are so happy that we could have our wedding in one of the most beautiful museums in SF (or even the country)!
author: Sara A.

description:
Go to your local library to get a free pass worth $20 for an adult/family admission! www.discover.ssf.net (or something like that).

Parking - Right across the street at a municipal parking lot $3.50/hr
Go on a weekday to avoid the influx of crowds.

The Terra Cotta solder exhibit is small (7 soldiers) with three viewing dark rooms.
author: Jboogie L.

description: This museum is so beautiful, rich, understated and serene - it is worth a special trip to the Civil Center just to marvel at the collection. If you want to feel still and small - in a good way - visit this space.
author: Morris R.

description:
I confess that I wasn't always interested in Asian history. I suppose what you are is what interests you least, so you go off seeking other worlds to explore. 

Lately, I've been enamored by the Asian Art Museum. Since their Shanghai exhibit, I've found more excuses to come to this serene and beautiful museum. I love how the different cultures are clearly separated, so, when walking through, you feel as if you're traveling through the continents and hurtling through time. 

If I learned anything from the Terminator films, traveling through time is the only way to get stuff done.
author: Keane L.

description:
I had a really good time at the Asian Art Museum for the Shanhai exhibit.  For an adult its 12.00 for General Admission than 5.00 extra bucks for the Shanghai for 17.00 but there is a free audio tour so that's cool. 

There are 4 to 5 rooms full of all types of different art from Shanghai going through their history and how they were influenced by other cultures.  Its hard to imagine China being influenced by other cultures because they seem to always distance themselves from the rest of the world. 

I particularly enjoyed the light installations.  After the 45 minute to 1 hour audio tour I was pretty pooped from the immense knowledge of the place.  Oh also no photography! 

I wanted to see the rest of the museum since I was already there and already paid but we pretty much breezed through it.  The art pieces were divided by country so it was cool to go to the South East Asia section because I am Thai.  Their were a lot of sculptures and a lot of the art had such a big religious influence. 

Even tho it was a Saturday afternoon the museum was not crowded and it was easy to walk around and read whatever placard I wanted. 

Their was plenty of parking since its right across from City Hall and this area is pretty much deserted over the weekend probably.  I parked in the lot though because the street parking was metered and who has that much change?? It was the same price pretty much in the garage so we went there. 

What I really loved was the HUGE statue across from City Hall and Asian Art Museum which is called 3 heads, 6 arms.  Its actually by a Chinese man and it is borrowed and will be here in SF until 2011.  Go take your picture next to it!  Its so amazing to look at!
author: Anya R.

description:
I recently had the pleasure of second shooting a wedding where the reception took place at the Asian Art Museum. It's certainly one of the most elegant venues I've had the opportunity to shoot at. If you are considering the Asian Art Museum for your wedding reception or special event, I don't think you can go wrong. The lighting is fabulous, the ambiance is exquisite.

Beautiful.
author: Nancy D.

description:
Travel to Asia is ridiculously cheap right now, but I can't afford to take time off. 

The next best thing?  a visit to the Asian Art Museum.

37,000 square feet of space houses over 6,000 years of Asian history. You will need 2 hours to browse through different galleries which includes collections of world class sculptures, paintings, ceramics, bronzes and jade.  

I came here for the special exhibit which had its last run over the weekend.  The Lords of Samurai exhibit was an apt introduction to the samurai way of life which I know nothing about, except from what I've seen on Tom Cruise's movie, The Last Samurai.  Although Hollywood tried its best to portray Japanese history at that time, it barely scratched the surface.  With this exhibit,  I was reminded of virtues that make a true samurai: honesty, self-control, self-sacrifice and loyalty to name a few.  It mainly focuses on the Hosokawa family's impact on Japan's history with their family lineage that dates back 700 years.  I wasn't able to take photos in the exhibit but I was able to see ornately designed samurai attire, intricate drawings on silk screens, beautiful tapestry and priceless ceramics.  There was also an education center where you can experience living as a "daimyo" for a day, practicing tea ceremony, trying on a warrior helmet and they also played Japanese short films.

An interesting fact I learned was the subtlety of courtship.  Japanese courtiers would make games out of guessing fragrances and write poems with references to a lover's incense scented kimono. 

Ahh....the thrill of the chase. 

What happened?  now, it's "I'm horny.  my place or yours?"

But I digress.

Asian Art museum succeeds at being an institution which not only showcases Asian art, but preserves its history as well. 

Come and visit.  I'm sure you'll learn something new. Just don't go bumping into those priceless Ming vases, you can't find a replacement on ebay for that.
author: Janice C.

description:
Got your college student ID handy? Use it! $7!!! Totally worth it! 

 really enjoyed the 3rd floor South/South East exhibit of religious statues. (Thai pride there...). I felt like I was wandering through an extraction of various temple ruins -- lots of buddhist/hindu/etc. statues that are really cool. Lots of information and story boards posted about all the different types of South/South East religions: Very interesting and inspiring to me -- to the point that I feel very inspired all of a sudden to take a trip to India in the next few years!

2nd Floor is composed of East Asian exhibits (China, Japan, Korea) with a variety of interesting pieces: paintings, sculptures, ceramics, and much more. Most stunning to me? The Korean "Egg Woman" painting which portrays the story of a woman through all the phases of her life. Poignant.

Anywho, if you've got time to spare in the Civic Center area and feel like culturing yourself, definitely check out this museum!
author: Gail N.

description:
If youre into asian art, textiles, religious artifacts, pottery, then heck, this is the place to go and wander.  one of my favorite sections is the ancient buddhist artifacts and sculptures.  they have a pretty good collection considering this is the US.  I'd venture to say they have a nicer collection than the Met even.  

currently, there's a special exhibition of Indian art and japanese bamboo works.  the bamboo art/sculptures were amazin!.  it's quite incredible how a flower basket can be such a beautiful sculpture with the various weaving methods and right artistic touch.

i would agree with one of the other reviewers that it would be nice to see some permanent contemporary exhibits.
author: Kris H.

description:
What a wonderful museum!  Their collection of ancient Indian artwork/sculptures is extremely impressive.  They always have fascinating special exhibits as well - everything from Chinese calligraphy to Javan textiles (Batik) to the Terracotta warriors.

The museum itself is gorgeous as well, and it's a great place to take visiting friends/relatives who have already seen/done all the touristy SF sights.  We ended up getting a membership which we haven't used nearly as often as we would have liked - regardless, we're happy to support this wonderful museum!

Btw, it goes without saying, but if you're not into Asian Art, this isn't the museum for you!
author: Gowri R.

description: This museum has wide collection of Asian art. I was here on their 50th Anniversary. They have so many kids activities. Kids would definitely enjoy. I would definitely recommend at least during this time.
author: Chiloo C.

description:
I'm not exactly a huge fan of museums.  I end up feeling like a rat trapped in a maze trying to find my way out.  My friend wanted to go check out the Lords of the Samurai exhibit, so I reluctantly gave in and went to check it out.  

We didn't think there would the THAT much to see, so we showed up at 4:00 on a Saturday afternoon(museum closes at 5:00).  We got through the Samurai exhibit in about 50 minutes...leaving 10 minutes to check out the rest of the museum.  I didn't do my research, so I had no idea there were 3 floors!  We only got through a portion of the 2nd floor before we got booted onto the street.  

I actually really liked this museum!  They had a lot of interesting items on display.  I liked seeing all the different suits of armor that the Samurais wore...very colorful and detailed.  They didn't allow photography in the main exhibit, but I was able to snap a few shots upstairs.

General admission is $12, and if you want to see the Lords of the Samurai exhibit, its an extra $5.  I would actually come back here to see the rest of the exhibits.  Now I know not to underestimate a museum because now I have to pay double to see the rest!
author: Patra I.

description:
Good collection, very beautiful but I felt a little jipped because the pieces were small.  I like how they separated the sections and showed the differences among all the Asian cultures. (See guys, we're NOT all alike!) One thing that gets me a little irked is the fact that the Korean exhibit was definitely lacking.  The fact of the matter is, what I recognize is Korean art was in the Japanese section.  This is not me being racist or hating b/c of the korea/japan thing, i wasn't even born so I don't even care, but I wish that they could have categorized correctly or have a section of the fusion of cultures because of the occupation of korea by japan.  It would make sense because a lot of japanese art is influenced by the countries they occupied. 

Still, without that part, the Korean exhibit is really small and disappointing. The other exhibits are good and I just enjoyed seeing everything and learning a bit more about other cultures.
author: Meena N.

description:
Gift shop.

Need more training! 
The staff, who mostly were volunteers, were not helpful. 

It was a weekday at the museum, I saw four sets of  "32 wooden blocks" for 2 years old and up. These educational blocks help kids to recognize Korean, Japanese, Chinese and Arabic characters while having fun learning. 

The sample displayed Korean blocks show English alphabet on one side.I wasn't sure if the Chinese blocks (in a sealed box) also show English alphabet - so I asked three staffs, whoever were available for help, two at the cashier and one the floor. Unfortunately, with the lack of courteous gesture, no one had showed any interest in finding it out. Just simple said "I don't know." 

Too bad, I could have bought two sets - $45.00 each - maybe my small purchase could have benefited the museum.

Aside from this shopping experience, I gave one extra star for its varieties of cultural crafts and arts tastefully displayed.
author: Marial L.

description: My favorite museum since being a kid. As far back as I can remember they have always come up with good exhibits to showcase. My favorite was the Mongolian collection, and the Chinese Emperors warriors. But if you are a fan of the art that comes from Asia in general this place is excellent to come to. They really cover all the different regions of Asia. It is a relaxing place to come observe art, and let the world drift away.
author: Christopher D.

description:
Could there be a more magical place to let you mind wander and your imagination take flight as you dive into rich art and cultural histories of Asia? The answer is no. I love this is museum. It makes me so happy.

I think it goes without saying the art and exhibits are captivating. But the building is quite impressive, very beautiful, easy to navigate and complimentary to the art.
I recently visited the Maharaja exhibit and was underwhelmed. Don't get me wrong, some of the art was so opulent and mind blowing and I am so glad that I took the opportunity to see it. 

I can't say enough about this place. It's magical. Visit it.
author: Denise S.

description:
Great museum.

This place is pretty awesome, a lot of old statues, and very unique art work. I came here with my boyfriend and I think we spent about 2 hours or more walking through this museum. There was so much to see, and everything was really interesting, especially the different colors and designs made from jade (that was my favorite part).

I really like seeing the different ethnic groups traditional clothing, and things they used. I also liked seeing the different soldiers uniforms and weapons. Definitely worth checking it out. Parking around this place sucks, so there is a garage you can park in across the street.
author: Heather C.

description: A very beautiful museum with an excellent collection.  The yoga exhibit was showing when we went and it was well laid out and very enjoyable to view.
author: Kevin M.

description:
We visited the museum to see "the roads to Arabia" exhibit, and it was so worth it!  Not only was the exhibit world class, but the staff is awesome as well. We needed special accommodation due to disabilities, and both Eric at the museum and Jason in the restaurant were so helpful and understanding, and went above and beyond to make us feel welcome and valued as visitors.  The restaurant also deserves mention for the great menus and fair prices.
We'll be back for sure!
author: Jim R.

description:
All I could think of was wow!!!! This would be a great place for a wedding!!!!

I went here the other night for a SPA products promotion.

I had a great time not only for the spa products (SPHATIKA) but the museum itself was great!!!!

This was the first time I've ever been in here and I feel in love.

The architecture was GREAT!!!  High ceilings, long stair cases, marble floors, great proverbs (I think) on the walls and great art stuff.

I loved it :)
author: Sandra S.

description:
Yesterday was a good day. I went to the Asian American Film festival and has two 5 star experiences. One was the Castro Theater where we saw the opening movie of the film festival and the second was the Asian Art Museum where they had the after party. 

Always thought that this was like a small museum with not a lot to see. Not sure why I thought that given the huge beautiful building they have.

This place is like a layer cake. On the bottom floor, they have Chinese exhibits including a video montage which was really cool. On the second floor they have Japanese and on the top floor they have Indian displays. 

Even the folks who are not usual museum goers will enjoy this place. They have amazing artifacts, some from the BC times on display. The whole place is set up extremely well starting from the overall building structure/skylights to the exhibits themselves. They have touch screen TVs that give you more info as well.  This would be an exceptional venue for a company party as well. They have huge halls that can be used for dancing etc in addition to the main museum.

I can write a few more pages about this place but won't. Just go and experience it for yourself.
