author: Sunil R.

description: This museum is really beautiful and has a lot of variety, its worth checking out if you enjoy some history and art!
author: Aya O.

description:
This was one of the museums I had been longing to visit. Finally, my friend and I stepped through the doors and the clean, magnificent museum welcomed us with open arms.

The primary reason we came here was for the Ming Dynasty exhibit. If you took your time, the exhibit was big enough to take up 30 minutes of our time, meaning it was extensive and very informative. History buffs unite. 

With time running out, I had a need to see what they offered on Filipino history and culture. We took the scenic route to the Filipino section quickly perusing and passing many impressive Asian exhibits along the way. When we arrived, I turned to my friend and said, "I think we passed it". We went back and forth and finally found it. Wow, was it a tiny section. I was saddened by the lack of Filipino culture on display.

With the excitement given by the Ming exhibit and the disappointment handed to me by the lack of Filipino exhibit, I very much look forward to returning to the Asian Art Museum.
author: Richard K.

description:
Apparently the word "FREE" admission appeals to everyone the first Sunday of the month at the Asian Art Musuem. I waited in line just to enter the museum for about 30-40min? Really? I'm assuming that their was a line because of the Terracotta Soldiers exhibit...which was amazing as well as all the other ancient artifacts throughout the entire museum! Definitely a great place to visit.

The only problem is...it was SO CROWDED!! Next time I prefer just paying the damn $12 admission and beat the crowds!
author: Suzette R.

description:
I am new to the Bay area and decided I should take advantage of the cultural offerings of the city.  I am a huge fan of east Asian culture and decided to make a day of exploring the Asian Art museum and going to the Orpheum to see Shen Yun.

It was my lucky weekend because it was the last weekend for the terracotta warrior exhibit.  I was told I could see the entire museum in just a couple of hours.  Hardly.  The exhibits were amazing and I tend to read a lot of the exhibit information and contemplate the artwork. 

I was in complete awe of the terracotta warrior exhibit and am grateful to the Chinese for allowing the museum to show some of the collection.  

The rest of the museum kept my attention with the 2nd floor exhibits including the many Buddha and Hindu deity statues.  It is hard to believe that thousands of years ago someone hand carved these works with such great detail.

The only drawback to me was the section on Japan.  I expected a bit more,  I was hoping to see more dealing with each era associated with their culture especially the Shogunate.  Maybe I am being picky, but I have been fascinated by traditional Japanese culture since I was a child.

All in all I love this museum!!!
author: Ryan F.

description:
I enjoy visiting the museum regularly...

Brief review of:  Maharajah, the Splendor of India's Royal Court open through April 8, 2012.

The excellently presented exhibit covers 3 galleries on the 1st floor, with 2 more related exhibits on the 3rd floor.  You may take a docent tour and/or the headset audio/video tour.  Since I linger I opted for the headset.  A good choice since I was there all day.  

Yes there is an awesome silver carriage, an opulent gold throne, and a royal Cartier necklace. 

Yet, I was astounded by the size & number of precious gems on almost everything.  The jewelry was amazing.  It covered almost all the human anatomy, from head, nose, ears, arms, hands, legs, ankles, to toes.  It was in elephants rugs, the elephant batons, carriages, chairs, clothing, game boards & pieces, and on and on...

Along with the art, the exhibit presents brief chronicles of the significant Indian states/empires from the 1700s to the 1900s.  Including their religious & political struggles.

From beginning to end everything was so well presented.
author: Saul M.

description: Whereas it has comprehensive and compelling collections and exhibits I had a hard time with the flow - getting stuck at the entrance through the doors with so many people and then stuck between walls and cases sitting in center of parts of the THREE different galleries that housed the current "Looking East" exhibit. When I went to the cafe I didn't know if I was to enter the area behind a long horizontal screen hiding the snacks, coffee and tea near the kitchen. When I discovered I was to go there I didn't know what side to enter. Signage would greatly help the latter issue. It feels a bit like a mall in the high ceilinged modern additions and long escalator; a bunch of separate glass door enclosed galleries. The older part is wonderful with the original gorgeous staircase leading to the beautiful columned lecture hall. I'd love to hear a concert there.
author: JA G.

description:
This is a review for a potential place my fiancé and I will hold our wedding. 

One word: breathtaking
author: Lauren T.

description:
Absolutely wonderful! I've visited the Asian Art Museum for various occasions; school field trips, extra credit for a class, family outings, awkward first dates etc and I've been impressed each time I've visited. NOTE: The admission is FREE on the first Sunday of every month so definitely take advantage of that!

The museum has 3 levels, tons of ancient artifacts, and informative videos about certain displays. They also have a gift shop and various arts and crafts booths available on certain days. I definitely recommend this place!
author: Joyce E.

description:
One of my degrees is in Asian studies with a focus of Japanese Art so I was very excited to visit this museum during my visit to the bay area.

However, it was just an OK experience. I wasn't too impressed with the collections from the other Asian art exhibits I have visited and seen. Nothing was super dynamic to me...maybe I just hyped up this place in my head too much...

But, it was a very nice and classy facility. The layout was nice and flowed well. I feel like they have a bit too much art from China and Indonesia, I wish they would've had more Japanese art.  There was some good pieces don't get me wrong, but I particularly liked the feature exhibit of the art from Shanghai - very colorful and insightful.

The cafe is a bit over-priced, as to be expected. The gift shop, barely got time to look through - sadly the staff was a bit rude to me when I was trying to ask about their hours and more information and such on the merchandise. But oh well - overall, I had a decent time.
author: Lara E.

description:
Being a Wells Fargo employee in San Francisco is so awesome!!! When I went up to SF for training, I got so many free perks for working at Wells, including complimentary admission for me & a guest to the Asian Art Museum. The museum is awesome - the architecture is a mix between traditional European style and modern. 

It's huge for a US based museum solely dedicated to Asian art. You could spend half a day in there if you enjoy art. They always have really fascinating special exhibits. In the past six months, they had Bhutan (really cool because very few people know anything about Bhutan) and Afghanistan exhibits. Obviously, the fact that it was free was awesome but I would have given it 5 stars even if I had to pay.
author: Yi Z.

description:
I was a little disappointed with the Samurai exhibit but then again, we went when it was really, really busy. Free first Sundays will do that to museum goers. The upstairs was much more manageable to see everything pretty quickly. There were even films being shown. There are lots of interesting artifacts from all over Asia. You are guaranteed to find something that interests you here.

The cafe is pretty reasonably priced. We only purchased beverages but we were pleasantly surprised that the prices weren't absurdly high. Pretty cool.
author: Amy J.

description: This place is HUGE. Has a tremendous collection of peices and artifacts. Last time I  went there was September of last year. There was a rotating exhibit on display downstairs. I've been here twice. One could easily spend several hours here. If I'm remember correctly it's about $12.00 to get in, again, one can easily spend lots of time here.
author: Peter J.

description:
Cheap Thursday nights, open till 9 p.m. (thru September).

Extensive collection.

Beautiful staircase.
author: Inigo M.

description:
Located right across the street from San Francisco's city hall is the Asian Art Museum.  I've walked/bussed/driven past it several times, but today was the first time I actually visited.  My boyfriend and I came right at opening, 10 a.m., and there was a short line of about 40 people ahead of us.  The line moved quickly and we inside, holding our free tickets, within minutes.  (General admission is normally $12.)

The museum is three stories, and there's a little bit of everything.  There's art from Cambodia, India, China, Korea, Japan, etc.  Most of the pieces are in excellent condition and there is a lot of information available if you're interested.  You can even rent an audio player from the museum to hear recordings about specific exhibits.  I particularly enjoyed the iPads located throughout the museum with short videos about each culture.  I watched videos and learned about Buddhist monks, the forbidden city, and jade artwork.  

Maybe if I appreciated art more, I'd give a five, but for me, it's a solid four.  The museum took my boyfriend and I about two hours to go through.  For those interested, guided tours are also available (this would probably be a several-hour-long-experience).  To me, it's worth a visit, especially on the first Sunday of the month.

Notes:
-Come on the first Sunday of the month, it's free!  Street parking is also free on Sundays, an added bonus.
-They have a craft area for children.
-They have a restaurant inside.
author: Samantha L.

description:
I took my almost 4-yr-old here for Chinese New Year celebration and enjoyed the place and activities and appreciated the friendly staff.

The storytime tour guide told engaging stories in different rooms and guided the children to locate dragons. The kids were also prompted to find animals during the gallery parade. Then we watched Red Panda Acrobat and my child even received a heart balloon after volunteering in a ball act. Two reporters from a local TV station were interviewing visitors. We didn't have time for yoga since my child preferred art activities.

I practically had no time watching exhibits other than what we saw at storytime and parade. Grandma went over most displays in a hurry. So we'll have to come back.

Arrived at 9:50 am on a rainy Sunday. 4 hr for $6 metered parking.
author: Paris C.

description:
I'm a museum junkie and once I get over the fact that I'm not at home in Washington, DC where the museums are free, I get to a happy place where I actually take pride in forking over my cash in support of the arts and city institutions like the Asian Art Museum.  Great cities deserve great museums and this one is perfectly, fittingly at home in a city where the influence of Asian culture is so readily apparent.

My partner and I came on a Friday afternoon for the Bali exhibit and it certainly did not disappoint.  When we lived in Japan teaching English in the 90s, one of our most enjoyable trips was to Indonesia over Christmas one year when we had the opportunity to spend three weeks exploring the islands of Bali, Java, and Lombok.  Bali was so fantastic (I mean, what's not to love?) that we actually went back for a visit in the first few years we were living DC. 

So many of the objects and images in this special exhibition were familiar to me, but this was one of the first chances I've had since those trips to delve into Balinese culture and history.  Apparently this is the first major exhibition focusing on Bali in the United States, so out here on business I marked this one as not to be missed.  Most of the objects came from museums in the Netherlands, which was the colonial power in Indonesia, so the exhibition was heavy on explanation and interpretation from the outsiders' points of view.  I only wish there had been some things from Bali directly besides photos and videos.

The permanent collection seemed kind of static, so I guess it must be the special exhibitions that draw folks in.  Still, this museum is a treasure and if I lived out here I might even be tempted to join as a member.
author: Sean M.

description:
Let me preface this review by saying that our visit to Asian Art Museum was to view their event space.  My review is not based on the galleries displayed.

My fiancé and I considered having our wedding here.  They comped us 2 tickets and we were in for a treat!  It was much more extravagant than how it looked in photos.

The Samsung Hall is the perfect space for a wedding reception.  High ceilings, modern design elements, and truly elegant.  Imagine your guests walking up the Grand Stairway and enjoying cocktail hour at the Loggia (just outside of Samsung Hall).  The pillars throughout this floor make for great photos and certainly sets the tone for the evening.  After cocktails, guests proceed to Samsung Hall for dinner & dancing.  Ideal size for about 200 seated guests with a dance floor.  

We were truly amazed by this venue but there were a few things we weren't too happy about.  After reading the fine print, there were excessive restrictions in regards to photography, flowers, decor, rentals, etc.  It was too much red tape and to top it off, since the museum is open on weekends, vendors cannot begin set up until 5:15pm which makes for a late start.  If you do not mind starting your reception at 7pm (at earliest) then I highly recommend this space.

We ended up going with a different and even more breathtaking venue.  I'll post a review after our wedding. ;-)
author: Nikki C.

description:
I came here on the first Sunday of the month for free.  I suggest you do the same.  When my boyfriend and I stopped by, we thought we'd come a little early so we wouldn't have to wait too long.  My goodness... we were not the only ones with the same bright idea.  The line wrapped around the block!

Fortunately the line moved quickly.  We paid 5 bucks a pop to check out the Samurai section.  It was pretty cramped, but  what can you expect when it's the only free day of the month?  The samurai section was interesting, but quite small.  It left me a little underwhelmed.

We moved on to the second floor to check out the photographs, statues, furniture, and artwork.  It was a sight to see.  We easily wandered around for a long time captivated by the works of China, Korea, and Japan.

After a while, we got pretty tired and stopped by the cafe for a lil pick me up.  I went straight for the coffee (black) and shared a chocolate hazelnut cheesecake with my boyfriend.  The cheesecake was yummy, but the consistency was more like a mousse than a cheesecake.  The coffee was surprisingly not godawful... if not enjoyable until I got to the sour-bitter bottom of the cup.

This place is definitely worth returning to.  It's great for groups, art aficionados, and families.

Some tips:
1. As mentioned in my other review, Taqueria el Castillito is located near the museum.  They provide the best and the cheapest burritos you'll ever put in your mouth.  I say if you get a rumbly in your tumbly, skip the museum cafe and have a burrito with a Mexican coke.

2. Street parking only.  There are some structures around the Asian Art Museum that you can use too.  However, if you plan on going on the free Sunday... the streets will be packed!  Leave your car at the hotel/home and just take the muni.
author: Xuan T.

description:
"Hearing foot steps from afar 
Past meets present 
I feel tranquil" 

Yes an ode...my Haiku to you. 

That's what I feel every time I walk your hallways; marveling at your exhibits; marveling at human artistry and ingenuity, and always in awe in amazement. What a gem this place is and it's full of history filled with wonderful arts and artifacts from around the world. 

I feel moved every time I look at the artifacts and they always say something different everyday. They each have a story to tell and you have to admire the craftsmanship that went into each piece. Some are made with love and devotion while others are made for necessity. No matter the story, you are looking into the history of a culture and the human being. 

But yet you wonder how can they make such elaborate things with such intricate details. Not everything speaks to you, but some actually shout and you gaze upon them with meticulous eyes telling me what can I learn. You transform yourself and go on a journey through time and see things thru their eyes. Then you realize that it's not all romantic, and some are quite tragic. Those are the ones that shout and get drawn to. 

However you may feel or what they tell you, that's a part of life: the construction and destruction; life and death itself; our history as human beings all etched on the hands of our ancestors. 

Then you go on another day and your journey is always different from the last one. Now, why would you not take that journey?
author: John G.

description:
3.5 stars. I give a better than okay rating since I do appreciate the exhibit but not the 3 rooms they were shown in, the crowd since it was free admission with $5 exhibit fee thing, the exasperated individual who was speaking like a know-it-all, and just the crowd. Sigh.

I went with Jonathan to check out this exhibit after talking with my best friend telling me about the exhibit a couple days earlier since she went with her bf. She said it was okay but we decided why not check it out.  Since it was the first Sunday of the month it was free admission and jonathan and i were going to be in the Castro area so we figure let's just make it in one trip. 

We take the underground muni to get to the museum knowing that surface traffic is shitty and walk to the museum. We see a line there dreading that there was going to be a long wait. Nope we were wrong, the line moved pretty fast and some of the employees were outside making sure those who were seeing the exhibit was prepared to pay the $5. 

We get inside and it was crowded. Ugh. And we knew it was going to be a little rough being able to fully enjoy the exhibit, yet it was. We went inside the first room, and boy, it was hard to determine where to start first and what to read/look without someone butting in and ruining the atmosphere. After the first room we were a little confused as to where to go next but we wanted to get an information pamphlet. Thinking we were going to get our hands on one, they were completely out. Sigh. Oh well. So we move onto the next room and I really didn't like how some people were sneaking in photos and not being truly appreciative of the showcase. I understand you want to captivate the wonders of exhibition but museums aren't meant to be exposed like that. It's only better if you actually see it yourself, this is why museums are actually built. 

But any case i liked the storyline of Musashi and the artwork presented. I think my favorite part was seeing how many of the artifacts had the family crests synthesized within the materials. I wished there was more to see. I feel like the exhibition was cut off knowing the full potential it had to offer. Oh well. Jonathan was, of course, glued to the glass with the swords :) Not surprising huh? ;P The swords were lethally elegant and beautiful, it's no wonder why they were such highly prized weapons of choice back in the days. 
All in all this exhibit was okay but I'm glad to have gone with Jonathan.  :) I wish I could come here more often and enjoy its entirety more thoroughly.
author: Marie G.

description:
I feel so grateful to live so close to such an amazing place as the SF AAM. I come here regularly not just for the rotating special exhibits, but to view the outstanding permanent collection again and again- I can only ever get though about half of it each time I go.

The museum store is itself a great place to find books and art.

Special events are going on all the time- the few I've been to include a live Balinese gamelan puppet show, a showing of Ringu, and a Zen meditation workshop. They have First Thursday specials- they are open late (til 9) and admission is $5 after 5pm. This is a great opportunity to bring a friend, and help people discover this kind of place who might not otherwise get to.

8/7 Update: The current special exhibit- PHANTOMS OF ASIA: Contemporary Awakens the Past (May 18-September 2, 2012) is none too exciting. The real choice pieces are actually scattered among the upstairs galleries, which are organized by region.
author: Hannah R.

description:
While I do appreciate their AAA discount (like another reviewer said, buy one ticket, get the 2nd half off), I wish all the museums in San Francisco would form an alliance and give each other's members a break.  For instance, if you're a MoMA member, shouldn't you get a discount from Asian Art and vice versa?  

Pricing aside, the exhibits are worthwhile overall.  I only wish they'd show more contemporary work - history is good, even glorious, but a modern twist would make the mix more interesting.
author: Kristen S.

description:
The Asian Art Museum here in SF is a well known and respected institution amongst Asian Art connoisseurs and scholars alike.  The Met and the Freer Gallery both have more comprehensive collections but the Asian Art Museum prevails on the west coast.

Admission is free every first Sunday of the month (10 AM - 5 PM).  I'm not really a fan of their special exhibits ever and I don't think it is worth the extra ticket price.  Permanent collection is great however and it is fascinating to learn the history!  Hopefully my future collection of Asian Art will be here someday (a girl can dream).

Whenever I go I feel like I'm playing a game of "I spy!"  For example:  I spy a Gandharan Buddha with a dharmacakra mudra... do you?!
author: Fei L.

description:
The Lords of the Samurai Exhibit is soon coming to a close.   The final showing is tomorrow Sunday, September 20th.

This exhibit at the Asian Art Museum, is definitely a great informational and culturally rich experience.

I learned many aspects of Samurai life.   From philosophy and strategy to a glimpse of the day in the life in feudal Japan.   Armor, swords, tea pots, kimonos oh my.    

I was definitely impressed about the knowledge that the tour guides had, and fascinated about facts like how a Samurai sword is made.   Did you know an authentic Samurai sword has 15,000 layers of metal.  They do this by folding metal (doubling each the layer after each fold), which gives the strength and sharpness to the sword (combining iron and steel into one blade).   The sword is actually made up of a several pieces.  The blade has both an inner core of iron which has very little carbon which gives it strength and prevents shattering, and outer layer of steel with high carbon gives it potential for sharpness.  That's why authentic swords are not only strong but has superior sharpness. 
   
I was slightly disappointed that there wasn't a larger selection of swords and armor on display at this exhibit, but I did appreciate the art and history of the overall theme.

Another very intriguing aspect is that a Samurai will die defending their lord also known as a Daimyo, but a samurai who loses their lord, then becomes Ronin.  Many know about Samurai and Ronin through the many of the mainstream movies.   What few people know is that one of the most famous Ronin, Miyamoto Musashi, wrote a book "The Book of 5 Rings" which shared many of his teachings which is comparable to Sun Tzu's "Art of War".   Not as war like as you might think, but more about philosophy and ways to think about situations.    

This exhibit has inspired me to read more about Musashi and "The Book of 5 Rings". 

Overall the Asian Art Museum, provides a large selection of Asian art with significant historical and cultural importance.    And their special exhibits are done well.    I'd definitely would make another visit and I recommend you do too!
author: Richard L.

description:
Had some time and wandered over.  The line was insanely long to get in on Sunday morning (be warned--it's free day).  But once they opened things moved quickly and the exhibition on the Samurai was first on the list.  

Great, multi-room show.  Very informational and the opportunity to get up close and see the beautiful works from Japan a pleasure.  

The museum's main collection is stunning.  A must-see for anyone visiting San Francisco.
author: Greg B.

description:
The Shanghai Exhibit is interesting!
  - I like it how they break out the different era in different rooms

There are a lot to see in the regular exhibits as well!  After 2 hours, I was tired but a bit more educated!

First Sunday is free :)
author: Coco L.

description: I love this place.  The exhibitions are always well thought out and are aesthetically pleasing.  I believe that the many of the staff are volunteers and it really shows in their friendliness and enthusiam.  Definitely check out the buddahs on the top floor - I've done so countless times and it never gets old.  Check out the restaurant too - the food is really good and is pretty reasonable.
author: Paul V.

description:
I got lucky and randomly came here on a free day!

Pretty large museum with many artifacts. If you wanted to really read all the info and take your time, you can easily spend at least half your whole day here.
author: Annissa H.

description:
With all the museums in The City, Asian Art Museum ranks right up there with the others farther west.  Definitely worth a trip a couple times per year.  This place is huge.  The recent Maharajah exhibit was really great and well laid out.

Make the trip to the Civic Center and visit!
author: Don G.

description: Ahh, Target Sunday = free admission (check their website for the dates). Love this place and learned quite a bit from the current traveling 'Yoga' exhibit. Which is way better and larger than the crappy traveling Terracotta Warriors (yeah, like 2) exhibit they had last year.
author: John H.

description:
Interesting Exhibits, the permanent collection of Indian statues is great.
The museum is actually on the site of the anti-chinese riots in the Nineteenth Century.
author: John X.

description:
I really like this museum. I think its my favorite museum in the city. I have been there 4 times (twice for a Matcha event). I strongly recommend the audio, you'll be missing on a lot of things if you skip it to save $5.

I was looking for the Matcha page on yelp and could not find it, so ill review it here. They have Matcha events a few times a year. I went to the Samourai one 2 years ago and the New Indian Cuisine last week. Its really well organized, they have a cash bar, free access to the new exhibition, a DJ and complimentary access to the museum. You hardly can do better for $10.

One complaint about Matcha is that they should really take care of the cash bar situation. I was all about spending $6 on a beer or $10 on a fancy cocktail but 1. they stopped serving the specialty cocktail at 7 (I guess they were out of the cocktail mix) 2. the line is ridiculous. I mean not ridiculous because a lot of people are getting drunk but ridiculously slow. One of the server was mingling with EVERY SINGLE CUSTOMER. I know you work for tips, but for god sake, pouring a beer in a plastic cup should not take a full 5 minutes.

Next time Ill get my booze from the cafeteria that stays open late for Matcha events (until 9pm I think).
author: Jeremy B.

description:
I'm so sorry to say...as much as i tried to love this place, i couldn't.  I generally love museums and love learning about culture, especially when it's about my own!  But honestly, i was bored out of my mind here.   

Everything is redundant and repetitive...they have the same displays of the same things but in various shapes and sizes.

And here's a tip...don't pay the extra $5 for the special "Bali" exhibit.  I think the country/island of Bali is fascinating as well as their culture, but the extra $5 wasn't worth it.  Everything on display was repetitive and uninteresting.  The only exhibit I found to be interesting was a Bali display out in the lobby for people with general admission to see.  So don't pay the extra fee unless you really have nothing better to spend it on...

I want to give this place 2 stars but I'm giving it an extra star just because the museum is set up very nicely and is very clean and organized.  They definitely do a good job of maintaining this place and keeping it in good condition.  

Overall, I don't recommend this place unless you're really into that history type stuff and looking at ancient artifacts that are like thousands of years old.  Not my type of thing though...i'd recommend the MOMA or California Academy of Sciences instead.
author: Cat P.

description:
I was here for a wedding in July. It's a beautiful/gorgeous venue I must say. They also opened the 2nd floor section for us to walk around during cocktail hour. I loved it. It has a really romantic atmosphere .. well maybe bc of the flowers and the lighting. But I really like it. 

Theres so many artifated and tons of information. I think I would need 2 days to explore the whole museum!
author: Jenna L.

description:
I had always been aware that this place existed but never had the opportunity to come and see it since it had been revamped.  One of my friends had to come here for a class and suggested that I come along.  It cost me $12 for admission without a student ID.  I believe the price with a student ID is $7.  The outside of the building maybe neo-classical French with lots of modern touches throughout the interior. The place is huge and spans roughly 165,000 sq. ft, with almost 17,000 art pieces.  

I started on the third floor as the brochure guide had suggested and work your way down.  That section had started off with the history of Buddha and depicted many different Buddha statues.  There happened to be one guide who started giving history of Buddha at the time, we had listened in shortly but lost interest in staying to hear her speech.  We decided to just go at a faster pace and interpret things for ourselves.  

I remember seeing an incredible array of various Buddha statues made from all different types of material.  This is probably one of the most extensive Buddha collections I've ever seen.  Another highlight would be the Asian Jade Sculpture room which is all black with lit cases showcasing these little Jems.  I really enjoyed seeing this room, and was familiar with the art as I've seen many Asian jewelry and art shops with this type of Jade.  

There was plenty more art and even architecture of the interior to amaze about such as Samsung Hall or the center hall with the massive columns.  There is also a gift store that is clean and modern.  I was glad to be able to see it, but I may not come back unless there is a special exhibit that compels me to.
author: Kenny P.

description: First Sundays are the way to go.  Every first Sunday of the month it's free admission; a great deal.  This museum has some great exhibits; I really enjoyed the jade exhibit and Buddha exhibit in particular.  Personal recommendation: Grab some crawfish beignets up at Brenda's on Eddy & Polk, sit in front of the Asian Art Museum and nosh, then head in for a late morning/early afternoon.  Really enjoyed it.
author: Mel G.

description:
Came here last Sunday for the free day. You have to put the sticker on to enter the museum. It is actually really nice and modern inside. There is a lot of to look at. It wasn't that crowded so you can take your time to look at everything. 

There was a guy that carve these stones. It was cool. I think it'll make a good gift for someone. Hes there on the weekends.
author: Sarah C.

description:
My friends and I went to the Asian Art Museum on the first Sunday of the month, so that it was free for us, thanks to Target! Anyway, the museum is located close to the Civic Center BART, so it was convenient for us BART riders. We arrived around 11:30am.. maybe closer to noon since I was running late. 

Anyway, we thought that since it was free admission that the place would be packed, but it wasn't so have no fear (however, it was a bit rainy, sprinkling that day.. so weather may have deterred folks?). I still think that the place is big enough, three stories tall, I believe to avoid huge crowds of people.

We started at the top floor and worked our way down.. I can't remember all the different exhibits, but it definitely will take you a while to go through the entire place thoroughly.. They have so much stuff!!! Good stuff. :o) Did I feel closer to my Asian heritage? Perhaps, I did... Overall, I think the people I went with made it more enjoyable. Haha :o) 

P.S. The Japanese screen was the special exhibit, but required a fee to see, which I didn't pay. One of my friends did and now that I think about it, I probably should have paid to see it.. He said it was pretty! So, I recommend it based on his reaction to the exhibit!
author: Cassy H.

description:
My main gripe with this museum is that they didn't do a vastushastra or feng shui treatment of the space -- and I asked, just to be sure. Go ahead and snicker at me. I don't care.
But whenever I walk into this place I feel like I'm in an office building or something. There is no welcoming, airy, central space that invites the visitor to explore -- every inch is partitioned or filled with "stuff." There is definitely no indescribable vibe that whispers to me: "feel the art!"
I only go here when I have to go for work and stuff. But when I want to go somewhere to enjoy art I go to the DeYoung.
author: Lisa T.

description:
While I am a big fan of the Beaux Arts-style architecture that makes up the core of this building (once the city's main library) I am less impressed with the overly teal touches put on the place by Gae Aulenti. Though the architect "specializes in the adaptive reuse of historic structures to museum spaces" I am not sure the Asian Art Museum is the best example of her work.

Like anyone, I love me some Buddha statues and ancient tea pots and vases, but I would love to see more modern work by Asian and Asian American artists to round out the collection and reflect the true diversity of Asian art.

NOTE: On the first Tuesday of each month, admission is free.
author: Miriam W.

description: I was visiting SF for Memorial Day weekend and needed something to do before going off to the airport. I thought it was a good idea to go to the Asian Art Museum since I'm interested in this stuff. I decided to only see the permanent collection since I didn't feel compelled to see the special exhibit. I got there about 15 minutes before the museum opened and was TURNED AWAY. "We're only allowing Terracotta Warriors people in until 1pm! It was 10am! No way was I going to purchase a ticket and wait around. No where on their website was this said and it seemed to be something they just made up that morning. TERRIBLE service. I went to the SFMOMA instead, and was very happy I did--since this was their last week being open since they're expanding and will be closed for the next couple of years.
author: George S.

description: This is a wonderful place. The beauty of Asian art is nicely displayed here and I didn't even make it through half of the place. I will be back.
author: Karimah H.

description:
I'm a member of this lovely museum. It has a large collection of art and artifacts from all over Asia. I love the space and the special exhibits. I just wish the museum cafe served better food; the prices are too high for the portion and quality of the food. The museum should have a real restaurant like other world-class museums in NYC and Europe. 

I've taken my preschool nieces and nephews there; they don't appreciate the art yet but they find various art pieces amusing and engaging. 

This museum is a wonderful destination for anyone, including local residents as well as people visiting San Francisco from all over the world.
author: Peace L.

description:
I love museums. Something about walking through one calms me down. The Asian Art Museum has free admission on the first Tuesday of every month, so I went this past month in an attempt to distract myself from studying for finals. 

I enjoyed their Japanese bamboo exhibit, which had so many cool baskets and vases that it made me want to try basket-weaving myself (reality hit me later and I haven't embarassed myself by actually trying this). Then I wandered around looking at their normal exhibits, which showcased various artifacts from China, Korea, Japan, and Southeast Asia. My favorite part of the whole museum, however, was the gorgeous stairway near the entrance. Just beautiful. 

The little cafe / eatery on the first floor also has some pretty decent food (you don't need to pay admission to eat there). I ended my museum trip with a Thai green papaya salad (steamed prawns served with shredded green papaya salad tossed with mint, basil, peanuts, and cilantro dressing) and a cold bottled Kirin. Sad how many Japanese restaurants don't have Kirin, and here I found it in a museum. 

Anyway, this is a lovely place to spend an afternoon :)

(See accompanying photos!)
author: Lisa M.

description:
BUDDAHS, JADE, AND MORE!

I was hesitant about viewing the collection because I had such fond memories of the visiting the museum at the de Young in Golden Gate Park.  The new location in San Francisco's former library blended beaux arts and modern design very well.  How could you go wrong hiring the designer of Paris's Musee d' Orsay?

The museum was full of exquisite art from all areas of Asia.  I was mesmerized by the sculptures, paintings, bronzes, and ceramics.  The highlight for me was the Jade Treasury room where I stared in wonder at the jade pieces that were dramatically lit and surrounded by sumptuous blue walls.  I enjoyed seeing the detailed carvings and variety of colors from shades of green to lavender, light blue, and even reddish orange.

On my way out, I stopped in the café for bracing pot of Jade Oolong tea and strolled by the gorgeously merchandised gift shop.  A fantastic way to spend an afternoon.
author: Rob L.

description:
For all the expectations and drama the museum's facade promises, rarely have I been as underwhelmed by an art museum as with the Asian Art Museum.  I really wanted to enjoy this museum, but my overall impression is that I didn't see much here that I haven't seen in other art museum collections around the country.  The collection is encyclopedic, but few pieces stand out as memorable, and many pieces are so dimly lit that their viewing strains eyesight to the point of recognition.  Seriously, why are most of the galleries void of any filtered outside light?

And that's really too bad because, for all the wonderful space planning the Italian architect created for the Musée d'Orsay in Paris, the Civic Center building has few contemporary embellishments that are revolutionary or interesting.  The exhibition halls only occupy a quarter of the building, and of that, only two "U"-shaped floors hold the permanent collection.
author: Robert S.

description:
FIrst of all, I can't believe that Asian Art Museum isn't on Yelp yet. I checked twice and couldn't find it, at least under the correct name. Weird!

This place is fantastic! First of all, the company I work for did a lot of the work on the new Asian Art Museum's interior. Wherever you see glass display cases, fancy architectural woodwork and paneling, that's us. The place looks wonderful!

My sister and I went during the holidays and saw these exhibits: Hiroshi Sugimoto and also Stylized Sculpture: Contemporary Japanese Fashion from Kyoto. They had some expert lighting people come in and they set up the most amazing visual display of the fashions of some very famous people in fashion. Rei Kawakubo and Issey Miyake to name just two. It was very dramatic and inspiring!

My favorite was probably the Hiroshi Sugimoto exhibits, though. He's an amazing photographer/artist. You could sit and stare at his works for hours. (We did!) I should've Yelped it right after I went, but it was Christmas, then New Year's, and I was really busy!

Anyway, my other favorite parts were: watching the Buddhist monk paint in the open space in front of the gift shop/bookstore, getting to do a wood block print with a Buddhist monk that I could take home, for free! And also the bookstore itself... they have some of the most amazing and beautiful books there! My sister and I went crazy buying all these books that were on sale, and the nice women at the cash register let us leave our bags behind the counter so we could finish up our tour. 

The museum itself is a short walk from the Powell Street Bart station, which is VERY handy! Close to shopping, obviously, too! 

So do yourself a favor and get yourself over there! Check out some of the antiquities up on the upper levels. Walk around and enjoy the architecture of the place. It's really gorgeous! And then have a nice lunch at the cool cafe!! You'll be done afterwards, though... there's a lot to see at the Asian Art Museum!!
author: Shari D.

description:
I went here on a free museum sunday. They were having a parol (traditional filipino lanterns for christmas) making workshop. Upon entering the building the cranky securities inspected our bags and gave us the regulations of the museum. (No flash photos etc etc) They were rude. Maybe because it was a free museum day and they wanted to go home to sleep only to wake up to go back to work there. Anyways, I was directed to the samsung hall for the workshop. Thankfully there were friendly volunteers that gave directions step by step on how to make the Parol. There didn't seem to be a limit on how much materials you used, so they were always happy to give you more materials if you needed some. I thought it was a great way for children to learn about the culture by making these laterns. That was fun, now I have my own handmade Parol hanging by my window. It's pretty dope.

For the museum itself, I can't say that it wows me much. Maybe it's just from a biased stand point, since not many asian artifacts wow me. I'm giving this place three stars based on the boringness of the museum, but the ones that prevented me from giving it a one star were the friendly volunteers, and the type of workshop that they had.
author: Monina C.

description:
I love this museum.
They always have great special exhibitions. The exhibitions run for several months (the upcoming Bali exhibition lasts 7 months), so you'll certainly have time to catch the show before it ends.
They also have great events related to the special exhibitions. Be sure to check out their calendar (today's Matcha had Balinese music and dancing for example).
The musuem is beautiful, clean, well-organized. 
Great museum shop too (you dont need to pay the entrance fee to go to the shop, just let the ppl at the front desk know this).

Bonus: Its close to Turtle Tower on Larkin, so you can get some great Pho before or after the museum.
author: Norman P.

description: One of my favorite art museums anywhere!!!  It would probably take a full day , or maybe two, to really examine everything in this amazing museum , in detail.. I have been here 3 times so far and have not have time to really look at everything.. Exhibits of stuff from India and pretty much all of southeast Asia and east Asia.  The cafe downstairs is great!!! Very close to a BART station, so quite easy to get to via BART or MUNI tram.
author: Mark N.

description:
3 Stars. I don't know...it's just that place could be so much better. As other yelpers said, the permanent collection is a bit stale. I enjoy the different incarnations of the Buddha as much as any art history buff, but there is such thing as overkill, with anything. 

The temporary exhibits generally are the main draw since you don't need to revisit the permanent collection more than 3 times.

I also wish that other, smaller Asian cultures were represented here as well. Finally, they don't do the contemporary Asian art scene much justice. 

So much potential here. I'll be waiting...
author: Art O.

description:
The Asian Art Museum is a nice introduction into Asian art.  It covers a lot of different types of art and is small enough not to be overwhelming.

I'm not sure it's worth the usual $12 entry fee - this really isn't a major museum.  I would recommend coming on a free day or during $5 admission for Matcha.
author: Jean K.

description: Target has allowed me to get in free twice. I know the free days are usually super crowded, but I don't mind it much. I did still have to pay for the exhibits (the Tibetan exhibit years ago, and the Shanghai exhibit more recently) and I don't mind that either. The collection of Asian art is impressive! So many differences and similarities between the many Asian countries. So much to learn!
author: Helen L.

description:
If you enjoy getting lost amid antiquity and great art, this museum is for you.  I came alone and enjoyed taking my time.  Although this is a world class musuem, it didn't have the crowded feel you get in some places.  (Note: I wasn't there on the 1st Sunday of the month.)

The Maharajah exhibit was extravagant and fun.  They have music playing in some of the rooms and, omg...the jewelry!!  Was worth the extra $5.
author: Marlena C.

description: I recommend the Korean exhibit with the audio tour guide.  The Korean narration seemed native and authentic.  The English narration is also good.  The visiting exhibit seemed more interesting than the permanent exhibit.  I recommend using your local library card (e.g. SF, Alameda, Contra Costa County) to get discount tickets.  I also recommend searching on the web for good deals such as Travel Zoo.
author: joe w.

description:
I came here with my mom today. We went to the Asian Cafe inside this museum and were impressed with the food. You would expect burgers and pizza inside a museum cafe but we ended up getting a crushed miso salmon sandwich with the nicest bread, pickled vegetables, and garlic fries on a cute rectangular plate for only 7.75. You can also get a BBQ pork sandwich that comes with noodles for about the same price. They have bowls of hot noodles that cost from 3.50 to 5.50.  They have good rice plates too. You can get hot teas served in a teapot and various cold teas. I had their hibiscus lemongrass ice tea (2.75), it tasted healthy. They also have Pom ice teas, thai ice teas, and lipton ice teas ranging from 2.00 dollars to 4.00 dollars.  They also sell various cookies and cakes.

The museum itself is four floors. The groud floor has two rooms with exhibitions (currently houses Japanese anime), a museum gift store with lots of cute stuff like dolls and fans, and the Asian Cafe. The rest of the museum is dedicated to museum art.  We saw alot of beautiful jade, scrolls, bits of furniture, some clothing and an extensive collection of buddhas which is my favorite. There are small buddhas, big buddhas, buddha heads, etc.  In one room where there are many life size buddhas, I actually feel more inner peace when I'm in this room. The escalators take you up to these upper floor exhibitions and there are glass walls in the entry/exit way where you can see the city quite well.  

There also little remote-looking things that speak English or Cantonese while you are touring the exhibitions. It might speak in more languages.

The Asian Art museum is definitely a nice gem in the city. While you're there, have a glass of tea and a sandwich with a friend.
author: Lorissa W.

description:
I went to the Asian Art Museum to see "Geisha: Beyond the Painted Smile" with my friend Dave. We went on a weekend and it was very crowded inside and often difficult to wholly enjoy the galleries. So many people! It was like Disneyland during summer vacation. 

Will go back again in the next month or so, to see "Traditions Unbound: Groundbreaking Painters of 18th-Century Kyoto." 

---
Free for museum members 
Free for children 12 and under 
$10 for adults
$7 for seniors (65 and over)
$6 for college students and youth 12-17
$5 Thursdays after 5PM

Free on the first Tuesday of each month, courtesy of Target.
Open Tuesday through Sunday 10:00 am to 5:00 pm. 
Extended evening hours every Thursday until 9:00 pm.
Closed Mondays and major holidays.
author: Amy D.

description:
My daughter wants to be an Artist, so we went to the Asian Art Museum of San Francisco today. It has one of the most comprehensive collections of Asian art in the world. 

We had the opportunity to see the "Emerald Cities: Arts of Siam and Burma" exhibition there. It's a very beautiful museum. I suggest taking at least one of the many FREE! tours available.

My daughter and I learned quite a bit from the tour we took.

I'm a foodie in town to document and eat one last time, before the closing of the 40 year old historic "Carnelian Room".

This was a great museum to visit, and I recommend it for families, singles, first dates etc. Just a wonderful museum.
author: Digital A.

description:
Out of all the museums (well I only went to this one) in San Francisco, this is a must.  There's just something about Asian art that I'm drawn too.  I must have taken about 200 pictures while I was here.

My girlfriend and I were lucky enough to be visiting on the first Sunday of the month, so we got in for free - paid $5 for the Samurai exhibit.  I was hoping for a little more out of the exhibit, but to be fair, I think we only went in 2 out of the 3 rooms.  

The museum overall though it great.  You could spend a few hours here.  You must check out the photography on the upper level.
author: Judd T.

description:
Let me preface this with saying this review is about the Gorgeous exhibit...
Every time i try to explore the Sf museum scene I am reminded of my final year at Parsons the dean and multiple professors blatant mockery and scowling disapproval of my plans to to relocate from NYC to SF. They all told me- i would lose inspiration to paint or for visual art application in SF due to the complete joke of an art scene. 
I hate to be so judgmental but stereotypically we are a bit more critical & outspoken from that coast and it pains me to say- but they were right. This is 20 years later and although SF has other gems- their formal art scene, gallery scene, and museums are pathetic for a supposedly cosmopolitan city.

I really wanted to give the museum scene another try as SF is developing and I would hope their sophistication would grow to keep up with the international flurry of new residents.
Sadly i really can't say they have.
This exhibit lacked any cohesion conceptually and in pieces displayed. There were historically phenomenal pieces such as Buddha and the Q'aran,  were mixed in with Jeffrey Koons, (Koons DID fit conceptually into exhibit's mission statement- as he is purposefully working with attraction and repulsion and many witness him this way)  Sallie Man's 80's controversial photography of overr-sexualizing her children, Picasso, the Hindu deity Durga, Mondrian, Rothko and a painting of Queen Latifah with elephant dung. There was a beautiful photo of a Senegalese girl in a pink dress and enjoyed the male re-make inspired by the famous  Odalisque.
But i could not understand conceptually how this could all be put together. No challenge to viewer, just unsophisticated conceptual execution & curation of a show of pieces spanning decades, movements and cultures that had no relation to each other or cohesive thread. It was a puzzle whose pieces could never fit. Maybe just a desperate attempt for finances to attract viewers with the title "Gorgeous" ?? I don't know- i am guessing..
It screamed of racism, & disrespect to display great religious traditions to many of these pieces in an exhibit that was supposed to challenge what the viewer saw as "gorgeous"  Advertised as "A fine line between attraction and repulsion".. in an attempt to shift focus from historical to cultural contexts"   

REALLY? MAJOR FAIL. not unique but discombobulated and juvenile.
The blurb under captions of pieces were juvenile as well- such as-  the photo of the Senegalese girl- "does she know the photographer" etc. umm really??

It is just horribly inappropriate to exhibit thangka paintings or the Q'aran which are just astounding in their significance, historical and cultural context, exquisite  craftsmanship, & geometric design in this exhibit supposedly challenging your concepts of "attraction and repulsion."  
I am exhausted with ubiquitous cliché  of three+ decades  inundating every advertisement of pushing some kind of stupid envelope.. The nauseating clichéd envelope did not get pushed nor did it have a sound basis in this exhibit. 
The reminder that San Francisco lacks an advanced education in visual arts surfaces. Felt like an overly ambitious, failing to hit the conceptual mark & lack of education of a college freshman studying art.
i love the concept of Thursday night performances with cocktails and socializing but I will omit any critique of what i witnessed..
author: shanti z.

description: Lucky to enter free of charge - thanks Target!  Fantastic way to spend a Sunday afternoon.  The sheer # of items on display are overwhelming.  I like the way the areas are segregated by country so people can get a feel of how they are distinct & different.  Gosh folks were tiny back in the day - check out how small the clothing & seating appear.
author: Kim S.

description: Exquisite museum!  We went on a first Sunday of the month when it's free.  The line was packed out the door & around the corner.  Parking was also difficult due to a weekend at the SF civic center.  There was a variety of displays to see that we didn't have time to finish.  We had to be out at 5p.m.  The exhibition this Summer is the Ming Dynasty, which was totally inspiring.  Great learning experience for the entire family.  The kids never knew so much about their heritage, as grandma was explaining the artifacts with expertise.  This place is modern and unique, but no photos allowed on the main floor exhibit, second floor okay.  We'll definitely have to go back another free Sunday or on Thursday evenings when it's $5 per person and closes at 9pm.
author: Christine R.

description:
I'm so so sorry, Asian Art Museum.  I have never been so disappointed with a museum experience before.

Today was the last day of the Shanghai exhibit, and two films I wanted to check out were playing as well, so I headed up to SF with the parents, already forewarned that it was a Target Free Sunday (free admission to the museum, which is a pretty good deal, although an extra $5 for the Shanghai exhibit).

There were SO many people in the Shanghai exhibit and the rest of the place, I barely saw anything without being crowded over by rude guests, blocked by taller guests, or herded to the next piece by a loud tour group.  I tried to enjoy the rest of the museum and IT WAS FREEZING.  I couldn't stand still without shivering and getting a runny nose, and I swear 85% of the other guests had NO museum etiquette.  I know there needs to be climate control, but how about guest control?  I pretty much hustled through a fourth of the museum, barely stopping to enjoy anything, before giving up and sitting.  The two films I saw, one of them had tons of technical difficulties, the second dragged ON and ON in a freezing room.

I understand, a lot of these complaints aren't entirely the museum's fault.  But the only thing I could feel good about was the wonton soup in the cafe to keep me warm.  I'll try to give this place another chance, but boy...I've never been so irritated at a museum like this.
author: Addi M.

description: A great museum with nice architecture. I loved to explore all the exhibits and lear more about all the different Asian cultures and see their artifacts.
author: Victor G.

description:
I went to the Asian Art Museum on Sunday for Target free first Sundays, with a $5 surcharge for their Shanghai exhibit, which I've been wanting to view for quite some time. It was my first time at the Asian Art Museum and I can say that I absolutely loved the architecture of the building. The high ceilings are gorgeous but the layout can be a bit confusing if you take one wrong turn  (such as going up the main stairwell to the second floor instead of the side escalator).

Their main collection is quite interesting, but I'll be honest when I say there's only so long I can look at the same essential statues of the same Hindu gods and goddesses. There's only so long I can look at the same basic pottery and the same looking wall hangings. All in all, it all starts to look exactly the same after a while.

The Shanghai exhibit was quite interesting, but we were not informed of the layout and I ended up viewing the exhibit backwards. I really enjoyed the Chinese Impressionist paintings, and the contemporary Mao paintings. But in general, I discovered I am much more a than of European art than Asian.
author: Stephanie H.

description:
Cafe review only - 3.5 stars for lunch. (Solid 4 stars for the food itself - it's just a bit pricey for a cafeteria-style meal)

You can actually eat in the cafe without paying for museum admission. Why would you do that? Perhaps you have back to back meetings at the court building across the street and need to grab something quickly...

Anyway, it's a cafeteria-style place that features legit stir fries, curries, and noodle dishes $9-$15. There is also an assortment of pre-packaged snacks, and cold teas.
author: Jacqueline W.

description: Went to see the Terra Cotta Warriors - came twice to see this exhibit as we have a membership.  The person saying how barbaric it was to see the exhibit was true as we made it a point to get there by 11 AM.  It was crowded and people were rude.  You try to walk and be mindful only to have people shoving you.  My 11 yr old was like jeez I'm just standing there looking and I get shoved around.  The exhibit viewing wasn't designed well.  Like they had a great timeline projecting on a wall, well people are looking at it naturally but it caused the viewers to block an entry way into an exhibit room.  But that was kind like all the wall depictions which were great information but then it caused blockages of people viewing the walls against those viewing the artifacts.  Just wasn't as well planned like an exhibit at the deYoung when they did the Impressionists.  Go early to the cafeteria if you want to eat there.  They had good food and if the weather is nice, eat outside.  Parking was easy (across the street) as we parked in the underground lot - just GPS Brooks Hall's address.
author: Denise L.

description:
I love this place! This is the only museum I've ever had a membership to, and tonight I'm going to renew my membership. Never before have I really been able to enjoy going to the same museum repeatedly until I discovered the AAM, and I'm so happy that I did!

As a history geek, I simply love the collection here. If you ever catch wind that I'm coming here, just ask a docent where the samurai sword is at in the Japanese collection, and chances are you're going to find me sitting there in awe of this amazing 600 year old razor-sharp weapon that looks like it was made yesterday. And the ancient Chinese pottery? Fahgetaboutit, love it - amazing! 

What really brings this place to life for me are the Matcha events, which are a brilliant combination of social mixers and live performance events  mixed with cultural education. Where else can you go to a beautiful, classic Beaux Arts building like this, feel like you're at a casual cocktail party, take in a live performance, and leave feeling like you had a brilliant time AND learned something educational? (Did you know the AAM was designed by the same architect that designed the Musée d'Orsay in Paris?) 

The museum also has a great program of visiting exhibitions from across Asia. Past exhibits have been on the Samurai, Shanghai, Bali and more. The variety is simply fantastic. If you don't like one exhibit, just wait a bit and another will take its place soon enough.

It's great that they also engage kids (and big kids like me!) with hands-on crafts (at least during Matcha events) to keep the kids occupied and discretely educate them about different cultures at the same time. Nothing here is in your face, and you can participate to whatever level you want. The staff has also been consistently awesome - polite, professional, courteous, and just downright happy. It says a lot about a place when the staff is happy.

If you get hungry or need some caffeine, stop by by cafe on the first floor. And if you're looking for swag, the gift shop has a good selection of stuff that you may (or may not) want to put into your home or gift to friends. It's pricey, but hey, it's a museum, that's usually the way it goes. 

I can't speak highly enough about this place. It's great for adults, kids, families, dates, or if you simply want to go someplace for inspiration. If you come here often, please seriously consider becoming a member and supporting an amazing museum. If you've not been, go!!!
author: Gregg G.

description: Spend your most time in Gallery #1 where the Warriors are, but also plan time to visit the rest of the museum. It is breathtaking.
author: Bevy M.

description:
First off let me say thank you to Target for sponsoring the first Sunday of every month at the museum. Nothing is better than an afternoon of free culture. The line to get in moved swiftly as we began our journey. We were in and exploring the treasures in no time and although we decided to just do the main exhibits and not the special exhibits there was still so much to see. 

We lazily wandered from piece to piece learning about the development of art and society in the various and  diverse countries of Asia. Statues, paintings, relics and artifacts gave us insight into cultures that have influenced much of our modern societies. It is a great museum overall with a wide array of objects. It is not too large or too small, just the right size to spend an afternoon with friends or family discovering your heritage or learning more about a culture different than yours.

I did notice that they had a cafe that looked quite good though we did not have time to try it. The gift shop is lovely too and full of great gifts instead of tacky souvenirs. I will be back soon... very soon because I cannot wait to see the Shanghai exhibit that is currently on display. It is a great way to spend a day in San Francisco.
author: Stephanie H.

description:
Thank you, Avery Brundage.

I think the roofline needs to have pagoda top.

[Now, do we really need 2 C the Shanghai, having just returned from there last week?]
author: Clifford L.

description: Every time I visit this place of reverence to Asian art and arts of the Eastern Hemisphere, I become more and more impressed.  It is difficult to tell where the place for the most part is oriented, what region and so forth, and that it is greatly sponsored by donors from East Asia, though all of the items and artifacts, arts, and so forth continue to greatly impress.  On this visit there was particular interest in the art and other items from Thailand.  A great place to take your children as well if they are "hands off" types and the like.  One improves one's education about the world, especially China and its near neighbors, upon any and every visit here.  For reasons of 2014 - Year of The Horse, there is some great equine art pieces featured in this museum in the permanent collection.  Really great!
author: Thomas H S.

description:
I haven't paid admission here before, but from what I understand its not *too* pricey. 

I've been here on a free day, a normal weekday, and the Shanghai Nights event (Open late Thursdays). 

Even when crowded its not hard to enjoy the exhibits, the late night event was so delightfully empty that I had plenty of time to absorb the collections. (AAM seems to have special events from time to time as well, but I've never been there at a time they were taking place.)

That said, this museum is pretty massive, and it feels easy to miss certain wings entirely. If you only have one day with limited time, you should probably ask the staff for a game plan on how to tackle it. The front staff are helpful but not overly energetic. (They probably get bored, confined to one desk and a wall to stare at.) Maybe try the info desk by the store instead..

Can't wait to see the next exhibition! Shanghai's not really my cup'o' tea but saw a few gems nonetheless.
author: Adora S.

description: WORTH THE PRICE (if you appreciate art) large location with many pieces shown in a fantastic display!
author: Jesse M.

description:
I came here on a Saturday at 7pm. A wedding was hosted here and it was a great idea. The location and ambiance was simply very pleasing. After the ceremony, we walked upstairs and had cocktail hour before the Wedding Reception. It was cool and I was impressed with the upstairs.

I'm rating this place simply on the atmosphere (We didn't have an opportunity to take a real look around the museum)
author: Eric A.

description: What a gorgeous little museum! Covering sculpture, ceramics, textiles, print and painting for the many diverse cultures included in Asia. Wonderful instalations which change fairly quickly. We saw the Ukiyo-e, art of the floating world collection with a guided tour. We were so impressed, we got a membership! Collections are rotated frequently, so even the permanent exhibits are new and fresh. Go. It's lovely!
author: A D.

description: Amazing! It's such a cool place to go on weekend. Personally, collections here are better than Legion of Honor and De Young museum. I like it so much!
author: Ting L.

description:
I was bored by this museum's permanent collection, as I was expecting more modern art and less ancient statues. I didn't really understand the logic behind putting some of the pieces together, especially on the third floor. There wasn't a lot of focus or encouragement to contemplate the pieces as art--just as archeological findings.

The temporary exhibits on the ground floor have been interesting, and if I go again, it will be on a free day to visit just those small modern shows.
author: Sagruilla P.

description: Um loved this place! I came here with my bff for a school midterm paper and I loved how the layout of the museum was! I have been to some museums where everything was mixed up and it literally discouraged me from continuing on! This has just the right lighting, lovely things to take photos with, and their big feature right now is the Terra Cotta. I skipped out on it and my bff went to China last summer so she said, "It looks just like this poster and they're small. Go to china and pay to see that". I really loved their Asian furniture which is all over and from different periods. They give you a brief summary of what things are made of and what it could or would be used for. Lovely place and highly recommended!
author: Crystal V.

description:
Ive been here several times over the years. Most recently I saw the Bali exhibit, which I thought was awesome. There was a little altar set up near the beginning of this special exhibit to give offerings - nice touch! Bali has maintained a strong Hindu presence despite the rest of Indonesia moving more strongly towards Islam, making Bali rather unique. I felt kind of high going through this exhibit - it was definitely inspiring. Bali has a strong tradition of mixing ritual into daily life and this was strongly represented. 

In the past I've seen the Persian Setar player Lotfi perform here.

I saw another exhibit last year about Chinese artists in the 20th century figuring out how to blend the western influence into their art while maintaining their own cultural influences; I forget the name, but that exhibit was cool too.

I never give myself enough time here, and I definitely have not seen the entire museum.
author: Ken L.

description:
I was here for only 1.5 hours and I think their collections are decent.

We were here on Tuesday afternoon and I thought it's very quiet. I saw like 20 people.... Then I realized - what are we doing here! It's summer and the weather is brilliant outside. Heck, I never realized that.

The only downside is that I was expecting like HUGE artifacts. Like 20 feet tall... something grand. Most of their collections are like 5 feet tall and small pieces. But the jade room is just magnificent.

If you like art, definitely go here. The Asian collection in Met in NYC is bigger though... way bigger. So don't expect something like that. But still, good place to visit in San Francisco.
author: Thigh C.

description:
The Asian Art Museum hosts a diverse variety of arts and crafts.  You will find porcelain, lacquers, ceramics, textiles, furniture, armor, puppets, sculpture, painting, calligraphy, books, and even snuff bottles.

The collection is very comprehensive yet not overwhelming.  If you're the studious type you can easily spend all day here.  I'm guessing that the average person will take about two hours here if they looked at everything with a patient eye.  I'm not a huge fan of ancient art, but there was enough variety and oddities to fascinate.  There's some stuff I have never seen before.  Like the exquisite lacquer boxes and gods that are dry humping each other(!).

I wish their collection of asian contemporary art was more ample.  I'm in love with the new art coming out of asia.  They did have a section on contemporary basket and fabric asian art which was kinda interesting.  It's easy to draw the differences and similarities of the new and old eras.  It was quite interesting to make those distinctions.

To my disdain, I had missed the grand opening of the new Afghanistan exhibit by a day!  Grrrr.  I should have done my research.

While the collection is quite alive the rest of the museum has this staleness to it.  Sometimes it feels like this isn't even an Asian Museum but more of a place where rich white people have shared their collections.  This isn't a particularly bad thing.  It just feels somewhat skewed in the way things are being portrayed; again, not in a bad way.  Perhaps they just need a makeover.

Adults tickets are $12.  Fortunately they have student prices at $7 and first Sunday of the month is free.  I'll keep my eye open for new exhibits.
author: Michael H.

description:
Pricing: Excellent. Got to love those free days.
Quality: Good-Excellent. Upper floors never change, but the first floor changes every few months.
Turnaround: Excellent. No lines! I guess Japanese wall scrolls/painting are not as popular.
Service: N/A. The person who gave us the sticker was nice, but we were on our own for the most part.

Please remember to ask for the audio tour on the first floor because that would give a better idea of what to look at than just wandering everywhere aimlessly. We came on a free day so we did not have to worry about paying any admission, but even if we did not come on a free day, I believe students get free admission and the general admission is $12. I am a lover of museums so I thoroughly enjoyed the exhibits especially since I took a Japanese history course before so I have a general idea of the different Japanese dynasties. I know more about the pottery, sword making, and woodblocks so the wall scrolls and paintings were new to me. I was very enthralled by the fact that the Japanese would have a small alcove dedicated to a flower arrangement and painting to match the season or festivity of that time. I have been to the museum at least three other times in the past five years so I already know what is on the other three floors almost by heart. Yet, I always enjoy relooking through all the exhibits. The day we went, we did not encounter any lines so I was happy for getting inside quickly. We did not interact with any of the staff members besides when the lady in front gave us our tickets and that lady was very nice. When we left, another lady was giving away origami as a takeaway souvenir. When asked, she gladly took one apart to show us how she folded the origami.
author: Jenny W.

description: Great museum!!!  I always love going to see the works of art.  Well worth a membership.  The audio guides are free.
author: Brandon L.

description: I visited last Thursday and avoided the storm.  I thought the special exhibition on Bali was just okay but I did enjoy the section on Hindu art.  The shop is rather small in comparison to most museums I've visited.  I also liked the Japanese section but overall I felt that the museum was rather small.  I'm glad i went and experienced it firsthand but I doubt I'd want to go repeatedly throughtout the year (something I do in regards to NYMOMA, the Met, and The AMONH) given the opportunity.
author: Francisco H.

description:
I was fortunate enough to see the Shanghai exhibit at the museum.  There are some beautiful pieces, so stop by before it leaves in September 2010.  Evening tickets are only $10 and another $3 with the audio guide. Don't miss the silk clothing and pin up girl section. 

Aside from the traveling  exhibition, the museum boast some lovely artifacts from all across Asia. Some of which are donated by local Asian families. I especially liked the Korean exhibit with its tiny intricate pieces.

I have to go back and see the Japan and India sections. I didn't have time because I had to, "stay with the group".

Housed in the old main library, the museum is a lovely place to wander around and get lost in the culture of the orient.

Don't forget to stop by the gift shop, there are some reasonably priced and fun items...actually skip it! I just remembered China, Japan, Koreatown,etc. Got to love the Bay!

On a, " keeping it real" note, the neighborhood is a bit sketchy after dark, so be aware of your surroundings.  If possible, take BART or Muni.
author: Benita S.

description:
I had my wedding here! I really love the Asian Art Museum. They have some great exhibits and really work with you. 

I'm not going to lie...this place is pricey for a wedding. But I honestly could not have chosen a better venue for my wedding. The Samsung room with the arched ceilings and crown moldings is absolutely breathtaking. 

I really highly recommend the Asian Art Museum as a wedding venue. I had the wedding of my dreams here.
author: Jacqueline C.

description: Please go as soon as you can to see the Terracotta Soldiers exhibit. It's worth seeing.  The other art is beautiful as well.
author: Myoung K.

description:
I enjoy the vast arrangements of exhibitions from many areas of Asia. I feel truly blessed to be living in San Francisco where I live only minutes away from an establishment that holds historical  pieces that has influenced many cultures throughout the centuries. Being a transplant from the Philippines and being raised in Japan, I was very interested in learning all what the Museum has to offer- past and present. 

However, I felt there were some historical facts that were biased and some Asian cultures that were missing in the Museum, but perhaps at the time I went it was not showcased? I'm not sure. 

Going to the Asian Art Museum is very beneficial in many aspects other than the art perspective. I definitely feel that this facility is great resource not only just for San Francisco but on a wider plane, a National plane. It is educational as well as entertaining for all ages and all backgrounds. The Asian Art Museum also offers great deals on the "first of the month" where customers have free admission but on regular days the entrance fee is inexpensive, they also offer discounted prices. 

To this day, I've visited the Asian Art Museum the most than any other museum in the Bay Area, whether if its my love for my Asian heritage, or the sheer admiration of the cultural art, I honestly just can't help myself but enjoy this place!
author: C M.

description:
In the past I've been a member of the Asian Art Museum and I've visited fairly often. I found that I wasn't going often enough to justify the membership fee. Before I explain why, I will tell you that I'm very interested in Asian culture, history, and art. And I know that the museum got its start with a large private collection of ancient Asian art, so this was the original mission of the museum (to house and display this collection). 

However, as an artist I am much more interested in the art that is being made today in places like China, India, Pakistan, Japan and Korea. Some of the most incredible art being made today is coming from Asia. I would LOVE to see some of this modern art, but you can't see it at the AAM.  For example, one of the best photographic artists in the world today is Hiroshi Sugimoto. In 2008, a traveling exhibition, designed by Sugimoto and covering all of his major works,  came to San Francisco. Where was it shown? The De Young.  I could probably list 50 living Asian artists today being shown widely at the world's top museums doing very exciting, influential work. Why can't AAM support these artists?

Our Asian Art Museum is probably the most important museum for Asian art in the US. Until they start acquiring and showing contemporary art from the region, I'm not going to visit very often.  To the director of the museum my message is  -  great Asian art doesn't have to be dug out of the ground!!!
author: David S.

description: So worth the extra 5 dollars to also see the Bali Exhibit I felt was money well spent. This is a great place to just wonder aimlessly and enjoy what you are seeing.
author: Alma S V.

description: Open up your mind to the world of Asian art and expose yourself to cultures you are not familiar with. Free admission on the first Sunday of every month or use your Library passes. New exhibits and events regularly. Three stories of exhibits going from one country to another, Sculptures, paintings, all kinds of items as well. You can get a self guided tour  at the desk that tells you about all the different exhibits, it even has some video about them.  $12/adult & $8/senior or youth Casual attire. Street Parking
author: Ron W.

description:
Art Musesums are something my baby boo and I wait upon for free days; we strike (admiss ourselves) on the free days! San Francisco is good about that afterall.

AAM is a classy museum as a venue, as an edifice, with a somewhat sinewy/hard to navigate set of galleries, but it's certainly the best museum I've ever seen dedicated to a particular ethnic cause rather than a historical art period or artist. I just feel that it felt more like a history museum because it was hard to pinpoint any particular spotlighting of "Art movements" in Asia (if there were any); but that rather the making of aesthetically pleasing utilizable forms (pans/kitchen stuffs for baking, Buddhas/Hindu Gods for worshipping, etc) was about the point of it. By this, I mean that I felt I was trying to find evidence that the broad, only geographically definable area called "Asia" really created art the way Europeans did: with complete abandon, sophistication, and most importantly, without reason. To me, art for the sake of art is the most exalted form it can be created in because you get a great deal of personal touch.
