The AAM featured an exhibit called "The Maharajahs", displaying the splendor and majesty of the Indian subcontinent lords who created a community of kingship (akin to Europe's kings before the day sof the EU) among themselves, and considerable visibility and foklore about themselves among their populace. AAM showcased the flamboyant artifacts of the Maharajahs; a red chair to be saddled onto an elephant during pageants, an impressive shiny silver carriage (a real one, just outside the 3 exhibits), art depicting factual events and other miscellani (like an umbrella). While these artifacts were a treat to the eyes, the historical text writing and follow-along (they lend you walkman style adgets that give you audio tours) was poor. I didn't really get a fundamental sense of what was going on with these Maharajahs; the writing was rather "glowy"; kind of like in the way North Koreans might attempt to portray King Jong Il if you were on a tour of Pyongyang---euphemisms flying about. Much of the actual painting art was 2-dimensional and portrayed actual non-fictional events, usually centered around a Maharajahs love interest and how everything around them was just hunky dory. Call me a cynic, or blood thirsty, sometimes I just want to know: "Was this possible because people in power were abusing underlies?". I'm sorry, I just gotta know!

The rest of what AAM offers is quite exquisite. They break up the Asian demographics into rooms, showing SouthEast Asia, Western (as far west as the Persian empire) and Far East; the Koreas and Japan. Apart from the very meager Persian empire display, the rest of the museum was mostly dedicated to Oriental Asia and the museum did disclaim somewhere that the continent "Asia" is a European term; in fact, the peoples of Asia in their respective countries may very well have very little to do with each other lingually, culturally and politically.

Lots of ceramics. Some of them were so well restored, it looked like my dad created them in a ceramics workroom, except these, especially ones featured in the Japan and China exhibits, were dated from as far back as 6000BC! And then there were tons of Buddha statues of all forms, from Tibet to Thailand, Korea to Japan. They dominate the museum, probably accounting for about at least 50% of the works by count. Paintings, lastly, were rare, and often 2 dimensional, which, if taken for what it was, were beautiful renditions of historical events, but lacked artistic signature (artists were often unknown) and any articulatable art movements. I ask again: does/did Asia have art movements like in Europe? Is art important enough in Asia to warrant not only historical significance, but cultural significance? 

I ask all this because I want to know; does the AAM have a daunting task on their hands trying to bring Asian art to a public that often does not associate that continent with art at the level of sophistication and innovation found in Europe or elsewhere? I find it hard to believe that *not* to be the case; I think it more a problem with identifying how record-keeping was done---do that and perhaps there is more to find.

Just as a side note, Russia is part of Asia too (at least Eurasia), right? I did not see anything coming from Russia either. Maybe a proper name for this museum is OAAM (Oriental Asian Art Museum).
author: Davey R.

description: I've been meaning to make a visit to the museum but after hearing about the Terracotta Warriors being displayed it was a must do now! What an experience to view one of the wonders of the world up close and personal. To see all the history from how they built all of the different statues and the story behind it all was amazing. Words cannot describe it all, you just have to make an effort to stop by and take a look for yourselves. They also have art from all over Asia that should keep you busy for at least a couple hours. I thought 3 hours was going to be enough to see the whole museum but I was mistaken, can't wait to come back and finish it up. They were kinda strict on people bringing in large purses and camera bags so check it in unless you want the guards to ask you every so often. Check into the 1 year membership it's not a bad deal.
author: T L.

description:
Ah, I cannot begin to tell you why I love this place.

Came here in 2009 for the Lords of the Samurai exhibit. Went with my then-69 year old aunt. We loved it. Came this year for the Maharajah exhibit. I loved it. Going to this museum is like meeting an old flame and realizing you're still in love with them.

Things to note:

1) If you're a senior, or a college student (bring IDs), there's a discount. Kids under 12 and goes to a local school here gets in free.So do US Armed Forces and a guest. 13-17 year olds get a substantial discount. It's a recession.  Every dollar saved counts.
2) Special exhibits (like the Maharajah exhibit) cost extra, but SO WORTH IT. It comes with a  free audio tour, so make sure you get your audio pack at the Info desk.
3) The museum store is so awesome. Everything from picture books to origami, to wooden furniture, to posters, to postcards. To whatever your brain can think of that might be in a museum gift shop, they have it and more. Well, maybe not everything, but I'm in awe of the shop and the wares they have. Oh, and you don't need to pay admission to shop at the store!
4) They have a dining place inside called the Cafe Asia. I admit, I've not eaten there, but the menu looks delightful. Just like the store, you don't need to pay admission to eat  here.
5) The staff is friendly and very helpful.
6) The place has an activity room just for children. Check it out!

Love love love this museum. It's fun and you will learn if you let it teach you something.

I'm going back the next time I'm in town.

Love,

Alex L.
author: Alex L.

description:
What a great place to just wonder around and forget about what else is going on ... I came here for the first time about 2 weeks ago ... I was intrigued to check out the Bali exhibit and everything else they have for show .... 

The museum has a great layout, lots of interesting artifacts in which they separate by floors and by countries and time periods .... my four hours flew by ...

All in all its a great way to kill time and learn a little while your at it ... Its cheap and in my opinion worth it ... 

* Funny side note* While there I got to watch a kid get his shoe caught within the escalator, made me laugh a bit ... (Hey! he was not hurt so its ok I laughed.) 

:)
author: Anthony S.

description:
What a fantastic museum!  Three floors of dedicated Asian art including special exhibits.  I wish we had had more time and I'll definitely be back.  We were there for 3 hours and unfortunately only got through the Shanghai exhibit and 1/2 of a floor.  I love the way it's laid out with reference to the history of religion and its influence on art.  I'm not art-saavy by any means so I especially appreciated the brief informative background plaques with each piece.   

At $17 for admission, it's a great bargain for a cultural experience.  Even so, will definitely try to make first Sundays free, courtesy of Target!
author: Heather s.

description: This is a BEAUTIFUL museum.  Fantastic staff.  Peaceful ambiance.  Don't forget to go to Cafe Asia--the best museum restaurant I've ever been to.  A must-see when you're in town!
author: Virginia C.

description:
This is a review for the LIBRARY at the ASIAN ART MUSEUM.

This is an amazing resource. It's a bit of a hidden gem. You need to make an appointment to visit. It's a research library only -you can't borrow books. 

The collection is AMAZING. Every book you could ever dream of. Some were so old and hand bound and beautiful - I didn't think we should be allowed to touch them.  The librarian was great - so friendly and really excited about what he did! 

A wonderful experience. I definitely will be going back soon.
author: Khloe M.

description:
The Asian Art Museum is a really fantastic SF locale, and it was very much worth the student-price I paid.  Due to some timing issues, I didn't get to spend a leisurely 3+ hours to browse the museum but it's very possible to power-browse all three floors in 2 hours.  

The art is organized chronologically and then by country starting from top-down.  That said, I probably learned more about Hindu and Buddhist art and religion in that one day than I have in a life time...the entire third floor and some of the second floor is dedicated to it.  The Chinese, Japanese and Korean exhibits come a little later, and I especially admired the ceramic work from these countries.  All in all, it's very fascinating.  Unfortunately, the Shanghai exhibit had just closed and I didn't get to chance to see any other changing exhibits.  I will be back for another go-around and really look long and hard at each and every description!
author: Ivana Y.

description: The Asian Art Museum is one of my favorite museums in the world. Right up there with the British Museum, the Smithsonian, and the National Archeological Museum in Athens. A true cultural gem.
author: Shalom O.

description: Great museum, but it's kind of small compared with other museums that I've been to. The Terra Cotta Warriors is not attractive for me cause I've been to Xi'an, the place where they come from.
author: Ji C.

description:
I'll need to go back...I only had enough time to view the Shanghai exhibit this weekend. Phenomenal.  

And I'll need to get a real tour guide.  The one I saw on Saturday had her whole tour group crackin' up. It's not too cool to laugh alone with one of those 1990's cell-phone-looking contraptions pushed up against the ear.  
 
As a DC native, museums were an important part of my edutainment.  I'm looking forward to spending more time here...
author: Kat M.

description:
I love a good musuem and this was really good.  

The first thing I noticed was the prime location right across the street from City Hall which is a great looking building in itself.  I was greated by the security guard and then went inside to pay.  They actually have a coat check!  Which means I didnt have to carry my bag around with me the entire two hours I walked around.  I went in the middle of the day and there weren't many people inside.  Perfecto! 

The museum is set up as a timeline and held some really nice pieces of work.  It started with Buddhism and ended with lots of Artifacts from China.  They have a rather nice collection of Imperial robes both formal and informal for the royal family. 

The gift shop was also nicely stocked with postcards, jewelry and reading material.  There were also a couple of restaurants.  There was a new exhibit on Bali but I didn't think it would interest me so I passed on it.  Now I regret that decision, some of the art that I saw in the brochure was spectacular.  Oh well, hopefully the exhibit will still be on display at the end of summer.
author: Ayanna H.

description:
I love museums.  Obsessed, even.  Blame my parents for bringing me to museums almost every weekend when I was a kid.  Or blame it on the fact that growing up in the Washington, DC, Metropolitan Area, free museums are the norm, and it's "the THING to do" when people come to visit (and people always come to visit). So we would take advantage of it and go to the Smithsonian Mall to patronize the museums (note: my favorite is currently the Hirshorn).

So when I first moved to San Francisco and discovered (gasp!) that we had to PAY to go to a museum?  Whaaaaaat?  NO WAY.  However, I quickly learned from my classmates that this is the norm in most of the rest of the world who grew up outside of the Bubble that is Washington, DC.  

Anyway, that is why although I live almost across the street from the Asian Art Museum, I have been there TWICE since I moved to San Francisco.  Hey, I'm a poor, broke student.  (Note:  even if you ARE poor and broke like me, it really is no excuse not to go to the Asian Art Museum-- they're free ever first Sunday of the month.  In other words, I just suck at going to museums out here.  Oh, if you do decide to go on a first Sunday, go early because the line WILL wrap around the block, and you WILL have to wait.)

The exhibit currently up (which I am reviewing now) is Shanghai.  I went to the Thursday Night special event last night, which is a $10 entrance fee ($11.50 online) to go after hours, drink some wine (pay at the bar).  We got to see a performance by Coco Zhao, a Shanghainese Jazz singer.  I absolutely ADORE jazz, so I thoroughly enjoyed myself.  Not only that, but in my spare time, I love creating art-- painting, drawing, etc.  This night was definitely perfect for me.  I got to dress up, look pretty, look at beautiful artwork, and hang out with friends.  There is definitely some amazing artwork on display.  We didn't get to finish seeing everything on the upper floors (I am debating going this coming Sunday for the first Sunday free entry!), but the Shanghai exhibit was definitely intriguing.  

The artwork from the 1920s showed Asian women dressed in Western garb.  Strange.  If you've watched Stephen Chow's movie, Kung Fu Hustle, you'll know what era I'm talking about.  First, the style of the artwork is clearly extremely Western-influenced (not just in terms of the subjects-- there is less calligraphy or sumi-e brush on rice paper, instead there is more oil on canvas, watercolor on paper, etc.), the subjects themselves are dressed in corsets and dresses rather than qipao or more traditional Chinese robes, and even the buildings look very boxy and Western, with balconies and pillars.  Very interesting.

The performance by Coco was excellent as well.  I can listen to old jazz forever and a day, and it was very strange (but cool!) to hear Chinese coming out of his mouth to melodic tones and patterns that are normally associated with Western cultures.  :D

I think, however, the highlight of my night was getting the chance to make prints (similar to woodblock printing, except we used Styrofoam).  I got to draw to my heart's content.  We drew out a picture/design and carved it into the Styrofoam and then roll on the ink and print it onto one or multiple sheets of paper.  LOVED it.  I felt like a kid again.

Maybe it's time to quit my day job and become an artist.
author: Jeanne Y.

description:
So, I haven't been to the museum to see the art, but I was at the museum recently for a wedding.  It is an absolutely beautiful space to have a wedding.  My friends held their wedding reception in the atrium just past the entrance; even though there were a few hundred of people at the wedding, it was an intimate space that enabled people to feel as though they were very close to the couple.  The reception was held upstairs in a room with really high ceilings - a beautiful, wood-paneled room that was, again, large but felt intimate.

I know that the museum requires wedding parties to choose from a list of vendors and usually that translates into unappetizing food.  But I was quite impressed with the food...but not sure who the vendor was.  The only negative is that they don't open the doors to the museum until 15 minutes before the ceremony, so some people had to stand outside...but generally, the space was great.
author: Wendy L.

description:
It's a chill museum to go to especially if you want to learn something about Asian culture. Lots of stuff on display to show the diverse nature of Asians. Too bad they didn't have a whole lot of Filipino artifacts and art there (when I went to a museum in the Philippines, they had a lot of great stuff over there). I was impressed with the Yoshitoshi display of his art. Storytelling of the time from transitioning from the old traditional Japan to the more westernized one. The colors were so clear and it looked more like beautiful drawings than paintings. Too bad the manga display they had there were only for "members". Whatever.

Funny thing is that there's a "coat check", but not a bag check. I guess I didn't hear the guard clearly as I went up to the third floor he approached me in a nice way and said that backpacks like mine aren't allowed to be in the museum they must go in the "coat check". Alright sir. There you go.
author: Gerard Y.

description:
I, too, went to the Mochitsuki event with Kagami Kai.  If you have little ones with you, you have to get there early.  It is a great New Years celebration (taking place this year on January 3rd).  I arrived at 11:20 and it took nearly 30 minutes to get a ticket and get inside.  The event is about 75 minutes long, but totally fascinating and the audience can participate.

I strolled through the rest of the museum at a quick pace, but will definitely go back.  Another cool event is the ringing of the bell on New Years day, which I missed this year.  Oh, well, there is always 2010 (yoinks).
author: Will A.

description:
Attended the opening night party for the Asian American media. Great event! Amazing Asian art and sculpture! Edison Chen was there! 

Was also here a couple of weeks ago for the Kristi Yamaguchi book signing. She went from being a figure skating superstar to a children book writer. "Dream Big Little Pig" is a cute book, and I had it signed off to my future children! :)

Looking forward to more wonderful events to be held in this museum.
author: Sweet P.

description:
The Shanghai exhibit is worth viewing if you are interested in Chinese history. Also, the Japanese section has some colorful displays right now.

Did I mention FREE audio tours??? Wowzers
author: Katherine B.

description: We made a special trip to SF for the Terracotta Warriors exhibit this week (Tues.) and it was the best of all worlds. Getting into the City was a breeze. Parking was a breeze and getting through the exhibit was so convenient for old folk and bad feet (I didn't have to walk too much).The items in the exhibit were totally worth-while. Not to be missed. Only a few weeks left. It will not disappoint. Also, they allow cameras (with no flash)! We did not stay in a SF hotel. Went to Pacifica to make it extra special trip to take in the beach and ocean. Same cost (minus the extra parking $$ for SF) and only a 30 min. drive.
author: Michele P.

description:
Generally when I'm visiting a museum, be it the MFA in Boston or the Art Institute in Chicago, my favorite galleries are those showcasing eastern art. I generally leave these galleries wishing there were a bit more, but after my trip to the Asian Art Museum in S.F., I realize that - as with a lot of things in life - more isn't always better.

There's certainly a lot to see on the museum's 3 floors (although the bottom floor is mostly gift shop and cafe), but, in my opinion, very little diversity. The museum covers a wealth of time periods and regions, but the collection seems a bit heavy on the statuary. How many granite renditions of Avalokiteshvara does one really need to see?! Personally, I'd liked to have seen some more paintings, sketches, or other modes of expression represented.

A worthwhile stop for any museum-going traveller, but for me a bit of a letdown.
author: Hugh R.

description:
One of the more wheelchair-accessible and disabled-friendly art museums in SF. There are often large-print versions of the exhibit tags (usually in a binder near the entry to the exhibit) for low-vision folks, and the exhibits are generally visible from a wheelchair (not well above my head) and well-lit. 

The AAM is in a beautifully re-purposed building which was formerly the SF Main Library. The building alone is worth seeing, both for the old parts and the way it's been modified. While in general I and my wheelchair are NOT a fan of stairs, the main staircase is absolutely gorgeous (best viewed from the entryway and again from the upper level after taking the elevators). There are benches to sit on for those who get tired of walking, although on crowded visits (free days and the evening tours) these can fill up. However, the special exhibits and timed tours are generally not overly crowded. 

The standard exhibits include some real gems and are informative without being overwhelming. These largely focus on items of decorative art, pottery, sculpture, etc. and relatively few textiles, with some lovely ancient Buddhist stone carvings as well as some modern pieces. 

Their MATCHA hipster evening programs are often very interesting as well as educational, and their exhibits and weekend programs always seem to include a child-friendly area and/or craft project. 

Their special exhibits have lately included some "first time in the US" and otherwise rare and difficult to see items. I've enjoyed their offerings enough to get a membership.

They also work with the local communities, often hosting art festivals, local Asian artists, craft workshops and much more. There's an annual New Year's bell-ringing and other seasonal offerings for various Asian holidays, festivals and so forth. 

The restaurant is a bit pricey but tasty and accessible. Gift shop is a little narrow but has a surprisingly good selection of books.
author: Anne K.

description: The breadth and depth of Asian art here was better than I've seen anywhere else, covering most areas of the continent, and from ancient times to the present day, with a sensible layout by country and time period.  Unfortunately, I was in town right before the Terracotta army exhibition started and missed it, which is really disappointing considering the rave reviews it's getting on here.  Still, the permanent collection was worth seeing on its own.
author: Mike W.

description:
I came here for an event party during the evening. This museum covers many Chinese, Japanese and Korean art. I managed to take a peek of the Beyond Golden Clouds showcase. I was pretty amazed how the art stood out and it is quite enjoyable. I really like the design of the staircase going up to the 2nd floor. It really reminded me of some mansion I've been to long time back.

I would come back to see more exhibits in the future.
author: Eric E.

description: Beautiful artworks, friendly, a world-class collection, and great events, including performances, artist demos. Storytelling Sundays at 1:00 in the galleries for adults and kids. The cafe is excellent, too.
author: Jeff B.

description:
ASIAN MUSEUM HITS THE SPOT AGAIN!

The asian art museum recently held an amazing collection of Ming Dynasty art pieces. It's current exhibition on Shanghai: Art of the City is likewise well worth seeing. I love the new location proximal to the Main Library (although a little difficult/lengthy for me to access via public transportation). I like going thursday nights when it is open late.
author: J E.

description: We finally went here for the first time for the Warriors exhibit and it was awesome. Loved the gift shop too, my wife got a gorgeous Chinese necklace for a very reasonable price. Sorry we haven't become members until now but better late than never.
author: Scott O.

description:
Went to the Samurai exhibit at the Asian Art Museum with my dad and son. The 8yo found plenty of cool things to see there beyond just the great armor and weaponry of the Samurai. I don't care for the way the small first floor galleries that hold the Samurai exhibit are laid out though.  No clear traffic flow, too much doubling back to see things or being unable to get around small groups blocking the way.  The 2 upper floors don't have that issue.

We had lunch at the museum, which had a nice variety of fairly tasty offerings. Since it was a lovely day, we ate outside, and afterwards tackled the upstairs galleries with all their statuary, carvings, and cool objects. 

This museum is very easy to get to on BART...but between BART's latest price hike and lunch, our "free" day (for KQED members) set the three of us back $65.  Kids 12 and under are free every day though...which is cool.
author: Linda M.

description:
I've been looking forward to seeing the Samurai exhibit since months before it opened. I finally went today, with my 4-month-old in tow, but never got past the security guy. 

See, I use a baby carrier rather than a huge-ass stroller, and a backpack rather than one of those $100 diaper bags that hang on one shoulder and hurt your back because they're so stuffed with toys, wipes, blankets and other gewgaws. But when I got to the doors of the AAM, I was told I was going to have to check my backpack. 

"You can borrow one of our strollers for free," the man said. "Then you can take your bag inside."

I asked why my pack would be OK if I borrowed one of their strollers. He pointed at a sign that said it was policy not to allow backpacks. That didn't make any sense at all, but I went with it. 

"But it's a diaper bag," I said.

"It's our policy," he said. I think something was getting lost in the translation. 

Here's the problem: my baby has never been in a stroller, and putting her in one would almost ensure that she'd start screaming. To soothe her, I'd have to feed her. And for that I'd need my bag, and I couldn't tell whether I was going to have that with me or whether I'd need to stash it in coat check. 

In other words, because of my choices, which would have ensured a happy, quiet baby in the museum, I was being asked to do a number of things almost guaranteed to disturb the other patrons -- all because they're presumably worried that I'm going to stuff some artifact in my backpack while nobody's looking. 

I accept that I chose not to take them up on their stroller offer. But I don't think a total blackout on backpacks is in any way patron-friendly, especially if it's because they're assuming everyone with a pack is a potential thief. Now it looks like I won't ever get to see the Samurai exhibit, because I no longer want to give the AAM my money.
author: Beth W.

description: Went to Free Target Sunday day to see the Daimyo exhibit, I arrived 15 minutes before the opening and the line outside was around 2 of the blocks but got in 40 minutes.  The exhibit was small but full of good exhibits and loved the various docents located throughout the museum.  Didn't check out the other areas, have seen them before and came for the Samurai exhibit.  Did get street parking across from the museum so lucked out there.  There is a small farmers market behind the museum.
author: Deb N.

description:
Went there for Lord of Samurai, not bad. Definitely was interesting on reading about the clothing, the sword, and life style. I was disappointed that I couldn't bring my camera into that exhibit though. There are couple of displays of armors from different eras and wow, they look amazing. The craftsmanship and the time it probably took to assemble one is unbelievable. Of course, there is always the swords with its sharp beauty. 

The rest of the museum was pretty interesting. I think my parents would gone nuts over the jade section.
author: Derrick L.

description:
Went on a Sunday mid-day visit and the place was pretty empty, which was nice.  The museum itself has great architecture and it's just a nice place to just sit and relax if you have that time. 

The exhibits were well thought out and I like the free audio self-guided tour.  No pressure!  

I'm a member so I'll definitely go back when there are special exhibits going on.  I just missed the Shanghai one, but the lady from the info desk said it wasn't one of their better exhibits.  I was slightly surprised by her honesty, but hey, she kept it real for me.  

I'll be back and not on a 1st Sunday when I heard gets super crowed because of the free admission.  EEkks!
author: Meshell C.

description:
I loved the Japanese, Chinese, and Indian art in the museum. We came here after brunch on a whim to explore the Shanghai exhibit. The exhibit wasn't as large as I had thought it would be but we ventured upstairs to the other Asian cultures and enjoyed that even more. 

My favorite part was seeing all the Japanese weapons and how elegant and detailed their WEAPONS were! Just makes you appreciate things in different ways. 

We walked through the Korean exhibit and found there was nothing really THAT interesting. It was probably my least favorite area in the museum. I was actually a little bit disappointed. 

Not a bad price to see both the Shanghai exhibit and the rest of the museum. We probably paid $12/pp for both. We paid the student price. Students, if you like art and history, this is a must see!
author: Kat T.

description:
AAA discount: Buy one ticket, get the 2nd half off.
Still, this place is wonderfully worth a full price ticket. Beautifully filled and laid out. Too many things to see in 1 day, so a multiple-day visit is in order.
The cafeteria offers decent mid-museum snacking treats and soothing piping hot tea.
If you have an aversion to children or ridiculously large crowds, skip visiting on the first Sunday of the month. Your visit might not be free but you will be able enjoy the museum with your sanity intact.
author: Loli L.

description:
I have to agree with a previous posters that the managers here are condescending and rude. 

One of the managers answered a cell phone call while I was interviewing for a job here. I would never accept a job offer where they treat their potential employees so very rudely. 

These people need to learn some manners.
author: J G.

description: A very nice collection of Asian art.  The collection is well curated and interesting.  My only complaint is that information is a bit uneven in some of the exhibits.  Some need more explanatory text and some just need larger text.  Still a great experience if you like Budha statues.
author: Paul T.

description:
If you think you're going to go to this museum more than a couple times a year and you're a couple a membership is a good deal. It's $75 a year for a couple and that includes entry into all the special exhibits. It also gets you in a shorter, faster line when things are busy.

Avoiding the free Sundays is my only criteria, it's nice to hit the museum when it's relatively sane.

Taking advantage of the docent lead tours is a great way to see the special exhibits.
author: Mark P.

description:
I give the Museum 4 Stars, but their MATCHA Event Series gets 5. I would definitely recommend attending then if there's one that sparks your interest.

We went fairly early I thought (5:30). The theme was ghost stories and just as we arrived one of their storytellers (bards?) was preparing to lead a tour through the Japanese wing and tell two tales there. Definitely enjoyable, although you don't have much time to admire the exhibits if traveling with a docent. 

We saw both performances of Brenda Wong Aoki and composer Mark Izu. While both the girl and I were familiar with the folklore Brenda told, I've never experienced anything like the fusion of music and her animated, hypnotizing style of storytelling. There were some slightly adult references mixed in, but nothing you couldn't bring a child to (which several parents did).

In-between Brenda and Mark's sets we went back to the Japanese wing. We barely finished that before 9:00 pm came and the museum closed. 

I would recommend following them on Twitter, as well. They post interesting links to Asian news events and status of the museum industry as a whole.
author: Justin B.

description:
Lord knows that I long to be a samurai warrior when:

-I get jumped walking home from school
-a driver cuts me off 
-douchebags holler
-metermaid gives me a ticket EVEN as she sees me rush to the car

So I thought to educate myself on the history of the samurai aside from endlessly watching these kill bill, crouching tiger movies. It was also a chance to discover the breathtaking art collection from the multifaceted countries of Asia

As I made my way pass these tourists' protruding backpacks, strollers, teachers, students..I opened my eyes and saw before me not just an expansive building full of wonder but an out of this world samurai exhibit that describe its history through complete beautiful displays of different samurai artwork and literature as well as vivid descriptions of religion, philosophy & way of life. There was also a live enjoyable session of samurai sword fighting to capture the moment.

Aside from the Samurai exhibit attraction, be sure to see all the other countries' beautiful works of art:

1st level: Samurai exhibit
2nd level: China, Korea and Japan
3rd level: Southeast Asia, South Asia and China

 I did notice there were not a lot of artwork displayed on Southeast Asia. I imagined there were more so especially from the Philippines. 

Great museum.
author: Charmian D.

description:
One of my favorite museums in San Francisco!

I really like their current location since they had ample room to expand and showcase many of the wonderful pieces of art they had. I like how  the museum is spacious and full of natural light. 

The first floor normally holds the special exhibits. I came here on Mother's Day (since it was free) to catch the last day of the Bhutan exhibit. Tons of gorgeous artwork from Bhutan and the two monks were really wonderful. I had never seen or heard much of the artwork and I loved hearing the stories of their deities. The sand pictures were gorgeous. 

Then on Father's Day, I came back to see the Lords of the Samurai Exhibit. I've always been fascinated with Japanese history and hearing about how the Tokugawa family lived through the times was wonderful. I loved the armor, the tapestries, the swords, and the tea ceremony sets. There's not a huge amount of armor and swords (which disappointed my friend) but the sheer amount of history of some of the pieces is amazing. 

The other two levels exhibit more of the regular collection. I enjoyed the Japanese art section as well as some of the Southeast Asian ones. 

You can pick up a little handheld phone for an audio self-guided tour. Or, for the special exhibit, you can have a guided tour and ask lots of questions. 

The gift shop is chock-full of interesting things to buy and is a bit on the pricier side. Still, little samurai figurines and lots of books on Japanese culture are for sale in there. 

It's one of my favorite places to just relax for an afternoon in SF.
author: Julia W.

description:
I apologize. I really loved the Asian Art Museum when it was at the De Young. The ambiance is not the same at the new location.

If you were a fan of the old location at Golden Gate Park, be prepared to long for the backdrop of the old building. Some of the showcase pieces are lost in the shuffle at the new location.

The art is still breathtaking. The crowds and modern feel of the location just don't work for me. Chalk it up to nostalgia.
author: Christina N.

description:
Thank you, Target, for free admission (first Sunday of the month).  This is a great way to check out the museum for the first time.  

The building is gorgeous--the renovation blending the old with the new is invigorating.  However, I felt they could have done a better job providing historical context for the (admittedly well-laid out) exhibit, for those of us who were not too familiar with the history of this region.  For example... I found myself looking up the differences between Buddhism and Hinduism on my iPhone, disengaging from the exhibit, because it seemed to gloss over this detail.  

Overall, a good experience.
author: Chris L.

description: It's Free on the first Sunday of the month. So, everyone should take advantage of this. I stopped by this past Sunday, didn't realized it was free. To my surprise how beautiful it was inside. Three levels of beautiful art, artifacts, history of all parts of Asia. There is a nice cafe and bookstore on the first level. And every level has a so much to see. I felt kinda lost at one point, wasn't sure where the maze will take me. But, I found every section of the museum to be fascinating. I took tons of pictures for my mom to see, cause she's from China, and she loves all the buddha stuff. Next month, I'm going to take her along with me.
author: Jenny W.

description: Gorgeous vast collection and hard to absorb the wonder of it  all in one day.  The building itself is a work of art ,skillfully blending old and new.  The museum was very quiet, almost deserted on a Friday afternoon.  Intriguing audio tour is offered.
author: Bleep S.

description:
Took advantage of the FREE admission this last Sunday and it was well worth it. Especially since it was my first visit to the AAM. 

The special Samurai exhibit was absolutely incredible. Such an educational display of extravagant armour, tapestries, swords, etc. I highly recommend checking it out before it's gone. 

The architecture of this building is beautiful. Lots of natural lighting and tiny details in the ceilings and walls. 

I love FREE and I love museums.
author: Kelly M.

description:
Entertainment and enlightenment at a bargain price. 

THE MUSEUM ITSELF 

I have been to the Asian Art Museum before, and enjoyed walking the several floors, discovering the variety of art from that vast area we call Asia. One piece of the Japanese god of passion impressed me, as he looked extremely angry. Well portrayed, because anger is one of the most common and one of the easiest to invoke. Sometimes it was amazing to see contrasting works in adjacent rooms, because the arts of Asia were so varied. The building itself was a work of art, as it was part of the Beaux-Arts Civic Center complex, the former main branch of the SF Public Library. 

One day was not enough to enjoy all that the Museum had to offer. 

AFGHAN HIDDEN TREASURES 

We went to see the Afghanistan Hidden Treasures, from the National Museum at Kabul. $12 each got us in the door, and another $3 each got us audio tour wands. Unlike the DeYoung, the Asian Art Museum did not have a special admission surcharge for the visiting exhibit. 

Four archaeological sites were represented in three rooms. We saw lots of detailed work in ivory, some amazingly sophisticated glass work, and some gold and silver work from various sites. There were interesting pieces done in alabaster, schist, porphyry, turquoise, and many other materials. A silver plate inlaid with gold was one of the first impressions, illustrating a mix of cultures from across the world and a skill of which a modern smith would be proud. Evidence of the influence of India, Babylon, Persia, and Greece were clearly pointed out in the interpretive signs and the audio tour. There was more, much more to be seen than the tours indicated, though. With open eyes we discovered much of the fascinating complexity and beauty of the Silk Road civilizations that were in the territory we now call Afghanistan. 

This exhibit is worth a trip just for itself. I would recommend seeing this on a weekday, while the majority of the population is busy at work. The exhibit was overwhelmed by the audience on Saturday. Thursdays, the museum is open until 9 pm. That would give one more chance to see the Afghanistan Hidden Treasures in the evening, as the exhibit ends on January 25, 2009. 

Here's a preview: http://ngm.nationalgeographic.com/2008/06/afghan-treasures/barnes-photography
And, of course, the expected one:  http://www.asianart.org/afghanistan.htm
author: David D.

description:
Samurai Exhibit

2 thumbs up!!

But I wish there was more than just 3 rooms..should of had like 100 rooms..never enough rooms for the Samurai!!!

I wish we could of took photos, but its probably because some idiots would probably be using flash ruining the artifacts. Why do people do that@?! I was at Monterey Aquarium one time and they have a huge sign saying no flash photography and this one dumb girl with a nice DSLR takes a picture and FLASH right on the poor fish..what a dumb ass..

but anyways though, it was a very educating experience and it made me love the world of the Samurai even more than I already do.
author: phillip w.

description:
No point in reviewing the musem since there are so many reviews already. 

But what I will say is that I've been to two parties here and they have been phenomenal. So if you are considering throwing a party or attending a party here, do not hesitate. The first floor is a fantastic location to mingle and of course to view exhibits. The natual lighting gives it a really warm vibe. Just remember no drinks or food in the exhibit halls.
author: Roger H.

description: Came here with a friend for his assignment. Realized how amazing ancient Asians artists and sculptors were.
author: Ruiyu W.

description:
I guess it's odd to be re-posting on this place again, but I was chomping at the bit to get to the Bhutan exhibit, and it finally opened today! Yay! It's rather simple, but does a captivating job of highlighting the role of Buddhism in Bhutanese life, with many items being shown outside Bhutan for the first time ever. 

Given that Bhutan is so poorly-known, it might have been nice to have more on everyday life, customs, etc...though I guess this is largely an art museum, and much of Bhutanese art revolves around religion. Eh, well.

I need to get a membership here.
author: Ramon E.

description:
Thursday matcha nights rock!! For only $10 you get to check out their regular exhibit, see their special exhibit (last night it was the Samurai!), listen to DJs spin, have special sake tastings and see swordsman demonstrations! the event goes from 5-9pm. what a deal!  

i think this was meant to be a singles event... there were lots of couples and friends... but not lots of "single to mingle" if you know what i mean

all in all, a great event :)
author: joyce l.

description: We were thrilled that with our visit here. There is a lot to see and everything is well displayed. We did pay the extra 5 dollars to also see the Bali Exhibit which both of us felt was money well spent. This is a great place to just wonder aimlessly and enjoy what you are seeing.
author: Edward B.

description:
I went here on a whim, after realizing I haven't done anything intellectual in at least a couple weeks, and have been in a work/ shopping in union square bubble. 
I liked it, I really did. It's a beautiful building, and it's huge. A lot of the art work goes back a thousand years or more, and I found a lot of the statues really interesting. Unfortunately, by the time I was getting over to the China exhibit, I was getting tired of reading at things and looking at things, and rushed through Korea and Japan. This museum has a large, beautiful collection, but it isn't very interactive.  I'd recommend it for people who are very interested in Asian Art, or their free first Sundays of the month.
The gift shop didn't really hold up to my standards for a good museum gift shop either. The cafe who boasts a "pan-asian" menu, has only a few things, and from what I remember, it didn't look that great. Skip it and go to one of local Asian places.
author: Montana O.

description: This review is just for the "Shanghai" exhibit just because that took up the whole day's visit (along with the late lunch).  My companion and I entered the museum around 1130am. It was free Target Sunday (the first Sunday of the month), but the special exhibit was $5 for this day which was no big deal. We spent to the first part of the exhibit (covering up to about 1949 when the Communists took over) and just that took almost 3 hours because we took the time reading the displays and studied many of them closely. We then had lunch at Cafe Asia located inside, and then by the time we finished the rest of it it was about half hour to closing. That was fine, I knew we can return for the regular exhibits anytime. I an so glad she reminded me about going on this day because I almost forgot about today being free Target Sunday. :)
author: H K.

description:
I came here because it was mandatory for my class. Prof told us that admission was cheap, $5 a person. So, imagine my surprise when I found out that the total for the two of us was $36. The Asian Art Museum is a special exhibit, and hence an additional $10 per person. Yes, $16 for me alone WITH college ID. My eyes bulged and my jaw dropped in horror, and then Y came to the rescue, whipping out his credit card.

So off we went, finding that the audio tour of the exhibit costs even more! We ended up just browsing about together. There were some pretty cool pieces, but nothing really wowed me. The internment-inspired art was very sad. There was one funny piece...a silver chair with a penises poking out all over it. Didn't look very comfortable.

I think that some of those artists are OCD. There was this one HUGE painting with just a bunch of specks...looked kinda like a cheetah coat.

One part that really disappointed us was the many typos in the placards which described the pieces. For example, one said that the man (god?) in the piece was holding a "star." We looked all over for the star but there was no star. It was a staff, which looks NOTHING like a star.

You'd think that they could proofread.

So, three stars for the overpriced semi-cool exhibit, and five stars for my boyfriend, who was super sweet about the whole thing and did a good job of masking any boredom, if he felt that...
author: K W.

description:
How am I supposed to rate a museum? What are the guidelines for rating a museum?

Reviews are all relative in the end; it all depends on the previous experiences at other museums.

For me, I've been to many museums in the past (it helped that I went to university near DC...), so they all kind of blur in my mind.

The difference between the museums here and the ones in DC is that all the museums here have admission fees (from what I can recall, most DC museums have free admission). My income doesn't allow me to pay $10+ to go to museums in San Francisco on a regular basis just yet. Sigh.

But, the good thing about the museums in San Francisco are the free days. 

Last Sunday was Target Sunday at the Asian Art Museum; I figured, "Hey, why not?" since it was free, and since I had seen the promotions all around the city for the Bhutan exhibit, I decided to take advantage of the free admission. It was a rainy day, but I felt the weather gave the right kind of cozy atmosphere for venturing through a museum.

The Bhutan exhibit was intriguing to look at, although I did expect to find a lot more than there actually was. There were monks there as well, partaking in some of the live exhibits. I highly recommend visiting the Bhutan exhibit before it ends in May.

As for the rest of the museum: well, I had seen the exhibits before, but it was still refreshing and calming to walk through the exhibits and see history unfold from the top floor downward. It takes at least 2 hours to get through the whole exhibit, but that time spent is well worth it.

I wouldn't recommend eating at the cafe inside since most of the food is heavily overpriced (then again, most museum food is overpriced). You'd find a better deal in food (and more authenticity) if you walk up Larkin Street and find Larkin Express (Burmese food!) or a few Chinese establishments. Saigon Sandwiches is also located on Larkin, but I haven't eaten there yet...I've heard it's quite popular though.
author: Helene K.

description:
Our family loves this place. I myself have probably been here a dozen or more times in the past nine years, but I just got back here in January for the first time since it moved to the old city library. I guess our favorite part of the new building was reading all the quotes about libraries, reading and literacy carved along the ceiling.

The man's two girls totally dug on the archeological dig going on in the library, and I suspect they learned more digging around with the Berkley student volunteers and identifying the bones and seeds they dug up than they have in their science class all year.

The man and I found the Afghanistan exhibit amazing and definitely world the drive up from the Central Valley by itself.
author: K. A. R.

description: This place is huge and well worth the $12-17 bucks per adult price. I recently came here for the Shanghai Exhibit and loved it- I also enjoyed the additional Japanese and Chinese and Indian art upstairs. If you can go to see the Shanghai Exhibit, I highly recommend it!
author: Lynn C.

description:
I love this museum. The permanent collection is vast and varied (modern and ancient art; ancient artifacts; etc.), and the special exhibits are always really interesting. I think I love it so much because I don't get to see this much art that spans all of Asia anywhere else.

The building is beautiful and easy to get around. The employees are nice. The museum store and cafe are both great. 

Every time I visit, I think to myself, "I need to come here more often." It takes a lot of time to get through the whole collection, especially if you see whatever special exhibition they have. So, plan a few hours or more than one trip. 

It is very easy to get to by public transit, too.
author: Mary C.

description: What an amazing SF gem! It's worth visiting if you have a whole day (or at least half a day), because you can definitely spend many hours  wandering through the different rooms and attending the various museum events. I also attended the free docent-guided History of Jade tour and the Architecture tour. The museum staff and volunteers were all incredibly friendly and absolutely thrilled to answer my questions. To top it off, the Asian Art Museum has free admission on the first Sunday of the month sponsored by Target.
author: Carrie W.

description:
This was my last stop on the free museum day sponsored by Bank of America. They offer free electronic audio handsets. I really enjoyed the additional information about the Indian & Thai gods and goddess. I saw small Chinese Jade pieces that were stellar. Unfortunately I couldn't find the Vietnamese gallery.

I took a bus across town to get here and noticed that there was a significant increase in the homeless in this area. I would be careful around here.
author: Susan D.

description:
Very nice museum. $17 to get in with the Emerald Cities exhibit.  We checked out the Emerald Cities exhibits which encompassed two rooms.  The collection on Burma was small which probably is because they are a pretty closed country. The Thai collections included furniture, scrolls, shrines and some other warrior pieces.

We wandered upstairs to Japan and India, but since it was almost closing, we had to hussle out of there.  I wanted to spend more time in the gift shop.
author: Natalie S.

description: This is one of my favorite museum based on content.  It's full of irreplaceable treasures to modern art.  It suits my tastes, galleries from old to new (anime).  I am glad it moved from Golden Gate Park to its new location.  It is now centrally located in SF across from City hall.  5 stars, another one of SF great attractions.
author: S F.

description:
Not huge fan of art, or rather I haven't quite learned to fully appreciate it.  I actually didn't take a visit to many of the exhibits.  Next time...

But as another reviewer posted, was here for the Asian American Film Festival Kick-Off Gala.  Fantastic set-up!  Very modern, very clean..I just felt artistic being here.  It's like the artifacts were rubbing off me..and I only had 2 drinks!

The layout of the place is more like a mall.  You have multiple level escalators and stairs that lead to many different exhibits.  They should do a nightlife in Asian Art Museum here..I'd go!  Parking was abundant on a weeknight since it's next to City Hall / Civic Center and they had the red carpet out.  Where's the paparazzi?
author: Yup S.

description:
I'd give it a five, but having screaming kids around while looking at Erotic Japanese scrolls is very, very distracting.

I went on the free day yesterday, but the parents seem to think it's okay to bring all three children into the erotic scroll section, when it clearly says on the door, children are suggested not to enter. 

I did enjoy the demonstration of Classical Indian Dance. The dancers were lovely and on point. However, with all of China present at the museum, it was loud and echoey throughout the small room. It's like the art world, became strollerville. Bhudda images were getting colored on, which although is technically Asian Art, is probably making Bhudda unhappy and covering his tummy from a stomach ache.  Wierdest find? Target symbol decorated origami paper. There's nothing I like more than the commercialism of a childhood past time of mine. They even had the dog with a dyed red bull's eye painted on around his eye. Poor doggie. It really was a spectacle and very overcrowded. 

The art itself is beautiful and the museum is laid out nicely, light and airy. I plan to go when it's full price. You pay for contemplation and study. Art as I understand is now for mass consumption and joined with a corporate financier you are bound by contract to survive. The issue is that it takes away from the beauty of the original works. Case in point:
 
It is a little unnerving looking at 1600 eroticism while  a kid is looking at me. I do have to say despite that, it was a beautifully drawn pussy. It looked like a lotus blossom. I don't understand how come the penises were blue though. In medical terms, that is a bad thing. 
I'm open to sexuality, but all parents should put boundaries. What? You gonna show the kid the large painted penises of Samurais as 'cultural' exploration and history? Please. That's what the Randall Children's Museum is for.  Age appropriate was not just a made up concept. Piaget is rolling in his grave.

It may be free, but it's not worth the headache.
author: J A.

description:
I should warn you that this review will get a little 'curatorial'. I did museum studies stuff at grad school. For me, what impresses at museums and galleries is not normal. Visitor flow patterns, spotlight angles, the wording of labels... these are the things that excite me. 
 
The basics: a great building. Airy and bright. The three story escalator ride is fun. The path through the galleries is direct, so there are none of those 'oh damn, did we miss a room?' sinking feelings. 
 
What I especially liked about the galleries in the AAM is that they are arranged to follow the spread of Buddhism through different geographic regions (South Asia, Southeast Asia, China, Korea, Japan). So often, museums are set up only to demonstrate "this is everything we've got". There's no concept beyond just showin' off some stuff. The overarching theme at the AAM brings meaning to the ordering of the galleries and to the display as a whole. (Yeah, admittedly, the theme crumbles a bit when we get to non-Buddhist Persia.) 

An earlier Yelper commented that the South Asian display seemed a little drab and dusty next to the shiny, sparkly stuff from China. I understand the sentiment but I thought the South Asian statues were fascinating and more relateable to me than, say, vases and laquerware. My date's impression of the South Asian sculptures: "Boobies! Boooobies!"

In general, the way the objects are displayed has been well thought out. It's possible to stand quite close to the cabinets to admire tiny artifacts without blocking your own light. The wall of jade pieces in the China area was very effective - you can see both sides of the pieces and the dramatic lighting emphasizes the carved relief.

One thing that bugged me was that one modest-looking Chinese bronze box was described in its label as being the most significant piece in the museum because of a particular inscription carved on the back. The box was displayed in a way that hid this all-important inscription. Hey - if something is interesting enough to mention on the label, let it be visible to the visitor! Interpretation should guide the eye and the mind.

I noticed that even after going through the whole building, I was not brought down by what I like to call 'museum drowse'. You know how it is: your eyes go hazy and your knees begin to buckle and you just can't look at another bronze Bodhisattva without collapsing into tears.... This did not happen to me at the AAM. So, yes, cool museum.
author: Andrea W.

description:
Spacious and clean enough to eat off the floor, the Asian Art Museum showcases a number of interesting exhibits throughout the year.  A visit here is not complete without checking out the gift store.  Always a sucker for a good bargain, I came for a visit on a Thursday night when the hours are extended and admission is only $5.  (It's free on the first Tuesday of every month.)  

I highly advise against coming here or to any other museum after a few drinks.  I never got to appreciate the art to its fullest.
author: Marsha Z.

description:
The Asian Art Museum proved a good schooling that one should always trust a hunch. My hunch was not to visit yesterday but the Lords of the Samurai seemed right down my alley of interest. Unfortunately the museum turned out to be a classy version of K-Mart in terms of their inflexibility, rudeness and un-empowered workstaff.

We dropped in at 4p to catch the museum and discovered about 45 minutes later that the staff were annoyingly and frequently directing us to begin to exit for closure at 5p. The Lords of the Samurai exhibit is impressive -- if small -- but $34 for an hour is not time nor value for us to take it in well nor to see anything else in the museum -- which we had maybe an extra 10 minutes that we stole in spite of the rude staff.

Unlike other quality museums we have visited, including San Fran's own deYoung that have the courteous policy to warn customers when one tries to buy a late-day ticket of the closure hours, or to offer discounted rates late in the day, according to the supervisor to whom we complained they have no policy to warn people of closure till after 4, and no discounts till 4:30. (We purchased at 3:55 and received no warning nor discount). There are no operating hours posted on the board at the desk where you buy tickets. They expected us to catch that on a single sign posted out on the steps at the front of the museum or to have come already informed. Perhaps a fair expectation, but unnecessarily unfriendly and inflexible.

In addition to the numerous rude watchstaff we found the staff at customer service desk unsympathetic and unempowered to address our complaint. "Please fill out a comment card," was as much service as we received until I kept insisting on getting a partial refund. Eventually a supervisor came on the scene who was also unwilling to sympathise with and address our complaint, offering no apologies and just reiterating the policy the customer service person already gave. The best offer I eventually got was they were willing to apply our tickets toward the cost of purchasing an annual membership which, of course, had little value considering we're visiting from out of town.

Unlike other museums that keep the gift store open for a little while longer if the normal exhibit hours are short, be advised that the whole lovely Asian Art Museum closes down promptly at 5 (except for Thursdays). And don't try to enjoy five or ten minutes longer.

It's always great to Yelp about a business whose policies, product and service exceed all expectations. In this regard the Asian Art Museum has policies that operate to remind me that I should expect no more than my own shortcoming to not notice the single operating hours sign standing on the steps out front.
author: Bryan J.

description: You don't need to know an obi from origami to recognize that this is one magnificent collection. Rather than demolish a part of San Francisco history, architects wisely incorporated the better design features of the former main library when they converted it into this extraordinary home for truly stunning Asian art and artifacts. You need the better part of a day to fully appreciate all that's here, and a return visit or two definitely is warranted. The interior is so warm and welcoming, the displays so beautifully arranged, that you'll want to pull up a bench and absorb the atmosphere rather than rush through. Bonus points for a small but fantastic gift shop, which not only reminded me how little I paid for the treasures I schlepped home from Thailand, but made me regret I hadn't bought a lot more.
author: Gourmet G.

description:
My god, it's full of boobies...

After six years renovation/relocation into the old city library building, the Buddhas are back on display. Seriously, I would wager there's no larger, more navel baring collection of Buddha bellies anywhere in the Americas. Walking from level to level, you really get a sense that you're walking through time, walking through Asia and following the spread of Buddhism across Asia.

I must mention that I found the informative plaques well written, easily digestible, and very educational. One gripe though: many of the Buddha statues are described as "Buddha in a sitting position," or "Buddha in a standing position." On one, a supplemental description even said something like, "Buddha found in one of the five common positions." My god people, maybe I give humans too much credit, but if you expect me to be able to read, I expect am able to realize if a statue is standing or sitting...! And as for common positions, yes, I would expect there are very few statues in poses such as:

-Buddha bowling
-Buddha doing a keg stand
-Avalokiteshvara, Buddha of Compassion, spread eagle
-Kwannon doing laundry

And even if there were such awesome statues, I don't think I would need the written description to figure them out. I can appreciate statuary on their knees at face value.

Mind you, it's not just Buddhas. There are Hindu boobies. There are Polynesian boobies. There are wooden ones, golden ones, even formerly golden ones --- worn down by the hands of ancient pilgrims waxing on, waxing off, I'm sure.

The new location is not as cool as the former. Parking is difficult, and the space seems smaller than the old space in the park. They fight this by trying to keep the space as open and airy as possible. Brightly colored walls, lots of glass and open rooms. It just feels too modern, when I'm looking at thousand year old boobies. I'm sure the curators would benefit from experience of other businesses where bevies of boobies are similarly displayed: dim the lights overall, to not distract from the main focus on the boobies, and add more spot lighting on each stellar pair. Oh, and maybe also a tip rail. Can I get change for a twenty? Singles, please.

P.S. You can thank Andrea W. for reminding me about the boobies. ;)

TIP!! The first Tuesdays of every month are FREE, 10am to 5pm.

TIP!! Thursdays are $5 with extended hours to 9pm.
author: Perci N.

description:
Teach me about Buddha!  Teach me about Shiva!  Teach me about the birth of civilization in Persia!  Tell me about Indonesia and the transition from Buddhism to Muslim!  Show me the meanings of the figures on the temples I saw in Thailand!  Tell me about Burma!  Great pieces of jade from China!  If you read hiragana, you can read the caligraphy on the shoji screen from Japan!  If you want to learn about samurai and check out a beautiful kimono you can do that as well!  The evolution of Buddhism in Nepal is rad!  My favorite part (it's temporary, so hurry)...The BASKETS!  They are unreal!  It's worth the $12 to check them out - unbelieveable!
Is my enthusiasm for this place getting through to you?!?!?!
author: ellyk E.

description:
I've been wanting to go here ever since I moved to SF.  I've always preferred Asian art to the western stuff (not to mention Asian architecture and furniture), but of course they don't teach you jack about it in school, so what do I really know about it?  Basically, nothing.

The AAM definitely fills that void, with extensive and informative galleries of South Asian, Southeast Asian, Tibetan, Chinese, Korean, and Japanese art.  Bear in mind that much of it (particularly the South Asian gallery) is almost more of an archaeological museum than an art museum, with lots of 1000+ year-old statues and useful maps showing spreads of different religions and such.

The museum is "paced" pretty well--I was able to make it through the whole museum in 3 hours without it getting tedious.  But I could have easily spent more time in the section on Chinese ink-on-silk scroll art, particularly the landscape works inspired by the scenery of Huangshan Mountain.  That stuff is just WOW.  Also, I love how they have a room called "Japanese Tea-Related Arts".

There are also a couple of temporary exhibits on the first floor.  The exhibit on Tezuka Osamu is a must for anime fans.  And for people (like me) who always feel a bit overwhelmed by the world of manga, it's a great introduction.

Didn't check out the cafe, but the gift shop is easily one of the best I've been to, in a sorely-tempted-to-blow-lots-of-money sort of way.
author: Wes M.

description: This place is amazing! I meant to review this place a while ago... the family and I came to see the Afghanistan exhibit. The sacrifices people made to get these artifacts on display.... wow! Our guide was really good, and after the tour we were able to wander on our own. Definitely worth it to visit this museum. I went browsing through the rest of the floors too, and there was just too much to see! I think I made my group impatient as I thoroughly examined all the exhibits. Whoops =P
author: Veronica C.

description:
Things I learned at the Asian Art Museum

1. If Pavarti the goddess looked anything like her sculptures, the Indians discovered boob implants long before the rest of the world.

2. Philipino burial jars are cool. Though the face and arms carved into the lids look more like a monkey than a man.

3. Most Japanese art started getting weird soon after they discovered dyes. 

4, Bhutan doesn't measure GDP, they measure Gross National Happiness.

5. There is a farmer's market at the Civic Center BART stop.

6. Also, I confirmed that most art doesn't move me. Hardly any of it even touches me.
author: Bob R.

description:
I was naive on exactly what the "art of basketry" was, having believed a basket was a basket was a basket. My simple mind pictured poor artisans using native plants to weave crude yet inexpensive products for local home use or for sale to the occasional tourist and nothing caught my attention until the Asian Art Museum hosted a special exhibit on Japanese basketry and my eyes were opened to an epiphany of sorts, a "basket case" of wonder . To say I was blown away by what I saw would be an understatement. This exhibit turned me on to how artistic perfection can be applied to bamboo basket weaving near impossible to describe. How could anyone describe an incredibly tight-woven basket that looked like a wave? Or another that looked like a conch shell? This exhibit, and my first visit to the museum  really sold me and I bought the book...a very rare thing for me and I spent most of the day enjoying the rest of the museum's holdings and took breaks to look through the book's remarkable images. After a tasteful lunch in the cafe, I finally made the trek back to my hotel to pen some notes about this beautiful exhibit and the museum itself. This place is so worth a visit and I hope to treat myself to many more outstanding exhibits here. I have posted 3 of the more interesting baskets for your marveling pleasure.

The location is ideal for a city walk-about and if you're still bored after your visit and want  to protest, City Hall is just across the street.
author: Robin Z.

description:
The Asian really trashed the main library building.  The galleries are poorly laid out, and the views are of HVAC units and roofs.  The first floor is built for parties, not for art, and the big grand staircase is visually blocked off by the ticket desks.
The Samurai Armor exhibit is very nice, but I remember seeing a similar show at the Asian when it was in GG Park, with much more in the exhibition, and that huge window overlooking the tea garden.  It was just enchanting!  I predict that the new Asian is soon going to be begging for subsidies.
author: Rob B.

description:
Visited last night for the first time, and I don't think I could've experienced it any better.

I was a guest to HOK's Holiday party which had rented out the Entire museum. While I could review the party itself, which was downright amazing, I'm glad I got to see the exhibits without the mad rush of the weekend crowd and 3 foot monsters running around touching every glass screen in site.

It's breathtaking to see items from 100 BC! It just makes you wonder if our iPods will be in displays years from now, and if people will look back at us and just laugh because our TVs weren't implanted into our heads.

The new Afghanistan exhibit is eye opening, and I have to say, what struck me the most about the various different cultures on display, was that there was a common bond amongst them all. 

Whether you lived in 100BC and lived at the opposite end of the world, there were similarities. Even without communication or intended thought, different cultures STILL had elements that were simply universal in their art.

It just signified the important component amongst all of us, which is our common humanity.

Yes, museums bring out the deeper side in me, but I can honestly say the Yelp Holiday party at the Exploratorium didn't get me thinking about science this way...
author: Mike K.

description: I visited this museum the other day for the first time and it has just become my favorite museum in San Francisco!. I can't wait to go back. So good i'm considering a membership. Go It's worth it!
author: Jay B.

description:
Whenever I visit the Asian Art Museum, I always find myself staring at the floor in the first floor gallery.  I know, I know, you are supposed to stare at the walls, not the floor.  But this one is special -  it's the one that's wood in very elongated small rectangles and polished to a warm dark shine.  I think it is the prettiest floor I have ever seen.  I must have that floor!

The building is wonderful too.  The exterior and structural details are Beaux-Arts style, while the interior is modern - designed by Gae Aulenti, the architect who did the Musee d'Orsay in Paris.  I love the idea of an Italian architect taking an existing American space and giving it an internal face-lift, then filling it with art from all over Asia.  You can either enjoy the large space and high ceilings of the main public areas, or spend some time up close with some beautiful art.  The Samsung Hall is particularly nice.

I have seen some wonderful special exhibits here, including the Geisha exhibit, Tezuka:  the Marvel of Manga, and tonight, Stylized Sculpture: Contemporary Japanese Fashion from the Kyoto Costume Institute.  

On the first Thursday of each month, the museum hosts an event called MATCHA, and for $5.00 admission, you can enjoy the museum in the evening hours from 5-9.  Usually they have some kind of interactive event on the main floor, as well as a DJ in the Samsung Hall with videos and a bar.  Depending on the theme, it can be either very crowded or more sedate.

What I usually come away with is not a huge impact of any one collection, but a quiet moment spent with a special piece.  Tonight that happened for me with one of the fossil displays in the Hiroshi Sugimoto:  History of History exhibit.  When art, or a found object, or a person's vision speaks to you...that is the essence of why we have culture.
author: Liz S.

description:
I really really wanted to have my wedding here. The grand ballroom was exactly how I envisioned my wedding. So why didn't I book the wedding here?

1) Timing: you can start your event til 630pm!! That is super late! 

2) Pricing: Just to RENT the place is $12K, it comes with NOTHING. Plus, you don't even get to really spend any time there!

Although I wanted to have my wedding here BADLY, it didn't make much sense if timing and pricing didn't work.
author: Denise L.

description: Excellent place. Great art and exhibits. Awesome cafe and food. My daughter loves it!
author: David S.

description:
Honestly...not on par with most of the museums in the City.

I would only go on the 1st Sunday of the month (free).

If you like Buddha statues/busts, this is the place to go!

The building is beautiful.  The Japanese exhibit is pretty cool, especially the photography exhibit.  However, it seems that Korea is almost completely overlooked.  The Korean section is lacking for sure.

I'm not Asian, so I'm not sure if I'm overly critical.  But, I am definitely a fan of the free days!

Last time I went there was a live Filipino dance/cultural festival going on that was really neat.  We checked out some native dances and music and I noticed that the Filipino community is kind of overlooked as well in the exhibits.

I guess I would like to see all of 'Asia' represented in the Asian Art Museum.  I'm sure there are tons of obstacles in getting the art necessary to support that...but...yeah.  More representation from Korea, Vietnam (especially with Little Saigon right up the street) and the Philippines would be great!
author: Tysen C.

description:
Things to do here before you get overwhelmed by the many, many big buddhas:

1.  Walk (clockwise, right shoulder in) around the Mani Wall on the outdoor patio; this is a collection of flat carved stones piled together, and is a Tibetan prayer ritual.
2.  Climb the marble staircase up to the Loggia; walk around reading the wise quotes carved high above the columns and windows.
3.  Check out the South Asian galleries on the third floor, where you'll learn about the origins of Buddhism and see some giant statues.  Some of the giant statues have large boobies.  This may/may not make you laugh depending on your maturity level.
4. Go to the second floor for Japanese Paintings & Screens, Tea-Related Arts, and this itty bitty little carriage that noble people used to have servants carry them around in.  It looks like an intricate wooden dog carrier.
5.  EAT AT THE CAFE!  Everything is fresh and delicious (I recommend the papaya prawn salad) and they have neat displays of curious Asian candy and knick-knacks.  If the prickly pear lemonade is a special, splurge.  Mm.  Refreshing.  Actually, do this first, so you can walk off lunch in the galleries.

Of course, there are a million more sights to be seen--this is a museum to get lost in, with meditative, dimly lit rooms and tons of information provided.  But hey, not everyone's a geek like me--and sometimes,  you've only got an hour or two--so definitely check out the above.  I plan to come back to do some more exploring soon.  This is a brilliantly planned museum, and a lovely place to learn.
author: Ellie L.

description:
I'm a museum lover, but growing up in DC I can be snobby about museums since I was spoiled with the Smithsonian.

This museum ranks right up there.  I was so amazed and surprised with everything it has to offer.  I was impressed with the wide variety of Asian cultures represented and with the overall selection of the museum.  There were so many artifacts in the exhibits, it just kept going and going and going.  I spent almost all day there and still didn't see it all.

Another plus is that in many of the exhibits you can actually take photos (sans flash).  I don't think I've ever been to a museum that allows that.  Very cool and very educational.

I attended the first Free Sunday and enjoyed the special events they had planned.  I saw both the Taiko drummers and the Chinese acrobats.  Both put on a great show.  There were plenty more special performances and tons of arts and crafts for all the kiddies.  If I was a parent I would have loved to have had my child participate.  So I highly recommend if you are a family, to go the first Sunday of every month, where it is not only free, but has plenty of activities.
author: Jen K.

description:
I've lived in SF for well over a year, and practically grew up here.  Still, my first time visiting was 12/28/08, to see the Afghanistan exhibit.

The Afghanistan exhibit was the star of the show, of course--the intricacy and craftsmanship of everything, particularly the jewelry, was amazing.  There was even a fountain cleverly built with weights so that when water ran through it, fish tails appeared to move.  

As for the rest of the museum--I wish I had gone when I was still studying East Asian history.  I and my companion particularly liked the jeweled daggers, and the sheer amount of religious artifacts is staggering.  In fact, that is my only complaint: several rooms are over-filled with similar stone Buddhas or Kalis or Vishnus.  You can easily miss something.

Much of the interior architecture is airy and open, making for a pleasant atmosphere, and at $12 ($7 for us students!), it's a lovely way to spend an afternoon.
author: Jennie K.

description:
I lived in San Francisco from 1994 thru 2002 and at that time the AAM was in Golden Gate Park, and despite living across the street from it for a time, I never made it to this museum. It has since moved to the old San Francisco Library building on United Nations Plaza. It's a beautiful museum, and the general admission (w/o special collection) is only $12 for adults. The price of the special collection was $17. At the time we visited it was an exhibition on Bali. We only had a couple hours to go before closing, so we opted out of the special collection fee. Todd went off on his own for a while, and I decided to do a free guided tour named, "Goddesses." The tour guide spent the time explaining the significance of the Goddess in Hindu and Buddhist cultures, comparing and contrasting Indian, Southeast Asian and Himalayan manifestations of the different Goddesses, in art and in their religious and cultural contexts. And it was FREE! Also, there were free audio self-guided tours. Extensive collections from India, Southeast Asia, Himalayan/Tibet, China, Japan, as well as modern art that is inspired by ancient Asian art and culture. I would like to go back and spend more than two hours. 

Small gift shop and a cafe (which we didn't visit.)
author: Elizabeth C.

description:
I went for the MATCHA "Shanghai Jazz" event last night (4/1).  It was awesome!  It is nice to be able to go to the museum on a weeknight, after work.  The special performance was amazing too.  A great way to spend a Thursday evening.  The next MATCHA event is June 3.

Definitely worth a visit any other time as well, this is one of my favorite museums in the city!
author: Erin D.

description: This is really a top-notch museum. The collection of buddhas from all across Asia are just stunning. The jade collection is magnificent. Museum staff are highly knowledgeable and constantly circulating throughout the exhibit. We went on Korean culture day, and there was literally an entire day of activities planned in addition to the normal exhibitions. A must-see for the San Francisco visitor!
author: Brian P.

description:
I love you, Asian Art Museum.  

The latest of exhibits I enjoyed here on Friday was the Bhutan Exhibit.  I found it fascinating.  

The sand art that the monk created was awesome and actually meeting the monk and speaking to him was amazing.  Almost spiritual.  

Aside from the group of obnoxious, loud and poorly behaved CHAPERONED students (and I'm talking freshmen, at least) that came bustling through on a field trip - it was a peaceful, lovely walk through the exhibits!

I wish there was more parking.  We got there around 1pm and had to find a garage.
author: Peggy N.

description:
Asian Art Museum, do you really need another review?

Probably not, but I'm going to write one anyway.

I think I must not be a very cultured person.  Don't get me wrong, I like museums, but after a little bit, all those little pieces of pottery and earthenware start to look the same.
