I don't understand their appeal.  I get that they were made a long, long time ago, but they look like they were made a long, long time ago in most cases!

I think I like shiny gold things.  The Asian Art Museum definitely comes through on the shiny gold things front.  The layout of the museum makes sense.  Its organized around several themes, one being the spread of Buddhism.  Perhaps my problem is my short attention span, but all the buddhas got a bit boring after a while.

There is also a Chinese art exhibit, a Japanese art exhibit and a Korean art exhibit.  The Korean art exhibit was a bit lacking, and was dominated by a calligraphy scroll from 2006.  

However, the visit to the museum was redeemed by the exceptionally cool Japanese woodblock print exhibit they have displayed right now.  They're all by the same person and have a theme of life and the supernatural.  You can also definitely see the manga connection through them.
author: elizabeth c.

description:
First - When in San Francisco the Asian Art Museum is a must see. Architect Gae Aulanti and co. took the urine soaked bum infested public library and turned it into a world class space once again. How proud the people of San Francisco must be to have this wonderful museum in their city.
Second - Try to get tickets to the Japanese  Way Of Tea (chanoyu). It is an ancient tea ceremony held in the museum's replica teahouse while audience members observe. My favorite part was the tea and sweets they serve after the ceremony. 
Last - The Asian rings in the New Year with the aptly named Japanese  New Year's Bell Ringing Ceremony. I always snag my little niece to come out and help ring that big bell.
author: Theresa H.

description:
Like most of SF's low brow who think they're high brow, I first made it to the Asian for the Geisha exhibit.  Okay so I read the book and was intrigued, cheesy I know.  I was stunned by the lack of line outside.  That is because it is hidden inside and so I was 20 minutes outside when my colleagues could have met me midline. Whatever, just beware of such trickery.

I can't say the rest of the existing collection inspired me to return.  A buddha statue, no way, its just like my yoga school.  Plus they're don't seem to be enough representations of all of Asia, which mind you, is a big continent to cover.
author: Sean S.

description:
I came here on their free day (1st Tuesday every month) when they had the exhibits on manga and managed to catch a screening of "My Neighbor Totoro". So I was happy. 

Pretty huge museum with 3-4 levels that is loosely arranged by the spread of Buddhism (from what I remember of the museum brochure).  Asia is pretty dang big.  Ground level had the special exhibits. I loved how they set up the manga exhibit, very colorful.  I plan to go back someday as I didn't get to see everything in one day. (Well, this was an uninformative review. Just go see it on their free day.)
author: Yan E.

description:
I have been here several times. I went when there was an exhibit from Indonesia, and I learned a lot about their culture, such as how Indoneisa is mostly Muslim, how burial processes are done there, and how they were once controlled by the Netherlands. I met and saw an Indonesian painter and his masterpieces (That was awesome). 

I also went when there was a samurai exhibit, and I learned a lot about how samurai culture and history. I did not realize how heavy samurai helmets were, until I tried one at a photo area where people could take photos of them wearing a samurai helmet. I learned how Miyamoto Musashi's Book of Five Rings was originally written on scrolls. There was artwork on the world's first novel: The Tale of Genji.  It was cool that the Hosokawa family, a legendary family lineage back to 1500's Japan, lent this exhibit to the Asian Art Museum. 

There is a lot of art and history from India, China, and Japan. There is some from Korea, some from Southeast Asia, and some from Mongolia, but not as much as I would have wanted to see.

The place is family friendly, and the restaurant has good food, though some of the waiters can be rude. The book store is nice, and there are different tables where people can do activities. The museum is three stories, and it is where one of the SF libraries used to be at. 

Flash photography is not allowed, but you can take photos, as long as they are not in the exhibit areas. The exhibit areas are three rooms on the first floor that show amazing art and history from countries in Asia that are temporary to the museum. 

The place is right near the new building of the SF library, really close to SF City Hall, really close to BART underground station, and close to the SF Symphony. The place is great for those that are into Asian cultures, Asian history, or people that are just into history and cultures. Having a student ID lowers the prices for students.
author: DJ Guan Yu M.

description:
I have real issues with this place. It's not a terrible museum, but if I could take over the place, I would in a heartbeat. 

The building itself is lovely. The work done to remodel the old Main Library is superb. The atrium is filled with light but the gallery spaces are dark enough to protect the pieces.

It's the focus of the museum itself that I can't stand. I studied art history in school and I have a deep affection for the arts. That said, I believe that the Asian Art Museum is less about art and more about anthropology. It's a fine line between art and anthropology but honestly, how many jade pieces can you view without becoming completely bored? 

The top three floors are dedicated to the Museum's permanent collection, much of which came from Albert Bender. It's a large collection of Asian antiquities, some are incredibly old and are worth it to see the handiwork. The collection of Hindi and Buddhist art is amazing. However with a majority of the Museum devoted to the permanent collection, it doesn't bode well for repeat viewers. Once you've seen the upstairs galleries, there really isn't too much of a need to go back. Trust me. I've been to the Museum four times for each of the four Asian art history classes I've taken and I can give the tour in my sleep. 

The best part of the Museum is when there is a show on a contemporary Asian artist. There is some amazing artwork coming out of Asia right now and yet the Museum doesn't seem to notice. Where is Shazia Sikander? Xu Bing? The first floor galleries are hardly big enough to sustain a large show of contemporary Asian art and that's incredibly unfortunate. There aren't as many traveling or temporary exhibits here to warrant many return visits. 

If you have a deep affection for older Asian arts, by all means come to the Asian Art Museum. If you're a fan of contemporary Asian art, you're better off going to the SFMOMA.
author: Jackie I.

description:
Really great spot to spend a few hours! Extensive exhibits well laid out and fully explained. Definitely worth a visit if you got about 3 hours to spare.
Tip: Good discount for AAA members
author: Frank D.

description:
I like the Asian Art Museum.  I usually wander through the same exhibits over and over again.  The last time I went was during one of the third Thursday Matcha events for the Samurai exhibit.  I'd been waiting for the samurai exhibit forever so I was really excited.  I think A and I chose to go on Thursday night because it was cheaper.  The samurai exhibit wasn't as big as I thought it would be, but it was still really cool. 

I really like the building, but probably because it brings back all those memories of when it used to be the Main Library!  They change out some of the items in the exhibits every so often so it's never really exactly the same each time you go.
author: Kris L.

description:
An amazing place to discover or re-discover Asian art!  From the overall architecture of the building to the exhibit spaces, you will find a visit to this place both educational and engrossing.

It's not surprising that this building was, formerly, the San Francisco Public Library.  From one beneficial place to another, it transformed into a holding space for the majority of Avery Brundage's Asian art collection.

As a matter of fact, I highly recommend this place for both enrichment and research purposes.  I wrote a paper and the professor required photos to serve as a reference.  Since many museums do not allow picture taking, the Asian Art Museum's Registration Department was extremely helpful in providing high quality prints (there is a fee, of course).  However, the clarity, detail and care that goes into the prints is phenomenal.  

The museum store also includes reference material as well as beautiful gifts for the Asian Art lover in your life or just buy for yourself.  Again, this is a wonderful place and is situated right next to the San Francisco Public Library.  Highly recommended!
author: Dorothy S.

description:
alright, so i'm not gonna try to be some poser hella artsy fartsy hipster but this place is pretty dope. i went awhile ago for the special afghanistan exhibit and had trouble exploring the entire museum in the few hours i had. the special exhibit was set up nicely and had a good variety of different things to look at, like statuettes, jewelry, pottery, etc. it's set up so it's easy to maneuver around and my short ass doesn't have to tiptoe over people to look at what's in the case. 

there's another collection upstairs which is.. i dunno what it's called but their normal exhibit i guess? there's the typical chinese and japanese exhibits, but they also had stuff from korea [woot], malaysia, india, etc. i didn't realize there would be so much to look at and actually ran out of time. next time i go, i'll make sure to give it more time =]
author: Angela L.

description:
I could easily spend a day here.  Someone commented that it's small enough to not be overwhelming, and that IS true, if you compare it to the Met in New York or the Smithsonian.  But I found it to be plenty large enough to fill your entire day.

I don't go often enough, but when i do go, I try to watch/listen to the video monitors built in to the various sections throughout the museum.  I will also try to attend the speaking events, learning about not just the curators, but those who financed the expeditions because of a true passion for culture.  The last time I was here, I spent an hour listening to the speaker who gave "mad props" to a noteworthy business icon who spent millions, get this, in the 1940's to finance a major expedition/excavation in Japan.  His generosity allowed western civilazation to learn of the East Asian culture long before they might otherwise have.

Come to this museum.  Sit down in the upstairs conference room and listen to a speaker.  Watch the videos that are built into the walls.  Eat lunch in the downstairs restaurant (it's not too too overpriced).

And on the way out, give a homeless guy a dollar.  Who cares if he buys a beer.  The 1 guy in 10 that would actually buy food will starve because you assumed they all just always buy beer.

Sorry for the mini-sermon, but when you go to this place, you will see a homeless person and I would urge you to at least not run from them.
author: Jonathan L.

description:
General exhibits were generally okay.  But perhaps my feelings of meh were colored by the fact that I've heard this museum talked up for so long, I expected sublime over solid.  And while I know we have museums for a reason, I'm always a little disappointed with any collection of artifacts taken out of their cultural and geographical context.  So... sigh.

Doesn't mean that a visit to the largest collection of Asian art in the US isn't in order.  Definitely start from the 3rd floor, and wind your way down.  Heavy on religious relics, with a good dose of folk art.  Be sure to stop for the Balinese puppets!
author: Jen C.

description:
The best thing about this museum is how it shows art from MANY different Asian cultures.

The funny thing is seeing some priceless artifacts on display that my parents use as everyday furniture. O_o  What?
author: Keika L.

description:
Sooo much to see and take in at this place, you really could spend a full day in there just looking at so many interesting exhibits and reading up on them. I spent most of my time in the Japanese part of the museum as my last gf was Japanese and I became kinda interested in the culture (but that's a whole other story entirely). 

They even have a completely admission charge free day on the first Tuesday of every month called Target Tuesday (thanks Target!!). Only thing I would stay away from is the cafe downstairs, Cafe Asia or whatever they call it. Places dishes are way overpriced for being of such small portions and mediocrity. Other than that you can't miss.
author: Tommy P.

description:
I love museum events.  Nothing is better than an open museum that has a bar.  Wait, I take that back... nothing is better than an open museum that has an open bar.  Anyhoo...

On the first Thursday of each month, they have an event called "Matcha."
This month's theme was Marial Arts based.  

Here are the stats:
$5 cover
There's alcohol for sale- cash only.  
Can't take pictures (duh).

You can roam around the galleries, and they have several different things going on.  When I went, there were art stations where you could paint and even sew.  Great for kids.  Upstairs they had a martial arts demo which was awesome.  Downstairs they had a tai-chi class.  There were other things going on as well.

Great event for families.
author: Sarah F.

description:
I actually really love the Asian Art Museum. It's one of the only places where I can go and see artifacts from and learn about my culture's rich history in person. The other day I stopped by with some friends since we wanted to catch the Lords of the Samurai exhibit before it ended, and I'm glad we did, because I'd almost forgotten how awesome this place is.

The layout of the museum is constructed in a way that you kind of work your way chronically and regionally, starting from the third (top) floor in southern Asia and India and moving down through early and medieval China, Korea, and Japan before you arrive back on the first floor where the special exhibits are. It's a layout that works extremely well, and it kind of builds anticipation if you're looking forward to some of the latter stuff - my friends and I are all Chinese, so we were looking forward to seeing those particular galleries.

I was a bit disappointed with the Lords of the Samurai exhibit actually. Considering it was an extra $5 it wasn't all that different from some of the things on display in the Japanese wing on the second floor, and there were far fewer artifacts than I actually imagined. It was nice to catch, but they really overhyped it with all the advertising. Since it's a special exhibition though I won't knock off stars.

Haven't tried the cafe before (museum cafes usually seem overpriced anyway), but I can say that the gift shop is fairly nice. There's a large selection of books on a wide variety of Asian topics, many of which you can't find at a store like Borders or Barnes & Noble (though I'm sure Kinokuniya would have them). They do sell other interesting items, but naturally they're all fairly expensive. Don't know why anyone would expect differently.

If you've never been here before, it's well worth spending the entire day to go through the entire museum at your own pace. My friends and I had to hurry since the place was closing in two hours and we were paying for nearby parking which was moderately expensive ($3/hour), so we didn't have time to go about reading all the descriptions and historical information. It's a great place for any Asian to go and learn more about their culture.
author: Will C.

description: LOVE. Fantastic museum and great gift shop. Trace the history of a whole continent through art.
author: Stacey R.

description:
Asian Art is fascinating.  The fee to get into the museum is well worth it.  My focus was more on Japanese than anything else, every exhibit was done beautifully.  Don't plan on spending an entire day (3 hours is more than enough). 
 
Even if your focus is on one particular culture over another be sure to try and spend time looking at all the fabulous exhibits.
author: Carl M.

description:
Tried the "Matcha" performance series and Happy Hour last night.  This was my first trip to the museum and what better way to coax me in than with alcohol and music with an urban flair.

I am full of all three, just not at the moment...where could I get some urban flair right now?

Anyway, I enjoyed seeing the "Dhamaal Artist Collective" perform.  They did a great job!  There was some acoustic issues because they were performing in a marble gallery, which in my opinion, was causing some tabla ricochet for lack of a better description.

Since this was my first trip to the museum, I sat my Saketini down to browse the collection (no drinks allowed in the exhibition rooms).  There were so many pieces to see and they were very nice.  I would have liked to see some work representing current Asian artists like Yoshitomo Nara or Takashi Murakami.  ...I guess that is what the MoMA is for, but I'm not asking them to purchase "Hiropon" - just a few more permanent pieces that represent a newer age.  I don't know much but I know what I like.

The Matcha schedule is through November and I am looking forward to the Theatre of Yugen next month.
author: Adam W.

description:
OK, "Target Tuesdays"?   Tacky, but free entrance on the first Tuesday of the month brought me in for an overdue visit.

Bigger collection than I expected and it was a pretty decent range of stuff, but heavy on religious imagery - especially for Buddhist and Hindu art.  I'm interested, but definitely needed more time than 2 1/2 hours to get through the exhibits.  

I want come back for some of their many events - especially the Thursday night ones when it's only $5 to get in after 5 pm.

Seriously, Target doesn't need any more advertising and they should give something back to the community without asking for something in return.  Think of all people working in Asia who are underpaid so you can buy cheap crap that you probably don't need at Target, but can make Target executives rich in the process.

Drop the chain store ads and I'll give it a 5 star rating.
author: Surf R.

description:
Ming Dynasty, that was what brought me to my first trip to the Asian Art Museum.  Driving thru the City all weekend, you couldn't help but wonder after seeing all the flags and banners on the City poles.....So we decided to go and check it out on a Sunday, it was the first Sunday of the month and Target, thank above, sponsors for free admission, so we took advantage of it and got in a line that actually went around the Museum, down to the third corner of the building, no joking......It took us about an hour, they were very efficient and very organized.....The displays were beautiful and impressive, things we would not normally see in the States......Anyways, I definately would have paid for that one.........
We were cruising around last Sunday after a wonderful lunch at T. Joints and decided to check out the Bhutan exhibits, it was the first Sunday again, how lucky can we get, no lines and it was full of energy in there....lots of great pieces and the colors were just magnificant.....I think it might be over now....can't wait to see what's next on their schedule.....
author: Leslie Y.

description:
The Asian Art Museum has a rich collection of Asian artifacts and art -- from Japan to Korea to China to South & Southeast Asian.  In the hours I spent here, I learned a great deal about Japanese paintings as well as gained a better understanding of Buddhism and Buddhist art.  

Since the many exhibits are located in three levels, do not expect to see everything in one day and definitely plan to return on another day.  I also suggest browsing in the gift shop, it has some real great things.  

On this particular day at the Asian Art museum, I even attended "The Spirit of Flowers and Plants" session to learn about "ikebana" -- the Japanese art of flower arranging.

Overall, a great museum to immerse oneself in multiple Asian cultures and learn about their rich histories.
author: Lupe M.

description: I came here on the 1st Sunday of the Month which is free and paid 5 dollars to go see the special exhibit on the ground floor called Shanghai.  I had to zip though the  museum fast cause i had to go to work.  I didn't see the top floor yet. Its cheaper on the first Sunday of the month for the special.   I would of came here for the Lords of Samurai if i have known this.
author: John F.

description:
I visited the museum with some friends on the first weekend of the month, which is free and sponsored by Target.  Warning, though, this free day of the month is a total madhouse.

I have to say, this is definitely one of best museums I've visited, the exhibits were interesting and very informative.  The funniest part is that one of my friends  or I would wonder about something random while walking through, such as how an Indian religion spread through so much of Asia, and lo and behold, a few minutes later we came across a display that explained exactly that.

Some of the art was completely amazing in how they have remained so beautiful over hundreds, sometimes more than a thousand, years.  There are a few pieces of more modern art here and there, but the more historical pieces intrigued me the most.
author: Crystal B.

description:
First generation Chinese grandma, first & second generation parents, and third generation college undergrad approved!

We spent half a day here and found it really lovely.  We all learned quite a bit about Chinese symbolism from this porcelain/pottery exhibit.  The day we were there they had a bunch of hands-on activities and crafts set up - coloring postcards was fun!  

We had lunch in the museum restaurant.  I'm usually not a fan of museum food but I was really happy with everything!  They had a substantial variety of Asian food (good for vegans!) and fun plates/bowls.

We didn't go through everything there as we didn't want to overdose on museum and end up cranky and annoyed at each other, so I would love to go back and wander through the other rooms.
author: Emily F.

description:
free first sunday of the month
thank you target! 

I love learning about art. Beautiful pieces here. Not much from the Philippines but a lot of Japanese, korean and chinese art. When I went Burma or what is now maymar was the special display. If you love culture and sf go here!

yay for culture in sf we are so blessed!
author: Diane S.

description:
Beautiful place, wow! 

Samsung Hall is gorgeous...I can definitely picture getting married there!  If only my man would even begin to fathom with the idea....

Main theme is Buddhism - and that goes on for about what feels like 1/2 of the museum.  Interesting stuff - tons and tons of sculptures.

For how big the place is, I'd imagine there would be more Japanese art but not really.  Anyway, it's awesome!  Today there was a tea ceremony exhibit - $20 which included a bowl of green tea made the traditional Japanese way and museum admission.  My sorry cheap butt paid $7 for entry (woohoo, thank you college id!)

I still like Philadelphia's Museum of Art - their Asian section includes a replica of a Chinese throne and Japanese tea house.  

what's interesting to note is that one petite area on the 2nd floor of the japanese exhibit included story telling scrolls.  And a huge sign that acknowledged that some people of Korean culture would find the scrolls offensive (b/c it depicted japan invading and "conquering" korea).   The museum apologised for any offense but is still displaying b/c it's a work of art and that they hope people won't be offended.  Good for you taking notice, museum!

I think the gift shop wasn't all that - more books than anything.  I rather have more knick-knacks than spines =)

Still, what a gorgeous place to be!  Fascinating and to take a walk outside is another treat in itself!
author: Thuy N.

description:
I was finally able to make it to this museum after wanting to come here for so long!  My sis and I stopped in to see the mochi pounding exhibition by a SF troupe (Kagami Kai).  The exhibition was pretty cool as they incorporated a taiko group as well.   Samsung Hall was PACKED.

Then we decided to skip the third and fourth demonstrations (which used volunteers from the crowd) and check out Cafe Asia.  Their cafe served excellent food which seemed to be healthier fare than other museums I have been to.  We had the Singapore Short Ribs and the Thai Curry.  The short ribs came with a lovely vegetable mix and brown rice (I had to ask for this instead of steamed rice).  While tasty, you should expect some work to get the meat off the bone.

The recommended tour is to start on the third floor and then work your way to the second floor in order to fully take advantage of the information they want to convey.   The information listed on the plaques were pretty informative and had great stories but I wish there were some interactive activities along the way as well.

The gift shop had some very unique items which I loved.
author: J L.

description:
This was a beautiful and well laid out museum.  Start at the top and travel through Asia in a more regional manner.  Nothing mixed up.  Everything well explained.  I actually learned a lot through this museum which I think is the POINT of museums.

We were there during the Drama and Desire display.  They had a Kabuki make up demonstration and the most interesting part was when the lecturer did different voices to represent the different characters that the men had to play.  From young girl to old man.  Was amazing how he made his voice change.
author: Brian M.

description: There are a lot of artifacts and artwork from South Asia, East Asia and Southeast Asia. Signage describes the historical context of the art presented in each gallery; it's very helpful to a patron walking through the exhibits. Don't forget to walk up the stairs from the font entrance. The grand stairway leads to a hall of beautiful columns on each side. It's absolutely grand!
author: Holt D.

description:
As a budding South Asianist, Art Historian and former LACMA employee, I am spoiled with good Asian Art.  This museum has a encyclopedic collection of art from all over Asia.  

The collection is huge, but the manner in which the the Indian collection is displayed is not conducive to easy viewing (too many pieces on display at one time).  My primary interest is Indian Sculpture and the Asian Art Museum has some very good examples in this genre.  The Tibetan collection is also excellent and is well-displayed (take a close look at some of the painted furniture!). 

The building itself was masterfully remodeled. The building was previously the city library.  Gae Aulenti maintained the feel of the original building and has managed to turn the library into a great museum and peaceful public space.
author: Andrew C.

description:
Been waiting to visit this place for a long while and finally, we decided to come here on a rainy day for the mochi pounding.  The pounding was done by a SF troupe composed of volunteers (Kagami Kai).  It was a cool exhibition for the fact that they did different movements for each pounding and they were bagging the mochi to give out after the whole pounding was done.  They also had volunteers from the audience come out for the exhibition to pound mochi.  Be aware - get there early as it gets PACKED in the hall.  

The museum cafeteria is called Cafe Asia.  The wait was a bit long, but that was because they make each meal right in front of you.  The menu selections were all pretty healthy for museum fare, and the cool thing also is that you can get brown rice for a lot of the food items.  I got the Thai Curry and was afraid it would be too overwhelmingly rich, but instead, it was light and yummy.  Not my fave curry, but not bad!  And the shrimp was tender not overcooked.  

The normal exhibits on the 2nd and 3rd floors were all really cool.  The best part was the explanations and history detailed.  We learned a lot about Asian culture today.  

Awesome deal if you are a student at $7 instead of the normal $12 admission.
author: A L.

description:
Trekked up from the South Bay last weekend to check out the Ming dynasty special exhibit...

House in the former main library, the exterior of the building is grand without being too imposing. The interior is split into 3 floors - the museum's collections start on the 3rd floor and wind their way down through the second floor. Three special exhibit galleries are on the first floor, as well as the gift shop and the cafe.

The Ming dynasty exhibit was pretty cool, but paled both in grandeur and volume to the Qing dynasty exhibit I viewed at the Field Museum in Chicago a few years back. Maybe it was due to the smaller space, maybe it was due to the older age of the Ming dynasty artifacts. They are 400+ years old, after all.

The museum's own collections range from India to Southeast Asia to East Asia. The majority are religious artifacts (statues of gods and Buddhas), though there are interesting things like the Javanese stick puppets. The Chinese collection is the largest and includes a fair amount of paintings and porcelain.

Overall, it's an impressive collection, outside of Asia, especially since I don't really consider SF much of a museum city. I wasn't wowed by either the Ming special exhibit or the museum's own exhibits, but I don't regret coming.
author: Albert C.

description:
It's a beautiful building and a nice collection though somewhat repetative, especially after the childhood doses of Asian art that I endured.

I do like to sit in the big gala/ballroom, though, on one of the two couches in the entire big empty room, and just stare, though.
author: Caroline C.

description:
The AAM cafeteria was not very good.  I had heard good things about it, but I was pretty disappointed in the daily special.

It was SALTY - as in the opposite of SWEET.  And yes, it was really salty.  

I really like the museum itself though so I'm still gonnah give it five stars.  Thursday nights are the best because no one is there.  You can enjoy the collection at your own pace - which is the only way to really enjoy a museum.
author: Jerry C.

description:
The first Thursday of each month brings a wonderful $5 gathering for city folk!  DJ Tong came in from Japan to kick off some kick-@$$ manga and anime showcased here this month.

Fun, lively - underground parking is available, people! And the entrance is right across the street on McCallister, the lot is underground. Around $2 for each hour. 

The drinks are not strong, but what an invigorating way to kick off a Thursday evening!

Domo!
author: dj z.

description:
Easy access from Civic Center BART. I got there a little after opening so it was not crowded at all. I love the architecture and layout, the price ($7 with audio tour as long as you have a student ID), and the quality of the exhibits. There is also a cafe which was packed by the time I left and a nice little gift shop with some reasonably priced items. 

You're supposed to start on the 3rd floor, which I did, but a lot of people didn't which was fine because that spread out the visitors a little more, so we weren't all looking at the same exhibits at the same time. Most visitors were respectful and quietly viewing the exhibits, but there were some people who were speaking really loudly and I ran into some children who were running around. Also, there were quite a few people taking pictures, which I thought wasn't allowed, but the security people patrolling through didn't seem to mind.

The exhibits are amazing. There were so many things to look at even I got a little tired and needed to sit a few times to rest my feet. Many of the items on disply were out in the open and not enclosed in glass, which I think is great so you can really see the details. 

I'd visit again and would tell out of town guests to visit this magnificent museum.
author: L H.

description:
The Bhutan exhibit was incredible. Some of the items featured were in the Western world for the first time. The prayer by the monks was also really cool.

However, the permanent collection was also stunning in its coverage of all of Asia with so many interesting artifacts and descriptions.

And they have free days, and unlike other museums' free days, everything, including the special exhibits, are free.
author: Mark A.

description: I went to the Maharaja Exhibit today totally excited and thrilled to see pieces that I've been studying for decades. Unfortunately the Museum staff made it a miserable experience. In room 1, I had my 2 year old toddler standing on my feet as I looked at exhibits and I was told my the security guy that I HAVE to hold my child's hand to be in the exhibit. Ok, I thought so I held his hand. Further along in the exhibit I was told again, please hold my son's hand as I was fumbling with my two hands to play their cassette that requires two hands to operate. He wasn't running around or anything just standing by my side. So I decided to head to my car and get the stroller. Enter room 2 where I was told that strollers had to stay outside. O.k. so I put it outside and just quickly carried my toddler (not screaming or crying or even misbehaving) through the exhibit. I didn;t even hear the cassette for fear of another person telling me to hold the child's hand. Enter room there where the security guard told me NO STROLLERS are allowed in the museum. What? This time I was starting to get irritated. I asked them to show me in writing where it says strollers are not allowed. Five minutes later the security guy says that my purse has to be on one shoulder, I can't wear it backpack style. I'm carrying a toddler, two cassette thingies, two headsets, a program and carrying the unwanted stroller int he other hand. If I had a china plate to spin on my head, I could be an exhibit too. I looked at him calmly and said it was a purse and the only reason I have it across my back is that I have to carry the kid in one hand and the stroller in the other since it was not allowed in. I was still waiting for the proof mind you. Instead of apologizing or understanding he calls his supervisor. It went even more downhill from there. The collection would be neat if you got to see it. I've never been to a museum where children in strollers are not allowed and purses have to be carried on one shoulder only! It borders on harassment! They should post a huge sign that says NO STROLLERS! NO PURSES!! NO KIDS!!!
author: Manju R.

description:
It's clear that Samurai warriors should have gotten unbiased third party tactical warfare advice from a 6 year old.  Nice lacquered wood helmets, beatiful armor, amazing katana swords.  But no armored shoes?

6 yr old's review
---------------------------
"Why are there no shields?  Only armor?  Well it's not even metal!  The pistols can shoot his foot, then he screams OWWW and he'll be bleeding."

Dang you got a point.  What good are leather shin guards and gloves when a 6 yr old notices your unprotected toes and takes a katana sword to them, hmm? 

3 yr old's review
---------------------------
"How come it's circle time for the statue?  That statue wants to play patty cakes."  Referring to Buddhist statues on 3rd floor that either sit cross-legged or hold both palms outward.

Lords of the Samurai!  Good exhibit, overlaps somewhat with the regular stuff in the Japan rooms but worth the $5 extra.  Asian Art Museum is pretty kid friendly.  The interactive audio/video screens and headphones in each room are cool.
author: Jason Y.

description:
We paid six bucks with student ID. Fully worth it and then some. 

Extensive collections of southeast Asia and China. But lacking on Japanese and Korean pieces. Or maybe Japan and Korea are lacking in general. Haha, China rules. Just kidding, all Asians are evil and dirty. Anyways. 

Every "country" had a little moniter and headphones for to learn about ... stuff. Like I watched the one about jade working. 

Things were set up with a real eye candy kind of feel. The Indonesian wire puppets, Chinese jade trinkets, Japanese inro box-purses, they were all displayed as to overload the eye. 

The gift shop was museum protocol: expensive. 

Museum is camera-friendly, no flash.
author: Jen K.

description: I had a great experience at this museum! They had guest author Amy Tan giving a presentation one day, and were giving out her new book in nice tote bags for free in the front lobby; not to mention you could actually get the book signed by her for free as well. This is a great cultural center and good way to learn about far-eastern countries and their many cultures.
author: Kyle S.

description:
Eh... came for the free museum tuesday and wasn't very interested in any of the exhibits at all. Also, we were the only asians there, almost. Just feels like everything we saw were things that we would normally see and things that we already know about. I'm not saying all asian cultures are the same, but you know it and you relate with it, so it didn't keep my interest at all. 

Left less than an hour after we got there.
author: Anh P.

description:
The most amazing selection of Asian art I've ever seen! 

I hiked a good 2-3 miles down Market on a Saturday morning (solo) b/c I had to tour the museum that boasts the largest collection of Asian art in the world. If you've ever hiked down Market St. in SF, toward the Museum, than you know that I must be a sucker for a little museum action.. that, or just a sucker. Man, there was a lot of junkies and hookers out at 9am on a Saturday!

Their collection is incredible. I've been to several museums, and their collection of asian art trumps even The Museum of London' collection which is quite extensive. There is so much to see, that I felt like I should have spent a day.

My favorites were some of the large and small scale statues of buddha, shiva, and ganesh. Very intricate and so well preserved for being thousands of years old.

Two idiot ladies in their oversized Mickey Mouse T's, fake nails, and Aqua- net "wet looking" hair took pics of themselves posing with a Giant porcelain Buddha at the end of the exhibit, when I cannot tell you how many "No photography" signs I saw throughout that place. A stern security guard scared the poo out of them and told them to leave. It was funny.

Too bad the dim sum was calling my name all the way back in Chinatown, that and my 3pm flight..  I would have stayed all day.

Two bronze Buddhas up!
author: Katie A.

description:
The galleries contain beautiful works of art from South, Southeast and West Asia, Himalayas, Tibet, China, Korea and Japan. Special exhibitions change through out the year and are located on the first floor.  Self-guided audio tours are complimentary and are very informative.  The museum also has a cafe, Cafe Asia.

Target Tuesdays will move to Sundays starting May 4, 2008.  Free admission first Sunday of each month courtesy of Target stores.

TIPS:  A limited number of wheelchairs are available to borrow for those visitors who might not be able to walk through three floors of galleries.
SFUSD students are free with ID.
Discounted admission for seniors and college students with ID.
author: Rachel R.

description: Astro Boy rocks!  I have been in San Francisco for 10 years and not once stepped for in the Asian Art Museum.  Yes a bit sad to say I know!  It took Astro Boy  (Tezuka Osamu) to get me there!   I am not a huge fan of Asian art so that is my excuse, but the museum has a beautiful collection and the building itself is wonderful to experience.  On top of that they give you the chance to see the exhibits the first Tuesday of every month for free, so money should not be a factor!    Go and check out this wonderful gem in the middle of our city.  If you are teetering them consider the free night and speed walk through it, maybe that will change your mind and you will go back for a more in depth viewing.
author: Scott P.

description:
I definitely lack knowledge in the asian art arena, but you have to be blind to not appreciate the extent of the collection here. I tried the free audio tour, which probably took away from the whole experience. For one, I somehow missed half the highlighted pieces. And two, it didn't add much more than what was already written on the cards. Enough of reviewing the museum...

Let's talk about that cafe INSIDE the museum! This is what made my experience 4-star worthy. I had a fantastic chicken salad, freshly tossed, with ample amounts of grilled chicken and a tasty light vinagrette. My friend had vegetable curry where the cook steamed the vegetables right there in front of her eyes. This was way beyond my expectations for a museum cafe!
author: Susan L.

description:
This is an EXCELLENT museum for everyone of any age group! I've gone here twice and I've loved both times. I also love that they switch out pieces every once in a while so there was many new pieces I hadn't seen when I went last year. There are 3 levels, starting at the top it goes from Indian to South East Asian (Thailand, Burma, Vietnam, etc) then into Tiebet, Laos, and on the second floor it is Chinese, Japanese and Korean. On the ground floor is where the special exhibits are (they change so this time is was a special on Japanese folding screens) and the gift shop and cafe. You can spend many hours here taking in the amazing sculptures, paintings, garments and ceramics. Some countries sections are small like the Filippines and Korea but I believe it's do to the fact that the museum hasn't been able to really start a real collection of those cultures artwork not because of any negative reasons. I'm an art history major so I know when artifacts go up for sale or auction, many museums (and private collectors) all over the world fight to purchase and display them...specially if it's a rare item. I def. recommended this museum!!

Students get discount with Student ID and there's probably AAA discounts too! :-)

Also, for those that were complaining that the pieces were too small, SERIOUSLY imagine being back in those times trying to carve such an intricate battle scene with warriors, animals, plants and celestial beings onto a 5" piece of ivory. The small pieces were my favorite, specially the Jade room, WOW.
author: Amber M.

description:
I've been coming to the Asian Art Museum since my sophomore year in college (not that long I suppose), but throughout the years this place still captivates me. Sure, Asian art can seem the same (lots of vases, paintings of landscapes with egrets and dragons, etc), but it's the intricacies and stories that keep me intrigued. I like this museum more than others because they tend to have a lot of artifacts which I love and appreciate. 

The museum also has special exhibits, but the wonderful thing is they do not charge extra for them, unlike other museums (i.e.Deyoung). The exhibits also have special activities you can partake in as well like calligraphy writing and special performances at no extra cost. Stop by with your Asian (or non-Asian) parents  when you can!
author: Angela L.

description: A fan for sure. This place has interesting exhibits and there is always some event going here here. The free days are nice and I would go back to see the rest of Bali exhibit soon.
author: Eva Y.

description:
The French architect did a disservice to Mr. Moon's bequest by not really making it a warm space. Mr. Moon and his wife are such warm and generous people, the museum just conveys the grey concrete more than invite you to take your time with the grant collection at the Asian Art Museum. One kid was dragged there by his haole Mom and he left his shoelaces untied and got them caught in the escalator, I rescued his 12 year old ass, but I should have let the machinery shred his feet, since he was dragging those appendages the whole way up. Go for the special exhibits because the two rooms generally have some good pieces collected there.

I would avoid the Cafe there because it is just so uninspiring and you could go for Thai around the corner.
author: miriam b.

description:
This is THE amazing collection of Asian Art in the Western Hemisphere.  The current location is the old Main Library and is a gorgeous beaux art building re-visioned by Gae Aulenti who also redid the rail station in Paris into the beautiful Musee D'Orsay.  The majority of the collection came from Avery Brundage with a generous gift from SV entrepreneur Chong-Moon Lee to challenge San Francisco to again house this growing collection.  

In the DeYoung, the Asian Art Museum housed the famed Xi'an Warriors, the Sacred Art collection of Tibet, and one of the first collections post WW II to travel outside of mainland China.

The current building is a complete delight with a feeling of space and light.  It has a fantastic cafe where you can sample all types of Asian fare, a well edited gift shop and of course the collections themselves.  If you have traveled to Asia, I think you even appreciate the magnitude of this collection more.  There aren't many venues this large dedicated to Asian Art and this well curated.  The visiting works, in themselves, are worth seeing.  But to stay for a day and soak in all the thousands of years of art is truly something special.

Play hookie and enjoy your day... lost in art.
author: Holly J.

description:
Free admission during the month of May 2007 courtesy of Bank of America so of course I give it 5 fabulous stars.

The exhibits are amazing, of course, and seem a bit better given the free admission.

We went early on a Sunday morning and the place was nearly empty. We had whole sections to ourselves.

Darrin Atkins
author: Darrin A.

description: Love this museum, their collection is truly very nice and well organized! The cafe tends to be a bit pricey (but hey you are in SF) but the food is amazing!
author: Caroline D.

description: A fantastic museum! A terrific venue to host parties. Intelligent guest speakers, exciting programs and exhibits, and a lovely staff make this all the more enticing. You must visit this great addition to the Civic Center.
author: Michael G.

description: Great museum.  knowledgeable docents who provide a variety of free tours of the collection.  Well kept rooms with good lighting and accurate and useful information.  I like the layout of the building and it is located right in the civic center area making it a perfect destination for both locals and tourists.  Highly recommended.
author: Kenneth H.

description: Outstanding museum. Wonderful mix of Asian art. Cafe Asia food was delicious. Exorbitant gift shop prices should be rethought.
author: Elizabeth B.

description: On your path to enlightenment, be sure to include a visit to the AA Museum of Sf - conveniently located two blocks from the civic center BART station.
author: Evelyn B.

description:
The Museum ihas three levels, with 2 and half floors of Buddhism artifacts...alright...don't get me wrong I love the history behind this particular religion, I even studied it in University, but I would love to see more of the Southern Asia arts.
Pros:  read the reviews below this one.
Cons:  I just had one problem with one of the guided tour, the woman was educating a group of visitor about a particular statue of Buddha, the statue portrays the time when Buddha battling with Mara the evil doer, and finally reached the enlightenment.  Ok, why oh why the guide  used an air-quote gesture whenever she mentioned the word "enlightenment"??!!  Somehow I felt a little bit insulted.  

Just my two cents.
author: Ting R.

description:
This is a great museum.  There is so much to see and learn.  The guided tours are nice because you will learn a lot but it is also nice to just see it by yourself and take your time.  It is hard for me to really appreciate the museum in just one visit so I like to take my time and see about 50%-75% at one visit.  Most museums have a free day once per month during the middle of the week but the Asian Art Museum has a free day on the first SUNDAY of every month.  

For more information about FREE museums click on this link:
http://www.examiner.com/x-20478-Oakland-Museum-Examiner~y2009m8d20-Top-5-Bay-Area-museums-with-free-days?#comments
author: Tim D.

description:
The Asian Art Museum does some things really right.  Great and beautiful space and cool "Matcha" parties which allow lovers of the arts to mingle with each other.  The crowd is mixed but predominantly female oriented.  It is definitely a few notches up from your standard bar crowd.

Once in awhile they have some really cool exhibits that matches my contemporary sensibilities but the permanent exhibit is all very old school.  The Museum should dive deep into Chinese Contemporary.
author: Laurence H.

description:
I don't think I've written a review about a museum yet, but I had to as the Asian Art Museum makes me come back time after time (luckily for me, Mumsy is a member and can get me in for free on her guest pass). Their exhibitions are always fresh and exciting - paring up old and new - and the standing exhibits are always worth a look too. 

Their cafe is really quite astoundingly good for, well, any type of cafe - last time I had tofu, soba salad and Mumsy had Mongolian beef - both delish - followed by a civilized stroll through the Artists of a Floating World Exhibition and then a fascinating video on how one of the paintings was restored by experts at the British Museum.

And the architecture is a brilliant marriage of preserving old while complementing new (or the other way round). Yes, I do like the Asian Art Museum. 

My one and only itsy bitsy tiny bit of criticism (losing half a star) is that their gift shop doesn't always have enough of the less expensive special exhibition memorabilia as one would like - I mean, I don't go there to buy an $80 kimono (I go to J-town instead!).
author: Mi M.

description:
I been wanting to come here since it moved to this location. so when i finally got free tickets... i called up the one friend who would appreciate coming to a museum, cus you know... people around you can either make a moment enjoyable or just ruin it, and museums are definitely not for everyone.
everything was so intricate and beautiful... lucky most of the pieces were behind glass, cus i for one know i cant keep my hand to myself. Then we read the description...1900's and we're like "THAT'S NOT OLD!"  ( we know old stuff are hard to come by, and the more recent weren't bad. but still...)
What makes this place fun is their awesome sculptures and statues which comes with myth and legends you can read about.  BUT the best part was trying to get in a few good (goofy) pictures while no one was watching except the security guard who laughed at us :)
author: Lynn T.

description:
I have always wanted to visit this museum for so long, but sadly I don't make it up to the city as often as I'd like. Fortunately, as fate would have it, I BART-ed it up to the city a few Thursdays ago to pick up something, and decided to not waste the trip. Here's how it all went down...

I noticed a few banners featuring the Asian Art Museum throughout the city, and on a whim, decided to look up the address and directions on my iPhone.  It was only a 20 minute walk from where I was (somewhere along Market St.), so I decided to carpe the diem.

Once I reached my destination, a sense of excitement came over me. I felt like a kid on a field trip, minus the darn worksheets you have to fill out so the teacher knows you are "learning" something. Which by the way, in my opinion is not the most effective means of exploring and appreciating a museum. 

The museum has 3 floors and the visitors guide map leads you throughout the museum, starting on the 3rd floor and working your way downward. If you follow the route suggested, the museum tells a beautiful story of some of the oldest cultures in the world and how each of the individual culture featured in someway influenced one another and how those integrated cultures were an influence around the world.

The museum features art from India, China, Thailand, Japan, the PI, and Korea, to name the few countries. Though I won't go into detail about the exhibits, what I will say is this...There is so much to experience, read and enjoy in this museum. I could literally spend the entire day there and still feel like I did not fully take in all this museum has to offer. I didn't get a chance to really appreciate the Bhutan exhibit because I did not realize that there were multiple rooms dedicated to the art of Bhutan. What I did enjoy was the "live art" exhibit of the monks focusing on various form of art, be it music or mandalas.

Since this is a museum, I was expecting a variety of people to visit. I was not disappointed. There were college students, sketching notable piece, older folk enjoying a leisurely stroll amongst antiques from their native countries, museum members enjoy the new editions to the museum, and oh yes, i mustn't forget the field trip kids. 

Wow, I don't ever remember being that rowdy in a museum before, when I was a kid. 

I have to say, the kids kind of ruined my day of solitary artistic enjoyment with their loud and sometimes "off-colored" comments and questions, trying to fill out their worksheets and leave as quickly as possible. I was saddened by this sight. The kids were so focused on trying to find "the answer to question 5a" instead of actually looking at the exhibits and really trying to learn a thing or two about different cultures.

All in all it was totally worth the $12, and I can't wait to experience the Samurai exhibit coming in June.
author: A. Claire C.

description:
The first museum i got a membership to. They've targeted my demographic perfectly! First there was anime... then there was Miyake, Watanabe, Yamamoto and Kawakubo... plus fossils!

Their cafeteria is the bomb. The last time i went they actually kicked me my lunch for free! ( i still don't understand why). THey're right down the street from my work so i go all of the time when the crackheads start destroying my rosy view of the world. Nothing like good clean architecture and a bunch of jadework to brighten up an otherwise grey, homeless, crazy landscape.
author: Domini A.

description: Free, every first Sunday of the month. Magnificent art! A must experience for culture and history.
author: Charlene K.

description: Fantastic collection of fine Asian artifacts. Great gift shop and wonderful cafe. I have been here a few times and always enjoy going back.
author: Sally Z.

description:
I know I'll get flamed for giving this place three stars but I appreciate more modern art than classic. I was expecting more than a copycat of the Asian wing at the Smithsonian and that barely held my interest. 

However, I do applaud that fact that the layout is amazing and easy to navigate. You leisurely pace yourself on each floor and take the stair or elevator to the next. Kind of reminds me of the SFMOMA layout.
author: S L.

description: Where do I begin? The building is gorgeous and the exhibits are even more ravishing. The traveling exhibits which comes for a short period of time are well worth the trip into SF for. As museum members, we do not take enough opportunity to make the most of our membership. However, when we do get the chance to get there, we find we spend at least 3 hours just taking in everything piece by piece. Their cafe is not bad either. Food is delightfully fresh and most of it light and tasty. Prices are very very affordable too.
author: Anita L.

description:
One word "Incredible!"

And the cafe' on the first floor has very nice food and well priced.

The gift shop (while a bit pricey) has lovely things to buy.
author: Lee S.

description: i love the entrance to this place. it's like walking into a grand building. they have every single Asian culture covered, Chinese, Japanese, Korean, Filipino .. etc.. and it's pretty cool how they have a place for you to sit to admire the artifact and paintings. when i was a student we should go here on the free Wednesdays, and take notes on the bench. i love how they have a lot of artifacts/paintings from the different dynasty's in China. at times they have different exhibits, like the samurai and now it's the shanghai exhibit
author: Belinda C.

description: The Asian Art Museum is full of fantastic Asian art exhibits all over the continent. I especially enjoyed the exhibitions from China and Korea.
author: Leo T.

description:
I am so conflicted. 

The collection at the Asian Art museum is quite large. I was impressed by the Indonesian and Indian exhibits. I love sculpture and there are some impressive pieces. 

Other than sculpture, I gravitate towards Chinese and Japanese art (paintings mostly) and while there are some nice works about, they are a bit weak compared to those I've seen abroad. I think maybe I've been spoiled though.

Still, it is one of the largest collections in the US and well worth the visit. The last time I visited, I didn't feel like I was entering a museum. I think it was the lack of signs out in front of the building or maybe it was just the civic center. Possibly it was the lack of a crowd. That was a bit disconcerting.
author: Jordan M.

description:
Usually when I go to Asian art museums or collections, I feel sad.  It looks as though permanent collection objects haven't been changed in forever and other details have been ignored.  I came to see the Filipino artists exhibit not knowning what to expect and was pleasantly surprised.  The building's gorgeous and does justice, not only its collection, but to its visitors as well.  It's both visually stimulating and educational.  The collections are mapped out well and its easy to navigate your way around the large building.  

I was also quite happy with the labels.  Their writers ensure that visitors are engaged in the paradigm brought about by colonialization and really contextualize how certain objects may have come into Westerner's hands.  

I'm thinking I should consider becoming member.  It looked like a good deal, plus I love me my tax deductions.
author: Kay G.

description:
Beautiful collection includes sculptures (religious, stone, bronze...) , functional items (like swords and bowls), costumes, and much more.  Don't miss: 
 
- The later Chinese jade gallery. It's fun to watch the light shimmer off the smooth, intricately carved stones.  
 
- The Javanese rod puppets: remarkably colorful, with odd, expressive faces and costumes. 
 
- The Sugimoto exhibit -- thought-provoking and disorienting.    And tragically temporary. http://www.asianart.org/sugimoto.htm
author: angela n.

description: Love this museum! Great collection of sculptures. Shanghai travelling collection is definitely worth seeing! Don't miss the baskets in the Japanese section, unbelievable!
author: Chuck F.

description:
I get overwhelmed quickly at museums, but this one has a lot of interesting stuff. I love the Ganesh statues and the Indonesian puppets. They have some interesting programs here, too, that combine visual and performing arts.

I think they should have more Mongolian art. I say this because I just returned from Mongolia. I know it's hard to cover EVERYTHING, but it is part of Asia.
author: Vandana M.

description:
Hell, I'm in a five-star kinda mood I guess.  

Seriously, this is a real gem in the city.  

I spent two hours today and definitely need to go back.

Easy to get to from Civic or Van Ness station.  Go on Wednesday so you can shop at the farmer's market in UN Plaza.
author: Aimee B.

description:
Me and my mom went here a year ago and saw 9 billion buddhas.  Seriously.  And approximately the same amount of jade.  

Other than the sheer quantity of it, "it" was all very pretty and historical and interesting.  And to make it even better, we visited during the last day of a special exhibit, which means, yep! everyone was in there while mom and me explored everything else in peace.  It was awesome timing and I always tell people I did it on purpose.
author: Emily C.

description:
I went there to see the Ming dynasty special exhibit last weekend, and the collection, especially the amount of material explaining everything is quite impressive. 

Given that I am used to the major museums in European and east coast cities, the Asian Art Museum in SF is deserving of the 4 stars for its collections specializing in Asian art.
author: Winifred X.

description:
The site of the old SF Public Library, it's hard to believe that it's floating so that it will take earthquakes much better!

I am bummed to have missed the kimono exhibit, but it's worth getting a membership so that you can go to popular exhibitions without waiting in line and other museums in its network for "free", such as YBCA.
author: Vera D.

description:
I've been to the museum on a lazy weekday as well as a busy weekend. The event that illicits this review was MATCHA!. 
Although I've attended quite a few, the 'Healing Arts' event was spectacular. 
The museum itself has  grandeur architecture that can only be described as spectacular and majestic. Love it.
I recommend going straight to the 3rd floor and working your way down. I love starting my evening off with Buddhist art. OM.
Explore it yourself but definitely do yourself a favor and get on their special events list. Well worth your while. Enjoy!
author: Claire S.

description:
Come here for the exhibitions. 

Come here for MATCHA. 
(http://www.asianart.org/matcha.htm)

Come here because you can get THIS close to the buddha statues and NOTHING would go off.  Lick them, then it's a different story.
author: Andrew P.

description: Went in the late-afternoon on a Saturday and it was fairly empty. The exhibits were laid out very well. Extremely interesting and I highly recommend this to anyone with an interest in Asian history.
author: Ryan M.

description:
I'm in to the whole art deal...and the Asian Art Museum has lots. My fav selection was the buddha business...I must say a.d.d. kicked in and I slowly lost interest as I wandered deeper into the museum..but go hungry! 

The museum cafe was perhaps the most stellar museum cafe I've been to in a long time. The food was fantab and they steamed vegetables in front of me! This was great knowing that the food wasn't sitting around all day waiting for someone to purchase. I was totes happy with this experience and I left full of art and good food.
author: Natalie C.

description:
I am seriously impressed with this place.  A gorgeous building and specific sections devoted to different regions in Asia, acknowledging that "Asia" isn't just one type of people.  Everything from Buddhist statues, Hindu gods, Korean ceremonial gowns, Chinese calligraphy, Japanese transportation, Sikh war banners ... and more!

Warning: if there are large groups of rowdy children in there the narrow pathways become very hard to navigate.

Times visited: 1
author: Amy L.

description:
I have never seen so many Astroboy merchandise in one store before and I've lived in Japan. I believe the concentration alone is to promote the well-designed gallery showing of Osamu Tezuka currently housed in the lower floor of the re-imagined museum space that once was the Main Library of San Francisco.

The Tezuka showing displayed tons of manga panels of Kimba, Astroboy, Black Jack and more. However, the pieces were all in it's original Japanese context with no English translation to help auteurs understand what they're seeing. I enjoy seeing the Astroboy statue, it reminded me of the giant Col. Sanders statue that greets people in front of KFC back in Tokyo.  A definite camera catch moment.

There are tons to see and I really like the layout of the artwork in accordance to each country. Don't miss the traditional ocha tatami room. If only everyone could step inside to get a feel for Japan. Make sure to hover in the Jade room...those pieces alone are eyecatching. 
It's best to take the escalator to the top floor and work your way down.  

The shop has quite an eclectic selection from books, toys, to jewelry. Love the kimono jewelry...too cute! Make sure to check out the Manga Lounge while it's here.  Look for touch screens throughout the place for interesting information.

Target Tuesdays...free admission on the first Tuesday of every month.  There's a coat check in and a wheelchair rentals.  Fun free architecture building tours are offered.
author: Pauline L.

description:
A good museum to check out artifacts of different asian countries  albeit a somewhat smaller collection compared to other museums I've been to in NYC and LA.  There is coherence among the art however and explanations that can help museum-goers learn about the history and relationships/interconnection between the distinct asian countries.  The only thing missing was more art representation from say Okinawa, Taiwan and the Philippines.

Cafe Asia is also located on premises and their Udon Miso Large Bowl soup was decent.  I did notice the guava soda was a Jarritos brand and that made me chuckle a bit.
author: Johanan L.

description:
Asian Art Museum has excellent and vast collection of asian arts! 

Although I was disappointed at some of the craftmanship of the display cases themselves.  Some interior paint job in the museum itself wasn't that impressive either.  I wish the museum itself could be constructed a bit better.
author: N. C.

description:
I could pretend to be fascinated by the 2000+ year old pottery, or the jade nicknacks, or the fancy Japanese screens that are probably worth more than my yearly salary. But let's face it, the best part was the Samurai section where I had to apply all of my willpower to not grabbing a katana, some armor, and single-handedly restoring the Samurai code, modern firearms be damned!

This is the first Asian museum I've been to, so I'll give it 4 stars for having tons of stuff to look at, descriptive labels and stories, and a pretty nice layout. And for the amusement in my friend's eyes as she wandered the special ukiyo-e exhibit.
author: Will A.

description:
I went to the MATCHA event last night and it was my first time to ever go to Asian Art Museum. I have been meaning to go since they opened but never had the chance.

It was AMAZING. The Matcha event was really fun. Free for members, $5 for non members. There were tea tasting, tongue diagnose, free 5 minute massages, within its galleries. It was a really fun event. 

Being just coming back from Cambodia, I love their extensive collection of buddha statues. Being an Asian transplant, I also love their progressive attitudes toward What it means to be "Asian." I read their definition of "Asia" in their 3rd floor gallery and I was totally in love with that! I am very happy and proud to have such a great museum that represents my culture. Moreover, having worked in museums before I appreciate their attention to details, planning their exhibits and aggressively acquiring new collections as well as being progressive and strong in the community they represent. I think having a strong identity is a very important quality in a museum.

I didn't get a chance to tour rest of the museum but will definitely come back. I can't wait to bring my parents when they come visit! The membership staff was also super friendly and helpful. I signed up for a contributor's membership which allows you to get into most bay area museums for free as well.  Plus I run a small business, that's one of my new employee benefits :D
author: Cindy L.

description: The musuem has extensive art work from India, China and Japan. At least from what I could remember. I have not been here in a while. It's a nice place  to look at ancient Asian art of course. Last time I was here I took my family for the Samuri Expedition and it was the first time I paid to get into this musem. I usually just go on Free Sundays. My nephew loved the samuri swords and displays. He even asked if I could get him a samuri sword. Cute, but no!  The gift store and cafe is pricy.
author: Thu L.

description:
I've been here for the tezuka, ming art and tea sweet class. It's got a large collection of art to look through, so you'll be busy for a while-not terribly great lighting though. Bring a friend to wander around with. It's extremely quiet and having someone around to talk with breaks up the monotony.

The cafe serves up bland pricey food, go out instead. The gift shop is fun to wander through-but pricey too.
author: Joh W.

description:
I liked the variation of pieces - it was noted somewhere that they separated the galleries into 7 sections, not only based on location but also on culture.  I would have liked to get a little bit more of a sense of why those designations, and also more about the context for each of the pieces.

The contemporary section was probably my favorite and the smallest and least varied - I definitely would have liked to see more of that!
author: Sarah X.

description: Beautiful building, reminiscent of  Musée d'Orsay (same architect) in the way it preserves elements of a historic building (the former library) but lightens and modernizes it with overhead glass and steel. An excellent collection of Asian art, arranged to follow the spread of Buddhism throughout the continent. The highlights brochure was particularly helpful to focus on prize pieces and not get overwhelmed. The jade room is stunning, as are the (few, but excellent and representative) artifacts from Japanese shōguns and samurai. There is a quiet alcove in the museum cafe to take a break with a bowl of soup, and escalators make the permanent collection on the upper floors easy to dip in and out of as needed. A first-rate museum.
author: Robert P.

description:
I love the Asian Art Museum.  I went with my brother and his wife when they were in town, and we all found something that fascinated us.  Apart from the phenomenal ancient Chinese scroll special exhibit they had, I nurtured my marital arts obsession in the Japan section (where they had a full samurai outfit and the full layout of a tea ceremony).  My brother immersed himself in the Southeast Asia section, and his wife spent most of her time in the Korea and India sections.  It really has something for everyone, as well as more Buddha statutes than you could possibly imagine.

This is definitely a must see for anyone in or visiting San Francisco.  Plus it's easy access by both BART and MUNI, just a couple blocks from the Civic Center stop.
author: Emily W.

description:
The Japanese Bamboo Basket exhibit was the shit.  That deserved 15 stars - but the lame ass KOREAN permanent exhibit definately put me out. 
 WTF?
So 3 stars for including something about Korean art in the museum and hosting traveling exhibitions  - but considering Chong Moon Lee put up 15 million for the joint - we're poorly represented.
author: sHoo o.

description:
Wli & I visited this museum on the last weekend of the Ming Dynasty. It was big, organize and clean.

It was fascinating, the scrolls, jewelries, furniture, and etc. One hour is not enough time to really decipher and study the art. It really strenghten my wanting of visiting China next year for vacation.

Time to freshen up on my basic Mandarin. I will def. visit this museum once again since I didn't have time to check the rest of the place.

It's free to the public on the 1st Sunday of the month.
author: jubi l.

description: As a Historian, this place is a good place to start learning about Asian cultures through art. I recommend one going when there is an exhibit of interest. Therefore it wouldn't be as boring as you think it might be. The Asian Art Museum has its free days as well. It is the second or third Tuesday of the month (I don't remember, so you should look into it). The museum has a large collection of Buddhist artifacts on the top floor and shows how Buddhism spread throughout Asia. I don't want to give it all away, you should just go and check it out!
author: Amy C.

description: My friend and I decided to come here to kill some time before meeting up with another friend.  We've opted to get the Shanghai Exhibit ticket and was kinda disappointed. We paid a little more expecting to be completely wowed with the items in there and although some did hold our interest most of it fell kind of short.  We did although enjoyed the museum in a whole.  I didn't realize this place was ginormous.  It was 3 stories I believe and the upper floors had displays of amazing sculptures from different Asian cultures and seriously...I haven't seen so many different kinds of buddhas in my life.  Totally loved it all.  However, one note, we did try to go early to avoid crowds and people and we kinda did although it was hard dodging a HUGE group of kids on a field trip...they were everywhere!
author: Kim D.

description:
If Buddha is your thing, you'll feel completely at home here.  I wonder if anyone has ever counted how many images of Buddha there are at the Asian Art Museum on any given day...more Buddhas than Buddhas mama for sure!  However, among the Buddhas from every corner of Asia there were some other gems...often literally.  From jeweled Indian headdresses to tiny Japanese Netsuke figurines to Korean celedon pottery to Chinese calligraphy...something will catch your eye and make you go "Hmmm...interesting!" or "'Wow, that's insanely intricate!"

I've been in SF long enough to have visited the old cavernous Asian Art Museum out in the Park.  This one is a vast improvement but definitely seems more compact, perhaps due to the painted beam ceilings and maze of dimly lit rooms.  I visited on free day (thanks to corporate sponsor Target the first Tues. of the month is free) and the flow of the building was such that it never seemed really crowded.  My motto is "I never wait in line to see fish or art" and I was pleased that I was able to accomplish that goal at the Asian.
author: Jon B.

description: It's a fairly unique and extensive collection of Asian art that is rarely seen in one museum like this. To walk through the regular collection, I would plan for a couple of hours or more. Here's my reasoning for the four stars. Because of its modest size (relatively), there may be limited re-visit value outside of the special collections.  Other than that, enjoy the friendly talks and storytelling, enjoy the neat cafeteria, and of course enjoy the art..
author: Mark L.

description: Fantastic museum. Amazing collection. Great architecture (take the architecture tour if you can, its amazing how they re-purposed the building).  Phenomenal special exhibits. The museum is one of my staples if I have out-of-town guests who are into museums, art, or there is lousy weather.
author: Mr. X.

description: I LOVE the Asian Art Museum. Why? Aside from the wonderful history,  my husband proposed to me here about 2 years ago and we became members that very same day.  Thanks Asian Art!
author: Mare C.

description:
What a nice cultural addition to this already splendid city. I'm usually reach the end of my museum attention span at about an hour or so, but the Asian Art Museum kept me interested for a solid three hours. So much to look at from so many diverse parts of asia - it was all very impressive.

Right now they have the Afghanistan exhibit, which I highly recommend for no other reason than these artifacts have survived against the odds under such challenging conditions. A reason for hope in a country that has seen nothing but conflict for so long.
author: Jason B.

description: One of the best Asian Museums in North America - docents are very knowledgeable and friendly and accommodating - had a 30 min tour scheduled which lasted 75 mins.  Elderly Asian lady who led tour on 'Decoding Chinese calligraphy' exhibit was precious and so passionate about calligraphy.  Highly recommended for anyone interested in Asian art.  Outstanding collection with multiple artworks of different periods and dynasties.
author: Charlie W.

description:
This museum is quite nice.  They have a major collection of Chinese and Indian art. Also a fair amount of Japanese and Korean. I really like the museum building. Just saw the Ming Dynasty  exhibit, simply amazing. 

The non-permanent collections are on level-1, Chinese,Japanese,Korean and Vietnamese on level-2 and Indian sub-continent and all other Asian countries not listed on level-2 are on level-3 :-).

I re-joined, yes my membership had expired. If you join at a certain level, you can bring in your junk and have the experts evaluate it; anyway that was the incentive. Avery Brundage donated his massive collection on the promise that the city would build the museum.  Interestingly this guy also praised the Nazis. So he replaced two Jewish athletes to the Munich games by Jesse Ownes and ???.  Brilliant man full of contradictions.
There is underground parking right across from the museum and it is reasonable. If you park on the street you will spend alot of time feeding the meter.
author: K N.

description:
Amazing cultural artifacts!! It was like stepping into another world.
The line was long on the outside but so worth the wait. We stepped over the threshold and paid our $5 for the samuri exhibit. I learned so much about Japanese culture and my boyfriend even tried on a Samuri helmet. the artwork was just beautiful!!! I honestly felt so priveledged to experience and learn about so many amazing things that many people dont even think about in their whole life time. You will learn culture, tradition, religion, and much more from just going through the Samuri exhibit. No cameras allowed because of the preservation of the sacred image of Samuri's. And plan to go EARLY it will take you about 2 hours to get through the bottom floor if you savor the exhibit. We went on the Target sunday and it was packed. But i didnt mind. I was having a good time with my BF. 
The 2nd floor was pretty good too. I was only interested in the Japanese stuff but the Indian, Persian, Chinese, Thai stuff was pretty cool too. I would deffinately come back again.
I would post the pictures i took BUT some jerkoff stole my camera the next day while i was at starbucks.
author: Katie F.

description: I love this museum. The membership prices are decent and the collections are awe-inspiring. You have to go there and experience it yourself. The museum is always hosting fun activities for families, teens, adults and Asian holidays. Try it.
author: Pepper S.

description: What a fantastic museum! The Bhutan exhibit is amazing!!! We were able to enjoy the Monks service and creating a Mandala. It was truly special. I highly advise enjoying this. The building has so much history and character itself it made the whole trip a lovely experience. *Now a member!
author: Tiffany L.

description: free entrance every first sunday of the month and you won't miss it cos there's a long line of people outside. $5 extra to see the shanghai exhibit, but not really worth it unless it's for an assignment/class. Cafe asia located 1st floor and it's just a restaurant not some place where you can order something small and it's overpriced/disgusting. Museum shop is a ripoff. Since the museum is in sf, almost everything in the shop you can buy them 75% cheaper or more in chinatown! The exhibits are great too I guess. if you want food sneak it in.
author: Jessica T.

description:
5 stars for all of the following:
exhibits
curators
docents
layout
building
location
price
author: nardo m.
