description: You know it is the first Sunday of the month when you see a line of people circling the Asian Art Museum anticipating their free entry. Great deal, but I do not have that kind of patience to wait in a line without the promise of good food at the end. Giant Museum with several floors dedicated to various parts and periods of Asia. There are rotating special exhibits that are free with admission (no special fees for special exhibits - which I really appreciate). Great way to spend the day, and when you are done you can head a couple of blocks up Larkin for a big bowl of pho.
author: Dana H.

description: went in this morning at 9am with a member to see the 4,000 year old tree of life crown. Various treasures salvaged from the Afghan National Museum after being excavated from the tombs of ancient nomads. There was a nickel-sized bit of gold with what is thought to be the oldest depiction of buddha known to exist. Its 6,000 years old. I mean ... wow. They also had many interesting small items which had been transported over the Silk Road. These central asian cultures depicted everything in their art - Buddha, Greek and Roman deities... I'm glad to see Afghanistan has been able to salvage these items after the Taliban's looting and destruction.
author: Roxmarie M.

description:
This museum is another one of my "havens" when I need to get away from all the busy-ness of life.  Though I am an art historian I know very little about Asian Art so coming here is always a voyage of discovery no matter which exhibition I see or which docent tour I take.

The displays are so beautifully done and the labels so very helpful that I always come away feeling like my visit has been time well spent.  The collection is outstanding and the curators have seen to it that it is presented to the public in an interesting and accessible way.  

OK...OK...sometimes when I am too stressed out I only make it to the shop and the restaurant and forget the high-mindedness of enriching my cultural life and just want some retail therapy or a good meal in a quiet setting.  

In short no matter what I do AT this museum I come away feeling refreshed and relaxed.  We in the Bay Area are lucky to have such a museum in our midst.

I would challenge ANYONE whether they like museums or NOT to visit the AAM and not come away with a zen sense of well-being.
author: JUDY O.

description: Loved the museum. Thanks for the free entrance the first Sundays of the month.
author: Colin P.

description: Skip it!  Dark, depressing, unhelpful staff, boring displays, inconvenient location, panhandlers outside.  It may have the largest number of pieces in north america, but number doesn't mean greatness!  It's a whole lot of junk.  My daughter described it as a commercial gallery and not a museum.  Badly curated.
author: cynthia c.

description:
We went for our first time today for Target sponsored free first Sundays. I stood in line outside while my hubby parked the car, and although I was chilly, I was grateful that the line moved along nicely. 
I bought our $5 tickets to the Shanghai exhibit, and so we went through the whole thing. We enjoyed it, there was a lot to peruse there. I found it to be a bit odd to walk across hallways into different galleries, for each of the four parts of this exhibit, but once we were in each one, it was fine. I lost track of time, but I think we took at least 2 hours to go through the entire Shanghai journey. I loved the gift shop, and although it is a bit small and hard to maneuver around other people, they have some great books and gift items. We went up to see some of the regular art too, on the third floor. We saw a lot of buddhas, which were interesting to learn about, and admired some 
ancient pottery from various countries. We didn't have time to sample the cafe, perhaps next time.
author: Debbie T.

description: Enjoyed the Shanghai exhibit, and wish I'd been up to seeing the upper floors that day.  I had a tasty stir-fry at the cafe.
author: Karen B.

description:
i was reminded yesterday that nyc's asia week is coming up march 15-19. in honor of it (and the fact that this will be the first time in 3 years i will not attend and meet up with all of my art school buddies and colleagues in the field), i'll review our very own asian art museum.

the collection of asian artifacts in san francisco is moderately extensive, and the museum generally does a great job of rotating exhibitions of major works of asian art from domestic collections as well as international ones. the core of this museum rests on the gift from avery brundage, one of the most prolific collectors of asian art in the united states. 

there are very few complaints i have about the new location as it is beautifully outfitted with steel and glass. the interiors are reminiscent of the shanghai art museum, which in all honesty, is one of my favorite museums as it houses one of the largest bodies of chinese bronzes and shang-tang period jade/ceramic sculptures in the world. plus, it's in the shape of a ding, a tripod bronze cooking vessel used during the shang period. i laughed out loud when my swedish boyfriend at the time and i stood out front and he remarked, "wow. this building is the shape of an old wok." 

my personal preference would be for a larger focus on pre-ming works of art, but avery brundage liked his ming and qing so i guess i'll have to travel back east, europe or asia for the good stuff. my favorite works of art always arose out of periods of conflict, like zhang guo shi dai (the warring states period, about 475BCE to 221BCE). we were magnificent barbarians then, and the craftmanship from that period reflected the splendour of the warring factions amongst the city-state kingdoms of current-day china. 

i don't want to neglect my southeast asian, south asian, japanese and korean brothren either. there is a smattering of decent material, but nothing, NOTHING like the collections they have in europe and asia. again, i'd like to see something more than samurai armour and katanas. perhaps a few more haniwa, koryo and nepalese/tibetan paintings?

so, all in all, it's a great place to spend an afternoon. i'd recommend going to the current exhibit on ukiyo-e (the floating world). you get a good sense of romanticism, beauty and fragility of this world of entertainment in edo-period nippon from the few pieces on display.
author: May T.

description: An amazing venue! White marble, lofted ceilings, very elegant. My only complaint would be they dont change up the exhibits enough.
author: Jess J.

description:
Just visited this evening to see the Samurai exhibit before it leaves town.  Museum is much bigger than I had thought, although the special exhibit was much smaller than I had expected.  For a separate admission price, I expected more items to view.  
I especially liked the Tibetan portion of the permanent collection.  The special exhibit was worth it since Thursday nights have a reduced entrance fee.  
Overall, a great place to visit!
author: A h.

description: A very eclectic collection of art from all over Asia. I love that they work hard to always have a captivating exhibit going on.
author: Christina L.

description:
This is one of the best museums in San Francisco- if not the best one.  It's a must-see.  I might be a little biased because I'm in love with Asian culture, but I'm not letting it influence my review.  

There are so many floors full of art.  There's such a wide array of art here- I love it!  Honestly, I don't know how to describe it, but this is one of San Francisco's best.  If you're debating between visiting two museums, definitely choose this one!
author: Blushed M.

description: With an eye for the religious, class and gender-specific influences on Asian art, this cool, lucid space houses some beautiful samples.  After studying a bit about Ancient China, my children and I visited this museum to see relevant artifacts.  We were given directions to the Shang dynasty gallery but never made it there.  My girls were so smitten with the Southeast Asian puppet exhibit they encountered en route, we'll have to return to the second century BC another time...Mercifully, the baby slept for much of our time there, as this affords a less interactive than reflective experience.
author: siobhan s.

description: We came to participate in the 24th Annual Japanese New Year Bell Ringing Ceremony. Since we are members we were able to come early and watch the first ceremony before it got crowded. It was so neat to watch everyone participate in the bell ring, young and old. We were lucky and got to ring the bell three times. It was an excellent experience.
author: Michelle B.

description: This place was really cool. Interactive stuff going down on the free Sunday. I got some new costume ideas from the Burma section. It's in an awesome building! Very cool collection, not just from the far east either, also from the middle east. I'll have to visit again.
author: Maggie P.

description: A member of the Asian Art Museum since its opening, I wander through its galleries to reflect and enjoy beautiful art, or bring a friend or two to kick back at the cafe.  The cafe has stepped down a notch in my esteem lately because it no longer carries my favorite Mariage Freres tea and Xingu beer.  It is still a cool place to hang.  The outdoor patio always beckons.
author: KarenG P.

description: Wow. Saw the Maharaja exhibit which was impressive.  What a fantastic show. The entire place is great with so many art pieces to see. Too many buddhas to count and the jade room is beautiful.  Will definitely return for another visit.
author: Don Z.

description: I went to the Asian Art Museum on a Sunday and to my surprise it wasn't crowded at all. I would definitely suggest starting at the top and making your way down. This is what I did and I got to see everything. I thought the museum was very informative and had some amazing pieces. It was also crazy to read the description of some of the pieces and discover how old they were. I was impressed and I would definitely recommend that people go see this museum.
author: Carly W.

description:
The Asian Art museum is a wonderful way to spend a Sunday afternoon. The location makes it easily accessible by BART or even from the freeway. Parking may be difficult as there is no parking structure nearby, but I've never had an issue finding a spot.
The museum is located right across from City Hall and from the outside is just a gorgeous building. The cost of admission is pretty cheap considering how expansive it is on the inside.
The art aside, the building on the inside is just breathtaking. 
The exhibits displayed are expansive and very impressive. Their traveling exhibits are always gorgeous. Having just returned from a trip to Bhutan earlier this year, I can say the pieces exhibited currently are truly indicative of the gorgeous culture from the country.
The permanent exhibits are displayed in a breathtaking and organized manner. When you walk through you don't realize how far you've gone because the art just leads you around. Luckily there are quite a few couches so when your feet do start to ache you can sit and relax and admire the ancient works of the far East.
The cafe is a little expensive but I really enjoy it. Especially the green papaya salad. yum!
It's always a thrill to visit. I highly recommend it.
author: prachi v.

description: Another place we are potentially considering for our wedding. It's gooooooorgeous but beware it is a bit spendy. About 10-12k. But if you have the money I think it's worth it. Our experience with the staff so far has been quite nice and I would highly recommend checking it out for your next event.
author: Cathy T.

description: I'm reviewing it not just for the culture (pronounced cul-chah) (the exhibits are fine), and not for the gift shop (beautiful things), but also for the cafe.  It's a rare place where you can sit outside in the TL (here, a nice veranda, though the view beyond can be trash-ridden), and the food is delicious.  There are the pre-made items (all good), and also dishes made to order.  On a nice day, it's a good spot.
author: Laurel B.

description: I'm not that big into art.  I enjoy seeing it occasionally, but I really don't appreciate it the way a studious art lover views art.  In fact, had I not had free admission through my employer which donates money to the place, I might not have gone.  But having visited finally, I must say I was impressed.  There's a lot of interesting and varying items at this museum, including a ton of Buddhas both skinny and fat.  My favorite is the one with 11 heads.  The pieces are arranged very nicely and the lighting almost everywhere is excellent, allowing you to see from many different angles in great detail.  The glass casings were immaculate.  Many times, it was so clear that I thought there was no glass, so they must use some fingerprint resistant stuff.  I appreciated that every single item was labeled clearly with probably 90% having long detailed analysis of how it was made and what significance it had to the culture or how it was used.  Too much to see in one day.  We saw the first two floors in detail and then blew through the 3rd, which actually is the main collection.  The buiding is cool.  Security seemed more serious that at MOMA but were very nice.  Open late Thurs.
author: Marc S.

description: This is the manatees favorite museum because she thinks she was born in China.   I keep reminding her Hayward California is not in China.  Its not even close to China.  She doesn't believe me and will yell at me in Chinese.  I just stare at her because I don't know Chinese.  I think the museum is on the boring side.  But if I tell her that I didn't give this place 5 stars she might  harpoon me.
author: Fatty A.

description:
this building is beautiful!!  i really like the high and ornate ceilings, the wide staircase, and the overall layout of the bldg.  i came here when it first opened in 2003 and then returned this past thurs night for one of the summer evening events.  there is a cool manga and anime exhibit going on, and on thurs nights, there are also performers, djs, presenters, etc.  this is a nice event to go to after work.

the collection here is pretty good.  i particularly like the buddhist and hindu deity carvings and statues on the 3rd floor.
author: Helen T.

description: Great Museum! I went to this place so many times for various exhibits, I really can't name what I don't like about this beautiful place... Go on a weekday if you can!
author: Valerie D.

description:
god, allah, yaway, buddah, shiva, quan yin, etc do i love this place!
every time i go i think to myself 'i really need to come back here more often'. its peaceful and fun and mesmerizing and most of all inspiring. i can look at the stuff i see every time i go and still be amazed. i can look at the revolving shows and it blows me away. i don't know whether to run out to the art supply store or the travel agent when the sugary sun hits my face upon exiting. 
don't miss the cafe. affordable for a museum cafe and everything i have eaten there has been super yummy.
author: Bad Ass Chic K.

description: MATCHA night was a yawner, but hanging out with Jane was fun.
author: Keith K.

description:
given that asia is no small landmass, nor is it a lightly populated area, the asian art museum tackles a topic that is far, wide, and deep.  the information offered here is vast. i like the logic to the display, following (roughly) the spread of buddhism in the region.  i didn't read every curator's blurb, of course, nor did i stop at the video displays or headphone kiosks at any point.  going into that kind of exhaustive detail for each room would require at least 10 multi hour visits.  how daunting, right?  try facing the task on pride day.  hell yeah!  i can't tell you why we were the only bay area residents who weren't apprised of the event.  it turned "hey let's go to the asian art museum" into "wow, bart is so full today" into "i think that man in the thong is about to puke".  then again, we had the museum mostly to ourselves.  

getting back to the review, it is true that some of the smaller/minority cultures of asia aren't given a ton of attention, and that the collection is decidedly...non-modern.  however, the manga exhibit happening now thru september 9th is super cool, and the miso soup in the cafe is delicious.  plus buddhas galore!  special message to everyone who has checked out the chinese visual puns display: peaches and bats to you!  i definitely got a good dose of asian art here.   it made me proud to be asian!  (i'm not asian)
author: bianca v.

description:
Something i wrote for a paper write up for an art class =)... thought I would share. 

As I entered the Asian museum last week, I instantly felt as if were transported into the historic culture of my ancestors. I became surrounded by splashes of color of unique material and achievements of Asian art and culture. Along with the broad range of various paintings other key elements caught my eye as well such as sculptures, textiles, ceramics, and even precious jade molded into many different objects. Within the museum there was so much diversity from Asia colliding together to celebrate the artistic achievements of the Asian community. The one painting that captured my attention was called the sparrow bamboo done with ink and color mounted on paper by the accomplished artist Chao- Shao-ang (1905-1998). When I first saw the painting the colors of the lonely bird was the first thing that caught my attention. I believe that he is trying to convey a natural feeling of deep sorrow and grief towards his audience. His careful brush strokes are also dark on one hand, while the bird is sadly looking away into the midst of the air from the branch he is sitting on. However, the one unique exhibit that I was blown away was the creative work by artist Zhan Wang ultimately created to mount the city of San Francisco out of steel silverware! I couldn't believe it because at first my friend and I were uncertain of why there was a pile of stainless steel pots and pans, silverware, and mirrored surfaces lying on the ground. But until the security guard explained to us about the unique idea Zhan Wang came up with, we started to see the resemblance of the Golden Gate Bridge, twin peaks, embarcadero and other well known monuments that drastically came alive. In conclusion, I enjoyed going to the Asian Art museum because it helped open my eyes and gain a new perspective towards different structures of art
author: leanna w.

description:
It is a toss up for me between this one and the Legion of Honor as far as SF art museums go but I appreciate this one a bit more for a few reasons.

First off, the pieces found here are not nearly as widely available for viewing as the more popular European art pieces. Many of the specific collections are the largest outside of their respective regions, meaning you can't find a more extensive collection without visiting the country itself or region to which it belongs. More importantly, my first visit to this museum really inspired me to seek out other and all varieties of museums and cultural centers whenever I travel and even when back home in LA. And on a personal note, this particular collection provides a great lesson and opportunity to learn more about my culture and ancestry while marveling at some of the most unique and aesthetic works of art in the world. Calligraphy, manuscripts, Buddahs of all shapes, sizes and colors, samurai swords, ceramic stonewares, elaborate metallic work, intricate textiles, Chinese jade, and snuff bottles are just some examples peculiar to the Asian Art museum that distinguish this museum from so many others. There is plenty more to discern than just paintings and sketches. Their collection even includes some contemporary art. A MUST SEE for those who appreciate Asian history, or fine art in general.
author: Cat L.

description: Thursday night museum specials are the best!  Ten bucks, music, demonstrations, booze and all the sweet Asian art you can stand.  Plus the Samurai exhibit.  That was cool too.
author: Corey V.

description: come here!
author: Shirley L.

description: I was there this summer when the Bali exhibition was ongoing. Although the size of the museum is a bit too small, its collection is quite solid and very comprehensive.  And I liked the show that they acted out with the paper dolls from traditional Bali. :) Their souvenir shop also has some high-quality Asian crafts.
author: J R.

description: I haven't had a chance to take a full tour of the museum yet, but I've been very impressed with their events calendar!  We went for the Japanese Family Day and were quite pleased.  Note that children are also most impressed with the glass elevator and lovely escalators!
author: Andi T.

description: All i can say is its really fun getting drunk in the Asian Art Museum (I am NOT an alcoholic, I went to a christmas party there!!)  Still, it was fun to wander around and check out the Kimonos and the  vases.  But then again, it was open bar so my judgement may have been slightly impaired.  The escalators sure are fun though!
author: Sloane R.

description: The Asian Art Museum is truly beautiful. I went here for my second time today, and had a really good time. I highly recommend taking out of town guests here. Not only do you get to see a great museum that isn't overwhelmingly huge, but you can stroll the farmer's market when your done! Well I know you can on Sundays and Wednesdays...I'm not sure about the rest of the week.
author: rachel c.

description:
Great place with a lot of historical artifacts. Its located right across from city hall in the tenderloin, but totally accessible by BART and MUNI.

Another good thing about this place, after exploring it for 2-3 hrs, is the cafetaria, where you can enjoy vietnamese cuisine. A lot of employees who work in the area actually come here just for lunch.
author: S. S.

description:
I actually liked the low-key, intimate aspect of  "the Asian's" old location, before it went all upscale. Everybody said, "That ol' thang?" Call me crazy, but there was something about the Golden Gate Park location, the musty scent of the earthquake endangered structure,  it's intimate and local feel, it's ........AND THEN I WOKE UP! Well the little ol' museum in the park went and grew itself up, to become a world class city museum, located at the center of  SF government and next to the new Main Library. Hooray!

Saving parts of the Old Main Library was probably the smartest thing the architects did, next to creating a structure that retains an intimate open feel, allowing for lots of natural light. It is an elegant and grand structure without being imposing. Word!

The Asian does it's fair share of community outreach: story telling, a teachers program, a number of family programs, not to mention ..Monsoon and Art After Hours (though that may have been done away with). The Cafe is great  place to meet that "never on time friend" before touring the collection. The art itself is amazing. The Avery Brundage Collection is always a treat: I mean this guy had taste ... or hired people who had taste to make sure everyone knew he had taste. They've got an incredible Jade Collection; Thai paintings; Chinese Scroll works & porcelain; Korean paintings, ceramics and traditional "Hanboks"; South Asian sculpture; Japanese ....(taking a breath here)  everything...Ok suffering from "kid in the candy store" syndrome. All of Asia seems to be well represented, but that's an amateur's perspective. It's all incredible! One personal mystery: there was a wonderful ivory piece called the Basket Seller that was part of the Brundage collection, which illustrated the affects of the Meiji period social reforms upon the former warrior class. It was cool! I know...y'all think J-Boy's gone all "Kill Bill" on yer asses!  This place is worth the price of admission.  The temptations of the museum store rival that of MOMA's.  4 duckets for an incredible place to view the best in Asian Art.
author: Johnny C.

description:
a really nice break from just seeing movies all the times or doing the same routine things that we kids do. for SFUSD students and kids under 12 it's free admission! thats right, FREE. they have interesting events sometimes. the japanese tea ceremony  club was there once, and they brewed me up a bowl of authentic tea. it was really gross, but so cool to get a real cup of japanese tea. the museum is huge. honestly, there is too much to read there. every single item has a story so be prepared to pick and choose or be there the whole day. even if you don't read the stories, the items are so beautiful and it's just so relaxing to stroll through the place. after you leave, you'll feel so much more cultured, and you can get back to your life of movies and popcorn.

* the gift shop is nice, but don't plan to eat here because the food is really expensive for cafe type food.
author: Douglas F.

description:
I must admit that we had never thought about going to the Asian Art Museum before the BofA  free museum visit program during May 2007.  Once we went, we were hooked.  My walking partner and I have been there 8 times since May 2007 and we still have not finished seeing everything there is to see in the museum.  

Although neither of us had ever really appreciated Asian art before, our visits have now shown us the rich variety of Asian art.  We have been enthralled and fascinated by every gallery that we have visited.  Since it is not as crowded as some of the other museums in San Francisco, it is an enjoyable experience.  You can linger before art pieces without feeling hurried. We have enjoyed ourselves so much that  we have decided to become members of the museum.  

If you are undecided about whether or not to visit the Asian Art Museum, decide to go.  You will not regret it at all.
author: John L.

description: a lot of sexual objects here haha. i saw some india sculptures that looked interesting.
author: Crystal H.

description: A serious, big time city museum.  Architecture -- if that's the word  -- is both endearing and stunning, composite the monumental, the sleek and the quirky.  Love the mini-Pompidou escalator raceway and 70's Hyatt Hotel glass elevator.  Sky bridges for all!. Tiny but beautiful gift shop.  If party beckons dress up in gown and tux because the long shallow grand stairs and ultra-ballroom make a Great Gatsby photo op.  The collection is intense and thoughtfully displayed & explained, but not the same treasure as the place itself.
author: Gil S.

description: Well of course if you're interested in art and it's history, this is a good place to visit. This is where I got interested in Chinese calligraphy. They have that section where you can draw and waste so much paper. I actually bought a calligraphy set after. I bought a couple of Chinese Chops too, I asked the old man that does the carving to translate my name into characters. So this is the place where my made up Chinese name was invented. I had them engraved on my chops. I thought it was so cool, so I went to Chinatown and bought a couple more. Surprisingly the man that does the carving in the museum, was the same guy that was also doing the carving in this one store in Chinatown. The chops were $5-$10 cheaper. And the store was actually close to that bakery that makes the really good custard cakes. Sorry my review was a little off =P
author: Allie A.

description: I went to bali arts exhibition. Although I missed their Bali dance show, I liked their overall exhibitions.
author: Hiroyuki T.

description: Amazing and interesting collections.  There are usually some interesting activities happening too.  It's an nice and easy self-guide walking tour if you are not in a rush.  Take the time to savor the arts.
author: Mindy C.

description: What a beautiful museum--a moment of chill.  I was fortunate to get to do a Chabana workshop with a demonstration of the tea ceremony that was really interesting! Had amazing tea and great noodles in the cafe.  I loved the meditation nook in the Japan exhibit--could see myself spending much more time there. The architecture of the building is a testament to a bygone era that built things to last- appropriate to house Buddhas and artifacts from civilizations of such a history.  Will be another momentary refuge in my overcommitted, under-yelped life!
author: Keri B.

description: One of the most rewarding experiences in visiting museums is learning something about yourself.  AAM sheds some light into my heritage (Pioneers of Philippine Art) and culture- I remember seeing those paintings in books, hearing about their lives- and struggles... My favorite is looking through the Buddha art and porcelain collection from different Chinese dynasties.  Next time I come back- perhaps it will be for a lecture, visit the library or free tuesdays on the first week of each month.
author: Arissa C.

description: I love their new location near the civic center, their jade collections is stunning, as is their collection of Indian art and artifacts. Their bookstore is perfect for gifts as well.
author: April M.

description: I visited the Asian Art Museum awhile back and I was in such awe.  I was was especially impressed with the Japanese Kimonos and Silk Screen paintings on display. I could spend days in here looking at all the art. Can't be the $5.00 after 5pm on Thursdays... That's just a steal!
author: Trish P.

description:
This review is for an exhibit at the museum that I would highly recommend:  Masters of Bamboo: Japanese Baskets and Sculpture from the Cotsen Collection.    
   It continues until May 6, 2007-- so check it out!   Lloyd Cotsen is the former CEO of Neutrogena and began a collection of many things Japanese after traveling to Japan while in the US Navy.  
   The exhibit consists of some older works that appear more utilitarian and quite a few modern ones that are truly beautiful to look at.  The bamboo work is just amazing, but the exhibit is very interesting as it explains the different regions of Japan and the various men who were so important in creating these baskets.  It seems that actual societies were created by the people who dedicated their lives to this art form.  
   Not only are the baskets simply nice to admire, but the exhibit explains the different patterns and weaves of each work.  I found myself peaking into each basket to see the different patterns of bamboo inside.
   Here's the link:  http://www.asianart.org/bamboo.htm
author: Karen W.

description: I was surprised to hear they had a manga contest and happily participated! I would have to say my favorite part of the museum is the tea house.
author: Allie W.

description:
could only say it's A-OK...  (though I did go on a free day!)

perhaps I just haven't grown to appreciate so much of the Asian art... being that I grew up in the Asian arts.

they did have a lot of collection but I am just not that impressed.
author: Sharon L.

description: They always keep a variety of special exhibits running through, they're almost all worth it. The permanent collection is best done in a couple trips, as it is quite large and get a bit tedious.
author: Ben G.

description: Gorgeous building along with a massive collection. Sometimes I wish I knew more about art so I could appreciate it better, but I always tend to leave with a sense of awe.
author: Bee H.

description: What really suprised me was that this museum is actually pretty big !! It had a lot of interesting pretty things . I remember last time I visited , they were doing a demonstration and they were giving out free script paper or something lol . Admission is free for children under 12 and SFUSD students with ID . Admission is to also free on "Target Tuesdays" which is the first Tuesday of each month .
author: Eileen L.

description: Being asian,  I felt obligated to visit and once in, I was amazed.  The thing that made my blood pump was the samurai swords, unbelievable!  I fell in love with the swords, not only the katanas but the east asian swords from indonesia, thailand.....  The museum is very well put together, kinda hard to explain but i thought everything had it's place.  Recommend coming here if you like musuems
author: Art W.

description: Recently visited this museum and had a great time. We could get there fairly easily from the East Bay by taking Bart. I really enjoyed how each level had art from a different country for example one floor was all Chinese art while the next had pieces from Japan. They have a vast collection and it could take an entire day to view it all. I loved the scrolls, the extremely detailed carvings, the serene Buddha, the sculpture, the jade works and paintings. They had a special exhibit from a painter from China who's wall sized oils addressed the political hot button issue of damn building in China which is causing major environmental damage and pushing many out of their homes. They have a lovely little gift shop and lots of beautiful stonework on the walls in some of the larger rooms. They also have elevators for wheel chair access, and escalators too. The museum caf serves tea, sushi and other Asian cuisine and has plenty of room to take a break and relax after strolling the three stories of galleries. A great place to take an art enthusiast or spend an afternoon.
author: Tiffany T.

description:
I visited the museum today with my father.  Thank goodness I was able to get in free since I am an employee of one of the sponsors.

The Lords of the Samurai were on exhibit.  It's a small exhibit and I was expecting much more to be displayed.  A few uniforms, a few swords, a few scripts and that's about it.

The rest of the museum is fine.  I prefer the DeYoung or the Palace of Legion of Honor.
author: Brian L.

description: I regret not going to the free first Sunday for the samurai exhibit... was I the only one who did not see the cool Darth Vader inspiring black samurai helmet and suit?  The museum promos show the black suit with the Hosokawa family crest on it but didn't see it anywhere in this museum!  Also would've been nice if they could've gotten different daimyo family's stuff to compare and contrast... they show mainly stuff from the Hosokawa clan in Kumamoto... influential, no doubt, but not one of the shakers during the age of a thousand feudal lands.
author: Takashi Y.

description: Wow, what the hell were they thinking when they designed this place? I used to enjoy going to the Asian back when they were in Golden Gate Park before the earthquake. I still don't get the design of the new building. I was going up that first escalator thinking to myself "what the hell is this place?" Is it built on top of another building? Is this the AMC 1000 on Van Ness with all this escalator-ocity? I enjoyed most of the art but I guess I didn't like the facilities. The museum cafe was pretty lame and unimpressive. It's a fancy museum in the Civic Center. They couldn't do any better? I decided not to become a member and do not plan on visiting again anytime soon.
author: Al B.

description: Regardless of your ethnicity, decent or beliefs I think history is something everyone should take in just to see how wonderful different part of the world are in art, history and creativeness.  The Afghnistan exhibit that is on display is pretty cool, yet too bad they do not allow pictures for this area. There is so many items of art here, you could easily take the whole day if you read each one. I learned a lot about the different Buddhist gods and though the Samsung room would be a cool place to hang out and chill after walking around. And would also make a nice party spot for private events.
author: Chris G.

description: Nuff said. The Asian Art Museum is a must-visit for any one in San Francisco. Beautiful building! I still make it a point to visit as frequent as possible.
author: Leroid D.

description: On par with the Sackler/Freer in DC. An exciting way to learn about fascinating historical cultures.
author: Anonymous P.

description: I like coming here on Thursday nights after work and having tea in the little cafeteria, and then strolling around looking at their collections.  I still haven't seen everything as their collections are quite extensive.  I'm still working my way around the Korean furniture exhibit.
author: Asteridae A.

description:
I love this museum.
The building itself has beautiful architecture
and the inside is filled with amazing artifacts
and beautiful pieces.

What I like best is the history lesson I get
going from room to room in this museum.

Some museums just put out the work and don't really explain
what you're viewing, 
but the the AAM does a good job of teaching too. :)
Yay for learning!
author: A W.

description: This place is amazing.  Made me want to go outside, get a book from the library on travelling to Asia, and go and buy a plane ticket!  Follow their advice, start on the third floor and work your way down.  I thought the third floor was intense enough, and then I went to the second floor.  Even had a small collection of Asian modern art.  Wow.  Definintely needs at least two days to appreciate it all....
author: Mark D.

description:
i really like the design of this place... how it's all layed out inside which is very modern and contemporary... very unexpected from just looking on the outside of the building.
as an asian art museum outside of asia, they have a great collection of things from asia and south asia
author: charlotte s.

description: It's still sort of in an infancy period, just opening a few years ago. The 2004 (possibly '05--can't remember) SF Asian American Film Festival opening night after-party took place in the lobby and was the perfect place for such a gathering. It's dominated by sandstone Shiva and Buddha statues on the 3rd floor and mostly Japanese, Chinese and Korean stuff on the bottom two. Was hoping to see more items from Southeast Asia (Thailand/Burma/Philippines/Indonesia/Malaysia, etc.), but hopefully the collection will grow in time. The information kiosks come in handy and help explain a lot. The bookstore has a pretty cool array of gift items and yeah..books. It's the perfect and ideal place to lose yourself on a weekend afternoon.
author: Chris C.

description:
I've been a member of this museum since the days when they were still connected to the De Young.

Generally, I like what they'd done to the old library.  Most of the architectural details were left intact.  The grand staircase was restored into a bright airy atrium-like area.  

Like:
The jade room is absolutely breath-taking.  The lighting, background fabric and the little glass display case where you can see both sides of some of the pieces is a really nice touch.
The architectural details that were retained from the old main library.
The floors!  Oh my!  The stone ground granite floors in the lobby, the little chunks of dark wood in the show areas.  I wish I can afford to put that in my home.  They're gorgeous.
Samsung Hall - the space.  It's just a great gathering space with the old corinthian columns, etc.
The Japanese tea house.  I have yet to join in with one of the tea ceremonies, but plan to soon.
The contemplation space with the reflective pool of water, a bench, and not much else.
On the rare occasions that I was able to visit - the Peterson Room.  The furnishing in there are elegant, simple but comfortable.  The little garden area outside is a true urban oasis.
The cafeteria actually serves pretty good food.  They're not cheap, but quite yummy.

Dislike:
Samsung Hall - the name.  Ok.  I know they're a corporate sponsor and donated a lot of money to make this museum happen ... but it's just a little too ... commercial.
The little glass addition with the escalators.  It's supposed to give the museum a lot of natural light.  It does that, but with a little glass chunk hanging out from the outside, it just doesn't fit into the rest of the building.  Just odd looking.
author: Winnie C.

description: Beautiful place to hang out. Haven't gone back for a long time however... I keep hoping that this place will become more similar to Asia Society in NY and even exceed it, in terms of taking risks and pushing the boundaries of Asian art.
author: Yvonne C.

description:
i went here for a field trip for my college class that had to do something with religion and buddhist culture. 

to be honest, i think the place is a damn maze. it's really hard to find the way out of this place and it always seems like your walking around and around. i have to admit that the place much better then the Asian art Museum that used to be located in the Golden Gate Park. 

The only problem is that the place is small and most of the stuff is pretty spread out. it lacks much of the stuff from the different dynasties of the chinese culture.

after going to a museum in Taiwan which was similar, i have to say that the taiwan museum is much more professional and has more exhibits that interested me.
author: Eric Y.

description:
I went to the Asian Art Museum to see the Afghanistan Hidden Treasures exhibit. I hadn't been there before and wasn't sure what to expect. I really like the space. It was bright and open, with interesting architecture. Plus, it was really cheap to get in - only $12, when it seems like many bay area museums are $20+ these days. 

The Afghanistan exhibit is not very big, but the story behind the artifacts is impressive. We were lucky enough to go on opening Saturday when the guest curator, Fredrik Hiebert, was speaking and got to hear the incredible story about the finding and re-finding of these artifacts. They're a very interesting fusion of far east and Mediterranean styles.  

I only saw portions of the rest of the exhbits, and sort of whizzed through them due to lack of time, but there were many beautiful pieces. I'd like to go back. 

I'm not sure if this museum is a good place to take kids. It could be a little boring for them.
author: Tracie L.

description: The museum is not bad and they do allow you to take photos of the exhibits, just make sure to disable the flash.
author: Narina A.

description: The Osamu Tezuka exhibit is awesome. Must see!! It ends September 9th, so go now. The rest of the museum is fairly meh, there's some pretty Buddhist statuary and some nice Tibetan Buddha stuff, but overall, it's the temporary exhibits that make it cool. Also, check out the Yoshitoshi exhibit while you are there, it's pretty great as well.
author: Jeannine S.

description: Being of Asian descent you are proud to see the beautiful works of art from that region of the world. A definite must see for tourists and locals alike.
author: Rommel N.

description: I came here on a discount Thursday night and it was thankfully not nearly as crowded as the MOMA gets on a free Thursday. The free audio guide is alright...not quite up to par with the guides at Berlin's museums, but then again, what museum is?  The second floor is my favorite with a really good balance of the old and new from Japan and Korea. I didn't get a chance to see their visiting exhibit from Afghanistan, but there was a whole bunch of buzz around it, so judging from the rest of the museum, it was probably pretty good. Also the doorman was exceedingly friendly, which is much better than snooty disgruntled docents that can be found at certain high art museums.
author: Alyssa J.

description: Since WHEN is going to a museum cool?  When I was 12 I hated going to museums with my parents. When I was 18 I hated going to museums for school.  When I was 23 I hated going to museums with guys who I swear PRETENDED to like museums.  I went to this particular museum on Saturday and it was goddamn crowded.  Damn these people for wanting to expand their horizons, damned the tour groups, damned the children forced to come here for school, and damned the people who pretend this shit is cool.  I was entertained for about 1.5 hours, then I had to get the hell out.  Thank god this was free otherwise I woulda been mad.
author: Tiffany L.

description: Huge collection from all over. Go on Thursday night after 5 - it is open until 9 and admission is $5. The gift shop has a ton of books, including a great selection of Asian cookbooks.
author: Amy E.

description: I love coming here because they have a great collection! Come here to learn and see the beauty art has to offer. Come with an open mind and an appreciation for art!
author: Mel P.

description:
this review's for matcha - hip-hop happy hour thursdays at the asian art museum.

so i heard about this recurring event randomly through friends and friends of friends and thought: hmm, what am i doing this thursday night?  i can go home and watch the giants lose on tv, or i can get drunk at a museum?  not too hard a choice.  the hard part was figuring out the appropriate attire - cool urban hip-hop gear, or something more befitting of a museum event?

after arriving, i was pleased to see plenty of both, so i fit right in.  there were plenty of anime dorks around too, for the current manga exhibit - so i wasn't at the bottom of the food chain.  whew.  it was a bit of a check-out fest, so be warned if you come to this event in the following weeks.

the asian art museum is always cool in my book - they have interesting special exhibits, and this summer's is no exception, delving into 1950's and 60's manga.  the exhibit itself was so-so (i really could've done with more storyboards, instead of presenting individual pages as art) but the concept was certainly out of the ordinary.

the bar was upstairs and to the left - there was only one, unfortunately, but the lines weren't too bad.  while waiting, we watched a few people dance (badly) to the japanese DJ spinning.  after a couple of beers on an empty stomach, we weren't feeling much pain, and departed to continue the drinking at suppenkuche (more on this later).

all in all, matcha was a pretty nifty event - probably a great way for singles to meet other singles.  if you're going to go to happy hour anyway, you might as well go to the asian art museum and appear cultured, rather than hanging out in some pub in the financial district trolling for hot admins and watching the giants lose on big screen tv.
author: brian w.

description: Beautiful, large building. The art focuses on Chinese, Japanese, and Korean art, and all the other Asian races are lumped into one group. So if you're into C/J/K artifacts, lucky you. Honestly, a lot of the art made me think I could just hop over to Chinatown and buy some of that stuff (though I'm sure that's not true). A pretty large collection overall (not quite as large as, say, the De Young) so bring good walking shoes.
author: Maximillian M.

description: Honestly, I'm not a huge fan of Asian art. But I feel this is a huge treasure for SF, and it really is a beautiful space. Enhancing the art itself were all of the wonderfully detailed didactic panels, which not only described each piece, but truly gave a huge amount of (fascinating) information about Asian cultures and religious traditions. I really felt like I learned something instead of simply being subjected to the curators' opinions on why the art is important.
author: Beth T.

description: This is a wonderful place to visit. While the collection is extensive, the size of the museum itself seems very manageable. And while any museum is best the 3rd or 4th time you have seen it, the Asian Art Museum can be appreciated on a day trip.
author: Brandy S.

description: Very nice renovation of the existing AAM.  Spacious of 3 floors and so clean too!  I loved the differing collections of Asian/South Asian exhibits for pottery, jewelry, culture, architecture, and artifacts.  It is a great experience!!!!
author: Carmen M.

description: I went here a few months ago and saw the Hidden Meanings In Chinese Symbolism exhibit that I believe is still running.  4 stars only since I didn't have the chance to finish off the museum.  I like the hundred flowers theme, I saw that later on upstairs on a vase.  Previously it wouldn't have occured to me, but after finding out about it, I was like oh......;-)  The whole symbolism deal made me think more about things that at first don't seem to stand out....like names of restaurants and stores for example.....things clicked a little after learning.  I will be back!!  ;-)
author: Rox M.

description:
I actually miss the old Asian Art Museum that used to be at Golden Gate Park.  It seemed to have more character and it had a jade mummy that fascinated me.  It's nowhere to be found in the new one -- perhaps it was on loan then?  Anyway, we wanted to check out the Ming Dynasty exhibit and thought it was a good idea to catch it on their free day -- apparently, so did everyone else in the Bay Area and beyond!  The place was a zoo!  
Still we soldiered on -- they had timed ticket entries so we headed up to the 2nd and 3rd floors to wander aimlessly until it was time to head back down.  There didn't seem to be anything new up there.  The artifacts of the Ming exhibit were kept in darkened rooms and no photography was allowed.  I'm sure I could've had a better grasp of how significant it all was -- it just wasn't possible, what with the jostling and head-butting (literally) and people yammering in my ear.  We decided to come back on a weekday and pay the 12 bucks for a quieter, more meaningful experience.  Unfortunately, we couldn't make it back before the exhibit ended.  Hmm, maybe I could try and catch up with it in St. Louis next year...
author: Rhea S.

description: We went on a weekday, on the first day of the Afghanistan exhibit.  Wow!  We ended up staying several hours and had lunch there -- which was really good for a museum cafeteria.  They had fresh stuff and vegetarian stuff, and outdoor seating.  I loved the Japanese art and some of the more modern Korean art, etc.  I don't get out much, so this was a real treat.  My feet were killing me afterwards, of course.  Maybe a segway next time (ha ha)???  Pictures were allowed on the second and third floors, according to the guy at the door.
author: Nancy R.

description: I just wanna write about a group that belongs to the AAM...it is called MONSOON!!! I hope you all will come and check out some of our events! We have been together for about 5 years now and have a lot of fun and educational events...Our next big event will be Istabul Night with casino tables!! Wooohoooo!
author: Mee-stique K.

description: I can't believe I haven't been here since they were in Golden Gate park. This new building is beautiful, and the museum has a fine collection of asian art, they have some of the largest Tang dynasty glazed statues I've ever seen...and I've been to a lot of museums.
author: C D.

description: Easily the best museum in San Francisco. I don't love the museum's building, but the collection is large and  of very high quality. It would be nice to see more Islamic art, but this is really nit-picking. The collection of Chinese art is very impressive; many of the pieces in the Chinese collection are masterpieces.
author: Michael W.

description: I am baffled to learn that the AAM is in financial difficulties.  It should be awash with visitors, but is not crowded at all.  This seems to be a world-class museum, with artifacts from Muslim, Hindu, SE Asia, Korean, Persian, Chinese and Japanese sources.   I'm not a big museum-goer, but I have been to a few in the US and Europe, and I prefer oil and water-color paintings to the sort of objects in this museum.  Nonetheless, this collection is stunning!  And extensive!  A person with interest and stamina could spend a day here.  I expected something much smaller.  The explanations of the individual exhibits are as helpful as any I have seen.  (However, raising them all to eye level and making them uniformly black on white would be an improvement.)  The cafeteria is very good and not expensive.
author: John H.

description:
things i learned at the asian art museum.

hokosai felt that until he was 70 he didn't really have the painting thing down.

when he painted after his 70 it's as if the impressionists were doing manga. very very cool

plus I saw a bunch of scrolls designed to highlight the erotic positions achieved by Japanese consorts & customers. Why not?

the exhibit of hindu/buddhist art has huge depth .
author: Lawrence K.

description:
I don't usually like going to museums, but I do like to go to museums of ancient art and history.  The Asian Art Museum is wonderful.  After about  9 hours inside the museum spread over several visits, I'd guess I've seen about 1/3 of the exhibits.  (I look at everything, including the accompanying plaques.)

It covers most of Asia, as opposed to specializing in one specific part of Asia, so I'd describe the collection as wide-ranging, but not especially deep in any one type of art.  For example, I was in Tokyo recently, and in a similar type of museum there (in Ueno Park) which specialized in Japanese art and artifacts, there were probably four or five rooms devoted just to samurai artifacts.  At the Asian Art Museum, samurai artifacts covered maybe a quarter of a room.   This is pretty typical of the exhibits.

There are lots of interesting talks that last an hour or two, and often they're free.

Weekends are relatively crowded.  On Thursday night, hardly anyone is in there.  I don't know about weekdays.
author: Steve S.

description: I decided to take advantage of the free admission from BoA in May and spend an afternoon here.  I've been missing out these past 5 years.  My ex- used to work here for a short time, so after working, she never wanted to go back to 'work'.  I'm glad I finally made it over here.  Their building is really a piece of work in itself.  They have a sizeable collection , which I would compare their exhibits to what you might see at the British Museum.  The collection starts in one country and progress to the next one, basically to follow the emergence of Buddhism throughout Asia.  Also on display were woodblock prints from the artist Yoshitoshi, which are considered to be the ancestor to the modern Manga (Japanese comic).  A Manga exhibit was also on display, but was closed when I visited. I had also missed out seeing the works of Tezuka, creator of the Manga Astro Boy, as it was not going on display until 6/2.  All in all, it was a fabulous afternoon here.  Although I spent about 3 hours here, I probably could've spent a couple more hours sampling food in their cafe or perusing the bookshelves at the museum store.  A must do in SF...if you want to appreciate Asian cultures.
author: JeFF T.

description: Being a big buff of everything Chinese, I was really excited a few years ago when the new Asian Art Museum was unveiled. Yet it took me a while to finally check it out, and I wasn't disappointed. The building is beautiful, which makes any visit a pleasure. The exhibitions however are quite a bit smaller than I anticipated: part of it, I suspect, is that the building is actually hollow, so that a lot of potential exhibition space is wasted (but then again, having visiting the AMAZING National Palace Museum in Taipei, I will never be impressed again by any Asian art museum or exhibit). Nevertheless, the quality of the collections is great, and they also have very interesting temporary exhibits: I remember really enjoying an exhibit about a year ago on Chinese painting and calligraphy, called "The elegant gathering" after the Chinese name for the gathering at scholar at which a lot of the works exposed were created. The bookstore is also quite nice, and in addition to the catalogs of the exhibits it also carries a fairly extensive selection of books on Asian art and cultures. A must-go for anyone with an interest in Asia.
author: David S.

description: It's only ten bucks to get in on Thursdays after five. Maybe the best deal in the city! So. Get your whiney ass off the barstool for a minute and try to open your mind.
author: Jeff B.

description:
any type of cultural activity is considered a 5 star for me... there's really not a doubt in my mind why it would be a 1 star or a 3 star... it's great for everyone, and it also gives you the satisfaction in reliving one's culture...

didn't go to work today, and so to keep myself busy, i not only went to the museum but i also drove down to sj to get out for a bit.

this museum is seriously one hell of a comprehensive museum comprised with so many different collections from every asian culture possible (korea, japanese, china, southeast asian, himalayas, tibetian, persian and contemporary art). tons and tons of monumental sculptures, paintings, porcelain, ceramics, etc...

one of the major* highlights of the musuem that is currently happening at the moment is something called DRAMA & DESIRE, which is filled w/japanese paintings from the floating world of the 1690-1850, depicting japans's edo period. basically, the paintings are comprised of seasonal activities of townspeople.

there are also other current exhibitions: there is something called ON GOLD MT, which is a pile of stainless steel scultpures representing san francisco. in fact, when you first walk into this exhibit, youll be wondering what in the heck these stainless kitchenware is all about, but make sure to read the description onto your left. the fun thing about this is, you have to be quite familiar with sf as a whole, that way you can point at each and one of the artifact and figure out what it resembles. i was able to figure out where the marina was, the golden gate, the transamerica, etc.. 

TIP: closed mondays.
Prices: adults $12, seniors $8, college students w/ID & youth $7 and children 12 and younger and SFUSD students free... oh and the 1st tues of every month is free, courtesy of target.
author: Jennifer S.

description: Here's a tip for individuals who want to explore the exhibits by themselves in relative peace and quiet. Check out the School Tour schedule on the museum's website. I failed to do this on a Wednesday noon and encountered wave after wave of docent led tour groups coming through the South Asia galleries. The museum is excellent in all respects except for a lack of sound absorbing surfaces in the galleries. (The ceiling is a beautiful painted restoration and the floor is handsome wood parquet.)
author: Lorinda S.

description: Very nice museum but I won't get into that because everybody else wrote about how great it is.  I do, however, have 1 reason as to why they only have 4 stars instead of 5.  I am 1/2 Filipino and expected to see some art/culture of the Philippines.  The only thing that my mom and I got to see was 1 painting.  One painting!  Now I knew that there wasn't going to be a plethora of Filipino art, but come on!  One painting?!!  This museum is HEAVILY geared towards Chinese, Japanese, and Indian (Southeast Asian) art.  That's great and it feels terrific to have representation of Asian culture.  But it is unfortunate to see that Pacific Islanders are heavily underrepresented.  Even the gift shop had very few Filipino items.  I asked one of the saleswomen if there were any more books/music/art from or about the Philippines and she said that if they were having a showcase or symposium on the Philippines then they would have had more things.  Wow.  We really need all the help we can get, don't we?
author: Andrea B.

description: Love this place, one of my favorites in SF. It's the only one to keep me renewing my membership (MOMA, you have such boring stuff!, you're certainly not the Guggenheim or the Tate Modern). I miss the old location in Golden Gate Park, since the parking was easier. The new location in the old public library is nice, but I'm not sure I like the layout. The main exhibition is split into 2 rooms on the 1st floor, and the year round collection is in a labyrinth that I'd be hard pressed to exit in an emergency. I've been to several parties here for the SF International Asian American Film Festival as well as the museum's own parties. That said, I love the art here. The Treasure from the National Palace of Taipei in 1997 was spectacular, and the Hokusai/Hiroshige exhibition in 1999 was superb (it's scary how much I bought). The gift store is first rate, and better priced than many antiques stores. I like to buy ceramics here as wedding presents (invite me to your wedding, I give good gift! :) Certainly better than Macy's gift registry (though in Macy's favor they do have superb gift wrapping). And they have tons of fun events, like making Tibetan prayer flags, etc.
author: Hao L.

description: a museum for just asian art?  oh yeah.  i came here a few years ago and  spent a lot of time studying the exhibits from my own country.  not a great place to bring the kids.  it's a good place to come alone, relax and reflect.   it's free the first sunday of the month.
author: Immer E.

description: a fantastic collection that is beautifully laid out.  i am particularly fond of the indonesian puppets and the thai buddhas.  i really like their mix of modern and antediluvian art.  it is a great place to while away a long afternoon.  i just wish the gift shop had a bit... more to it.
author: Samantha W.

description: the art part wasn't that impressive, but the artifacts were amazing. definitely check out the afghanistan exhibit if you get a chance.
author: Dana D.

description:
My friend, Matthew, and I enjoy visiting special exhibits at SF Museums. The AASF is a beautiful museum, with a solid exhibit base. But what a disappointment when we visited the Ming Dynasty exhibit a couple of weeks ago! We had planned for a month to visit it. We showed up in anticipation on a Thursday night, paid our $5 (which we were very happy about), ate dinner in the cafe (they were out of the first 2 entrees I wanted), and stepped to the customer service counter. "Hello, we would like to rent the handsets to view the Ming Dynasty exhibit". "Oh, no", she replied, "we don't have handsets for that exhibit". "Excuse me?". "No, we can't afford them, since it's just a temporary exhibit. We only have them for our permanent exhibit".  !!!!  A premier exhibit in a notable museum, and you can't afford handsets for a self-guided tour?!! Can we say, Get it done?!! We viewed the exhibits, with plenty of other attendees. Yes, they had docent tours, and if I was willing to be standing 4 people deep trying to hear what the docent was saying as she/he pointed to the item which I could not see, that may have worked. But it didn't. So we read the little plaques on the glass cases and muddled through. We were done in 45 minutes. 
I have always been so grateful for the handsets and headsets rentable or provided in other museums, from the Treasures of the Vatican exhiibit in New Orleans in the 1980s, to the Friday to the Frida Kahlo exhibit at MOMA recently, and it makes a HUGE difference for me. I'm art-challenged, and the equipment gives me the perspective I need to appreciate what I'm seeing. So, the Ming Dynasty exhibit was okay, to me. Old stuff. Pretty.
I tried to send a comment to the Museum the next day, on their website. Maybe I'm blind, but I couldn't find anyplace to send a comment, or write to the Curator, or any email contact for feedback. Strange.
Surely the Museum could have provided handsets for rental, to offset the cost; or asked a donor to sponsor handsets for the exhibit? 
I'll call ahead the next time: no handset, no visit.
author: David F.

description: The first free Sunday of the Month event (sponsored by Target) last year was what draws me to this place the first time. Since then, I've been back here at least couple more other times. This is the only museum in San Francisco that I know off with a free day that falls on a weekend - awesome! Their self-tour audio guide was really helpful and it was a great learning experience for me as far as Asian history and religion. My favorite part of the museum is the third floor exhibit. It made me feel like I was in a great temple and if it wasn't for the crowd, I probably started meditating in one of those rooms. I've never seen as much different forms of Buddha in my life. The artwork, crafts, and paintings are filled not just with creativity and character but with rich history. You definitely have to check out all the unique stuff they have at the gift shop. Kids will love the activities they offer in the ground floor. It's where I started learning Chinese painting and language with my niece!

description: As a child, I remember visiting the Asian Art Museum with my family at the De Young Museum in GG Park.  Over the years, many exhibits have graced the halls of  the AAM in GG Park. The remodeled site where the old Main Library used to reside, has served the new AAM well for the past 5 years. From the entryway, it still feels like the old library where going down the stairs leads to the newspaper room Those stairs are no longer there, even the wide staircase leading up to the library has vanished.  The interior was completely gutted and is replaced by a modern and well-lit museum.  We came specifically for the Ming exhibit which didn't disappoint.  Afterwards, we roamed the new museum and I recognized many old friends from my childhood.  I especially appreciate the new display for the ancient nephrite pieces from the Warring States.  Many pieces in the Jade Room are mounted in a clear case as if suspended from air where you can see both sides of the pieces and a legend with brief info on each piece.  What a great place to spend the day!  The gift sholp is small and has a limited book selection. What I did learn was that an older book on the collection of Avery Brundage was discarded and discounted, and a new publication came out last year in hardbound.  Evidently, a few pieces from the AB collection was determined to be unauthentic and replicas.  We've seen the Asian Arts collection at the British Museum which is significantly larger and should not be missed if you are ever in London.
author: Ry T.

description: As of the time of this writing, I have visited 4 museums in the last 2 months, the other 3 being the De Young, the Legion of Honor, and the Egptian Museum in San Jose.  Of the 4, I am probably more impressed by the Asian Art Museum.  In addition to what I consider a very wide and diverse collection, I am glad that almost each piece of art has a detailed explanatory plaque.  The Egyptian Museum has this and I find such plaques to be indispensible to the learning process.  For the Asian Art Museum, the plaques regarding various interpretations of statues of Buddha, for example, to be wonderfully informative as the specifics of a Buddha statue from, say, Japan in 1100 a.d. differs quite a bit from a Cambodian statue of Buddha from 1300 a.d.  Paintings and art pieces at the De Young and Legion of Honor often have almost no accompanying materials unless the pieces art part of a special exhibition.  In the Asian Art Museum, my favorite permanent piece is the bookshelf wall of dozens of jars from many various countires over the course of centuries.  It's a fabulous piece of condensed history. ...The special Exhibition on display I saw was Drama and Desire, primarily Japanese pen on silk drawings from 1600-1750 regarding the theater and prostitution districts.  Very detailed plaques about the astonishing differences and meaning in hairstyles, types of brushes, sashes etc.  Yes, there were also many erotic drawings.  Interesting that we here in the West apparently could not even show these in a Museum until now.  Overall, our three hours here were wonderful and we plan to go back soon, and I have recommended this museum to many others.
author: Richard W.
